quote: One of the best art museums
reviewnospace: While I'm not an avid museum goer this is one of my favourites. The size and organisation make a 3 hour visit manageable and enjoyable. While there are only a few 'blockbuster' works the collection covers a wide range of artistic periods and allows a great overview of the development of different styles.
titleopinion: One of the best art museums. While I'm not an avid museum goer this is one of my favourites. The size and organisation make a 3 hour visit manageable and enjoyable. While there are only a few 'blockbuster' works the collection covers a wide range of artistic periods and allows a great overview of the development of different styles.

reviewnospace: not my type of art, so difficult to rate, however the entrance we used was not well sign posted to try to find on the way out.
titleopinion: easy to get lost. not my type of art, so difficult to rate, however the entrance we used was not well sign posted to try to find on the way out.

reviewnospace: This intimate, newer museum is so warm and welcoming that we could have stayed for days. Excellent curation.

reviewnospace: good way to review your history of art knowledge. All the good painters very well chosen. Wonderful bookshop

reviewnospace: This is a great museum to see if you don't have a lot of time, it is small and it has some great impressionism paintings. There are about 3-5 van Goghs that are beautiful, not many Monets, but have nice paintings from the impressionism movement.

quote: Great collection - nice lay out - recommended
reviewnospace: We liked the fact that this museum is a bit smaller than the Prado but offers a great collection of art. Nice lay out and rooms. The collection modernists is limited but some gems.
titleopinion: Great collection - nice lay out - recommended. We liked the fact that this museum is a bit smaller than the Prado but offers a great collection of art. Nice lay out and rooms. The collection modernists is limited but some gems.

quote: So much great art that it's easy to get overwhelmed...
reviewnospace: If you love art this is a must see in Madrid. But, be forewarned this museum crams so much art on to it's walls that it can be dizzying. We went on a Monday because admission was free and were not disappointed with the collection of masters spanning the 1400s to 1990s. But you will need to pace yourself. I suggest starting with the second floor while you are "fresh" taking a break in the cafe before walking through the less intense first floor. Then you can complete the first floor with any energy you have left! Truth is, like all the great museums, to maximize your enjoyment and understanding, it's best to visit more than once if your itinerary allows. Enjoy!
titleopinion: So much great art that it's easy to get overwhelmed.... If you love art this is a must see in Madrid. But, be forewarned this museum crams so much art on to it's walls that it can be dizzying. I suggest starting with the second floor while you are  fresh  taking a break in the cafe before walking through the less intense first floor. Then you can complete the first floor with any energy you have left! Truth is, like all the great museums, to maximize your enjoyment and understanding, it's best to visit more than once if your itinerary allows. Enjoy!

reviewnospace: If your art preferences favor impressionism & expressionism this is your stop in Madrid. Hard to believe this incredible collection is the work of one family.
titleopinion: An amazing collection. If your art preferences favor impressionism & expressionism this is your stop in Madrid. Hard to believe this incredible collection is the work of one family.

reviewnospace: A fantastic collection of virtually every artistic era. From El Grecos and works of the 1,400s to impressionists of the 1,800s to modern masters like Picasso, Dali and Rothko.
titleopinion: Tremendous Collection . A fantastic collection of virtually every artistic era. From El Grecos and works of the 1,400s to impressionists of the 1,800s to modern masters like Picasso, Dali and Rothko.

quote: Wonderful permanent collection of one of world's great art collecting families
reviewnospace: Well-curated, and amazing collection. Some wonderful pieces of American art included. The special collection of Carmen Thyssen-Bornemisza is amazing.
titleopinion: Wonderful permanent collection of one of world's great art collecting families. Well-curated, and amazing collection. Some wonderful pieces of American art included. The special collection of Carmen Thyssen-Bornemisza is amazing.

reviewnospace: Visits on Mondays from 2.00 to 4.30 are free entrance, an excellent collection dating from as early as 1300 to modern art exhibits. would allow at least 2-3 hours as there are 3 floors to get round to see and includes the Dutch masters the French impressionists as well as a Picasso and a Van Gooth. All in all a great afternoon in central Madrid if Art is your thing.
titleopinion: Visit to Thyssen-Bornemisza. Visits on Mondays from 2.00 to 4.30 are free entrance, an excellent collection dating from as early as 1300 to modern art exhibits. would allow at least 2-3 hours as there are 3 floors to get round to see and includes the Dutch masters the French impressionists as well as a Picasso and a Van Gooth. All in all a great afternoon in central Madrid if Art is your thing.

reviewnospace: This is my favorite Madrid Museum. It is a human-size museum that contains extraordinary works of art and is not as crowded as the Prado. The lighting and disposition of the paintings are optimized for maximal enjoyment. If you are an art lover, this is a place not to miss.
titleopinion: Beyond beautiful. This is my favorite Madrid Museum. It is a human-size museum that contains extraordinary works of art and is not as crowded as the Prado. The lighting and disposition of the paintings are optimized for maximal enjoyment. If you are an art lover, this is a place not to miss.

quote: private museum that is likely to be sold
reviewnospace: this museum is charming with a number of iconic paintings. The temporary exhibition was masters from Hungarian Beaux Artes that is being renovated.
titleopinion: private museum that is likely to be sold. this museum is charming with a number of iconic paintings. The temporary exhibition was masters from Hungarian Beaux Artes that is being renovated.

reviewnospace: Everything about the Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum from the beautiful building to the layout of the art work makes this the best in Madrid. The spacious rooms provide an excellent venue to see renowned works of art by various artists as well as accommodate many visitors. Be sure to purchase the audio guide to enhance your tour. Also, the restaurant service and food is top-notch which makes for a lovely mid-day stop for a brief refuelling.
titleopinion: Best in Madrid. Everything about the Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum from the beautiful building to the layout of the art work makes this the best in Madrid. The spacious rooms provide an excellent venue to see renowned works of art by various artists as well as accommodate many visitors. Be sure to purchase the audio guide to enhance your tour. Also, the restaurant service and food is top-notch which makes for a lovely mid-day stop for a brief refuelling.

quote: Amazing Collection of many different artists and ers
reviewnospace: Loved this collection, from an Edward Hopper to Degas, Dutch Master's etc. I would definitely put on your Madrid agenda. Easy to tour and great cafe.
titleopinion: Amazing Collection of many different artists and ers. Loved this collection, from an Edward Hopper to Degas, Dutch Master's etc. I would definitely put on your Madrid agenda. Easy to tour and great cafe.

reviewnospace: the visit was a dream you start from the second floor and you go through the Spanish art's a great pleasure I recommend +++

reviewnospace: Simply awesome, 3 floors of well displayed art, dali, Picasso, tons of others, Great variety of styles and genres, from the middle ages to modern. The best Museum in Madrid. The Prado is nice, but it's too big and all the art is the virgin Mary, Jesus, etc, etc.
titleopinion: 5 Stars!!!. Simply awesome, 3 floors of well displayed art, dali, Picasso, tons of others, Great variety of styles and genres, from the middle ages to modern. The best Museum in Madrid. The Prado is nice, but it's too big and all the art is the virgin Mary, Jesus, etc, etc.

reviewnospace: I did not know that the Thyssen-Bornemisza had so many Impressionist paintings. They were amazing and almost as worthy as the collections in Paris: Degas, Cezanne, etc. Then there were the El Grecos, the Renaissance artists, and the moderns, including Hopper. Well worth the entry fee. I visited in February; thus the museum was not very crowded.

Well worth the entry fee. I visited in February; thus the museum was not very crowded.

quote: The history of Western painting in one museum
reviewnospace: From the Middle Age to Pop Art you have it all here. Plan a whole day for this museum if you really want to enjoy it fully.
titleopinion: The history of Western painting in one museum. From the Middle Age to Pop Art you have it all here. Plan a whole day for this museum if you really want to enjoy it fully.

reviewnospace:
A private collection turned into a museum. Not as large as the Prado but very manageable in 2-3 hours. Also means the visit is more linear as opposed to the Prado. More diversified than Prado Museum. I selected the card to visit Prado, Thyssen and Reina Sofia. I got my money's worth for sure.

Visited Thyssen Museum on first Sunday of March. No line up and very light crowd compared to the huge waiting line at El Prado the other side of the street.

quote: Great museum with ancient to modern art.

titleopinion: Great museum with ancient to modern art.. If the lines at the Prado Museum are too long, skip it and go to this nearby museum. Additionally there is a day that you can visit for free. From ancient to modern and every artist in between

reviewnospace: The Thyssen Collection has paintings from the 14th century to the present day, many by well-known artists. I would not hesitate to pay the entrance fee to view this impressive collection, however admission is free on Monday afternoons from noon to 4pm. I spent almost the full 4 hours smiling with pleasure and managed to see all three floors very comfortably. Please note that any special exhibitions are closed at this time.

reviewnospace: After you've seen the Prado Museum, you must spend a few hours at the Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum which is diagonally across the street from El Prado. quote: Dont over look the neighbor of the prado

reviewnospace: The Thyssen has a lot of great paintings in a broader time scope than the Prado, but surely not the depth in the Masters like Goya and Velasquez. Both are wonderful, but have different collecting objectives. Thank goodness for the Baron and Catherine Thyssen-Bornemisza.

reviewnospace:
The Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum is reputed to be the finest private art gallery in the world, and it is easy to see why it enjoys this distinction. It has a huge collection of pictures - from 13th century Italian masterpieces through to Picasso and beyond.
The Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum is a lovely modern gallery and the pictures are wonderfully displayed. I would say that it is worth visiting the gallery just to see Caravaggio's picture of St Catherine - but there is of course much, much more to see.

quote: amazing collection - one of the 'through the ages' that i have ever seen
reviewnospace:
so recommended during our weekend stay in Madrid. Was a delight. Great venue - well run and some additional exhibitions at no extra cost. Amazing collection of art from 13C through to contemporary but some wonderful original Canaletto's and a host of Impressionists - many Gaugins. More than a few Picassos too!
cafeteria food was very high quality and scrupulously clean. Overall a very very well spend 15 euros.

quote: underrated museu that deserves your visit
reviewnospace:
if i had to choose between Reina Sofia or Thyssen, i'll pick Thyssen.
The staff are friendly, the place is well maintain, its cozy and i didn't encounter any crowd here. You may explore the history of art, old masters here.
But if you like new age contemporary art you should head to Reina Sofia.

reviewnospace: This museum has a wide ranging collection: from 1400 up to the present time. Well presented with information in Spanish and English. So if you have no time for a lot of museum visits, this one will give you a great overview.

reviewnospace: This museum is just right! It's not so large that you get overwhelmed by the amount of art, and it's manageable in a few hours. It's arranged in chronological order starting at the top floor. It is truly a stunning collection. The cafe is very nice if you need a little something to eat.
titleopinion: Lovely museum. This museum is just right! It's not so large that you get overwhelmed by the amount of art, and it's manageable in a few hours. It's arranged in chronological order starting at the top floor. It is truly a stunning collection. The cafe is very nice if you need a little something to eat.

quote: The greatest private art collection in the world
reviewnospace:
The Thyssen, as it is normally referred to, is Madrid’s third most important art museum and just across the street from the Prado Museum.

It is also most likely the best and most complete private collection of art in the world. Undoubtedly there are other great private art collections in the world; however, this is the only one that builds a chronological narrative with outstanding examples from each period and very few gaps.

Indeed, visiting the museum is like strolling through the last 600 years of art history. No other private collection presents anything similar. Make sure you grab a guidebook as there is a lot to cover!
titleopinion: The greatest private art collection in the world. The Thyssen, as it is normally referred to, is Madrid’s third most important art museum and just across the street from the Prado Museum.   It is also most likely the best and most complete private collection of art in the world. Undoubtedly there are other great private art collections in the world; however, this is the only one that builds a chronological narrative with outstanding examples from each period and very few gaps.   Indeed, visiting the museum is like strolling through the last 600 years of art history. No other private collection presents anything similar. Make sure you grab a guidebook as there is a lot to cover!

quote: If you go to Madrid you must visit the Thyssen Museum
reviewnospace: A wonderful Museum with one of the world's finest collection. And there are always extraordinary temporary exhibitions of classical art.
titleopinion: If you go to Madrid you must visit the Thyssen Museum. A wonderful Museum with one of the world's finest collection. And there are always extraordinary temporary exhibitions of classical art.

quote: The Prado may be Popular, The Thyssen is Terrific
reviewnospace: Really, you can't compare the museums. Who'd want to? They both have amazing art. Go to both but don't miss the the Thyssen, it's across the street. Of course, take in the Velazquez at the Prado then see the Ghirlandiaio, Van Gogh, Rembrandt or Klee. You'll even find a Georgia O'Keefe. If you're taking kids, give them a list of famous artists to find and send them on their way, so you have time to really take it in.

You'll even find a Georgia O'Keefe. If you're taking kids, give them a list of famous artists to find and send them on their way, so you have time to really take it in.

reviewnospace: The permanent collection is great, but the temporary exhibitions are even better. Went for an exhibition of Bulgari recently and it was so well curated, with such impressive pieces. The best!
titleopinion: Favorite museum in Madrid. The permanent collection is great, but the temporary exhibitions are even better. Went for an exhibition of Bulgari recently and it was so well curated, with such impressive pieces. The best!

reviewnospace:
I visited this museum as part of the Paseo del Arte tour (3 museums in one).

The collection shown is one of a kind. It gives you a good impression of art through all decades and offers some outstanding masterpieces.

Please be aware that if you buy a Paseo del Arte ticket that you only can visit the permanent collections. The temporary exhibitions in this museum are not accessible with this ticket and it is not possible to buy an additional entrance for these exhibitions without paying the full entrance fee (and standing in line again).

This museum is really worth visiting, a must do when you visit Madrid.
titleopinion: Wonderful and worthful visit. I visited this museum as part of the Paseo del Arte tour (3 museums in one).  The collection shown is one of a kind. It gives you a good impression of art through all decades and offers some outstanding masterpieces.  Please be aware that if you buy a Paseo del Arte ticket that you only can visit the permanent collections. The temporary exhibitions in this museum are not accessible with this ticket and it is not possible to buy an additional entrance for these exhibitions without paying the full entrance fee (and standing in line again).  This museum is really worth visiting, a must do when you visit Madrid.

reviewnospace: We spent a morning in this smaller (than the Prado museum) which houses the older masters and modern artists. Senior discounts are available and I would recommend a visit. Cameras without flash are permitted.After the tour we had a light lunch in the cafeteria, a bit pricey but the soup was absolutely delicious. Homemade and served quite eloquently by the waiter.
titleopinion: Delightful Museum. We spent a morning in this smaller (than the Prado museum) which houses the older masters and modern artists. Senior discounts are available and I would recommend a visit. Cameras without flash are permitted.After the tour we had a light lunch in the cafeteria, a bit pricey but the soup was absolutely delicious. Homemade and served quite eloquently by the waiter.

reviewnospace:
This is really two museums. One the Thyssen-Bornnemisza family collection and the other a more routinely curated world class gallery. It is interesting to contrast the collections.
The galleries for both collections are arranged chronologically which really facilitates a visit. I was also impressed with the excellent lighting.
The restaurant was tasty and efficient
Clearly a must in Madrid (buy the 3 museum pass to save a few Euros
titleopinion: Comprehensive and well organized . This is really two museums. One the Thyssen-Bornnemisza family collection and the other a more routinely curated world class gallery. It is interesting to contrast the collections.  The galleries for both collections are arranged chronologically which really facilitates a visit. I was also impressed with the excellent lighting. The restaurant was tasty and efficient  Clearly a must in Madrid (buy the 3 museum pass to save a few Euros

The special exhibition on Bulgari & Rome was beautifully designed and elegantly mounted. Great book shop too!

A great half-day to full-day museum.

quote: Lovely, Diverse Collection. Both Cafe and Store Very Good
reviewnospace: NOTE: if you plan to visit the Thyssen, Reina Sofia and the Prado purchase the combo ticket for 28€. It will save money and time. Spent about 4 hours at the museum which included lunch. The collection is very diverse. The museum generously lends out it paintings, so quite a few of the great pieces are on loan. We purchased an app with audio guides for three museums which in the end was a disappointment with outdated info/picture locations. If you have the time, purchase the audio guide at the museum.

reviewnospace:
This museum is free from 5-7 on Sunday's (it might be every day too) and we couldn't believe it (sponsored by MasterCard). We saw original art from Picasso, Dali, Van Gogh, Monet, and I can go on and on! The entire collection is privately owned and graciously shared!
3 floors from 13-1400 art to present day.

We saw original art from Picasso, Dali, Van Gogh, Monet, and I can go on and on! The entire collection is privately owned and graciously shared!  3 floors from 13-1400 art to present day.

reviewnospace: My first visit to the TB happened to coincide with a visit by the King and Queen of Spain, unveiling a plaque to commemorate 25 years of the gallery opening! Despite the Royal entourage, heightened security presence and assembled ranks of the Press, my visit was a hassle free ramble through some of the most exceptional works of art in Spain. The collection is simply but effectively organised by region/period, with a handy audio guide and map. Timed entry to the special collection ensures that the gallery is much less busy then it's more famous neighbour, with space and time to enjoy the experience. In contrast with the UK, there are no paranoid barriers, glass screens or annoying notices - just a lovingly and expertly displayed formerly private collection of outstanding art. Don't miss the Flemish masters of C15/16, the Drurer (Christ amongst the Doctors) and the Superb Monet and VGs. The restaurant too is quite simply superb, but avoid shorts and sandals as seating and eating is quite formal. A great gallery, eclectic and wide ranging collection and very helpful signage and staff - even in the presence of Royalty!!
titleopinion: A surprising visit!. My first visit to the TB happened to coincide with a visit by the King and Queen of Spain, unveiling a plaque to commemorate 25 years of the gallery opening! Despite the Royal entourage, heightened security presence and assembled ranks of the Press, my visit was a hassle free ramble through some of the most exceptional works of art in Spain. In contrast with the UK, there are no paranoid barriers, glass screens or annoying notices - just a lovingly and expertly displayed formerly private collection of outstanding art. Don't miss the Flemish masters of C15/16, the Drurer (Christ amongst the Doctors) and the Superb Monet and VGs. reviewnospace: Astonishing private collection now open to the public. The rooms and self guided tour ordered chronologically which we appreciated. Some El Greco and older art gives way quickly to Van Gogh, Pissaro,Monet, Gauguin, Matisse, Picasso, Miro, Tooulouise-Lautrec,Degas. Nice surprises are John Singer Sargent, Homer, Chagall, one Richard Estes, one Lichtenstein, and statues by Rodin. There's more, just go. Nice gift shop, good prices, beautiful building.

reviewnospace:
We purchased a ticket on line for all 3 museums.. (Thyssen, Prado and Sofia) the cost was €28...Represented very good value for money. You present your preprinted voucher at your first museum of choice and you will be issued with a ticket which enables to gain entry to other two. Do arrive early and avoid lengthy queues.
This was our favourite museum..
Did our homework before we went and we were selective during our visit.
To see everything you would probably need two days in each museum! The paintings were amazing...an experience you won't forget.
The restaurant in the Thyssen was our favourite for coffee and lunch. The food and service were both excellent.
There is access to the restaurant from the street, don't have to be in the museum.
All in all a wonderful experience.
A feast of magnificent art to be enjoyed in all three museums.

quote: Get up close to the Art
reviewnospace: We spent AGES in this museum. The paintings are a mixed bag, lots of famous names but perhaps not the most well known or best examples. And many of the pictures seemed darkened to the point where they appeared set at nighttime - in contrast the Prado's art is all brighter and I suppose cleaned and restored. I do wish they could look at cleaning some of the most darkened paintings though as you miss a lot. HOWEVER, despite all of this, we loved it. You could get right up to the pictures and really study them. My daughter and I spent hours happily critiquing, admiring and sometimes laughing at the art. In contrast we felt overwhelmed by the Prado and its crowds. I'd also say the gift shop is fab and so is the cafe- very reasonably priced and a nice way to end the visit with a glass of wine and a cake. Highly recommended.

reviewnospace:
This has got to be my favorite museum in madrid. It is free on Mondays (the permanent collection anyway), and it houses a very good selection of art through the ages. The bottom floor especially has a great selection of everything from cubism through futurism and german expressionism into dada and post modern and abstract. There's also an entire floor of dutch and english realism that moves into some impressionists, post impressionists, and more than i expected to find from fauvist and other expressionist artists.

Their temporary exhibitions have always been AMAZING. I've been to three and always wish I could see more - but their impressionists in plein air was amazing - they managed to pull fantastic pieces from a lot of other famous museums including the musee d'orsay. Most recently I saw their Caravaggio exhibition and it was absolutely stunning. Even if you don't go on a monday, the price is nominal, 12euros, and absolutely worth your time.
titleopinion: Fantastic collection. This has got to be my favorite museum in madrid. It is free on Mondays (the permanent collection anyway), and it houses a very good selection of art through the ages. The bottom floor especially has a great selection of everything from cubism through futurism and german expressionism into dada and post modern and abstract. There's also an entire floor of dutch and english realism that moves into some impressionists, post impressionists, and more than i expected to find from fauvist and other expressionist artists.   Their temporary exhibitions have always been AMAZING. I've been to three and always wish I could see more - but their impressionists in plein air was amazing - they managed to pull fantastic pieces from a lot of other famous museums including the musee d'orsay. Most recently I saw their Caravaggio exhibition and it was absolutely stunning. Even if you don't go on a monday, the price is nominal, 12euros, and absolutely worth your time.

reviewnospace: As other museums are just dedicated to certain period of time, visiting Thyssen museum is a great experience as you can see the evolution of painting since the middle eagles to our time.
titleopinion: The history of painting. As other museums are just dedicated to certain period of time, visiting Thyssen museum is a great experience as you can see the evolution of painting since the middle eagles to our time.

reviewnospace: This is one of the highlights of Madrid. We spent 2 hours visiting just half of the art work - modern 20th C Spanish artists and beyond. Brilliant.
titleopinion: Fabulous museum - don't mis it. This is one of the highlights of Madrid. We spent 2 hours visiting just half of the art work - modern 20th C Spanish artists and beyond. Brilliant.

reviewnospace: I found myself immersed in the art so nicely displayed in chronological order. The crowds were smaller here than the Prado and I found myself elated after viewing. I realized joy from the process - isn't that how art is meant to be experienced? This reminded me of Musee d'Orsay - another favorite spot of mine. Smaller in size and content than Prado. I recently saw an exhibit at the Meuseum of Fine Art Houston - of a Degas on loan from this museum - that painting spiked my interest in Thyssen Bornemisza and I was not disappointed.
titleopinion: Joy for the soul. I found myself immersed in the art so nicely displayed in chronological order. The crowds were smaller here than the Prado and I found myself elated after viewing. I realized joy from the process - isn't that how art is meant to be experienced? This reminded me of Musee d'Orsay - another favorite spot of mine. Smaller in size and content than Prado. I recently saw an exhibit at the Meuseum of Fine Art Houston - of a Degas on loan from this museum - that painting spiked my interest in Thyssen Bornemisza and I was not disappointed.

reviewnospace: The Thyssen is a private museum, but it displays some of the best works of art in Madrid (bearing in mind the tough competition presented by the Prado and the Reina Sofia). It is opposite the Prado. Some say that Baron Thyssen-Bornemisza started collecting art as an investment. His wife, however, the Baroness, followed in his footsteps a while later, but did it as a hobby. This led her to discover and buy works of art by artists who were not yet that famous (eg Andy Warhol, Liechtenstein, etc). As a result, her collection today is even more interesting than his (you can visit them separately at the museum). The Baron died a few years ago, but the Baroness is still alive. The museum's gift shop is also amazing.
titleopinion: A wonderful surprise. The Thyssen is a private museum, but it displays some of the best works of art in Madrid (bearing in mind the tough competition presented by the Prado and the Reina Sofia). It is opposite the Prado. Some say that Baron Thyssen-Bornemisza started collecting art as an investment. His wife, however, the Baroness, followed in his footsteps a while later, but did it as a hobby. This led her to discover and buy works of art by artists who were not yet that famous (eg Andy Warhol, Liechtenstein, etc). As a result, her collection today is even more interesting than his (you can visit them separately at the museum). The Baron died a few years ago, but the Baroness is still alive. The museum's gift shop is also amazing.

reviewnospace: Art is a matter of personal taste. And this art is what my taste appreciates. Well done display. Hidden gems. Don't miss the Van Gogh. Better time for my money than the Prado.
titleopinion: Excellent visit. Art is a matter of personal taste. And this art is what my taste appreciates. Well done display. Hidden gems. Don't miss the Van Gogh. Better time for my money than the Prado.

reviewnospace: I have been there twice in a twoyearperiod and was surprised by the themes of the temporary exibtions: they were related with fashion. In adiction, this last time we saw a very good Renoir exibit.
titleopinion: Always surprising. I have been there twice in a twoyearperiod and was surprised by the themes of the temporary exibtions: they were related with fashion. In adiction, this last time we saw a very good Renoir exibit.

quote: Amazing Experience of Art Through Our Senses
reviewnospace:
A must visit, must experience museum which has fulfilled its promises of wonderful exhibitions every single time I've visited. On this occasion I went for the Renoir, which floored me, yet was also spoiled by a delightful extra: the Bulgari and Rome, which I tripped through like a spoiled child, exclaiming at the sensory delights, the clever audio-visual involvement which enfolded everyone into its glorious arms.

The staff at the Thyssen are attentive, polite, helpful, and friendly. The restaurant superb, both in gastronomy and service. The collections head-shakenly wonderfully complete. A full experience of art in a few hours, that make you climb stairs and race corridors again and again for just one more look through room 13, or sala D.

Cannot recommend it enough. In my experience the best art museum in Europe.
titleopinion: Amazing Experience of Art Through Our Senses. A must visit, must experience museum which has fulfilled its promises of wonderful exhibitions every single time I've visited. On this occasion I went for the Renoir, which floored me, yet was also spoiled by a delightful extra: the Bulgari and Rome, which I tripped through like a spoiled child, exclaiming at the sensory delights, the clever audio-visual involvement which enfolded everyone into its glorious arms.  The staff at the Thyssen are attentive, polite, helpful, and friendly. The restaurant superb, both in gastronomy and service. The collections head-shakenly wonderfully complete. A full experience of art in a few hours, that make you climb stairs and race corridors again and again for just one more look through room 13, or sala D.   Cannot recommend it enough. In my experience the best art museum in Europe.

quote: Wonderful range laid out in a friendly way
reviewnospace: Good things come in small packages... not a Louvre or a Prado but none the worst for that. Bite sized and packed with wonders.
titleopinion: Wonderful range laid out in a friendly way. Good things come in small packages... not a Louvre or a Prado but none the worst for that. Bite sized and packed with wonders.

quote: Outstanding Collection - A real treasure trove
reviewnospace: This is a remarkable gallery that reflects a wonderfully varied collection spanning many styles and artists. Beautifully laid out, the visitor is never bored and is led easily from hall to hall. What really impresses is the fact that one was able to enjoy every element without having to struggle for a viewing point. I imagine it will be much busier in the summer months when visitor numbers increase and seek the shade from the heat of the city. However, in late January it felt as though we had the gallery to ourselves and were able to maximise our enjoyment of the rich treasures on view. There were many highlights as you would expect in such a fantastic collection and every visitor will find something special without doubt and whatever their preferences.. Certainly we found this collection more enjoyable than many we have seen over the years and the added Bulgari exhibits were truly outstanding though somewhat over the top for those that prefer somewhat less bling! No doubting the craftsmanship of the goldsmiths and jewellers on display and right at the pinnacle of their art for this Italian treasure house. A very pleasant day of browsing and education.
titleopinion: Outstanding Collection - A real treasure trove. This is a remarkable gallery that reflects a wonderfully varied collection spanning many styles and artists. Beautifully laid out, the visitor is never bored and is led easily from hall to hall. What really impresses is the fact that one was able to enjoy every element without having to struggle for a viewing point. I imagine it will be much busier in the summer months when visitor numbers increase and seek the shade from the heat of the city. However, in late January it felt as though we had the gallery to ourselves and were able to maximise our enjoyment of the rich treasures on view. There were many highlights as you would expect in such a fantastic collection and every visitor will find something special without doubt and whatever their preferences.. Certainly we found this collection more enjoyable than many we have seen over the years and the added Bulgari exhibits were truly outstanding though somewhat over the top for those that prefer somewhat less bling! No doubting the craftsmanship of the goldsmiths and jewellers on display and right at the pinnacle of their art for this Italian treasure house. A very pleasant day of browsing and education.

reviewnospace: It was a very cold day in Madrid so we thought we would walk to the museum and spend time indoors. What a fantastic day! There was a Bulgari Exhibit and a Renoir Exhibit.The entry fee with an audio guide was 19 Euro. Enjoyed it thoroughly. The Bulgari had jewelry, the history of how it was established, and celebrity photos wearing the jewelry and much more. But the Renoir exhibit I could have spent all day, sitting and looking. It was extraordinary! We had lunch in the cafe which was very busy, but courteous and food was great. We enjoyed all the older paintings from the Middle Ages to the 19th Century. Not into Modern art but did see some Picasso.
titleopinion: Great Exhibits. It was a very cold day in Madrid so we thought we would walk to the museum and spend time indoors. What a fantastic day! There was a Bulgari Exhibit and a Renoir Exhibit.The entry fee with an audio guide was 19 Euro. Enjoyed it thoroughly. The Bulgari had jewelry, the history of how it was established, and celebrity photos wearing the jewelry and much more. But the Renoir exhibit I could have spent all day, sitting and looking. It was extraordinary! We had lunch in the cafe which was very busy, but courteous and food was great. We enjoyed all the older paintings from the Middle Ages to the 19th Century. Not into Modern art but did see some Picasso.

reviewnospace: Visited Renoir exhibit and Bulgari and Roma exhibit. Both were excellent and I would definitely return to this museum!
titleopinion: Great exhibits!. Visited Renoir exhibit and Bulgari and Roma exhibit. Both were excellent and I would definitely return to this museum!

quote: Great mix of art through the ages and styles
reviewnospace: Enjoyed the variety and quality of art. Free on Mondays. Like how you start at the top and make your way down through time. Shows the evolution of art and civilization. Who commissioned art, who could afford art, how people have more time to express themselves now than earlier. Freedom of expression also evident
titleopinion: Great mix of art through the ages and styles. Enjoyed the variety and quality of art. Free on Mondays. Like how you start at the top and make your way down through time. Shows the evolution of art and civilization. Who commissioned art, who could afford art, how people have more time to express themselves now than earlier. Freedom of expression also evident

reviewnospace: This museum has a large and varous kind of painting, from middle ages to XX century, from baroque to expressionism, a especial range from famous to unknown artist. The entrance fee is 12 euros for adults. Students and under 18 students pay 8 euros.
titleopinion: Large painting exibition. This museum has a large and varous kind of painting, from middle ages to XX century, from baroque to expressionism, a especial range from famous to unknown artist. The entrance fee is 12 euros for adults. Students and under 18 students pay 8 euros.

quote: Fantastic museum to learn about art
reviewnospace:
This was my second visit to the Thyssen and both times I have been impressed with their collection and ability to teach me about the artwork. They have a world class collection that highlights the major evolution of painting styles over the centuries. You need the audioguide.

The museum is free on Monday afternoons from 12pm.
titleopinion: Fantastic museum to learn about art. This was my second visit to the Thyssen and both times I have been impressed with their collection and ability to teach me about the artwork. They have a world class collection that highlights the major evolution of painting styles over the centuries. You need the audioguide.  The museum is free on Monday afternoons from 12pm.

quote: Good afternoon or partial day activity
reviewnospace: The Thyssen museum is a good part day activity. The range of what exists in the museum is what is impressive. Not too much of each particular artist, but a good sampling of all the different types.
titleopinion: Good afternoon or partial day activity. The Thyssen museum is a good part day activity. The range of what exists in the museum is what is impressive. Not too much of each particular artist, but a good sampling of all the different types.

quote: The gift shop is a must
reviewnospace: The museum showcases a large number of important paintings of various periods, from Renaissance to modern. And if you particularly like any of them, the gift shop sells replicas of many of the paintings printed within minutes on paper or canvas. They make nice keepsakes.
titleopinion: The gift shop is a must. The museum showcases a large number of important paintings of various periods, from Renaissance to modern. And if you particularly like any of them, the gift shop sells replicas of many of the paintings printed within minutes on paper or canvas. They make nice keepsakes.

quote: The history of Western art on three floors - with the very best examples
reviewnospace: What a wonderful museum. Start at the top in 13C Italy and leave at the bottom with Lucian Freud and Miro and and and. Very visitor friendly, benches to stop and consider the wonderful art on display, and it is so well displayed. The Renoir temporary exhibition was wonderful, but as with all solo exhibitions you leave thinking slightly less of the artist - less is more!

quote: The second largest meseum next to the Louve
reviewnospace: If you want to see so of the greatest works of art in the world while in Madrid this is the place to go. it is not to expensive and easy to see art up close and personal
titleopinion: The second largest meseum next to the Louve. If you want to see so of the greatest works of art in the world while in Madrid this is the place to go. it is not to expensive and easy to see art up close and personal

reviewnospace: Good value for 7 euors that included the special exhibitions of Renoir (over 90 paintings) and Bvlgari. Do hire the audio guide.
titleopinion: 5 nights in Madrid. Good value for 7 euors that included the special exhibitions of Renoir (over 90 paintings) and Bvlgari. Do hire the audio guide.

reviewnospace: Amazing array of modern art and grand masters. Friendly support and such a rich feast of paintings with excellent restaurant. The location is so close to other major museums. A must see!
titleopinion: Aesthetic feast of artistic delights. Amazing array of modern art and grand masters. Friendly support and such a rich feast of paintings with excellent restaurant. The location is so close to other major museums. A must see!

reviewnospace: Good gallery. Well laid out good audio. ,learnt something as progressed thru the gallery. Laid out by the Yeats as you walk thru. Some wonderful works. Amazing collection
titleopinion: Fabulous. Good gallery. Well laid out good audio. ,learnt something as progressed thru the gallery. Laid out by the Yeats as you walk thru. Some wonderful works. Amazing collection

quote: Beautiful things in a beautiful building.
reviewnospace: We didn't know what to expect but wanted a casual 'culture fix'.This was the perfect choice and was so well layed out with good descriptions and perfect lighting to bring out the best in these 'never seen before 'works of art in this once private collection.It has a super gift shop with a souvenir to suit any budget.Very user friendly if you need to stop now and again with wide aisles and a lift for wheelchair users.A must see on any trip to Madrid.
titleopinion: Beautiful things in a beautiful building.. We didn't know what to expect but wanted a casual 'culture fix'.This was the perfect choice and was so well layed out with good descriptions and perfect lighting to bring out the best in these 'never seen before 'works of art in this once private collection.It has a super gift shop with a souvenir to suit any budget.Very user friendly if you need to stop now and again with wide aisles and a lift for wheelchair users.A must see on any trip to Madrid.

reviewnospace: This museum is lovely. At the entrance you have a free coat room. The special exhibitions are timed. We saw Bulgari y Roma and Renoir Intimacy. Oh what beautiful jewelry and the pics of their owners were mesmerizing, to the tune of Audrey Hepburn, Sofia Loren, Gina L., Elizabeth Taylor, Baroness Carmen Thyssen, all crafted by Sotirio Bulgari. The Renoir paintings gave a peek into the artists' favorite subjects with paintings of his family. You'll also see in the permanent exhibition paintings and the collection of the Baroness works by Rodin, Dali, Monet, van Gogh, Rubens, Picasso.
titleopinion: Impressive Museum. This museum is lovely. At the entrance you have a free coat room. The special exhibitions are timed. We saw Bulgari y Roma and Renoir Intimacy. Oh what beautiful jewelry and the pics of their owners were mesmerizing, to the tune of Audrey Hepburn, Sofia Loren, Gina L., Elizabeth Taylor, Baroness Carmen Thyssen, all crafted by Sotirio Bulgari. The Renoir paintings gave a peek into the artists' favorite subjects with paintings of his family. You'll also see in the permanent exhibition paintings and the collection of the Baroness works by Rodin, Dali, Monet, van Gogh, Rubens, Picasso.

reviewnospace: Definitely worth the visit. Great to see Joseph Cornell, John Singer Sargent (the first landscape painting of his I have seen), Dali, Picasso, and more.
titleopinion: Great museum - a must see!. Definitely worth the visit. Great to see Joseph Cornell, John Singer Sargent (the first landscape painting of his I have seen), Dali, Picasso, and more.

reviewnospace: Two absolutely amazing exhibitions set this tour up. We had coffee down the road at Starbucks and hit the door about 10.45. The initial rush had already been processed and we had no queues. Timing of entry into the two exhibitions meant that they were not too crowded. Even the cloak room staff were friendly and helpful. A great visit.
titleopinion: Renoir and Bulgaria exhibitions stunning. Two absolutely amazing exhibitions set this tour up. We had coffee down the road at Starbucks and hit the door about 10.45. The initial rush had already been processed and we had no queues. Timing of entry into the two exhibitions meant that they were not too crowded. Even the cloak room staff were friendly and helpful. A great visit.

reviewnospace: I enjoyed the art here. My favorite things were the Bvlgari and Renoir exhibits and since they are limited time things, I do not know how timely this review will be once they are gone. The museum did an amazing job of making these exhibits multi-sensory and I enjoyed that very much.
titleopinion: Beautiful. I enjoyed the art here. My favorite things were the Bvlgari and Renoir exhibits and since they are limited time things, I do not know how timely this review will be once they are gone. The museum did an amazing job of making these exhibits multi-sensory and I enjoyed that very much.

reviewnospace:
The building is clean, modern with an amazing collection. It happened to be free the day I went in (extra bonus).

Totally worth your time.
titleopinion: Great Museum . The building is clean, modern with an amazing collection. It happened to be free the day I went in (extra bonus).  Totally worth your time.

reviewnospace: Very cool place, and very manageable with a few excellent examples from each era, you can have a walk through art history from 1500 to contemporary art, and get an understanding of how the journey happened
titleopinion: Perfect sized museum. Very cool place, and very manageable with a few excellent examples from each era, you can have a walk through art history from 1500 to contemporary art, and get an understanding of how the journey happened

quote: A fabulous private collection, definitely worth a stop
reviewnospace: Just a block or so away from the glorious Prado museum is this wonderful archive of art collected by the late Baron Hans Heinrich Thyssen-Bornemisza (1921–2002) and his wife "Tita" Cervera (a Miss Spain), but which was started in the 1920s by the Baron's father. Very interesting and eclectic collection, and when I've visited there have been interesting temporary exhibitions also in place. Highly recommend you include this in your museum-hopping while in Madrid; it is most definitely worth a stop.
titleopinion: A fabulous private collection, definitely worth a stop. Just a block or so away from the glorious Prado museum is this wonderful archive of art collected by the late Baron Hans Heinrich Thyssen-Bornemisza (1921–2002) and his wife  Tita  Cervera (a Miss Spain), but which was started in the 1920s by the Baron's father. Very interesting and eclectic collection, and when I've visited there have been interesting temporary exhibitions also in place. Highly recommend you include this in your museum-hopping while in Madrid; it is most definitely worth a stop.

reviewnospace: It is a huge and great museum. If you need to make a choice Prado vs. Thyssen and you like to see more modern art, go for Thyssen.
titleopinion: A Madrid must. It is a huge and great museum. If you need to make a choice Prado vs. Thyssen and you like to see more modern art, go for Thyssen.

reviewnospace: Just follow the numbers and in no time you would have seen several styles through several centuries with a few classic pieces.
titleopinion: Quality Art Gallery made Simple. Just follow the numbers and in no time you would have seen several styles through several centuries with a few classic pieces.

quote: Visiting the Renoir exhibition and general museum
reviewnospace: A great exhibition of Renoir paintings(temporary). Followed by a general visit of this great museum. It was our second visit in 6 months. We intend to come again. The museum is well laid out and well documented. Great for 17 century and impressionist paintings
titleopinion: Visiting the Renoir exhibition and general museum. A great exhibition of Renoir paintings(temporary). Followed by a general visit of this great museum. It was our second visit in 6 months. We intend to come again. The museum is well laid out and well documented. Great for 17 century and impressionist paintings

reviewnospace: they have a wide variety of art selection and have constant changes in their pieces to attract more people. i got to see the bvulgary exposition and was fascinated.
titleopinion: MUST VISIT. they have a wide variety of art selection and have constant changes in their pieces to attract more people. i got to see the bvulgary exposition and was fascinated.

quote: skip all other museums for this collection
reviewnospace: This collection has representatives of so many Spanish (and other) masters that just going through this museum provides an amazing insight. Seeing Prado Museum and Queen Sofia Arts center later seemed like an overkill to us. Great temporary exhibit "Bulgari and Rome" - also Renoir but we didn't get the tickets. General comment about museums in Madrid - buy tickets online as the lines are huge and with an online tickets you can stroll right in!
titleopinion: skip all other museums for this collection. This collection has representatives of so many Spanish (and other) masters that just going through this museum provides an amazing insight. Seeing Prado Museum and Queen Sofia Arts center later seemed like an overkill to us. Great temporary exhibit  Bulgari and Rome  - also Renoir but we didn't get the tickets. General comment about museums in Madrid - buy tickets online as the lines are huge and with an online tickets you can stroll right in!

reviewnospace: You will see Goya, Titan, Reuben, and many more of the masters. A very large exhibit. This one takes time, all day to really appreciate everything. We did it in an afternoon and were hard pressed to see everything. They have restrooms, several gift shops and a really nice cafe. Would be a good option when the weather is not so great outside.
titleopinion: Art lovers dream. You will see Goya, Titan, Reuben, and many more of the masters. A very large exhibit. This one takes time, all day to really appreciate everything. We did it in an afternoon and were hard pressed to see everything. They have restrooms, several gift shops and a really nice cafe. Would be a good option when the weather is not so great outside.

quote: One of the best private collection of the world!
reviewnospace: Choose the art period you prefer. Take your time visiting the inumerous exhibitions rooms where painting is at its best. Some of the temporary exhibitions are interessting, but are generally very crowdy. Good cafeteria. The shop is ok.
titleopinion: One of the best private collection of the world!. Choose the art period you prefer. Take your time visiting the inumerous exhibitions rooms where painting is at its best. Some of the temporary exhibitions are interessting, but are generally very crowdy. Good cafeteria. The shop is ok.

reviewnospace: The last time we were here was shortly after the museum had opened (in the nineties), and I remember thinking it was an interesting small private collection, but no more than that. This time, however, the impact was completely different. It has become a world-class art centre and is well worth the visit. Besides the permanent collection, which deserves a visit in itself, we had the chance to see two temporary exhibitions (one about Renoir, providing insight into his technique, and the other a collection of jewellery by Bulgari, showing how so many designs had been inspired by architectural features of Rome). All of this followed by lunch of a quality and variety rarely seen in museums, and a visit to the shop, where there is an amazing selection of items, not to mention the art books. I'm sure we have missed a lot since our first visit and we are determined not to miss any more - this will now be a regular feature of visits to Madrid.
titleopinion: unmissable. The last time we were here was shortly after the museum had opened (in the nineties), and I remember thinking it was an interesting small private collection, but no more than that. This time, however, the impact was completely different. It has become a world-class art centre and is well worth the visit. Besides the permanent collection, which deserves a visit in itself, we had the chance to see two temporary exhibitions (one about Renoir, providing insight into his technique, and the other a collection of jewellery by Bulgari, showing how so many designs had been inspired by architectural features of Rome). All of this followed by lunch of a quality and variety rarely seen in museums, and a visit to the shop, where there is an amazing selection of items, not to mention the art books. I'm sure we have missed a lot since our first visit and we are determined not to miss any more - this will now be a regular feature of visits to Madrid.

reviewnospace: The Thyssen museum located near the famous Prado museum covers a broad range of western art---something by almost everyone of the well known artists---including Italian artists and French Impressionists not well represented in Madrid's other great museums, the Prado and Reina Sofia. The nucleus of the museum is the personal collection of the baron Thyssen-Bornemisza, acquired in the first half of the 20th century and originally kept in Italy. In 1985, the baron moved the collection to Madrid, and the Spanish government later bought the collection, which is supplemented by the loan of many works from the baron's wife, Carmen Cervera.
titleopinion: Great art museum!. The Thyssen museum located near the famous Prado museum covers a broad range of western art---something by almost everyone of the well known artists---including Italian artists and French Impressionists not well represented in Madrid's other great museums, the Prado and Reina Sofia. The nucleus of the museum is the personal collection of the baron Thyssen-Bornemisza, acquired in the first half of the 20th century and originally kept in Italy. In 1985, the baron moved the collection to Madrid, and the Spanish government later bought the collection, which is supplemented by the loan of many works from the baron's wife, Carmen Cervera.

reviewnospace: When you've finished with the Prado and feel you really need a change from looking at pictures - please don't. Just down the road you will find this astonishing collection, acquired mainly by two aristocratic members of the same family, and representing around seven hundred years of European art, but particularly impressive in 19th and early 20th century works. It's a beautifully designed space and full of wonderful pictures. When I visited, I found, to my intense pleasure, two additional exhibitions of two of my favourite painters - Caravaggio and Gustave Caillabotte, one of the less well known Impressionists. This was just wonderful, but meant I didn't have time to do justice to the permanent collection, focusing on the 20th. century American and European works due to lack of time. I will certainly return next visit and make sure I have time to do it justice.
titleopinion: Wish I'd had more time..... When you've finished with the Prado and feel you really need a change from looking at pictures - please don't. Just down the road you will find this astonishing collection, acquired mainly by two aristocratic members of the same family, and representing around seven hundred years of European art, but particularly impressive in 19th and early 20th century works. It's a beautifully designed space and full of wonderful pictures. When I visited, I found, to my intense pleasure, two additional exhibitions of two of my favourite painters - Caravaggio and Gustave Caillabotte, one of the less well known Impressionists. This was just wonderful, but meant I didn't have time to do justice to the permanent collection, focusing on the 20th. century American and European works due to lack of time. I will certainly return next visit and make sure I have time to do it justice.

quote: Nice museum but too many not interesting works
reviewnospace:
The museum has several very impressive works from artists such as Caravaggio, Monet, Gauguin. Unfortunately some works from artists I would have liked to see, especially impressionists like Degas where on lease to other museums.
The rest of the works was not that impressive, there were many portraits which I personally am not really interested in, for me that was too much of filler art that I could have skipped.
It is worth a visit, but I would not consider it a must.
If you are going here and to Prado and Reina Sophia also, check the Paseo del Arte which is a combined ticket for all three you can buy online.

By the way, there is a temporary exhibition requiring a separate ticket which must be bought in advance - online or the day before.
titleopinion: Nice museum but too many not interesting works . The museum has several very impressive works from artists such as Caravaggio, Monet, Gauguin. Unfortunately some works from artists I would have liked to see, especially impressionists like Degas where on lease to other museums.  The rest of the works was not that impressive, there were many portraits which I personally am not really interested in, for me that was too much of filler art that I could have skipped. It is worth a visit, but I would not consider it a must. reviewnospace: Not as comprehensive as the Prado, but many fine masterpieces, with a bit more emphasis on more modern works, very well laid out and organised
titleopinion: World class museum. Not as comprehensive as the Prado, but many fine masterpieces, with a bit more emphasis on more modern works, very well laid out and organised

reviewnospace: This museum was not on our initial itinerary, however I would highly recommend it to others. We purchased the full access ticket, which allowed us access to the temporary Renoir experience, which was wonderful.
titleopinion: Well worth a visit. This museum was not on our initial itinerary, however I would highly recommend it to others. We purchased the full access ticket, which allowed us access to the temporary Renoir experience, which was wonderful.

reviewnospace: Incredible private collection now public. Excellent pieces that span from medieval iconic religious art to modern abstract art. Definitely part of the Paseo del Arte Pass: 3 museums (Prado, Thyssen & Reina Sofia) at an excellent price.
titleopinion: a Fine Collection. Incredible private collection now public. Excellent pieces that span from medieval iconic religious art to modern abstract art. Definitely part of the Paseo del Arte Pass: 3 museums (Prado, Thyssen & Reina Sofia) at an excellent price.

reviewnospace: Small but lovely museum with a grand collection of some of the best works.. Renoir and Bvlgari exhibit was an added bonus. Spent an easy 3 hours
titleopinion: Worth a visit. Small but lovely museum with a grand collection of some of the best works.. Renoir and Bvlgari exhibit was an added bonus. Spent an easy 3 hours

quote: The same procedure as last year
reviewnospace: Every time we are in Madrid (and we are almost every year there), we pay a visit to this museum. There you find, very well organized and displayed, some works of art of the best artists in the world. Dutch, French, Spanish, German, Italian, North- and Southamerican painters and sculptors, classic and modern. Once someone asked me in Bilbao, why the Guggenheim was precisely there and not in Madrid, if she asked me today the same question: I would answer, Madrid has all the other museums, and I mean with this Thyssen, Prado, Caixa, why can´t the Basques have a jewel like that? Because Thyssen is also a real jewel.
titleopinion: The same procedure as last year. Every time we are in Madrid (and we are almost every year there), we pay a visit to this museum. There you find, very well organized and displayed, some works of art of the best artists in the world. Dutch, French, Spanish, German, Italian, North- and Southamerican painters and sculptors, classic and modern. Once someone asked me in Bilbao, why the Guggenheim was precisely there and not in Madrid, if she asked me today the same question: I would answer, Madrid has all the other museums, and I mean with this Thyssen, Prado, Caixa, why can´t the Basques have a jewel like that? Because Thyssen is also a real jewel.

quote: Very Good Museum But Not The Prado - Separate Tickets for Renoir and Bulgari and Rome Exhibits Must Be Bought In Advance
reviewnospace: My wife, two children and I visited Madrid in December 2017. Since my wife and children were tired, I went to the Thyssen museum by myself. I bought a museum pass online which included the Prado, the Thyssen Museum and the Queen Sofia Art Center and cost 28 euros. The Thyssen museum includes the private collections of Thyssen and his wife. The ground floor had modern art including Picasso, Kandinsky, Paul Klee, Dali and others and was the best part of the museum. The other floors had extensive collections of paintings but many of the artists were obscure and I had never heard of them before. Some of the paintings by famous impressionists were out on loan which was disappointing. I did make one mistake which I would like to point out to the benefit of anyone visiting Madrid now. There are separate exhibits - Bulgari and Rome (jewelry collection) and Renoir. However, this requires the purchase of a separate ticket. After I had finished visiting the permanent collection, I asked if the museum pass was valid for the Renoir and Bulgari and Rome exhibits. Unfortunately, I was told it required the purchase of a separate ticket and that the tickets were sold out. So I was not able to see these two exhibits. Other than that, I think this museum is definitely worth visiting for two hours but I do not put it at the same level as the Prado.

The other floors had extensive collections of paintings but many of the artists were obscure and I had never heard of them before. Unfortunately, I was told it required the purchase of a separate ticket and that the tickets were sold out. So I was not able to see these two exhibits. Other than that, I think this museum is definitely worth visiting for two hours but I do not put it at the same level as the Prado.

reviewnospace:
We visited the Thyssen-Bornemisza collection many years ago, when it was still situated in a villa in Lugano. Already at that time it struck us as an amazing collection of very high quality paintings. This was the first time we visited Madrid and the Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum here. And we couldn't stop going from one room to the other. It is almost unreal how many high quality pieces Th.-B. has been able to lay his hands on. And later on his wife Carmen added a whole new section to the existing collection, among which also many very interesting pieces.
We will return soon.

The gift shop has nice souvenirs and theme books from the current exhibits.

quote: A great art museum -- especially for 19th & 20th centuries
reviewnospace:
When in Madrid, you can't not go to the Prado, the Reina Sofia (for Guernica), and this museum.
Well, as I look at the negative reviews, if you don't like art, don't go. If you insist everyone in a foreign country speak and act like an American, don't go. Etc. But once you get in, you are in a great collection of 19th and 20th c. European art. It contains what the Prado doesn't, and its overlaps with Reina Sofia in time period best has a greater French emphasis.
I was amazed that some negative reviewers complained that paintings were on loan to other art museums and traveling shows -- yes, I was disappointed that in the final impressionist rooms half the painitings were away. But, really, that is what does (and should!) happen in art: great works travel. If you miss one or two, go look at others; you'll be fine.
titleopinion: A great art museum -- especially for 19th & 20th centuries. When in Madrid, you can't not go to the Prado, the Reina Sofia (for Guernica), and this museum. Well, as I look at the negative reviews, if you don't like art, don't go. If you insist everyone in a foreign country speak and act like an American, don't go. Etc. But once you get in, you are in a great collection of 19th and 20th c. European art. It contains what the Prado doesn't, and its overlaps with Reina Sofia in time period best has a greater French emphasis. I was amazed that some negative reviewers complained that paintings were on loan to other art museums and traveling shows -- yes, I was disappointed that in the final impressionist rooms half the painitings were away. But, really, that is what does (and should!) happen in art: great works travel. If you miss one or two, go look at others; you'll be fine.

The only downside was that during the visit, quite a lot of the permanent collection was on loan, but the upside was a nice special exhibition on Renoir at no extra charge.

It is said that the Museum is a Collection of minor works by major artists, and major works by minor artists, but nonetheless, you will not regret visiting this beautiful collection.

The service and food in this cafe have been disappointing before. This time I sat at the bar. The staff were busy but the service could have been more pleasant. I had a bottle of water, mint tea and a ham sandwich for €8.45. It was ok value given the convenience of staying in the gallery.

Well worth the effort, a very impressive space for this private collection, you can calmly promenade three floors from medieval madonnas via Holbein's Henry VIII of England, Dutch masters, a whole group of American nineteenth century artists quite new to me, through to Roy Lichtenstein and really ,Oder stuff.

quote: Amazing broad collection of Western art.
reviewnospace: I had never heard of this museum before coming to Madrid and was so glad I visited. What an amazing collection ranging from early religious icons through contemporary works. The focus is on painting, although there are some sculptures as well. I found myself gasping with joy as I moved from one gallery to the next, discovering paintings by some of my favorite artists that I had never seen before. The collection cover a nice range of Western art. Some great Impressionists, Post Impressionists, Pointilists, Fauvists. They have some amazing Edward Hoppers, a large selection of Sisley, a stunning John Singer Sergeant. It just goes on and on. Don't believe me. Go to the website. They have a virtual tour where you can see every piece in the collection. While it's not as good as the real thing, it's pretty spectacular. Plus in addition to having such a great collection of work, the space itself is welcoming and warm with great light and lots of places to sit and admire the work. One of my favorite places in our visit to Spain. In my opinion, way better than the Prado.

It make my day.

I strongly recommend the current exhibition on Renoir... It is a must!

quote: One of the Finest Collections Anywhere
reviewnospace:
The art here is stunning. A MUST-SEE for artists and art lovers. Three magnificent Van Goghs I've never seen before. A famous Lucien Freud, a brilliant deKooning. Troves of truly great work. The man who put together this collection had a real sensibility.
Take a hint, NYC curators.
Set aside a full day for this museum.

A famous Lucien Freud, a brilliant deKooning. Troves of truly great work. The man who put together this collection had a real sensibility.  Take a hint, NYC curators. Set aside a full day for this museum.

reviewnospace:
My wife and I arrived in Madrid en route to the States on a rainy Sunday afternoon.

As quiet walk was not an option we decided to go to the Museum to enjoy the extensive collection and special Renoir exhibition.

The facility is A plus, the collections outstanding, and quality of staff exceptional.

We try to visit museums during our extensive international travels.

One one of the walls was a testimonial that art should be shared.

Kudos to all involved to collecting, cataloging, and showcasing such outstanding pieces.
titleopinion: Pleasant Surprise . My wife and I arrived in Madrid en route to the States on a rainy Sunday afternoon.   As quiet walk was not an option we decided to go to the Museum to enjoy the extensive collection and special Renoir exhibition.   The facility is A plus, the collections outstanding, and quality of staff exceptional.   We try to visit museums during our extensive international travels.   One one of the walls was a testimonial that art should be shared.   Kudos to all involved to collecting, cataloging, and showcasing such outstanding pieces.

reviewnospace: We stumbled on this magnificent museum on a trip to Madrid virtually by happenstance. It was raining hard and cold, making our usual stroll along the Paseo uncomfortable. A short distance from our hotel was Museo Thyssen-Bornemisza and lo and behold there was an exhibition of Chagall paintings, among my very favorite artists. What a delight!
titleopinion: Serendipity. We stumbled on this magnificent museum on a trip to Madrid virtually by happenstance. It was raining hard and cold, making our usual stroll along the Paseo uncomfortable. A short distance from our hotel was Museo Thyssen-Bornemisza and lo and behold there was an exhibition of Chagall paintings, among my very favorite artists. What a delight!

reviewnospace:
Totally supreme and totally western. An incredibly rich collection (actually two collections) of western paintings, and a few pieces of furniture. Excellently conserved and well displayed. But at the end I was left feeling disappointed. What world do these people live in? I suppose the world of the fabulously rich, desperate to find a good investment for their money. Hence the safe choice of art. The old western canon, plus a few modern works. All from W Europe and USA. Hard or impossible to spot anything or anyone Black, Asian, S. American, Jewish, gay - or in anyway different.
That said, the space is wonderfully managed, visiting is very easy, and there is a pleasant cafe.
Definitely a must for anyone visiting Madrid.
titleopinion: Western supremacy. Totally supreme and totally western. An incredibly rich collection (actually two collections) of western paintings, and a few pieces of furniture. Excellently conserved and well displayed. But at the end I was left feeling disappointed. What world do these people live in? I suppose the world of the fabulously rich, desperate to find a good investment for their money. Hence the safe choice of art. The old western canon, plus a few modern works. All from W Europe and USA. Hard or impossible to spot anything or anyone Black, Asian, S. American, Jewish, gay - or in anyway different.  That said, the space is wonderfully managed, visiting is very easy, and there is a pleasant cafe.  Definitely a must for anyone visiting Madrid.

reviewnospace: I enjoyed the Thyssen-Bornemisza more than the Prado. The collection, curated by one family, is amazing. Plus, when we visited the museum was hosting a fabulous special Degas show. I loved the fact that I could take pictures of the pictures (no flash allowed).
titleopinion: Do Not Miss This Museum. I enjoyed the Thyssen-Bornemisza more than the Prado. The collection, curated by one family, is amazing. Plus, when we visited the museum was hosting a fabulous special Degas show. I loved the fact that I could take pictures of the pictures (no flash allowed).

A few guides on walking tours we had suggested this was the pick of the museums as it was best explained in audio guides. Was €12 to get in and around €7 to get an audio guide for both the standard and the special exhibition.

quote: Wonderful Collection of Paintings and Sculptures

titleopinion: Wonderful Collection of Paintings and Sculptures. Enjoy impressionist painting not limited to Dega and Monet. Other favorites Rodin and Tinoretto. Large private collection worth an afternoon. Close to the Prado and Reina Sofia.

reviewnospace: Although much smaller than the Prado this collection is full of wonderful paintings that seem carefully curated. I loved the medieval religious works on the top floor and then worked my way down through the largely chronologically displayed collection. Highlights included the Impressionists and Post-Impressionists. I was lucky to catch a temporary Renoir exhibition which was an added bonus. Everything is so well thought out and organised. Highly recommended. They allow non-flash photography (except in the temp exhibition) which is welcome and unusual for Madrid.
titleopinion: My favourite gallery in Madrid. Although much smaller than the Prado this collection is full of wonderful paintings that seem carefully curated. I loved the medieval religious works on the top floor and then worked my way down through the largely chronologically displayed collection. Highlights included the Impressionists and Post-Impressionists. I was lucky to catch a temporary Renoir exhibition which was an added bonus. Everything is so well thought out and organised. Highly recommended. They allow non-flash photography (except in the temp exhibition) which is welcome and unusual for Madrid.

reviewnospace: This museum with its spacious galleries filled with natural light has over 1,000 painting that trace the history of Western art from 13th century Italian Gothic to 20th century American pop art. It is a wonderful way to spend a rainy day and a good second choice after the Prado.

This museum with its spacious galleries filled with natural light has over 1,000 painting that trace the history of Western art from 13th century Italian Gothic to 20th century American pop art. It is a wonderful way to spend a rainy day and a good second choice after the Prado.

reviewnospace: Went on Monday when it was free, so had low expectations that a lot of exhibits would be closed. Boy was I wrong. I saw so many famous artists and works, from Monet to Dali to Renoir to Picasso. You name the artist, there was probably something from them there. You can take pictures, which is nice to have a good memory of the museum. In my opinion, it is better than the Prado, where everything looks the same after a while!
titleopinion: A must see in Madrid!!!!. Went on Monday when it was free, so had low expectations that a lot of exhibits would be closed. Boy was I wrong. I saw so many famous artists and works, from Monet to Dali to Renoir to Picasso. You name the artist, there was probably something from them there. You can take pictures, which is nice to have a good memory of the museum. In my opinion, it is better than the Prado, where everything looks the same after a while!

reviewnospace: The Thyssen is doable in a day and has an exceptional selection and variety of art. I've been to many art museums all over the world and have to say the medieval art was like nothing I've seen in the past. They had a delightful Caillebotte exhibition. He was an extremely talented impressionist artist but also the patron of Degas, Cezanne, Manet, Monet, Renoir, Pissarro and Sisley. His is an amazing story. The American art was also very impressive. This museum is a must see when visiting Madrid. It's directly across the street from the Prada

Overall the Renoir exhibition was great. They had a good number of paintings the audio Guide was very informative

reviewnospace: We called into the Thyssen while killing time before our flight... wow what a gallery. There is a great mix of artists populist and more obscure. There's a lovely coffee shop/restaurant in the grounds. The coffee was good and the food looked and smelt delicious, can't wait to go back and try it out.

reviewnospace: Amazing collection of famous painters (18th century) on the first floor. Must see if you like such piece of arts. They brought his paintings together from all over the place on this planet (U.S., Europe, etc.). Don't miss that out - and it is included in the standard admission fee :)

reviewnospace: Art gallery packed with highlights from across the centuries, over three floors. As a visitor because it likely to be less crowded than the Prado, it may be a better choice. Although there are more Spanish must-see classics in the Prado.
