quote: Staggering array of masterpieces from the 13th to the 20th centuries with most major art movements represented.
reviewnospace:
The museum was established in 1992 and holds 2 separate collections being the former private collection of Baron Thyssen-Bornemisza - which is by far the larger and more diverse of the two collections, and secondly the private collection of his wife Carmen Thyssen-Bornemisza which comprises over 200 paintings spanning the period from the 17th to the 20th century.

The museum itself is well designed with the art works being well displayed in good light and with good signage. There is an excellent handout containing a map of the museum, a suggested route and pictures of some of the must-see paintings, though this doesn't do justice as to what is on offer. Entry cost was Euro 12 which included a special exhibition dedicated to Caravaggio.

This museum was far less crowded than the Prado and accordingly easier to navigate and get a good view of the art. At one stage my wife and I were the only people standing in one room that contained 3 Gauguins, 2 Renoirs, 2 Sisleys plus about another 8 impressionists paintings - amazing. We had difficulty trying to book in advance online but the queue to enter was not long in any event when we visited on a Tuesday morning.

The list of artists whose work were on display was like a who's who of the art world over a 700 year period. Unlike the Prado where there appeared to be many works from some artists eg Goya, here there was mainly one painting from a plethora of world renowned artists.

Absolutely spectacular. We spent just less than 3 hours viewing what was on offer, including the excellent Caravaggio special exhibition that contained 7 of that masters paintings plus other works from those he had a significant influence on.

Really is a must see even if you are not an avid art lover.
titleopinion: Staggering array of masterpieces from the 13th to the 20th centuries with most major art movements represented.. The museum was established in 1992 and holds 2 separate collections being the former private collection of Baron Thyssen-Bornemisza - which is by far the larger and more diverse of the two collections, and secondly the private collection of his wife Carmen Thyssen-Bornemisza which comprises over 200 paintings spanning the period from the 17th to the 20th century.  The museum itself is well designed with the art works being well displayed in good light and with good signage. There is an excellent handout containing a map of the museum, a suggested route and pictures of some of the must-see paintings, though this doesn't do justice as to what is on offer. Entry cost was Euro 12 which included a special exhibition dedicated to Caravaggio.   This museum was far less crowded than the Prado and accordingly easier to navigate and get a good view of the art. At one stage my wife and I were the only people standing in one room that contained 3 Gauguins, 2 Renoirs, 2 Sisleys plus about another 8 impressionists paintings - amazing. We had difficulty trying to book in advance online but the queue to enter was not long in any event when we visited on a Tuesday morning.  The list of artists whose work were on display was like a who's who of the art world over a 700 year period. Unlike the Prado where there appeared to be many works from some artists eg Goya, here there was mainly one painting from a plethora of world renowned artists.   Absolutely spectacular. We spent just less than 3 hours viewing what was on offer, including the excellent Caravaggio special exhibition that contained 7 of that masters paintings plus other works from those he had a significant influence on.  Really is a must see even if you are not an avid art lover.

reviewnospace:
Well worth the entrance fee. Many more artists that I anticipated. Spent three hours and only scatched the surface. Discovered many artists that were unknown to me but absolutely blew my mind.

A must to visit if you're in Madrid.
titleopinion: Wonderfull Selection of the Masters . Well worth the entrance fee. Many more artists that I anticipated. Spent three hours and only scatched the surface. Discovered many artists that were unknown to me but absolutely blew my mind.  A must to visit if you're in Madrid.

quote: If you have to choose, this is the one.
reviewnospace: Mind-boggling that this is essentially the collection of one family. It is smaller than the Prado across the road and you can just walk around without saturating. I particularly enjoyed the section on the impressionists. This will be my first destination the next time that I go back to Madrid

quote: Excellent - well worth the entry fee
reviewnospace:
If you like art, this is the place - really clear to follow (start at the top and you get a tour through the history of Art and end on the ground floor with the very modern artists).
It is not as crowded as the Prado and thus more pleasant.
titleopinion: Excellent - well worth the entry fee. If you like art, this is the place - really clear to follow (start at the top and you get a tour through the history of Art and end on the ground floor with the very modern artists). It is not as crowded as the Prado and thus more pleasant.

quote: Worth a visit - need 2 hrs min.
reviewnospace: Relaxed and spacious museum with lovely cafe restaurant available. Renoir exhibition present when we arrived.
titleopinion: Worth a visit - need 2 hrs min.. Relaxed and spacious museum with lovely cafe restaurant available. Renoir exhibition present when we arrived.

quote: One of the best galleries in the world.
reviewnospace: It is located in an historical building close to El Prado Museum and Reina Sofia Museum. It is a complete collection of many of the best art masters from the 13th to 19th centuries. Occasionally they also have temporary exhibitions, usually very good ones. If you don´t have time to visit the three Museums, just visit this one. Fantastic!!!

If you don´t have time to visit the three Museums, just visit this one. Fantastic!!!

reviewnospace: One of the three great museums of Madrid.. A large connection with many German expressionist paintings. This is a very unique collection of Art that one rarely sees anywhere else. It is big and yu must allow at least 3 hours to enjoy it. A must for Art Lovers
titleopinion: Thyssen. One of the three great museums of Madrid.. A large connection with many German expressionist paintings. This is a very unique collection of Art that one rarely sees anywhere else. It is big and yu must allow at least 3 hours to enjoy it. A must for Art Lovers

reviewnospace: Had already bought an Arte Pass to cover this at the Prado the day before - unfortunately they had not told us there that it did not cover the visiting exhibition which was a Renoir exhibition and I would have liked to have seen. Still had to queue to get a ticket for my 17 year old as she was free in the Prado but not here. Lots of impressionism - we walked round the whole gallery which is probably too much in one day and shlddl have planned better. Enjoyed it though.

reviewnospace: For people visiting Madrid with limited time this is a wonderful option. The prado museum is huge and takes a lot of time so for museum lovers this little jewel of a museum is a fabulous alternative. You will enjoy European art from the 13th to the 20th century. It also has a restaurant serving good food so you can happily take a lunch break and continue with you viewing after a rest.

reviewnospace:
The Thyssen was easy to get around in. Very enjoyable in terms of the artworks and display. It also has a nice cafe to take a break in and enjoy a quick refreshment.
Make sure to ask for your senior discount if your over 65 saves 50% off the regular fee.
titleopinion: One of the great museums. The Thyssen was easy to get around in. Very enjoyable in terms of the artworks and display. It also has a nice cafe to take a break in and enjoy a quick refreshment. Make sure to ask for your senior discount if your over 65 saves 50% off the regular fee.

reviewnospace: A very lovely collection of a wide variety of painters and periods. There is a breadth to the collection that will satisfy all kind of art lovers.
titleopinion: Better Than the Prado. A very lovely collection of a wide variety of painters and periods. There is a breadth to the collection that will satisfy all kind of art lovers.

quote: Fantastic Pizza, yes the real thing
reviewnospace: Buy a ticket in advance it is quick and easy and you miss the long queue. This museum is very central and walking distance from all central hotels. Ticket prices are E 12 for a adult and E 8 for retired travelers. We spend about 3.5 hours and it was fantastic. You will find works from Durer, Caravaggio, Caneletto, Rubens, Rembrandt, Monet, Renoir, Rodin, Degas, van Gogh, Derain, Kirchner, Marc, Gris, Hopper, Kandinsky, Dali.... FANTASTIC

reviewnospace: This museum really suited us as it was accessible, diverse and informative. Although it was busy at 11 am we got tickets in about 20 mins and were in line for the Renoir exhibition 59 mins later having already been to the Caillebotte rooms. The main museum was the best aspect of the whole thing for me and we travelled forward in time by starting at the top floor and working our way down. We loved the post impressionist work and enjoyed the real diversity available.

quote: Fabulous! My favourite gallery in Madrid
reviewnospace:
We visited three gallery's Thyssen, Prado, Reina Sofia. Queue was long mid morning in Thyssen when we arrived so we booked a discounted ticket to visit all three museums online on our phone and then printed it in the gallery reception to avoid the queue really easy!
This was our favourite gallery as there was a mix of modern and old artworks. Definitely visit on your Madrid trip.
titleopinion: Fabulous! My favourite gallery in Madrid. We visited three gallery's Thyssen, Prado, Reina Sofia. Queue was long mid morning in Thyssen when we arrived so we booked a discounted ticket to visit all three museums online on our phone and then printed it in the gallery reception to avoid the queue really easy! This was our favourite gallery as there was a mix of modern and old artworks. Definitely visit on your Madrid trip.

reviewnospace: Went on a Sunday and spent about 3 hours there! Great range of paintings and periods and very spacious. Easy to get around and no large crowds to spoil the visit.
titleopinion: More culture. Went on a Sunday and spent about 3 hours there! Great range of paintings and periods and very spacious. Easy to get around and no large crowds to spoil the visit.

reviewnospace: After several hours at the Prado, the Thyssen collection was a refreshing delight. There was a wonderful but crowded Renoir exhibition on the first level. Having been to the Barnes Collection in Philadelphia recently, I was a little Renoired out. When we proceeded on to the rest of the collection, I could breathe, relax, and enjoy the magnificent works along with the few other people admiring and appreciating. The galleries were easy to take in with just enough works in each to allow visual space to digest them aided by a background wall color that was easy on the eyes. Although this was a long day in museuns, I regretted leaving the Thyssen because there was so much to appreciate. My Susan recommended the museum to me as one of her favorites. Now I know why and totally agree. A must see. Highly recommended.

Now I know why and totally agree. A must see. Highly recommended.

reviewnospace: This once private museum was donated to the Spanish state over 20 years ago and is an incredible collection of important works by important artists. Much more of an art survey then say, the Prado, which is more focused. Definitely worth a visit, and also has a good, reasonably priced cafe.

Much more of an art survey then say, the Prado, which is more focused. Definitely worth a visit, and also has a good, reasonably priced cafe.

location: National Capital Territory of Delhi, India
reviewnospace: Thyssen-Bornemisza is a classy museum, with a lovely collection of paintings....a highlight of any trip to Madrid...
titleopinion: Worth a watch!. Thyssen-Bornemisza is a classy museum, with a lovely collection of paintings....a highlight of any trip to Madrid...

quote: My favourite art gallery in Madrid
reviewnospace: Whilst the Prado has lots of works by the key artists, this just has the best works by a range of artists. We spent 5 hours here and really enjoyed it. The art ranges from beautiful 14th/15th century art on the top floor through to modern and pop art on the ground floor. The gallery building is modern and well laid out and shows all works to best advantage. The restaurant is very good.
titleopinion: My favourite art gallery in Madrid. Whilst the Prado has lots of works by the key artists, this just has the best works by a range of artists. We spent 5 hours here and really enjoyed it. The art ranges from beautiful 14th/15th century art on the top floor through to modern and pop art on the ground floor. The gallery building is modern and well laid out and shows all works to best advantage. The restaurant is very good.

reviewnospace: The Thyssen collection is interesting, but the Renoir special exhibition was amazing. One of the best collections of Renoir's works I have seen anywhere. I highly recommend the Thyssen for their special exhibitions if nothing else. Congrats to the curator!!
titleopinion: The Renoir exhibition is amazing!. The Thyssen collection is interesting, but the Renoir special exhibition was amazing. One of the best collections of Renoir's works I have seen anywhere. I highly recommend the Thyssen for their special exhibitions if nothing else. Congrats to the curator!!

reviewnospace: The art on offer here is almost overwhelming in its variation, with thousands of classics and more modern pieces to see. It stands up there with anywhere in the world.
titleopinion: World-class gallery.. The art on offer here is almost overwhelming in its variation, with thousands of classics and more modern pieces to see. It stands up there with anywhere in the world.

reviewnospace: We didn't know if we would gain access to the museum on our final day in Spain, a Sunday, but we stood on line with some hope. At 10:00 the gate opened and a mad rush to the the ticket booth ensued! We were in and purchased our tickets both general entry and the Renoir exhibit at 14:45. We were in! Never seen anything like it, this mad rush to get in a museum, in the future will buy tickets online, but for us this wasn't an option since it showed availability three days out. The collection is not the equal of The Prado, of course, which is my new favorite museum, holding the most number of works of interest to me. The Thyssen collection was interesting to me in a different way, although I was disappointed the Dali work was not on display. This museum introduced me to a number of artists whose works I did not know: Durer, Strigel, Stom, Dix, Grosz, Hetzinger, Kupka. It's at times like these that I wish I had a more comprehensive knowledge of art.

reviewnospace: We started at the top and followed the comprehensive collection chronologically. It was a very worthwhile journey. The audio guide was very good and there is plenty of seating from which to enjoy the first rate collection of masterpieces. For us it was a long museum visit (about 3 hours) but we were not at all tired by the experience - simply uplifted.

The audio guide was very good and there is plenty of seating from which to enjoy the first rate collection of masterpieces. For us it was a long museum visit (about 3 hours) but we were not at all tired by the experience - simply uplifted.

reviewnospace: There are some exquisite paintings here, particularly 13-15 century religious art. The modern European is also good. Our favorite Edward Hopper was missing - away on loan. We were very disappointed. It is a museum not to be missed.
titleopinion: Beautiful building for great art!. There are some exquisite paintings here, particularly 13-15 century religious art. The modern European is also good. Our favorite Edward Hopper was missing - away on loan. We were very disappointed. It is a museum not to be missed.

reviewnospace: We spent hours in this museum on our trip to Madrid wonderful works of art and not crowded it has works from Picasso which is my wifes favorite painter and Monet which is my favorite and many more artist. I believe we went on a Monday and got in free which made it more enjoyable. If you are over 65 you get a lot of discounts at Museums and parks.

We spent hours in this museum on our trip to Madrid wonderful works of art and not crowded it has works from Picasso which is my wifes favorite painter and Monet which is my favorite and many more artist. I believe we went on a Monday and got in free which made it more enjoyable. If you are over 65 you get a lot of discounts at Museums and parks.

reviewnospace: The Thysen is a must on your visit to Madrid. Besides a very complete permanent collection there is usually a very well curated exhibition - during my visit a remarkable Renoir retrospectivecovering the full span of his career. Do not miss this or other exhibitions. They are usually of the same caliber.
titleopinion: Outstanding collection. The Thysen is a must on your visit to Madrid. Besides a very complete permanent collection there is usually a very well curated exhibition - during my visit a remarkable Renoir retrospectivecovering the full span of his career. Do not miss this or other exhibitions. They are usually of the same caliber.

quote: Amazing private collection - some real treasures
reviewnospace: We didn't have time to go to both Prado and the Thyssen, and in the end went to the Thyssen. It is an incredible collection, with some real treasures, showing some lesser known works by artists such as Picasso, Van Gogh and Monet. We spent 5 hours here - fabulous.
titleopinion: Amazing private collection - some real treasures. We didn't have time to go to both Prado and the Thyssen, and in the end went to the Thyssen. It is an incredible collection, with some real treasures, showing some lesser known works by artists such as Picasso, Van Gogh and Monet. We spent 5 hours here - fabulous.

reviewnospace:
The name Prado rings a bell with more people, but the Museo Thyssen-Bornemisza is of the same dazzling quality, and deservedly part of the "Golden Triangle" Prado-Thyssen-Reina Sofia.

I like the Thyssen most, for 2 reasons:
(1) It may be large, but compared to the Prado it's less huge, allowing you to take in the full collection (could not manage the Prado in less than 4 sessions).
(2) The temporary exhibitions illustrate in the first place how good the staff is. The temp exhibitions are always worthwhile (not just the "big names"), the information pannels give you perfect context and background information on the art on display.

The restaurant allows for a break. Quality is ok, but waiting time was too long, service so-so, and prices way too high. There is, however, some lovely outside seating.
I spent 3.5 hours in the museum, of which a good half an hour in the bar (just to get a coffee), and just over an hour at the temporary exhibitions. If you don't have 2 hours to spend at the Thyssen, give it a miss.

You may want book your visit online, although lines are by no means as long as in the Prado. For some temporary exhibitions pre-booking a time slot is needed.

TIPS:

(a) COMBINE WITH: To wind down from this visit, walk up to the Plaza de Cibeles (5'), and head for the Palacio de Cibeles. The cultural centre CentroCentro (free admission) is a cool place, the building is splendid inside (walkways offering views of other floors. Don't miss floors 3-4-5). The Galleria de Cristal (entry around the corner, or just ask the staff) is STUNNING (Google Images, people. Free of charge btw), but sometimes closed because of events, and even the guards can't tell you if the place will be open the next day. There's a rooftop viewpoint ("mirrador") in the Palacio at the top floor (ticket with time slot needs to be booked at the boot outside the building). Research this place a bit.
Next, you can have a great walk in the park (Parque de Buen Retiro). Don't miss: Palacio de Cristal (free of charge, run by the Museo Reina Sofia), and the Monumento Alfonso XII (impressive. Next to the lake). The San Jerónimo el Real church, next to the Prado and the park, only takes 10' to visit.

(b) Food: The best (and cheap) bocadillos (100 of them, 1€ to 1.5€ a piece): "100 Montaditos", 2' from the Thyssen (Plaza de las Cortes). It may be the only restaurant chain in the world with great cuisine. Go for a few bocadillos with a salad.

Enjoy!
titleopinion: Simply a must. World class.. The name Prado rings a bell with more people, but the Museo Thyssen-Bornemisza is of the same dazzling quality, and deservedly part of the  Golden Triangle  Prado-Thyssen-Reina Sofia.  I like the Thyssen most, for 2 reasons: (1) It may be large, but compared to the Prado it's less huge, allowing you to take in the full collection (could not manage the Prado in less than 4 sessions). quote: One of the big 3 in Madrid
reviewnospace: A private collection spanning the centuries. Start from level 2 and work your way down in chronological order. Pleasant garden to rest
titleopinion: One of the big 3 in Madrid. A private collection spanning the centuries. Start from level 2 and work your way down in chronological order. Pleasant garden to rest

quote: Rivals the D'Orsay for impressionist art
reviewnospace: I have to say I was really impressed at the collection of impressionist masters and the accessibility of this museum. They offer free entry on Mondays from 12-4 and it wasn't that crowded. They had all the greats...Renoir, Cezanne, Gaughin, Manet, Monet, Van Gogh, Pisarro, Degas...it really does rival the D'Orsay. Awesome spot....and they allow photos!
titleopinion: Rivals the D'Orsay for impressionist art. I have to say I was really impressed at the collection of impressionist masters and the accessibility of this museum. They offer free entry on Mondays from 12-4 and it wasn't that crowded. They had all the greats...Renoir, Cezanne, Gaughin, Manet, Monet, Van Gogh, Pisarro, Degas...it really does rival the D'Orsay. Awesome spot....and they allow photos!

reviewnospace: This is a visit one should not miss. You immediately notice that they take care and want to please the visitor. Plenty of wonderful details: music different in each room that goes along the rope of art shown, excellent application to follow explanations... great place!
titleopinion: Great . This is a visit one should not miss. You immediately notice that they take care and want to please the visitor. Plenty of wonderful details: music different in each room that goes along the rope of art shown, excellent application to follow explanations... great place!

reviewnospace:
The museum has a broad collection and some of the paintings are world-class while others seem lesser works by famous artists. While I was there I saw a big exhibit of Renoir, whose work I sometimes find just a bit too sweet. There was also an excellent exhibit of works by Caillebotte, one of my favorite painters. Almost all the works were from private collections so I had never seen them before and that was a treat.
There's also a really good museum shop.
titleopinion: Broad-ranging collection. The museum has a broad collection and some of the paintings are world-class while others seem lesser works by famous artists. While I was there I saw a big exhibit of Renoir, whose work I sometimes find just a bit too sweet. There was also an excellent exhibit of works by Caillebotte, one of my favorite painters. Almost all the works were from private collections so I had never seen them before and that was a treat. There's also a really good museum shop.

reviewnospace:
In my opinion one of the best museums of Madrid, if you're looking for a mix of impressionism, epressionism, modern art... Great collection!

Be prepared to visit this museum twice if you want to see the temporary exhibition. I went to see the Renoir exhibition but had to wait 4 hours to visit due to large popularity.
titleopinion: Great collection!. In my opinion one of the best museums of Madrid, if you're looking for a mix of impressionism, epressionism, modern art... Great collection!  Be prepared to visit this museum twice if you want to see the temporary exhibition. I went to see the Renoir exhibition but had to wait 4 hours to visit due to large popularity.

reviewnospace: We unintentionally went to the museum on a day when it was no-cost, so there were a lot of people there. This is a wonderful gallery, with impressive holdings (some have described it as a collection of major works by minor artists and minor works by major artists, which I think is a disservice to this gem of a museum). Some works to see are the 'Portrait of Henry VIII' by Hans Holbein the Younger, 'Venus and Cupid' by Rubens, and 'Jesus among the Doctors' by Durero. A grouping of paintings by each of Monet, Van Gogh, Lichtenstein, and Titian make this a worthwhile stop in this city full of art. While there is a lot to see, it is not nearly as overwhelming as the Prado.
titleopinion: Wonderful gallery, with impressive holdings. We unintentionally went to the museum on a day when it was no-cost, so there were a lot of people there. This is a wonderful gallery, with impressive holdings (some have described it as a collection of major works by minor artists and minor works by major artists, which I think is a disservice to this gem of a museum). Some works to see are the 'Portrait of Henry VIII' by Hans Holbein the Younger, 'Venus and Cupid' by Rubens, and 'Jesus among the Doctors' by Durero. A grouping of paintings by each of Monet, Van Gogh, Lichtenstein, and Titian make this a worthwhile stop in this city full of art. While there is a lot to see, it is not nearly as overwhelming as the Prado.

reviewnospace: If you only have time to 'do' one art museum, I would advise you to visit this one. The paintings have less of a 'Spanish slant' than those found in the Prado and are more instantly 'accessible' to a variety of different nationalities. Internal cafe isn't really big enough, but is run very efficiently, so just about manages to cope. Brilliant Renoir exhibition at the moment. Audio guide a must. Stone floors all day are hard on the feet - wear comfortable trainers!
titleopinion: Better Than The Prado. If you only have time to 'do' one art museum, I would advise you to visit this one. The paintings have less of a 'Spanish slant' than those found in the Prado and are more instantly 'accessible' to a variety of different nationalities. Internal cafe isn't really big enough, but is run very efficiently, so just about manages to cope. Brilliant Renoir exhibition at the moment. Audio guide a must. Stone floors all day are hard on the feet - wear comfortable trainers!

reviewnospace:
Many paintings from famous impressionist and Picasso, Monet, Cezanne....
A must go for art and culture lovers!

Skip the queues by buying tickets online or Paseo Del Padro ticket that included the 3 art museums: Thyssen, Reina, Del Prado.
titleopinion: Famous Guernica. Many paintings from famous impressionist and Picasso, Monet, Cezanne.... A must go for art and culture lovers!  Skip the queues by buying tickets online or Paseo Del Padro ticket that included the 3 art museums: Thyssen, Reina, Del Prado.

reviewnospace: I went on a Monday afternoon, when it was free (12-4pm) and bought an audio guide with was priceless as it gave me so much more information than I'd expected. A wonderful experience. Go.
titleopinion: Tantalising Thyssen. I went on a Monday afternoon, when it was free (12-4pm) and bought an audio guide with was priceless as it gave me so much more information than I'd expected. A wonderful experience. Go.

reviewnospace: The Thyssen-Bornemisza is located within the triangle that contains the Prado and the National Museum. There is a minimal admission charge. We were fortunate that the day we visited the museum was the opening of their special Renoir exhibit. The exhibition was incredible featuring works from all of the phases of Renoir's work. There is the collection of Carmen Thyssen-Bornemisza which features both renaissance art and modern.You can go from Titian to Mark Rothko. This is not a collector who specialized but rather bought whatever struck her fancy. There is also a permanent collection which mirrors the same eclecticism of Carmen. Sometimes it can be jarring as you wonder why some pieces are hanging next to each other but there is much to enjoy.
titleopinion: An eclectic museum. The Thyssen-Bornemisza is located within the triangle that contains the Prado and the National Museum. There is a minimal admission charge. We were fortunate that the day we visited the museum was the opening of their special Renoir exhibit. The exhibition was incredible featuring works from all of the phases of Renoir's work. There is the collection of Carmen Thyssen-Bornemisza which features both renaissance art and modern.You can go from Titian to Mark Rothko. This is not a collector who specialized but rather bought whatever struck her fancy. There is also a permanent collection which mirrors the same eclecticism of Carmen. Sometimes it can be jarring as you wonder why some pieces are hanging next to each other but there is much to enjoy.

quote: Great way to spend a few hours
reviewnospace: Super gallery which had a Renoir exhibition at the time we visited. Very well laid out and organised. Easy to navigate.

reviewnospace:

The permanent exhibit was very impressive and worth the while, for sure.
I ate snacks at the Cafe but it was not impressive in food quality; cafe itself is open and attractive.

quote: One of the worlds best museums
reviewnospace:
On my first proper visit to Madrid, so we did the Prado, Reine Sophie and this museum. We just saw the permanent collections at each.I have to say this was by far the best. A great range of art work. I would highly recommend a visit.

I have just returned from another visit to Madrid and we again went here. This time we saw two temporary exhibitions as well as the collection. The only down side was that we could not get separate tickets or return on another day to see what we couldnt manage on the day. So we decided to go for it. We saw a wonderful exhibition of Caillebotte - one of the impressionists but less well known although i don't know why. We also saw the "intimate" exhibition of Renoir. It was good but i prefered the Caillebotte.
There is a lovely cafe in the building - busy but very well run with good food.
Overall an outstanding experience. We will return on our next visit.

quote: If you like the Impressionists, you'll love this
reviewnospace:
A large part of this gallery is devoted to the Impressionists, so if this is your thing, you will love this place. There are some interesting American paintings too. There are some older, mainly religious, works, on the top floor, and also some modern art on the ground floor. If you are only into the older stuff, go to the Prado instead. Personally I preferred this place.

There are also two areas of temporary exhibitions, both devoted to Impressionists when I visited.

To tour the whole gallery in chronological order start at the top floor and work down.

You can easily spend half a day here.

Based on my visit this place is less crowded than the Prado.

You can buy tickets in advance on the internet, but you have to do this a few days in advance. You can't buy on the internet just the day before, so plan ahead to avoid queuing for tickets.

reviewnospace: Although I am not knowledgeable enough to rate museums, I'd be amazed if this collection is not on experts lists of"can't misses." About a million visitors a year are drawn to the extensive collection (1600 well organized and intelligibly curated pieces.) I love the impressionists, and the Thyssen has them all, and expressionists, and classics. Comparing Carvaggio's use of light to later masters, say Van Gogh, makes me feel like I get it. The location (across from the Prado), and the lighting and layout of the structure make the visit memorable.

reviewnospace:
I spent a few days in Madrid and I was lucky to see two wonderful temporary exhibits at the Thyssen-Bornemisza: Caillebotte and Renoir. Although I have seen their works before, seeing both exhibits added to my understanding of the artists' development, particularly of Caillebotte's influence on others.

I've been here a few times, and I strongly recommend getting an audioguide. For EU4, it is good for all exhibits (permanent and temporary). Unfortunately, it was the first day of the Renoir exhibit and there was a problem with the English audio guide. I managed to understand some of the Spanish explanations, and the rest I googled on my phone as I was looking at the works. I then asked the desk to re-configure it for the Caillebotte. exhibit.

I also recommend buying tickets in advance, especially when there are timed admissions, such as the Renoir. I like staying in this area, and sometimes I buy tickets at the ticket office the day before. This time I bought online just before I went to the museum, and I was glad because there was a long line-up. I just printed it when I got there.

Those who like art will enjoy spending some time at the Thyssen Bornemisza

reviewnospace:
The museum houses the 'private' collection of Baron Thyssen and his wife (a former Miss Spain who also had a very fine eye for art). It was sold, in its entirety for $350 million which sounds a lot. However, the pictures themselves must be worth billions and so it was a great deal for \Madrid and Spain.
This museum should be on everyone's list if they appreciate art at all. There are pictures from the early renaissance to the modern day, and it has its fair share of Impressionists, post Impressionists and earlier periods too. They are all beautifully hung and lit. There is a real wow factor about this gallery.

reviewnospace: We were surprised at the breadth of this collection, given it is from a private collection (at least it started that way). They have a wide variety of works, both from artists that you know (Monet, Picasso, etc) but a lot of works from those artists' peers who are not as well known, but who have created some impressive work. We found that it expanded our knowledge base significantly and made for a good day's outing.

reviewnospace:
The museum is full of great paintings, and if you go there when it's free, the place is a little crowded as you can imagine, but the queue is short (5-10 minutes to 0 after the people waiting for the opening are inside).

Too bad, some interesting paintings were missing (quite a lot) but when it's free, you can't complain.

Also interesting insight into the Spanish civil war, which wasn't that long ago...

quote: Can't miss it while in Madrid!
reviewnospace: An great collection of modern and post-enlightenment era art; the 20th century is well represented; I would say it's the 3rd best art museum in the city. The minimalist exhibit on the first floor was the highlight for me with Mondrian in the collection, an well as a Lichtenstein down the hall.

reviewnospace: We enjoyed this museum even more than the Prado. A huge variety of world famous masters and some we never had heard of before. The collection is astonishing because it is the result of one family's love of art. The way the paintings are grouped made the experience even more special. Three floors of awe inspiring talent.........unforgettable.

reviewnospace: We have been to the Thyssen several times, and now when we visit, we only go to see the wonderful temporary exhibits. If you are staying at the Westin Palace, as we do, or in the general vicinity, the Thiessen is a short walk and easily accessible.
titleopinion: Our favorite museum in Madrid!. We have been to the Thyssen several times, and now when we visit, we only go to see the wonderful temporary exhibits. If you are staying at the Westin Palace, as we do, or in the general vicinity, the Thiessen is a short walk and easily accessible.

reviewnospace:
The Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum, the second of the Big Three along Paseo del Prado, is really two museums in one. The original was donated by a really, really rich family who donated their palace and art collection to Spain in the early 1990s. The second and somewhat separate section, which is housed in an extension of the original building, was donated by the last Baron Thyssen's widow, who did not start collecting art in her own right until 1987. Six years later, she donated her own collection to Spain.

The result is something like a museum within a museum or two connected museums that really could (and probably should) be combined into a more unified presentation. Each of the two collections is well organized chronologically and in some cases thematically. But each more or less repeats the same chronology, ranging from early Renaissance through to the present day, with each displaying an impressive collection of Impressionist paintings.
Overall, the combined Thyssen is a fine museum, even though it suffers somewhat from its bifurcation. Must have been something in her will. Regardless, we spent nearly three hours there.
titleopinion: Two museums in one. The Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum, the second of the Big Three along Paseo del Prado, is really two museums in one. The original was donated by a really, really rich family who donated their palace and art collection to Spain in the early 1990s. The second and somewhat separate section, which is housed in an extension of the original building, was donated by the last Baron Thyssen's widow, who did not start collecting art in her own right until 1987. Six years later, she donated her own collection to Spain.  The result is something like a museum within a museum or two connected museums that really could (and probably should) be combined into a more unified presentation. Each of the two collections is well organized chronologically and in some cases thematically. But each more or less repeats the same chronology, ranging from early Renaissance through to the present day, with each displaying an impressive collection of Impressionist paintings. Overall, the combined Thyssen is a fine museum, even though it suffers somewhat from its bifurcation. Must have been something in her will. Regardless, we spent nearly three hours there.

An excellent tip now... they are exhibiting "Renoir's great paintings" at this moment. If you are traveling Madrid now, don't lose this 'never again' opportunity.

I visited this museum with a small tour and an expert guide, spending just a few hours, after Prado.

This art was quite a contrast to Prado. While I tend to prefer the classics, seeing other styles with commentary, such as cubism and the impressionist, was a welcome contrast. The works here deserve multiple visits though all I had time for was one.

I was also pleasantly surprised by how much time could be spent with individual works without obstructing others - quite a contrast to my Florence trip.

quote: Second most important gallery in Madrid
reviewnospace: After the Prado, this is the next one. It is close by which is lucky, but I wouldn't try to do them in the same day. We tried to visit in September, but the queue was prodigious and it was stinking hot. Luckily, we were back in Madrid a few days ago (October) and it was much cooler and a lot less tourists. We thoroughly enjoyed it. The collection takes you on a journey through five centuries of European art and makes no excuses for its preferences. Couldn't find a Turner and but there were a few English artists. Three women represented in the whole collection, so it's not only Eurocentric but is also malecentric. Still there.s a few Gabrielle Muenters and that always helps. A good van Gough. Some Modern USA, but nothing from the Southern Hemisphere. We enjoyed being educated about how lacking in culture the Antipodes are.
titleopinion: Second most important gallery in Madrid. After the Prado, this is the next one. It is close by which is lucky, but I wouldn't try to do them in the same day. We tried to visit in September, but the queue was prodigious and it was stinking hot. Luckily, we were back in Madrid a few days ago (October) and it was much cooler and a lot less tourists. We thoroughly enjoyed it. The collection takes you on a journey through five centuries of European art and makes no excuses for its preferences. Couldn't find a Turner and but there were a few English artists. Three women represented in the whole collection, so it's not only Eurocentric but is also malecentric. Still there.s a few Gabrielle Muenters and that always helps. A good van Gough. Some Modern USA, but nothing from the Southern Hemisphere. We enjoyed being educated about how lacking in culture the Antipodes are.

reviewnospace:
Fantastic collection of art from five centuries including beautiful 19th century impressionist art as well as some great 20th century pieces.
If you are not really into Renaissance art, this is a much less overwhelming showcase than the Prado and the gallery itself has a much more straightforward layout.
I arrived at 2.30pm and there was no line and it was not crowded at all. Allow at least 2.5 hours for an "express" visit or 4 hours to take it all in.
titleopinion: Better than the Prado. Fantastic collection of art from five centuries including beautiful 19th century impressionist art as well as some great 20th century pieces.  If you are not really into Renaissance art, this is a much less overwhelming showcase than the Prado and the gallery itself has a much more straightforward layout. I arrived at 2.30pm and there was no line and it was not crowded at all. Allow at least 2.5 hours for an  express  visit or 4 hours to take it all in.

quote: one of the 3 must see museums

Las Terrazas del Thyssen also looks great, it was closed when I visited the museum. Some day will have tapas there!

reviewnospace: This museum is a jewel in Madrid. We spend there 4 hours but we can use one more because we love the collection. If you want to have lunch just cross the street next to Starbucks in Vips, it has better prices and service.

reviewnospace:
During a long weekend when we stayed in the middle of the 'Museum Triangle', we were able to visit the Prado, the Reina Sofia, and the Thyssen-Bornemisza. Although the first two both had delights and interest to offer, it was the Thyssen-Bornemisza that gave us the greatest pleasure.

It wasn't just because we took advantage of the free entry available on Mondays; I think it is more that this collection consists largely of the personal taste of individuals. Also, although you can find works by Picasso, Dali, Rothko, Degas, Manet, Hopper, and most of the other greats of 19th and 20th century painting, there are so many other pieces by lesser known names.

Room after salmon pink walled room blossoms with colour and movement; and almost every room contains a surprise. Highly recommended.
titleopinion: Wow!!. During a long weekend when we stayed in the middle of the 'Museum Triangle', we were able to visit the Prado, the Reina Sofia, and the Thyssen-Bornemisza. Although the first two both had delights and interest to offer, it was the Thyssen-Bornemisza that gave us the greatest pleasure.  It wasn't just because we took advantage of the free entry available on Mondays; I think it is more that this collection consists largely of the personal taste of individuals. Also, although you can find works by Picasso, Dali, Rothko, Degas, Manet, Hopper, and most of the other greats of 19th and 20th century painting, there are so many other pieces by lesser known names.  Room after salmon pink walled room blossoms with colour and movement; and almost every room contains a surprise. Highly recommended.

reviewnospace: Went to see Renoir exhibit which opened today. Big line up and crowded tickets sold by time slot. Worth seeing. Also went to see permanent exhibitions. If art history is your thing welcome to nirvana. Plan on spending the day
titleopinion: Renoir. Went to see Renoir exhibit which opened today. Big line up and crowded tickets sold by time slot. Worth seeing. Also went to see permanent exhibitions. If art history is your thing welcome to nirvana. Plan on spending the day

quote: One of the best museums in the world. Probably better than Prado.
reviewnospace:
If you like impressionists, old Spanish painters and modern paintings from Kandynski, you must go there. Most people goes to Prado, however it is like going to Louvre while you can go to d'Orsay in Paris. There are not so many visitors so it is not very crowded and selection is much better than in Prado.

It is really worth of reading about how museum was founded before going there.

reviewnospace: Permanent collection is open and free on Monday but only 12-4pm. Barely enough time to go through all the important painting and listen to comments on the audioguide. A very long line started to form at about 11:30am. We were eating right opposite and saw the line forming. When the museum opens, all move in very fast. There were paintings by Van Gogh and Picasso before and after their own tranformation into their respective style. Excellent collection.

reviewnospace: Unlike the Prado, there was no line up to get into the Thyssen. Spread over three floors, the collection has good flow and some impressive pieces by many well known and some lesser known artists. Start on the top floor and work your way down, as the most modern pieces are on the ground floor. The complex also has a good restaurant.

Spread over three floors, the collection has good flow and some impressive pieces by many well known and some lesser known artists. Start on the top floor and work your way down, as the most modern pieces are on the ground floor. The complex also has a good restaurant.

quote: What a surprise! And larger than expected.

reviewnospace: Excellent museum for people with only an afternoon. This is doable in 2 hours. The Museum boasts an important collection of 19th-century American painting not found in any other European museum institutions. It really has something for everyone. I wish I had gotten there earlier so I could have had a coffee on there beautiful terrace cafe. Highly recommend a visit!

reviewnospace: Personally I think this is the best museum in Madrid, not the biggest, but certainly the most interesting! Here, as in others attractions there are times when you can get in for free, but I would still recommend the Madrid Card because you can skip the lines.
titleopinion: Unmissable!. Personally I think this is the best museum in Madrid, not the biggest, but certainly the most interesting! Here, as in others attractions there are times when you can get in for free, but I would still recommend the Madrid Card because you can skip the lines.

reviewnospace: I visited this Museum during the month of June and I must say I was very impressed with its collections, especially the Impressionist and Modernist art ones. It was absolutely amazing and I would highly recommend it. The onsite restaurant had a reasonable offering and pricing, including a terrace (where the prices are slightly different). Anyways, there are lots of places to eat in the area, so a lunch break during hours of watching those beautiful paintings should not be a problem. Also to mention is the bookshop / gift area, which I would say was the best of all the 3 major Museums in Madrid, and which is worth a stop by.

quote: 5 star museum if you budget time correctly
reviewnospace:
We had high expectations for museums in Madrid after seeing the Prado. The quality in the Tyssen was mixed - the medieval and older art is covered extensively in that Prado so it felt skip able at the Tyssen. The museum is divided into the husband and wife's separate collections. We started with the husbands which focused more on medieval art and I wish we would have known to start with the wife's collection. Her collection was focused on Impressionism and modern art - in a way it picked up where the Prado left off.

Recommend getting the audio tour, starting with the wife's collection and checking out the lovely gift shop

The Thyssen has a great collection of art ranging from the 14-15 century masters through impressionist and post impressionist artwork. The museum's current exhibition was a small but minimally adequate show of Renoir's works.
While in Madrid the Thyssen is a must see stop 2nd only to the Prod in Madrid's lineup.

reviewnospace: The Thyssen family collected paintings through several generations, resulting in fine selections from various periods, from the 19th century through the 20th. The collection was sold to Spain because the last Thyssen-Bournemisza married a Spanish beauty queen, Carmen, who encouraged it, and thus, landed a treasure in Madrid. The state has supported the purchase with a beautiful gallery and state-of-the-art conservation facility. A must-see and a great museum gift store!
titleopinion: Superb Collection. The Thyssen family collected paintings through several generations, resulting in fine selections from various periods, from the 19th century through the 20th. The collection was sold to Spain because the last Thyssen-Bournemisza married a Spanish beauty queen, Carmen, who encouraged it, and thus, landed a treasure in Madrid. The state has supported the purchase with a beautiful gallery and state-of-the-art conservation facility. A must-see and a great museum gift store!

If you are an art lover spend a couple of hours here at least.

reviewnospace:
The thought that one rich family could own, and then give, such an array of paintings is both awesome and a bit fearsome, given that their money came from arms.
That being said, the collection is superb and eclectic - something for every taste and genre and all of the highest quality. Some paintings illuminated a painter in new ways for us, such as a group of 4 Van Goghs unlike any we had ever seen.

quote: A Private Collection is the Core
reviewnospace:
It's hard to fathom that one family acquired such a vast collection of priceless art, which was acquired by the Spanish State and became the core of today's museum. 800 works from the late 13th century to the present day are displayed in chronological order on three floors, thus making it easy to navigate. Just pick your favorite periods if you don't have 2-3 hours to spend, which would be ideal. Many pleasant cafes are in the area so a visit could be broken up by lunch. If you are an art lover, the Thyssen is a must!

,

reviewnospace: The interior of this building is very attractive and the use of natural light very effective. Effectively two collections. One in rooms with numbers and the other on rooms with letters. If I understand correctly the numbers are those for the collection acquired by the Spanish Govt in 1993 from a private person and the other on loan since 2004 from his wife. I wish the two collections were merged as it would make the timing sequence more sensible. The advice from the gallery is to start at the top (level2) and work down, OK if you have the time and like early art. If I went again I would be tempted to just start on the level 1. A couple of amazing van Gogh's.
titleopinion: Well worth a visit. The interior of this building is very attractive and the use of natural light very effective. Effectively two collections. One in rooms with numbers and the other on rooms with letters. I wish the two collections were merged as it would make the timing sequence more sensible. The advice from the gallery is to start at the top (level2) and work down, OK if you have the time and like early art. If I went again I would be tempted to just start on the level 1. On a Saturday in October it wasn't crowded so you don't have to deal with some of the inconsiderate groups with their audio guides all in front of the same painting. (There are audio guides available but fewer people.) The museum is also of a manageable size.

So... we set off too late for the Prado(at least an hour queue) and it was on a day when the Reina Sofia was shut. So we went to the Thyssen-Bornemisza instead.
Wonderful happy accident! Very short queue, average price.
Excellent collection inside, some works from the masters, all put together very well. I especially liked the more modern works that were on the ground floor.
Couldn't take it all in, would have to go back on another trip and start from the opposite side!

titleopinion: Free visits every Monday, great building& location, worthwhile collection if you already visited Prado and Reina Sofia. Beautiful museum, well located, a nice collection, not great as the Prado or Reina Sofia, but worthwhile going

reviewnospace: We really enjoyed our visit to the Thyssen-Bornemisza museum. It actually had more works than we anticipated and I would suggest a minimum of three hours, preferably more, to do your visit justice. When we stopped by, they had a very nice Caravaggio exhibit. The special exhibit space for this showing is somewhat constrained, so if you are attending a popular show, come early to enjoy more viewing room. The museum’s works are chronologically arranged. Start your visit at the top floor, then serially view the oldest paintings first (Byzantine art), working your way downstairs to the most modern works. This approach offers an extremely convenient and logical manner to see the transformation of art over the centuries. There are an enormous number of works, many by famous artists, not all headline grabbers, but it’s rare to see so many different artists’ works in one easy-to-navigate setting. A tour de force museum visit capped off with a really fabulous museum store.
titleopinion: Comprehensive, Well-organized, Pure Pleasure. We really enjoyed our visit to the Thyssen-Bornemisza museum. It actually had more works than we anticipated and I would suggest a minimum of three hours, preferably more, to do your visit justice. When we stopped by, they had a very nice Caravaggio exhibit. The special exhibit space for this showing is somewhat constrained, so if you are attending a popular show, come early to enjoy more viewing room. The museum’s works are chronologically arranged. Start your visit at the top floor, then serially view the oldest paintings first (Byzantine art), working your way downstairs to the most modern works. This approach offers an extremely convenient and logical manner to see the transformation of art over the centuries. There are an enormous number of works, many by famous artists, not all headline grabbers, but it’s rare to see so many different artists’ works in one easy-to-navigate setting. A tour de force museum visit capped off with a really fabulous museum store.

reviewnospace: I love impressionist and post-impressionist art, and this is a great art museum for both. But it has a really good older collection that clearly shows the progression of art from religious to practical to impressionist and beyond (and some more modern too). The only disappointment was that a few paintings I really wanted to see weren't hanging.

But it has a really good older collection that clearly shows the progression of art from religious to practical to impressionist and beyond (and some more modern too). The only disappointment was that a few paintings I really wanted to see weren't hanging.

reviewnospace: Great Gallery to visit and much quieter than the Prado but so much to see through so many periods. I like the impressionists but the extra exhibition underground had pieces from private collection by Gustave Caillebotte. Amazing , hadn't heard of him before, wonderful paintings. Museum is free 1200-1600hrs one day a week and would recommend visiting if you can make that 'window' or even have to pay the 12 euro. Even had a beer in their amazing outdoor bar, bliss!

Museum is free 1200-1600hrs one day a week and would recommend visiting if you can make that 'window' or even have to pay the 12 euro. Even had a beer in their amazing outdoor bar, bliss!

reviewnospace: If you like Impressionist paintings this really is a must. The collections of this husband and wife are stunning and the gift they made when they gave it to the Spanish nation is literally priceless. There are many paintings you will find deeply moving, like some of the Edward Hopper. I think if I could only visit one art museum in Madrid this would be the one.

reviewnospace: Major permanent collection of high quality European paintings, not too crowded, well lit and well exhibited. A must see for art lovers.
titleopinion: Not to be missed. Major permanent collection of high quality European paintings, not too crowded, well lit and well exhibited. A must see for art lovers.

reviewnospace: This museum is much more intimate than the huge Prado, and the queues for the tickets are a lot shorter. But it is still a very big museum - we are always surprised. There are plenty of beautiful, representative paintings from the Renaissance right through to the twentieth century. And if you want to see them with your eyes, and not with a camera, you will have to take your time. It is worth it.

reviewnospace: For those like me who only want a small dose of art and culture. This museum is perfect. It is not as crowded as the Prado Museum. There is usually only a short queue to get in. The art pieces are beautiful. Can easily spend 2-3hrs here. Well worth a visit.

quote: A Exquisite, Well Curated Art Collection that Spans the Whole History of European Art
reviewnospace:
Everything about this Art Gallery is excellent. The collection is exquisite. It has several good examples of almost every significant art movement since days of Gothic art. The Italian Renaissance with the mastery of perspective and space. The Northern Renaissance with the mastery of play of light on different surfaces. All the way through to modern Abstract Expressionism. You can see art styles evolve just by taking a few steps. (Plus any gaps in the main collection seems to have been filled in by the Baroness's private collection which has been loaned to the gallery.)

The Ambiance is great. The Salmon coloured walls feel fresh and joyful. The rooms are spacious, the lighting excellent, and there is plentiful seating from which to relax and enjoy the art work. (Plus an excellent cafe if one feels the need for a break.)

Finally, the collection is well curated. The audio handset that is provided with entrance ticket give good background information. And you are allowed to take photographs (but no flash.) But it doesn't stop there. The gallery has a excellent web site with a virtual reality tour that is great if you fell the need to check up of the details any piece after your visit.

While it is doesn't have the depth of work of the major national art museums such as The Prado across the road from it, It does have a better breath. If you enjoy art you definitely enjoy this gallery. It is a standout.

If you enjoy art you definitely enjoy this gallery. It is a standout.

I was glad I made time for this.

quote: A museum that's actually comfortable to look round
reviewnospace: We arrived at 10:30 am, had a coffee and then bought tickets (no queue) for the museum. Wow, it was so easy and comfortable to wonder round. The lack of crowds meant you could really spend time looking at pictures, you can also photograph them (no flash) if you wish. The sixteenth century paintings were so detailed and bright they looked new not 500 years old. We found the experience so enjoyable we actually went back in the museum after having lunch in the cafe, something we've never done before.

reviewnospace: Contains an extensive, mind blowingly, representative collection of European and American art from medieval times through to the 1980s, culminating with examples from De Kooning, Lucien Freud and Rothko. Not always the best works but the featured artists, but interesting nonetheless. The medieval paintings, minor works by well known impressionists, and wonderful examples from the German expressionists, including Kirchner, Beckman and Nolde, were the best bits in my view. But it was also exciting to see works by key American artists Winslow Homer, Andrew Wyeth and Edward Hopper, as well as the best selection of Russian art I can recall seeing.

But it was also exciting to see works by key American artists Winslow Homer, Andrew Wyeth and Edward Hopper, as well as the best selection of Russian art I can recall seeing.

quote: Impressive collection organized from 13th to 20th century
reviewnospace:
Definitely less crowded than the Prado, but holds some very famous pieces such as Dali's Dream caused by a flight of a bumble bee....; Hopper's Hotel Room; and El Greco's The Annunciation. Others by Monet, Van Gogh, Caravaggio, Degas, Rothko, Lichtenstein, Picasso continues an extensive list of masters.

But for the sensory overload, I could spend a day there. Their website is excellent and allows one to explore in advance or relive your visit.

Photos without flash are permitted and you can get quite close to the paintings to really see the brushstrokes!

reviewnospace: The absolute best recommendation I can give for this museum concerns my husband, who has never enjoyed a visit to an art museum. He was amazed by the scope of paintings and the audio was excellent. He loved the day - you need at least 3 hours to complete this museum in a satisfactory manner. Also recommend eating at the outside restaurant adjacent to the museum. We should have taken a lunch break there and then continued on with the museum. As it was we happily sat down to wine and cheese and people-watched. It was a good place to eat after an exhausting few hours of museum wandering..

As it was we happily sat down to wine and cheese and people-watched. It was a good place to eat after an exhausting few hours of museum wandering..

quote: An excellent collection, a must see for art lovers
reviewnospace: An excellent collection with great art pieces of art, a 'must see' for art lovers of all period, especially the Dutch Great Masters, highly recommended. Also, you can take pictures!!!
titleopinion: An excellent collection, a must see for art lovers. An excellent collection with great art pieces of art, a 'must see' for art lovers of all period, especially the Dutch Great Masters, highly recommended. Also, you can take pictures!!!

reviewnospace:
This incredible private art collection, now in the hands of the state, fills three floors and features more than 1,600 paintings from the 13th to the 20th century. Though the collection focuses on older European paintings, a new section opened in 2005 that displays works from the 17th to 20th century, which include Impressionism, Post Impressionism, German Expressionism and two galleries devoted to North American artists of the 19th century.

I always head to the addition first when visiting the Thyssen. As a fan of paintings done in the most 'recent centuries, I like to ensure that I see works by such artists as Monet, Renoir, van Gogh, Degas, Bonnard, Munch, Kandinsky, Winslow Homer, Picasso and Jason Pollack. Then, depending on time available, I look at the Old Masters, such as Rubens, Tintoretto, Rembrandt and Fra Angelico.

It is easy to spend half a day in this museum. Not only are the paintings compelling, but the art is beautifully displayed and the lighting is excellent. I have never encountered a crush of visitors as I have in the Prado. Thus, it is possible to stand for a long time in front of a painting without the necessity to move on. And I have never needed to wait my turn to look at a masterpiece.

On my most recent visit, I was delighted to learn that a temporary exhibition, titled "Caillebotte, Painter and Gardener," was being held on the basement level. Nicely curated, this exhibition focuses on the artist's shift from city to country, accompanied by a change in painting style. It is a small exhibition rather than a blockbuster, but that adds to its charm. The exhibition closes on Oct. 30, 2016, and I consider it to be well worth attending.

The Thyssen is located in the beautiful Palacio de Villahermosa near the Prado. Photography is permitted. The nearest Metro stop is Banco de Espana, with many bus routes serving the immediate area.

reviewnospace: A very large museum, from which you need to select individual highlights, or else find yourself walking through room after room of nineteenth century American landscapes etc. There were two terrific (free) shows on during our visit: Caillebotte (about whom I knew nothing previously) and Caravaggio and the painters of the North, showing his influence over European painting, especially the Netherlands. Terrific altogether, but be prepared to pre-edit your visit.

Terrific altogether, but be prepared to pre-edit your visit.

Also if you happen to travel these days, do not miss the Caillebotte exhibition !

reviewnospace:
For anyone who is an art lover, this is also a must see. And make sure to get the audio so you know what you're looking at.

An added bonus for us, that we didn't even know we'd get, is that we visited on a Monday, and admittance on Mondays is free due to a sponsored program by MasterCard (free for everyone - you don't need to be a MC cardholder)
titleopinion: Many very famous paintings/artists. For anyone who is an art lover, this is also a must see. And make sure to get the audio so you know what you're looking at.  An added bonus for us, that we didn't even know we'd get, is that we visited on a Monday, and admittance on Mondays is free due to a sponsored program by MasterCard (free for everyone - you don't need to be a MC cardholder)

quote: Phenomenal collection - and easy to explore
reviewnospace: Amazing collection that spans quite a lot of history. We are more interested in contemporary work and were not disappointed.
titleopinion: Phenomenal collection - and easy to explore. Amazing collection that spans quite a lot of history. We are more interested in contemporary work and were not disappointed.

reviewnospace: Having thought I would spend a morning here ended up being over 4 hours and only really did one floor could have spent all day. The variety of works is great from el greco to Mark rothco ,Paul gauging to a spectacular van goth and famous portrait of Henry VIII it's all here. The great thing about it is you can get really close to great works of art and they are not too fussy, also its not as busy as the prado.
titleopinion: Loved this museum. Having thought I would spend a morning here ended up being over 4 hours and only really did one floor could have spent all day. The variety of works is great from el greco to Mark rothco ,Paul gauging to a spectacular van goth and famous portrait of Henry VIII it's all here. The great thing about it is you can get really close to great works of art and they are not too fussy, also its not as busy as the prado.

reviewnospace: Visited this impressive collection located just a block away. A lot of interesting paintings here but not a huge amount of masterpieces like in the Prado. I liked the impressionist collection the best. The overall breadth and volume of the Thyssen collection and the venue is what impresses you the most.
titleopinion: Worth a Look. Visited this impressive collection located just a block away. A lot of interesting paintings here but not a huge amount of masterpieces like in the Prado. I liked the impressionist collection the best. The overall breadth and volume of the Thyssen collection and the venue is what impresses you the most.

reviewnospace: An impressive collection of art. Even had some Americans even my favorite Winslow Homer (but Breezing Up is at the National Gallery in DC). Loved the impressionist pieces. It's almost overwhelming when coupled with Prado on same day but they are very closely located so it made sense to do both while in area.
