quote: Another world class art museum in Madrid
reviewnospace:
Museo Thyssen-Bornemisza (€12 per person) is located along Paseo del Prado in Madrid. This is an important inclusion in the Golden Triangle of Art in Madrid along with fellow art museums, Prado and Queen Sofia. Opening Hours are 10am to 7pm Tuesday to Sunday and 12-4pm on Mondays.

Visitors can enjoy a world-class permanent collection representing a wide range of art periods from the 13th to 20th century and showcasing over 1000 paintings from a who's who list of historical artists. You'll see works by the likes of Fra Angelico, Jan van Eyck, Veronese, Caravaggio, Rembrandt, Gainsborough, Kandinsky, Dali, Renoir, van Gogh, Chagall, Pollock amongst many many others.

The main collection is spaced out over 3 floors. Your visit will start on the 2nd floor with galleries arranged mostly in chronological fashion, allowing you work your way from earlier periods to more recent Post Impressionist and Modern art works of the last century on the ground floor. We spent around 90 minutes on the 2nd and 1st floor and another 30 minutes in the smaller ground floor exhibition area.

The ground floor is where you find ticket booth, gift shop, access to the museum cafe as well as temporary exhibition spaces. During our visit, there was also a very rewarding temporary exhibition featuring the works of American father and son, Andrew and Jamie Wyeth. This was a quality exhibition that was well worth 20-30 minutes if you are interested in the works of Wyeth.

Presently, there is a Caravaggio exhibition until mid Sept 2016. Best to visit the museum website to learn about exhibitions that may be available during the time of your intended visit.

Note: Photography is allowed through the permanent collection. However, it is not allowed in the temporary exhibition area.

Overall, we very much enjoyed our time at Thyssen Museum in Madrid, finding it a nice complement to Prado and Queen Sofia. This is a world-class venue and a place that will be greatly appreciated by anyone who enjoys viewing fine art.

reviewnospace:
This was our favorite of the three big art museums in Madrid.

We took our time walking through the medieval art before we realized just how much art was contained in this museum. The art is arranged chronologically, which we thought was a really cool way to do it. There is a path to walk the museum to go from a thousand years ago to today. You can also walk back in time if you so choose. This museum is known for its medieval artwork and had more than the Prado.

There are a lot of impressionists. There are a few El Grecos which again are beautiful. We had to breeze through the last couple of centuries to make it out for lunch.

reviewnospace: Decided to go with a friend to kill time. Excellent collection... was really surprised. All major artists included. Loved the works by El Greco. Some really good 20th century art too. Fortunately there was also a temporary exhibit on Caravaggio too. Didn't have to queue for more than 5 minutes to get tickets. Good value for money, wandering around for easily over 2 hours at 12 euros a ticket. Definitely would recommend! Good cafe attached too

quote: Favorite museum in Madrid...which says a lot!
reviewnospace:
Madrid is blessed with several prestigious museums, but from our experiences this week I can say that Thyssen-Bornemisza was definitely the best.

First of all, the museum is far less crowded than the Prado across the street. Secondly, you can actually take pictures of the works! (That's without flash of course.) Madrid seems to take itself a bit too seriously, with guards at the Prado and the Royal Palace watching like hawks and shouting at anyone who dares to pull out a camera...the vibe here is respectful but relaxed.

Finally, the collection of works is diverse and impressive. Having spent two weeks traveling throughout Spain, I can promise you that EVERY museum will give you rooms and rooms of early religious work...and you will get your fill of El Greco's and the like here as well. However, you'll ALSO get European works (French, Italian, Dutch, German, and Spanish) from the 18th, 19th, and 20th centuries! The impressionist masters are well-represented, and there is even a nice amount of American work...I enjoyed seeing Winslow Homer and John Singer Sargent among the many fine paintings.

Final tip: for only 5 Euro extra (27 instead of 12), you can purchase a ticket that lets you in to BOTH the Museo T-B and Royal Palace...we went here first and were able to skip the long line at the Palace later.

quote: Outstanding - if you do one in Madrid, do this one.
reviewnospace: The best, easiest to visit, biggest range without being at all overwhelming. Fantastic art, well curated, well informed guides and in English. reviewnospace: I suppose you have to go to the Prado and Reina Sofia on your first visit, because where else could you see such excellent Goya, Velázquez, Picasso and Dali. However, on your 2nd visit to the city or if you are an art lover or have extra time, the Thyssen-Bornemisza is a must. It provides an excellent overview of Westerns paintings over many centuries and one could clearly see the development from the Renaissance, Impressionism, Expressionism, Surrealism, Pop Art. What I liked particularly about this museum is that it doesn't have the crowds of the Prado and therefore ensure a much more peaceful and enjoyable experience. The shop at the end is the best I have ever come across in an art museum. Not only do they have various sizes of prints of most of the paintings for sales, but also posters and very stylish articles. Well worth a visit. The website is well designed and makes it possible to prepare your visit in advance...I always prefer to limit my visit to a specific period, instead of breezing through the whole museum. The staff is friendly, especially the guy at the cloak room.

To keep it simple at 12 euro for an adult, given 3 floors of paintings in a nice cool space that is never very crowded and where getting the tickets etc is simple .
This place is well worth a visit.
With 3 teenagers I went in at 2pm and left it at 4.20pm and frankly the time flew for all of us.

quote: Good collection, but scandalised by the ticket policy
reviewnospace:
What if you go to a great museum, and at the end get your experience spoiled, essentially being ripped off?

I bought the Paseo Del Arte ticket, which gives you entry to the 3 largest museums. However, Thyssen had a special Caravaggio exhibition that I didn't want to miss. Naturally, I was okay with paying extra for it, - but I was told that I could only buy an entire ticket for entry to the whole museum, and that would include the special exhibition! So I paid 12 Euros for several Caravaggio paintings (always a pleasure to see) and quite a lot more paintings of his followers. A spoiled experience.


The collection is great, however, especially if you like your impressionists. The museum itself is also airy, light and pleasant, does not have crowds, and you can take pictures. I would only have positive things to say about it, if not for the above.

quote: Excellent art gallery, preferred to the Prado
reviewnospace:
On a recent visit to Madrid, my wife and I purchased "Madrid Cards" as were were not really sure where to go, and these gave us the flexibility to visit multiple places without booking tickets in advance to skip the queues.

Therefore we had put the Museo Thyssen-Bornemisza on our list, not really thinking about it, but it actually turned out to be one of the highlights of our stay.

The gallery itself is very open, and whilst we already had tickets to skip the queue, there didn't actually seem to be a queue to skip as it all looked to be run very efficiently.

The collection itself is amazing, there are works by a vast selection of artists, but the works themselves really complement each other too so there seemed to be a really good flow around the gallery.

Overall we actually preferred this to the Prado, and would very happily visit here again next time we are in Madrid.

We had done the Prado and the Reina Sofia Museos but found the Thyssen to be at least my favorite. Very manageable to do on your own without a guide and tour the three floor galleries. Recommend starting on floor 2 and working your way down to 0. Great private collection representing the ages of art. There is also something for everyone's tastes.

quote: It's ok to take photos (without flash)
reviewnospace:
What a pleasure! The museum is well organized, airconditioned and extensive but not exhaustive. I found myself inspired by periods of art that have not interested me before. The collection is clearly a carefully curated selection of works meant to be shared and enjoyed (not an archive like Prado).

To my unexpected delight it's ok to take photos (sans flash)! What a fantastic and comtemporary attitude. So refreshing after being stared at by guards in the Prado and Royal Palace for carrying a camera.

The museum shop is large and offers a lot of prints, posters, books and gift products.
