quote: Great art in an expansive setting
reviewnospace: The museum houses the family's art collection that has a bit of a lot of styles and ages from Gothic to Modern. It's a great venue for exposing oneself to a sweep of Western art without getting bogged down. The museum is large enough to allow each painting to be set apart and appreciated on the ochre walls that provide a harmonious backdrop. Only negative was the cafe where an overstretched staff couldn't keep up with the crowd.

reviewnospace: We loved this museum bc it has a nice mix of Old Master's, Impressionists & lots of more current works as well. In addition- admission is FREE on Mondays (Mastercard Mondays) so take advantage of that!

reviewnospace: My score would have been higher, as this museum has a fantastically varied collection, something for everyone. But the ticket seller, when asked if they had a senior discount, told me they had one for someone over 75. The sign behind her on the wall said 65. I didn't appreciate the seller trying to get more money out of me.

reviewnospace:
We hadn't planned on visiting this art museum but after the disappointing Prado Museum and taking the adbice of others we spent a wonderful few hours wandering through this museum. It was the world's largest private collection with a 1000 paintings until purchased by the Spanidh government in the 1990s.
The collection ranges from 17th century European masters through to 20th century American modernists. Masters included Monet, Picasso and Gauguin. The Museum was beautifully laid out and spacious. You were also allowed to take photos (no flash).
Highly recommended.
titleopinion: A masters surprise. The collection ranges from 17th century European masters through to 20th century American modernists. Masters included Monet, Picasso and Gauguin. The Museum was beautifully laid out and spacious. You were also allowed to take photos (no flash). Highly recommended.

reviewnospace: I had no idea how many wonderful works this museum had. It is one of the best collections of American masters outside of the US. I was very impressed. It is a larger museum than I thought and ended up spending the whole afternoon. Very enjoyable!

reviewnospace:
This is a huge collection. We used the audio guide which was actually a bit "too much" in terms of all there is to see and hours of old Flemish art is a bit much but enjoyed the modern art a lot.
Had lunch in the museum and it was okay but not remarkable.
titleopinion: Thyssen-Bornemisza. This is a huge collection. We used the audio guide which was actually a bit  too much  in terms of all there is to see and hours of old Flemish art is a bit much but enjoyed the modern art a lot.  Had lunch in the museum and it was okay but not remarkable.

reviewnospace: Often overlooked in the shadow of the two star museums in the Spanish capital (Museo del Prado & Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofia), this museum is full of masterpieces which can be marvelled at so easily thanks to the museum's wonderful signalling which guides you through the collection. Tip: Upon entering, buy the Pocket Guide to the Collection (available in many languages) which will render your visit even smoother and more pleasant. This museum fascinated me and I would go as far as to say that if you have time for only one museum visit in Madrid, choose Museo Thyssen. Free entrance to the permanent collection on Mondays (May 2016).
titleopinion: The best museum in Madrid!. Often overlooked in the shadow of the two star museums in the Spanish capital (Museo del Prado & Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofia), this museum is full of masterpieces which can be marvelled at so easily thanks to the museum's wonderful signalling which guides you through the collection. Tip: Upon entering, buy the Pocket Guide to the Collection (available in many languages) which will render your visit even smoother and more pleasant. This museum fascinated me and I would go as far as to say that if you have time for only one museum visit in Madrid, choose Museo Thyssen. quote: Smaller than the Prado but equally as good
reviewnospace: The Thyssen generally is less busy than the Prado so is definitely worth a visit. Lots to see so you can plan your visit by the floor or the era which attracts you most. Plenty of italian, french masters to see nd the famous portraits of Henry VIII of England and Catherine of Aragon his first wife both painted by Hans Holbein. Beware though, if you are expecting these to be big paintings - they are both actually quite tiny!

reviewnospace: The building is nicely laid out with the master pieces organized by country, type and year completed. If you are an impressionist fan, you will love this museum. Give yourself 4 hours to go thru the mueso and I think it suitable without a guide

quote: Art! Art and more wonderful art!!!
reviewnospace: After visiting Reina Sofia and Museo del Prado, this was my favorite of the three. I was amazed by all the wonderful work displayed (Monet, Van Gogh, Degas, Rothko, Gaugin)... The list was endless! Wonderful experience!

quote: Nice mix of art periods and styles
reviewnospace: While smaller and not as well known as the Prado or the Reina Sofia, the Thyssen is definitely worth a visit as well. It covers a nice range of art periods and styles, making it more of a "one-size fits all" museum compared to the modernity of the Reina sofia and the antiquity of the Prado. They also seem to have a lot of really impressive/crowd-drawing special exhibits.

This is the best private collection of paintings which fullfils the expectations of every art lover.

quote: Best Art Collection in Madrid or ever!

titleopinion: Best Art Collection in Madrid or ever!. This museum has the best art to see in Madrid across genres. I like it much more than Prado - which is just Jesus on the Cross.

reviewnospace: Interesting museum. Especially interesting to visit with children, because you travel through the history of painting (from 14th until 20th century) in about 2 hours. From all the important painters there is exactly one painting.
titleopinion: Impressive collection. Interesting museum. Especially interesting to visit with children, because you travel through the history of painting (from 14th until 20th century) in about 2 hours. From all the important painters there is exactly one painting.

reviewnospace:
We only visited for an hour or so, butgave us a far better experience than the Prado. The guide to the museum was excellent and allowed us to easily find the works we particularly wanted to see.
The range of paintings was impressive and set in small rooms with an intimate feel which made each section easier to assimilate.
Well worth a visit; not to be missed if you're a lover of fine paintings.
titleopinion: Short visit. We only visited for an hour or so, butgave us a far better experience than the Prado. The guide to the museum was excellent and allowed us to easily find the works we particularly wanted to see. The range of paintings was impressive and set in small rooms with an intimate feel which made each section easier to assimilate. Well worth a visit; not to be missed if you're a lover of fine paintings.

reviewnospace:
We really enjoyed our visit to the Thyssen. The three of us love impressionism and enjoyed their collection. The museum itself is just the right size to be able to spend several hours without becoming completely exhausted and yet get a chance to see all the pieces or art.

My only piece of advice is that if you plan to purchase a paseo del arte pass, you can do so on the Thyssen web site but I strongly advise you NOT TO. You aren't really getting the pass, just a receipt for the pass and so you will need to go to the Thyssen first before being able to use the pass at the other museums which will limit your flexibility. Furthermore, while you get to bypass the regular ticket line at the Thyssen you still need to stand in line to get your pass. The paseo del arte line and the other line were both exceedingly short so there is just no reason to prebuy the pass.
titleopinion: Our favorite museum in Madrid. We really enjoyed our visit to the Thyssen. The three of us love impressionism and enjoyed their collection. The museum itself is just the right size to be able to spend several hours without becoming completely exhausted and yet get a chance to see all the pieces or art.   My only piece of advice is that if you plan to purchase a paseo del arte pass, you can do so on the Thyssen web site but I strongly advise you NOT TO. You aren't really getting the pass, just a receipt for the pass and so you will need to go to the Thyssen first before being able to use the pass at the other museums which will limit your flexibility. Furthermore, while you get to bypass the regular ticket line at the Thyssen you still need to stand in line to get your pass. The paseo del arte line and the other line were both exceedingly short so there is just no reason to prebuy the pass.

reviewnospace:
It is my favorite museum in Madrid and I do always encourage people to pay a visit to the Thyssen.
You will never forget such a wonderful experience!
titleopinion: Thyssen. It is my favorite museum in Madrid and I do always encourage people to pay a visit to the Thyssen.  You will never forget such a wonderful experience!

reviewnospace: Lots and lots of paintings, among which many by the Dutch painters after whom the streets in the Amsterdam neighborhoods 'de Pijp' en 'Oud Zuid' were named. The collection starts to thin after World War II, but for that there is the Reina Sofia museum.
titleopinion: Incredible collection of painting. Lots and lots of paintings, among which many by the Dutch painters after whom the streets in the Amsterdam neighborhoods 'de Pijp' en 'Oud Zuid' were named. The collection starts to thin after World War II, but for that there is the Reina Sofia museum.

reviewnospace: A lovely collection art from the Dutch masters to contemporary artists. It really seems like you have been invieted to a home of a person who truly loves art and wishes to showcase their favorite pieces.
titleopinion: Moderate sized and versatile gallery.. A lovely collection art from the Dutch masters to contemporary artists. It really seems like you have been invieted to a home of a person who truly loves art and wishes to showcase their favorite pieces.

reviewnospace: Rembrandt, Van Gogh, Degas & Canaletto - almost all my favorites & you can take pictures (without flash)! Some of these you have never seen as they were in private collections. Gorgeous!
titleopinion: Sweet personal collection!. Rembrandt, Van Gogh, Degas & Canaletto - almost all my favorites & you can take pictures (without flash)! Some of these you have never seen as they were in private collections. Gorgeous!

quote: Must Go, 4 hours for visiting is recommended
reviewnospace: Thanks to the sponsor of Master card, Monday is free. But it is better arrival there half hour at least before opening, long queue. if you like western painting, it is better prepare 4 hours for a detailed visit. Audio guided is highly recommended. camera is allowed.
titleopinion: Must Go, 4 hours for visiting is recommended. Thanks to the sponsor of Master card, Monday is free. But it is better arrival there half hour at least before opening, long queue. if you like western painting, it is better prepare 4 hours for a detailed visit. Audio guided is highly recommended. camera is allowed.

reviewnospace: Definitely worth a trip if you love art. Many major artists represented, though often with lesser works. But you get to see the full span of Western art up to the early 20th century.
titleopinion: Fabulous collection for one family. Definitely worth a trip if you love art. Many major artists represented, though often with lesser works. But you get to see the full span of Western art up to the early 20th century.

reviewnospace:
Just across the Prada this is a real gem of a place. However, we did not go there the same day. Again we got there early. Saw a modern exhibition addition to the permanent one, before we went to see the Bornemissza collection.
Personally, I liked it more than the Prada one.
It was not so heavy with some of the best French impressionist paintings on show. It was also more on the manageable scale.
Spent the morning there and went for lunch after that.
Do not miss this!
.
titleopinion: Art Lovers Paradise. Just across the Prada this is a real gem of a place. However, we did not go there the same day. Again we got there early. Saw a modern exhibition addition to the permanent one, before we went to see the Bornemissza collection. Personally, I liked it more than the Prada one. It was not so heavy with some of the best French impressionist paintings on show. It was also more on the manageable scale. Spent the morning there and went for lunch after that. Do not miss this! .

reviewnospace: The Thyssen-Bornemisza collection is absolutely stunning! And it is easily visited in an hour or so. They usually have very interesting and wonderful temporary exhibitions as well. Highly recommended!
titleopinion: Wonderful collection!. The Thyssen-Bornemisza collection is absolutely stunning! And it is easily visited in an hour or so. They usually have very interesting and wonderful temporary exhibitions as well. Highly recommended!

reviewnospace:
This was absolutely our favorite museum in Madrid - if you love the impressionists, the collection is amazing. We also found the facility to be excellent - unlike many museums where charting a path through the collection is confusing, the floorpan of the building makes it very easy to circulate through the collection in a logical manner entering or skipping areas as your interests dictate.

Overall, a wonderful way to spend an afternoon!
titleopinion: Fabulous!. This was absolutely our favorite museum in Madrid - if you love the impressionists, the collection is amazing. We also found the facility to be excellent - unlike many museums where charting a path through the collection is confusing, the floorpan of the building makes it very easy to circulate through the collection in a logical manner entering or skipping areas as your interests dictate.   Overall, a wonderful way to spend an afternoon!

reviewnospace: renaissance thru Warhol, at the top of each. The temporary exhibit of Madrid Realists was the art Highlight of our two week trip.
titleopinion: a walk thru art's time. renaissance thru Warhol, at the top of each. The temporary exhibit of Madrid Realists was the art Highlight of our two week trip.

reviewnospace: Take at least 3 hours, and this is a wonderful, easily navigable place to view paintings from many of the greatest artists: Rembrant, Picasso, Monet, Sargent,... I am leaving many out, I'm sorry, but go. Currently, they also have a great photography exhibit too! Should be on your list.
titleopinion: Magnificent Collection!. Take at least 3 hours, and this is a wonderful, easily navigable place to view paintings from many of the greatest artists: Rembrant, Picasso, Monet, Sargent,... I am leaving many out, I'm sorry, but go. Currently, they also have a great photography exhibit too! Should be on your list.

quote: Beautiful collection and a very pleasant atmosphere
reviewnospace: This museum had a beautiful collection of paintings from different periods. The building is a great place in itself; architecture with a great atmosphere
titleopinion: Beautiful collection and a very pleasant atmosphere. This museum had a beautiful collection of paintings from different periods. The building is a great place in itself; architecture with a great atmosphere

reviewnospace: Big queues at the Prado so, as this museum was nearby, thought we'd give it a try and so glad we did. A fine collection covering all periods up to 20th century. Lots of well-known names plus some interesting works by artists that were new to us - particularly enjoyed seeing the Edward Hoppers. No great crowds so one was able to view the works comfortably in a relaxed environment. Back in Madrid in September so would most certainly consider a return visit.
titleopinion: Pleased we missed the Prado. Big queues at the Prado so, as this museum was nearby, thought we'd give it a try and so glad we did. A fine collection covering all periods up to 20th century. Lots of well-known names plus some interesting works by artists that were new to us - particularly enjoyed seeing the Edward Hoppers. No great crowds so one was able to view the works comfortably in a relaxed environment. Back in Madrid in September so would most certainly consider a return visit.

reviewnospace: Madrid has the Prado but it also has this fantastic museum that houses some great private collections. Housed in a three story building, there are great pieces from Dali, Picasso, etc. Not as crowded as the Prado and a great way to spend a Sunday morning before walking to the park up the street.
titleopinion: Fantastic alternative to Prado. Madrid has the Prado but it also has this fantastic museum that houses some great private collections. Housed in a three story building, there are great pieces from Dali, Picasso, etc. Not as crowded as the Prado and a great way to spend a Sunday morning before walking to the park up the street.

reviewnospace:
I live in Madrid and ive visited this museum several times .. I think it is worth visiting it
great painters Works are often displayed .
titleopinion: Thyssen-Museum. I live in Madrid and ive visited this museum several times .. I think it is worth visiting it great painters Works are often displayed .

quote: So much beauty at the Thyssen
reviewnospace: This art museum has such a gorgeous & varied permanent collection of paintings that it's hard to describe. Some people actually prefer it to the Prado, but they are just different. The Prado has, of course, Magnificence in all its forms, and it is Vast. The Thyssen is smaller & more intimate (by Prado standards), but an amazing collection from all over the world.They have a Rubens that takes my breath away, & one of the most beautiful Goya paintings in Madrid (in my opinion!). They have a huge selection of Impressionists & they always have wonderful exhibitions. If you love art, don't miss this Museum. Someone has collected with Love!
titleopinion: So much beauty at the Thyssen . This art museum has such a gorgeous & varied permanent collection of paintings that it's hard to describe. Some people actually prefer it to the Prado, but they are just different. The Prado has, of course, Magnificence in all its forms, and it is Vast. The Thyssen is smaller & more intimate (by Prado standards), but an amazing collection from all over the world.They have a Rubens that takes my breath away, & one of the most beautiful Goya paintings in Madrid (in my opinion!). They have a huge selection of Impressionists & they always have wonderful exhibitions. If you love art, don't miss this Museum. Someone has collected with Love!

quote: Much more interesting than the prado
reviewnospace: In fairness we didn't go to the prado as all our research made it look old and stuffy with no artists the kids would recognise. This gallery had a couple of Van Goghs, a monet, Rembrandt and some good surrealists enough for us to enjoy by skipping a few bits.
titleopinion: Much more interesting than the prado. In fairness we didn't go to the prado as all our research made it look old and stuffy with no artists the kids would recognise. This gallery had a couple of Van Goghs, a monet, Rembrandt and some good surrealists enough for us to enjoy by skipping a few bits.

quote: Wonderful overview of European and American Art over the past 600 years.
reviewnospace: So many great artists, many well known, on display in this well curated museum, blending two excellent collections.
titleopinion: Wonderful overview of European and American Art over the past 600 years.. So many great artists, many well known, on display in this well curated museum, blending two excellent collections.

reviewnospace: This is one of the most impressive art collections in the world, beautifully displayed - I think it rivals the Prado, and being on a smaller scale, easier to absorb.
titleopinion: Don't miss this museum!. This is one of the most impressive art collections in the world, beautifully displayed - I think it rivals the Prado, and being on a smaller scale, easier to absorb.

reviewnospace: The variety, layout, and selection is much better than the Prado. While the Prado may seem like an endurance course, this museum is pure pleasure.
titleopinion: Much Better than the Prado. The variety, layout, and selection is much better than the Prado. While the Prado may seem like an endurance course, this museum is pure pleasure.

quote: Well organized museum with beautiful paintings
reviewnospace: Nice museum, friendly staff, great café and terrace. Paintings from the middle ages up till now. Nice Lyon organized. Free entrance on mondays from 12 till 16 hour. Start at the second floor and then go down. If you want to see specific paintings take a map at the entrance or ask the staff. If you make an easygoing tour, it will take you about 3 hours.
titleopinion: Well organized museum with beautiful paintings . Nice museum, friendly staff, great café and terrace. Paintings from the middle ages up till now. Nice Lyon organized. If you make an easygoing tour, it will take you about 3 hours.

reviewnospace:
On the Saturday morning we visited the entrance queue was minimal and the admission price very reasonable at 12 euros each.

The museum is very well organised and laid out. Starting on the second floor with 15th century works progressing through the centuries to modern work on the ground floor.
titleopinion: Very interesting. On the Saturday morning we visited the entrance queue was minimal and the admission price very reasonable at 12 euros each.  The museum is very well organised and laid out. Starting on the second floor with 15th century works progressing through the centuries to modern work on the ground floor.

reviewnospace: This private collection is just spectacular. Major works of art of many famous painters hang in the walls of this museum. The cafeteria is also very nice.
titleopinion: A must. This private collection is just spectacular. Major works of art of many famous painters hang in the walls of this museum. The cafeteria is also very nice.

quote: If you like Degas, this one is for you
reviewnospace: I'm a fan of Degas ballerinas. This museum has quite a bit of Degas' collection. Other masters include Monet, Matisse, Van Gogh. A must visit in Madrid.
titleopinion: If you like Degas, this one is for you. I'm a fan of Degas ballerinas. This museum has quite a bit of Degas' collection. Other masters include Monet, Matisse, Van Gogh. A must visit in Madrid.

reviewnospace: Decided to stop by here and are so glad we did! I am not super artsy and although the Prado was amazing in scope and size and famous things to see , I actually preferred the art here. Some really pretty pieces by Monet, Pisarro, Roudin... We didn't have a lot of time here - could have spent more for sure.

quote: Amazing stroll through 5 centuries of paintings
reviewnospace:
The museum lets you walk by masterpieces and most representative paintings from XV to XX centuries, from artists all over Europe and Americas.
The audioguide is excellent. The only advice I could give is to create a path and audio guide section for youngster.

reviewnospace:
Really, you must come here. Go to both parts of what are really two, combined collections. Don't think that Mrs. T's collection (more recently assembled) is somehow the lesser of the two. It's magnificent.
Make sure you get the audio guide too.
Finally, the very stylish cafe is a welcome break.
Good gift shop too.
titleopinion: Don't Miss It!. Really, you must come here. Go to both parts of what are really two, combined collections. Finally, the very stylish cafe is a welcome break. Good gift shop too.

reviewnospace:
One of the best museums in Madrid, in my opinion better than Prado.
It covers all the art history. An amazing collection of impressionists, with paintings of Monet, Pissarro, Gauguin. Also amazing paintings of Rembrandt and Van Gogh.
You can not miss it, if you are visiting Madrid.
titleopinion: Great museum.. One of the best museums in Madrid, in my opinion better than Prado.  It covers all the art history. quote: A magnificent gallery with a huge collection of outstanding paintings
reviewnospace: This amazing gallery has a vast collection of beautiful paintings. It is thoughtfully laid out in chronological order and, unlike the Prado has paintings of the 19th & 20th century. The impressionist collection is remarkable with the major artists if the period well represented. The cafe is good too, and worth stopping off for lunch after your visit
titleopinion: A magnificent gallery with a huge collection of outstanding paintings. This amazing gallery has a vast collection of beautiful paintings. quote: Great museum, less overwhelming than Prado
reviewnospace: We had no intention of visiting this museum, but due to Prado having a very long queue we changed our plans and came here. I´m truly glad we did, as the museum was a perfect size, broad survey of several centuries of paintings. Suitable even for a person like me who cannot boast of being very knowledgeable in arts.

reviewnospace: You could spend many happy hours here. The exhibition of Andrew Wyeth paintings was a memorable experience. The cafe is ok with outside tables.
titleopinion: Fabulous pictures!. You could spend many happy hours here. The exhibition of Andrew Wyeth paintings was a memorable experience. The cafe is ok with outside tables.

quote: The best collection ever view in Spain.
reviewnospace: I spent a lot of time enjoying the Guernica by Pablo Picasso. One of the most important works of Spanish contemporary art. A magnificent work by its political significance, its art and its size.
titleopinion: The best collection ever view in Spain.. I spent a lot of time enjoying the Guernica by Pablo Picasso. One of the most important works of Spanish contemporary art. A magnificent work by its political significance, its art and its size.

reviewnospace:
Wow! This art museum has a huge range of artists. The collection stems from the private art of the Thyssen-Bornemisza family which was acquired by the Spanish State in 1993. The works date from the 1200s to modern art of the 1980s. Some of the artists include Roy Lichtenstein, Arshile Gorky, Rembrandt, Vincent van Gogh, and so, so many others. The walls are painted a cooling salmon, which lends itself to viewing against the fabulous art. It is a smaller museum than some of the more famous ones, but the range of the art is vast and contains important pieces.
The museum is open each day, but with limited hours on Monday (all visitors are free on Monday from 12 to 4p.m.) Reduced rates are offered at other times for certain categories with identification.
titleopinion: Favorite Art Museum. Wow! This art museum has a huge range of artists. The collection stems from the private art of the Thyssen-Bornemisza family which was acquired by the Spanish State in 1993. The works date from the 1200s to modern art of the 1980s. Some of the artists include Roy Lichtenstein, Arshile Gorky, Rembrandt, Vincent van Gogh, and so, so many others. The walls are painted a cooling salmon, which lends itself to viewing against the fabulous art. It is a smaller museum than some of the more famous ones, but the range of the art is vast and contains important pieces.  The museum is open each day, but with limited hours on Monday (all visitors are free on Monday from 12 to 4p.m.) Reduced rates are offered at other times for certain categories with identification.

reviewnospace: Huge private collection originated by the Thyssen family as in the elevators. From classics to modern, from Gothic to Pop Art...so worth it!
titleopinion: Amazing Collection of Artwork!. Huge private collection originated by the Thyssen family as in the elevators. From classics to modern, from Gothic to Pop Art...so worth it!

reviewnospace:
Absolutely fantastic collection! Less crowded than Prado, but no less interesting and worth visiting.
The on-site cafe is so-so, but convenient
titleopinion: A real gem. Absolutely fantastic collection! Less crowded than Prado, but no less interesting and worth visiting. The on-site cafe is so-so, but convenient

quote: The best museum in Madrid for 20th century art.
reviewnospace: I can only look at religious classical art for about 20 minutes before getting bored, so luckily this museum is different than the others in Madrid. It's got a large, eclectic collection and some very nice pieces arranged in a manner that helps explain how one movement led to another. At least a few paintings from all the most famous artists and many of their lesser-known contemporaries. Free admission Monday 12 to 4.
titleopinion: The best museum in Madrid for 20th century art.. I can only look at religious classical art for about 20 minutes before getting bored, so luckily this museum is different than the others in Madrid. It's got a large, eclectic collection and some very nice pieces arranged in a manner that helps explain how one movement led to another. At least a few paintings from all the most famous artists and many of their lesser-known contemporaries. Free admission Monday 12 to 4.

reviewnospace:
What a place, a time line of the history of art right up until the modern day.

Be sure to get a map and start on the top floor and work your way down. Definitely recommend!!!
titleopinion: Wow!!!!. What a place, a time line of the history of art right up until the modern day.  Be sure to get a map and start on the top floor and work your way down. Definitely recommend!!!

reviewnospace: The collection is a must see. I especially enjoyed the impressionist sections. My only complaint is the same for all museums in Spain...Set up some directional or suggested route for the visitors and include other languages in your signage. The museum is not very friendly to non Spanish visitors.
titleopinion: A great collection!. The collection is a must see. I especially enjoyed the impressionist sections. My only complaint is the same for all museums in Spain...Set up some directional or suggested route for the visitors and include other languages in your signage. The museum is not very friendly to non Spanish visitors.

reviewnospace: I visited all three major art museums in Madrid and thought this was the best one. It's smaller than the other two but better organised. The most of major eras of art are represented here so this museum is well suited for beginners too. If you have time for only one art museum in Madrid, come here.
titleopinion: Definitely worth a visit. I visited all three major art museums in Madrid and thought this was the best one. It's smaller than the other two but better organised. The most of major eras of art are represented here so this museum is well suited for beginners too. If you have time for only one art museum in Madrid, come here.

reviewnospace: We visited the Thyssen after spending the morning at the Prado. The crowds were significantly less which allowed us to enjoy the amazing art. Well worth a visit and might suggest that if you only have time for one museum, the Thyssen should be it.
titleopinion: Maybe better than the Prado. We visited the Thyssen after spending the morning at the Prado. The crowds were significantly less which allowed us to enjoy the amazing art. Well worth a visit and might suggest that if you only have time for one museum, the Thyssen should be it.

reviewnospace: As the art was collected by 2 different types of people, it reflects their different views. The art covers several centuries and countries, and I found it really enjoyable. Some guidebooks are rather dismissive of this museum, but I thought it was great. A nice café too.
titleopinion: Quirky. As the art was collected by 2 different types of people, it reflects their different views. The art covers several centuries and countries, and I found it really enjoyable. Some guidebooks are rather dismissive of this museum, but I thought it was great. A nice café too.

quote: Eclectic art: mix great alternative to Prado and Reina Sofia
reviewnospace:
I'm not really into museums. Whilst I appreciate the classical art of the Prado and the modern art of Reina Sofia, they are...errr..."not my cup of tea". For me Thyssen is the perfect solution as it contains a more eclectic...and for me, more interesting range of paintings.
BTW check out the website for free entry on Mondays between 12noon and 4pm. Nice outdoor seating in it's cafe...note...items on display on the bar counter seem to be significantly cheaper than others.
titleopinion: Eclectic art: mix great alternative to Prado and Reina Sofia. I'm not really into museums. reviewnospace:
Nice collection of Spanish portrait artists
Go with time to see all the rehular exhibitions and the special ones too. Their regularvcollection is quite ample.
titleopinion: Very interesting. Nice collection of Spanish portrait artists Go with time to see all the rehular exhibitions and the special ones too. Their regularvcollection is quite ample.

reviewnospace: The couple who gave their art collection and planned this museum had an amazing appreciation for and an exquisite gift for selecting upcoming masters. I had a similar experience when I visited Peggy Guggenheim's house in Venice. I was able to experience a collector's personal vision and passion for works of art in a way that delights and astounds me. Loved it!
titleopinion: Fabulous Art Collection!. The couple who gave their art collection and planned this museum had an amazing appreciation for and an exquisite gift for selecting upcoming masters. I had a similar experience when I visited Peggy Guggenheim's house in Venice. I was able to experience a collector's personal vision and passion for works of art in a way that delights and astounds me. Loved it!

quote: One of the most beautiful museums in the world
reviewnospace: Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum is one of the "must go places" if you visit Madrid. Of course the entrance is expensive but, at the end, you will see that was a good waste of money. The main exposition is amazing. You will find the evolution of the peinture through great masters of this art. The impressionism room is my favourite. Here I can visit my favourite artist Degas. Picasso, Zubaran, Van Gogh, Matisse, Gauguin.... everyone is here.
titleopinion: One of the most beautiful museums in the world. Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum is one of the  must go places  if you visit Madrid. Of course the entrance is expensive but, at the end, you will see that was a good waste of money. The main exposition is amazing. You will find the evolution of the peinture through great masters of this art. The impressionism room is my favourite. Here I can visit my favourite artist Degas. Picasso, Zubaran, Van Gogh, Matisse, Gauguin.... everyone is here.

reviewnospace: The collection spans a very large period of time, and is consistently amazing. I especially found the more modern parts outstanding. In my opinion, Thyssen-Bornemisza is the best part of the golden triangle.
titleopinion: Amazing collection. The collection spans a very large period of time, and is consistently amazing. I especially found the more modern parts outstanding. In my opinion, Thyssen-Bornemisza is the best part of the golden triangle.

reviewnospace: What a collection! Very eclectic with works over several centuries. On top of the permanenet collection we. Were. Lucky to have a nice temporary exhibition
titleopinion: Extraordinary. What a collection! Very eclectic with works over several centuries. On top of the permanenet collection we. Were. Lucky to have a nice temporary exhibition

reviewnospace: We were in there around 2hrs & was pleased with the array of art being displayed, Although some not to our personal liking we would still come back.
titleopinion: Must see. We were in there around 2hrs & was pleased with the array of art being displayed, Although some not to our personal liking we would still come back.

reviewnospace: You can get a ticket which allows access to the three museums, thyssen, Prado and Sofia. Its about 26.50 which is a about 2 euro more then the cost of visiting only two museums. But even if you were only visiting two, it's still advantageous to buy the ticket as you can skip the queues. If you are planning evening or late afternoon visits it might not be cost effective as some are free after a certain time
titleopinion: Plenty to see. You can get a ticket which allows access to the three museums, thyssen, Prado and Sofia. Its about 26.50 which is a about 2 euro more then the cost of visiting only two museums. But even if you were only visiting two, it's still advantageous to buy the ticket as you can skip the queues. If you are planning evening or late afternoon visits it might not be cost effective as some are free after a certain time

reviewnospace:
The organisation, attentiveness and absolute concentration of all staff in their treatment of visitors to the museum to ensure the visits are enjoyable and complete is impeccable and faultless.
I went especially to see the Realists of Madrid Exhibition, which also turned out to be the best, most complete temporary exhibition I have ever visited, not only for its entirety, but also for its thorough management of visitor numbers, staging pre-booked slots, at no extra cost, which meant I could take my time and enjoy the exhibition, without crowds nor rush.
The Permanent Collection was outstanding and the Carmen Thyssen-Bornemisza Collection out of this world! Gazing at Picasso, Rubens, Rembrandt, Renoir, Monet, Vincent van Gogh, Degas, Hopper, Dali and Caravaggio amongst many many others in an afternoon is a cultural and life experience I will recommend to everyone I meet. Outstanding.
I ate lunch in the restaurant and was attended quickly and professionally, nothing too much trouble. There was a wide range of choice and price to suit all needs and appetites. I chose from the menu and the food was freshly cooked, and exquisite. A fantastic day out all round.
titleopinion: Best Museum I've ever visited.. The organisation, attentiveness and absolute concentration of all staff in their treatment of visitors to the museum to ensure the visits are enjoyable and complete is impeccable and faultless. I went especially to see the Realists of Madrid Exhibition, which also turned out to be the best, most complete temporary exhibition I have ever visited, not only for its entirety, but also for its thorough management of visitor numbers, staging pre-booked slots, at no extra cost, which meant I could take my time and enjoy the exhibition, without crowds nor rush.  The Permanent Collection was outstanding and the Carmen Thyssen-Bornemisza Collection out of this world! Gazing at Picasso, Rubens, Rembrandt, Renoir, Monet, Vincent van Gogh, Degas, Hopper, Dali and Caravaggio amongst many many others in an afternoon is a cultural and life experience I will recommend to everyone I meet. Outstanding. I ate lunch in the restaurant and was attended quickly and professionally, nothing too much trouble. There was a wide range of choice and price to suit all needs and appetites. I chose from the menu and the food was freshly cooked, and exquisite. A fantastic day out all round.

reviewnospace: The museum has a good collection of impressionism, modern and classical art. Give yourself a good 3-hour stay otherwise you will regret. Like the art shop at the museum, there is lots of art infused items and you can also print your favourite painting either on paper or canvas in the shop in 10 minutes and get it framed as well (this takes a week to do so).

quote: One of Principal museums of Spain
reviewnospace: If you like museums, you should see it , because it's second one after Museo Prado. In this museum you can see war times 'Obras' and some revistas and newspapers..
titleopinion: One of Principal museums of Spain . If you like museums, you should see it , because it's second one after Museo Prado. In this museum you can see war times 'Obras' and some revistas and newspapers..

reviewnospace: The collection contains many beautiful masterpieces and spans over several periods in the art history. For me it was a great experience

quote: One of the world's greatest galleries
reviewnospace: The range of art treasures in this gallery puts to shame the, perhaps more famous, galleries in London and Venice and Florence. The most impressive of the many spacious and beautiful rooms are devoted to Modern Art. I used to be a great admirer of the Guggenheim Museum in Venice and the Uffizi. But their art collections fade into near insignificance when compared to the works displayed in the the Thyssen. (In fact one of the penultimate rooms in the Thyssen - a kind of foot note to an extra-ordinary journey of discovery - contains art works by all the major artists making up the Venice Guggenheim collection.) A helpful handout identifies - to assist visitors - their top twenty art works. Though this may assist tourists in a hurry, almost anyone interested in art might choose a totally different twenty. Though the modern art on display is exceptional, the collection also contains a fine history of art starting with very early hints of the Renaissance in Italy and moving on through Dutch painting as it progresses towards the world of modernism. A fine feature of the early works is an emphasis on portraiture. And when we visited the Museum there was instant access and no need to queue.

quote: Another great art museum in Madrid
reviewnospace: This is an amazing private collection, beautifully laid out (with some paintings hung to advantage on orange walls.) The three floors are basically arranged chronologically. Start at the top with early European / medieval work (e.g. Holbein's stunning portrait of Henry VIII, Titian, Tintoretto, Caravaggio, Ribera), move through the Renaissance and down a flight to 18th, 19th, 20thC work (Tiepolo, a surprising Degas, gorgeous Hoppers, Bonnard, Picasso, Modigliani...), and down one more to 20thC abstraction and experimentation (more Picasso, Braque, Kupka,Kandinsky, Schwitters, Chagall, Dali, Rauschenberg.) It's also the best (only?) place in Madrid to see Impressionist paintings and 19C American landscapes. Thyssen-Bornemisza's wife Carmen became a collector in her own right and the sections in the museum bearing her name (the rooms designated by letters rather than numbers) also astonish. Unlike the Prado, where you can luxuriate in seeing scores of paintings by Goya, for instance, at the Thyssen you get a thorough excursion through the history of Western art with just a specimen or two from many great painters, famous and not. The temporary exhibit of contemporary Spanish realism that was on while we were there was also quite interesting --and fun to compare those still lifes to those by Zurbarán upstairs, painted some four centuries earlier. Plan for plenty of time here. You can take a break in the nice ground-floor restaurant.
titleopinion: Another great art museum in Madrid. This is an amazing private collection, beautifully laid out (with some paintings hung to advantage on orange walls.) The three floors are basically arranged chronologically. Start at the top with early European / medieval work (e.g. Holbein's stunning portrait of Henry VIII, Titian, Tintoretto, Caravaggio, Ribera), move through the Renaissance and down a flight to 18th, 19th, 20thC work (Tiepolo, a surprising Degas, gorgeous Hoppers, Bonnard, Picasso, Modigliani...), and down one more to 20thC abstraction and experimentation (more Picasso, Braque, Kupka,Kandinsky, Schwitters, Chagall, Dali, Rauschenberg.) It's also the best (only?) place in Madrid to see Impressionist paintings and 19C American landscapes. Thyssen-Bornemisza's wife Carmen became a collector in her own right and the sections in the museum bearing her name (the rooms designated by letters rather than numbers) also astonish. Unlike the Prado, where you can luxuriate in seeing scores of paintings by Goya, for instance, at the Thyssen you get a thorough excursion through the history of Western art with just a specimen or two from many great painters, famous and not. The temporary exhibit of contemporary Spanish realism that was on while we were there was also quite interesting --and fun to compare those still lifes to those by Zurbarán upstairs, painted some four centuries earlier. Plan for plenty of time here. You can take a break in the nice ground-floor restaurant.

quote: Yet another excellent museum in Madrid
reviewnospace:
This is a private collection, with a big range of displays ranging across several centuries including Old Masters and more modern artists. The works include Spain, Italy but also Dutch German French and other painters. Many American works too , and a lot from the Impressionist and Post Impressionist periods.

Notable paintings include Uccello, Fra ANgelico, Bellini, Caravaggio, Titian, Tintoretto, Ghirlandaio, Tiepolo. There are also works by Rembrandt, Van Dyck, Reubens, and many french works by Matisse, Gauguin, Cezanne, ReNOIR and Monet. Others notable include Degas , Van Gogh, Canaletto etc.

Well worth a visit . Again late evenings are free if you do not wish to pay for the tickets

reviewnospace: This art gallery near the Prado is a don't miss. A great collection of art from classical to modern times. Well worth a visit. Good audio guide
titleopinion: DOn't miss art gallery. This art gallery near the Prado is a don't miss. A great collection of art from classical to modern times. Well worth a visit. Good audio guide

reviewnospace:
If you only have time or the interest to do one museum this might be a better option than the Prado. It may be a case of less is more. The museum has very much smaller queues, is easier to find your way around and if you work your way from top to bottom then by the time you finish you will have had a good overview of major art movements and artists through the ages. It is worth noting that this was a private art collection. The family wealth must have been almost unimaginable!
If you are over 65 and have something to prove it you will get a substantial reduction in the entrance charge and as well as audio guides being available if you search online before you visit there is an excellent free app you can download.
Your ticket also seems to allow you to leave and return - but check on that before you do.
Although it is a smaller museum than the Prado there is lots to see and you could, legs, feet and interest permitting easily spend an entire day there.

reviewnospace:
If you are just in Madrid for a few days and can not spend all your time in larger museums, this is the place to go and spend a few hours. At last, a museum of art that is perfectly laid out, starting from primitive Italian art on the second floor and ending with pop art on the ground floor. All the paintings are displayed at eye level in beautifully lit rooms. While you may not see masterpieces you recognize, you will see pieces by just about every major artist you have ever heard of.
The ticket line moved fast and took just a few minutes. There was a temporary exhibition of Madrid realist art and most people seemed to be going there. Once inside the permanent collection there were very few people and no large groups.
Highly recommended!

Once inside the permanent collection there were very few people and no large groups. Highly recommended!

quote: Guernica by Picasso - A Must See
reviewnospace: We went to this museum at 7 pm when it is free. Even though there was a line to get in our major purpose was to see Picasso's Guernica - which he painted - showing the turmoil of the Spanish War in the 1930s. He definitely shows the bloodshed and devastation of the War. A beautiful painting with much expression.

quote: Gorgeous art and well laid out gallert
reviewnospace:
Laid out across three floors (we started at the top and worked out way down) this is a gem of a gallery featuring the incredible personal collection of the family. The cafe was excellent too.

There isn't long left for the Madrid Real temporary exhibit but I thoroughly recommend it if you get the chance.

reviewnospace:
This is a lovely gallery, small enough to see in 2-3 hours, but it has absolutely beautiful pieces, chosen with impeccable taste and love. There is something for everybody's liking: early Italians, Renaissanse, Dutch and Flemish painters, some superb Canaletto, El Greco, and then accomplished collection of 19-20 century art, of course French, but also German Spanish and American.
My absolute favourite of this collection is the masterpiece of Vittore Carpaccio "Knight in landscape". Every time I come here, I spend some time in enchanted, sad and enigmatic world of this picture….
Don't miss Renoir's landscape, Van Gogh, portraits by Edward Munch and J.S.Sargent, Maurice Deni and many more. Enjoy.

reviewnospace: Both floors travel in roughly chronological order from Renaissance through post-impressionism. This formally private collection is more majestic that the Barnes in Philadelphia.
titleopinion: Time Travel through Art History. Both floors travel in roughly chronological order from Renaissance through post-impressionism. This formally private collection is more majestic that the Barnes in Philadelphia.

reviewnospace: While visiting my son recently, who lives in Madrid, I had a couple of hours to spend while waiting for him to get off work and decided to see the Madrid Realists Temporary Exhibit. It was quite interesting, and right at 2 hours to view. It's a nice alternative to the grand Museo del Prado, which has long lines for entry, and is a vast collection of works. (If you have time, a must see, too) There were different ticket options available at the Thyssen, and I decided on viewing only the Temporary Exhibit. I was quite happy with my audio-guide and strolling at my own pace. I recommend catching the Temporary Exhibit being presented when you go. If you have or want more time at the Thyssen, choose the main museum and temporary exhibit tickets.

quote: Massive Collection, Not as Crowded as the Prado or Reina Sofia
reviewnospace: I was impressed about the massive collection of the Museo Thyssen-Bornemisza. It actually spans an enormeous scope from early religious art to very recent modern art. It´s a large Museum but not as overwhelming or crowded as the Prado or Reina Sofia and therefore ´easier ´to handle´ and manageable in half a day. Nevertheless it boasts numerous world famous works of art. Recommendation: buy your ticket pass for all three art Museums here. The queues are much shorter than at the others and hence you can skip the queues at Prado/Reina Sofia which will save you a lot of time.

reviewnospace: Absolute gobsmack! Make sure you have plenty of time to explore all 3 floors. So much to see. So much to take in. Wonderful and comprehensive collections of groups of painters - impressionists, post-impressionists, cubists, etc.

reviewnospace: Loved this museum- the permanent collection is excellent with great 20th Century art - Van Gough, Degas,Monet, Manet, Picasso, Hopper etc just brilliant. There was also a fabulous Madrid Realist exhibition on when I visited which was a movement I had not heard of before and blew me away! There was also a visiting exhibition of Wyatts from US, quite a treat! Highly recommend a visit here and preferred it to the nearby Prado!
titleopinion: Fantastic Museum of Art. Loved this museum- the permanent collection is excellent with great 20th Century art - Van Gough, Degas,Monet, Manet, Picasso, Hopper etc just brilliant. There was also a fabulous Madrid Realist exhibition on when I visited which was a movement I had not heard of before and blew me away! There was also a visiting exhibition of Wyatts from US, quite a treat! Highly recommend a visit here and preferred it to the nearby Prado!

quote: one of the best museums i have ever visited in the world
reviewnospace: if there was a 6 star rating, i would give it to this attraction- it is possibly one of the best collections of european art in one place that i have seen. Sympathetically displayed- with logic and structure- it is a sheer joy to walk around the three floors of fantastic art through the ages- an art lovers dream.

reviewnospace: There seemed to be something by everyone spanning hundreds of years.Well laid out and manageable in half a day
titleopinion: An amazing private collection. There seemed to be something by everyone spanning hundreds of years.Well laid out and manageable in half a day

reviewnospace:
Thoroughly enjoyed our visit to this museum. Had to pre-book a timed ticket as they only allow in a limited number of people at one time. This means that the rooms are not unduly crowded, all the better to enjoy the art.

It is best to start on the second floor as this contains the oldest paintings and then work ones way day to the first floor and the more modern works. Every well known painter seems to be represented, it is a truly amazing collection and well displayed too. Highly recommended.
titleopinion: Wonderful collection of art. Thoroughly enjoyed our visit to this museum. Had to pre-book a timed ticket as they only allow in a limited number of people at one time. quote: One of the finest art collections on the planet
reviewnospace: We are lukewarm art lovers but this was stunning. 700 year old tryptics an inch in front of your nose and many more modern pieces by famous artists which we had never seen. A must visit when in Madrid. In fact, worth a trip to Madrid for it.

We are lukewarm art lovers but this was stunning. 700 year old tryptics an inch in front of your nose and many more modern pieces by famous artists which we had never seen. reviewnospace: Hit in afternoon on Saturday. So many paintings under on roof. Got audio guide, a must. You can pick the period you like best and spend hours. Almost too much for one visit.
titleopinion: Amazing collection. Hit in afternoon on Saturday. So many paintings under on roof. Got audio guide, a must. You can pick the period you like best and spend hours. Almost too much for one visit.

quote: Interesting collection of modern and traditional art
reviewnospace: The building itself is gorgeous, the staff were very friendly, there were some gorgeous Picasso and Impressionist pieces to see. The museum itself is small enough to cover in a few hours so it's a good daytime activity. I felt its collection was better than the Prado and it was a much nicer, friendlier and more worthwhile place to visit.
titleopinion: Interesting collection of modern and traditional art. The building itself is gorgeous, the staff were very friendly, there were some gorgeous Picasso and Impressionist pieces to see. The museum itself is small enough to cover in a few hours so it's a good daytime activity. I felt its collection was better than the Prado and it was a much nicer, friendlier and more worthwhile place to visit.

reviewnospace: We enjoyed this museum as much or more as the Prado--the scale and collection are lovely. Not as encyclopedic a collection as the larger collection, but exquisite.
titleopinion: great collection. We enjoyed this museum as much or more as the Prado--the scale and collection are lovely. Not as encyclopedic a collection as the larger collection, but exquisite.

quote: Stimulating spread of widely different works.
reviewnospace: Far more interesting than the Prado, sensibly laid out, cool and spacious. Lots of paintings from different periods. Great to see well known paintings and then have your eye taken by an unknown masterpiece.
titleopinion: Stimulating spread of widely different works.. Far more interesting than the Prado, sensibly laid out, cool and spacious. Lots of paintings from different periods. Great to see well known paintings and then have your eye taken by an unknown masterpiece.

reviewnospace: A must see this museum. Great time looking at paintings. Liked it a lot more than the Prado Museum. Judge for yourself.
titleopinion: Liked it a lot. A must see this museum. Great time looking at paintings. Liked it a lot more than the Prado Museum. Judge for yourself.

reviewnospace: As planned we went to La Reina de Sofia Museum and were terribly disappointed. We're just not into modern art. So we decided to go to the Thyssen- Bornemisza which was so much better. It is a bright, spacious museum with art from many different eras. The displayed art is magnificent and we spent many happy hours enjoying the paintings.
titleopinion: Better. As planned we went to La Reina de Sofia Museum and were terribly disappointed. We're just not into modern art. So we decided to go to the Thyssen- Bornemisza which was so much better. It is a bright, spacious museum with art from many different eras. The displayed art is magnificent and we spent many happy hours enjoying the paintings.

reviewnospace: The third of the three major art museums in Madrid. Just north of the Prado Museum, across the street on Paseo del Prado
titleopinion: Thyssen Museum. The third of the three major art museums in Madrid. Just north of the Prado Museum, across the street on Paseo del Prado

reviewnospace: We enjoyed this museum almost as much as the Prado museum. So much to see - make sure one has at least 4 hours.
titleopinion: Awesome Museum!. We enjoyed this museum almost as much as the Prado museum. So much to see - make sure one has at least 4 hours.

quote: The best art gallery in Madrid
reviewnospace: For me this is by far and away the best gallery / museum in Madrid. Lots of different types of art, not just old masters (Prado) or modern art (Sofia Reina).
titleopinion: The best art gallery in Madrid. For me this is by far and away the best gallery / museum in Madrid. Lots of different types of art, not just old masters (Prado) or modern art (Sofia Reina).

reviewnospace: A very modern museum after the vaulted ceilings of the Prado. Huge collection covering paintings of every era. Particularly liked Canaletto , Rembrandt self portrait and Hopper. Small but clean and airy restaurant.
titleopinion: Interesting collection.. A very modern museum after the vaulted ceilings of the Prado. Huge collection covering paintings of every era. Particularly liked Canaletto , Rembrandt self portrait and Hopper. Small but clean and airy restaurant.

reviewnospace: One of the biggest private art collection, and probably the most important one. XIV century pictures, and incredible impressionist collection, Lichtenstein, Rothko... You must visit it if you've never been.
titleopinion: All ages art. One of the biggest private art collection, and probably the most important one. XIV century pictures, and incredible impressionist collection, Lichtenstein, Rothko... You must visit it if you've never been.

reviewnospace: I enjoyed this museum very much. Considering that it was essentially a private collection---the 2 Barons Thyssen-Bornemisza, and Carmen Thyssen-Bornemisza---the number and variety of paintings is nothing short of amazing. Ranging from the 13th century to the late 20th century, just about every type, style, artist, and subject matter is represented. Of course, not everyone will be interested in everything---I'm not fond of the ancient religious paintings, but was impressed that so many were included and beautifully preserved. It was fascinating to see clearly how art has evolved. I found many favorites that spoke to me, some familiar, others exciting revelations. The setting is austere and soothing, and though there were many people there, it never felt over-crowded. You can take pictures without flash in the permanent collection, so don't hesitate to record your favorites. Relax and take as much or as little time as you'd like---though it would seem a shame to rush. The entrance fee is reasonable (I paid 8 euros with a senior discount), for such an enjoyable experience.
titleopinion: Wonderful museum. I enjoyed this museum very much. Considering that it was essentially a private collection---the 2 Barons Thyssen-Bornemisza, and Carmen Thyssen-Bornemisza---the number and variety of paintings is nothing short of amazing. Ranging from the 13th century to the late 20th century, just about every type, style, artist, and subject matter is represented. Of course, not everyone will be interested in everything---I'm not fond of the ancient religious paintings, but was impressed that so many were included and beautifully preserved. It was fascinating to see clearly how art has evolved. I found many favorites that spoke to me, some familiar, others exciting revelations. The setting is austere and soothing, and though there were many people there, it never felt over-crowded. You can take pictures without flash in the permanent collection, so don't hesitate to record your favorites. Relax and take as much or as little time as you'd like---though it would seem a shame to rush. The entrance fee is reasonable (I paid 8 euros with a senior discount), for such an enjoyable experience.

reviewnospace: While visiting Madrid, you probably go to the Prado (which you should do) and the centro de Arte Reina Sofía to see the famous Guernica. But make sure that you also pay a visit to the museo Thyssen Bornemisza, This museum presents an incredible array of works of art from the 13th to the 20th Century. The building itself is very spacious, so you can take your time to watch the masterpieces that hold your interest (of great names such as Caravaggio, Rubens, Van Dyck, Rembrandt, Frans Hals, Jan Steen, Canaletto, Gainsborough, de Goya, Renoir, Manet, Monet, Sisley, Bonnard, Gauguin, van Gogh, John Singer Sargent, Winslow Homer, Matisse, Picasso, Kirchner, Kokoschka, Dalí, Chagall, Klee, Rothko, Hockney, Bacon, Karel Appel, Lucian Freud... I have never seen my teenager daughter so engrossed!
titleopinion: Truly magnificent. While visiting Madrid, you probably go to the Prado (which you should do) and the centro de Arte Reina Sofía to see the famous Guernica. But make sure that you also pay a visit to the museo Thyssen Bornemisza, This museum presents an incredible array of works of art from the 13th to the 20th Century. The building itself is very spacious, so you can take your time to watch the masterpieces that hold your interest (of great names such as Caravaggio, Rubens, Van Dyck, Rembrandt, Frans Hals, Jan Steen, Canaletto, Gainsborough, de Goya, Renoir, Manet, Monet, Sisley, Bonnard, Gauguin, van Gogh, John Singer Sargent, Winslow Homer, Matisse, Picasso, Kirchner, Kokoschka, Dalí, Chagall, Klee, Rothko, Hockney, Bacon, Karel Appel, Lucian Freud... I have never seen my teenager daughter so engrossed!

reviewnospace: Great Museum. Lot's of modern art and classical. Not as stuffy as others. Great place to see beautiful pieces of art that would make your heart smile.
titleopinion: Almost better than Prado. Great Museum. Lot's of modern art and classical. Not as stuffy as others. Great place to see beautiful pieces of art that would make your heart smile.

reviewnospace:
This gallery once used to be the second largest private art collection, after the British Royal Collection. Now it's a museum and it's a great one!

I liked Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum more than I liked Prado, firstly because it's smaller and less tiring, secondly because the rooms are more "friendly" and the lighting is really good and thirdly because it contains works of art from more periods. Even though it's considerably smaller than Prado, it still makes up for a 1-2 hours duration, also depending on your visiting pace. You'll find here paintings from artists like Monet, Tiziano and Picasso. What I liked the best are the Renessaince paintings the museum has, they are simply amazing.

Totally worth a visit!
titleopinion: Beautiful. This gallery once used to be the second largest private art collection, after the British Royal Collection. Now it's a museum and it's a great one!  I liked Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum more than I liked Prado, firstly because it's smaller and less tiring, secondly because the rooms are more  friendly  and the lighting is really good and thirdly because it contains works of art from more periods. Even though it's considerably smaller than Prado, it still makes up for a 1-2 hours duration, also depending on your visiting pace. You'll find here paintings from artists like Monet, Tiziano and Picasso. What I liked the best are the Renessaince paintings the museum has, they are simply amazing.  Totally worth a visit!

reviewnospace: do not miss this great museum, I liked it much better than the Prado and the ReinaSofia museum of modern art, do not miss this one
titleopinion: better than prado. do not miss this great museum, I liked it much better than the Prado and the ReinaSofia museum of modern art, do not miss this one

quote: Something for all and its free on a Monday
reviewnospace: Only in Madrid for a couple of days visiting my son and so didn't take in all the culture but as this museum was free to enter on Monday afternoons, we popped along. A huge well laid out collection of works. Personally, classical art isn't really my thing but if you enjoy it, there is so much to see. There is some more modern stuff and Lichtenstein's Woman in Bath was probably my favourite. The Josephine Douet photography exhibition (The Secret Sits) was an utter highlight for me. Inspired by the works of Andrew Wyeth, these photographs really spoke to me - so much so I bought the book in the ubiquitous gift shop.

quote: A great art gallery that offers a bit of everything
reviewnospace:
It may seem grange that there is another art gallery so close to the Prada but this is really different because the range of pictures is greater and once you start at the top you work your way through time to the modern day on the ground floor. The audio guides are good and two people can listen together if you don't mind cozying up a bit. The main exception to the chronological arrangement is the special new collection on the top floor and in this group can be found some wonderful modern works.
Unlike some Spanish attractions there are numerous loose and the cafe is not as formal as it might seem while you wait for the MD to take your to your table.
The museum has a number of special exhibitions but I doubt whether you could do these justice if you are trying to take in the regular collection on the same day. If I lived here I would be in this gallery on a regular basis just enjoying the collection.

reviewnospace:
We spend the whole morning at the museum and it was worth every minute of it. The exposition Madrid Realists was breath taking and filled me with nostalgia of the city and its people, so close to you. Andrew and Jamie Wyeth were refreshing and proved to be most interesting which we enjoyed throughly.
The permament collection of Carmen Thyseen Bornemisza was unexpecting large and wide in range, beatiful. We were saturated and could not cover everthing but will return another day.
When we left our spirits were high and full thanks to all these works of the great artists.

quote: Stunning collection almost too much to take in
reviewnospace: Free on Mondays 12.00-16.00 but no access to the temporary exhibitions and 12 euros the rest of the time, this has got to be one of the best value museums in Europe. What a fantastic collection covering centuries of work across a host of genres and containing most people's favourites from Gaugin to Van Gogh, Hopper to Munch, Dali to Picasso, Renoir, Tizian to Tinterretto. I shall return again and again to try and absorb in bite sized chunks, some of my favourite pieces of art.

reviewnospace: This museum is definitely worth a visit. The depth of the collection is really impressive. So many of my favorite artists in one place, it was almost too much to take in.

quote: Lovely Museo right across the street from the park a short walk from the Plaza Del Sol
reviewnospace: The museum was great! It was about 12 Euros to get in plus another 4 for the audio tour in English. Money well spent.

reviewnospace: I was very impressed by this diverse museum. With works ranging from antiquity to more modern there is really something for everyone. I would highly recommend spending at least 2 hours if possible, but actually this museum merits multiple visits to process it all. If you are an art-lover do not miss the Thyssen-Bornemsza!

reviewnospace:
This is for me the best museum in Madrid if you are very short in time and you are looking for Art History thought excellent paintings.
The collection is excellent in any sense and the temporary exhibitions are always brilliant. You can find much better specific period/themes museums in Madrid, but none with such a wild range of quality paintings.
Enjoy it!

reviewnospace: nice collection of classics and modern art plus contemporary temporary exhibitions of Spanish artists. Very nice museum. A must for art lovers
titleopinion: Modern and contemporary art. nice collection of classics and modern art plus contemporary temporary exhibitions of Spanish artists. Very nice museum. A must for art lovers

quote: Start here! Cover most artists, genres and periods in one museum.
reviewnospace:
Of all three major museums in the golden art triangle (which also include museo Nacional del Prado & Sofia Reina, located nearby) this is the one I liked best.
I decided to start my rounds here, both to get my Paseo del Arte ticket (pass to all 3 museums, as I figured the lines are longest at the Prado) and to get a glimpse of all artists and periods in one visit to get an idea of what I'd like to see more of later. I was right - and recommend the same strategy for others. The lines at Prado can go around the block, at least when it is free 2h before closing. At Thyssen-Bornemisza there were no lines at all in the day, and very quiet and roomy to take it all in. Photography is allowed, and you can get very close to the art to see details and techniques. Ranging from El Greco and Caravaggio to modern art, it is all here from all over the world. For families, I suggest to opt for this more managable and varied one over the Prado which can be overwhelming, and the Sofia which can be too abstract, experimental and boring.
titleopinion: Start here! Cover most artists, genres and periods in one museum.. quote: Must have been good because it was crowded

reviewnospace: After our disappointment with the Prado, my wife noticed the signs that the Wyeths were being exhibeted at the Thyssen. It is accross the street from the Prado and was a breath of fresh air. After laboring to get through the confusing Prado, this is the go to museum in Madrid.
