Lived the gadget on the table in the cafe.. To get the waiters attention or ask for the bill  Very efficient

quote: From Iconic Paintings to Pop Art
reviewnospace: The Thyssen (as locals call it) has an impressive collection of paintings which is set up in chronological order (beginning from the top floor), starting with the middle age religious paintings over impressionists, expressionist, cubism, to Pop Art. One of the top 3 museums in Madrid and just across from the Prado. They also hold very good temporary exhibitions.
titleopinion: From Iconic Paintings to Pop Art. The Thyssen (as locals call it) has an impressive collection of paintings which is set up in chronological order (beginning from the top floor), starting with the middle age religious paintings over impressionists, expressionist, cubism, to Pop Art. One of the top 3 museums in Madrid and just across from the Prado. They also hold very good temporary exhibitions.

reviewnospace: What can nobody say about one of the bigest privates collections of art. Won be left indiferent. Must-see destination.
titleopinion: Unbelieveble. What can nobody say about one of the bigest privates collections of art. Won be left indiferent. Must-see destination.

reviewnospace: This is a massive and comprehensive collection of modern art. It is well laid out and can be an all day adventure or take a couple of hours, depending on how long you are captivated! I love that they allow pictures to be taken.
titleopinion: Amazing collection of modern art. This is a massive and comprehensive collection of modern art. It is well laid out and can be an all day adventure or take a couple of hours, depending on how long you are captivated! I love that they allow pictures to be taken.

reviewnospace: This museum is a beautiful antidote to the ancient masters at the Prado - but still a great place to access amazing art! take the time and discover!
titleopinion: Great museum - different spectrum. This museum is a beautiful antidote to the ancient masters at the Prado - but still a great place to access amazing art! take the time and discover!

quote: Huge range of artists not often seen in UK
reviewnospace: Much more manageable than the Prado, it has a great selection of masterpieces from al, periods, including by artists not well represented in Britain. German expressionists (Beckmann, Grosz) and American landscape painters of the 19th century. Two interesting exhibitions while we were there - the Wyeth family and Madrid Realists, both well presented. The cafe is excellent and s good place to break up the visit.
titleopinion: Huge range of artists not often seen in UK. Much more manageable than the Prado, it has a great selection of masterpieces from al, periods, including by artists not well represented in Britain. German expressionists (Beckmann, Grosz) and American landscape painters of the 19th century. Two interesting exhibitions while we were there - the Wyeth family and Madrid Realists, both well presented. The cafe is excellent and s good place to break up the visit.

reviewnospace: Lovely artworks complementing the Prado. There seemed to be many more Dutch paintings here and it was good to be able to take photos of pieces I liked. Definitely worth the visit if you have time after the Prado
titleopinion: another great museum worth visiting. Lovely artworks complementing the Prado. There seemed to be many more Dutch paintings here and it was good to be able to take photos of pieces I liked. Definitely worth the visit if you have time after the Prado

reviewnospace: We didn't realize the extent of the collection. It is extremely good quality as well as large. We discovered quality 19th and 20th century artists we did not previously know. Well worth a visit.
titleopinion: More overwhelming than the Prado . We didn't realize the extent of the collection. It is extremely good quality as well as large. We discovered quality 19th and 20th century artists we did not previously know. Well worth a visit.

reviewnospace: The Prado is great but this museum has a far greater collection of more contemporary pieces, from Dutch to Impressionist to Modern.... Photos are allowed and everyone was doing their best to capture the incredible array of familiar works displayed. The museum is easy to get around with detailed guides available.
titleopinion: DO NOT MISS!!!. The Prado is great but this museum has a far greater collection of more contemporary pieces, from Dutch to Impressionist to Modern.... Photos are allowed and everyone was doing their best to capture the incredible array of familiar works displayed. The museum is easy to get around with detailed guides available.

quote: One of the best Art collections I have ever seen
reviewnospace: Just amazing. I do like a bit of art and I hadn't seen this collection. It is missing do blowing. Beautifully displayed. Some of the greats that you would not see anywhere else. Especially thrilled to see the famous Rembrant self portrait. Don't miss it if you love art.
titleopinion: One of the best Art collections I have ever seen. Just amazing. I do like a bit of art and I hadn't seen this collection. It is missing do blowing. Beautifully displayed. Some of the greats that you would not see anywhere else. Especially thrilled to see the famous Rembrant self portrait. Don't miss it if you love art.

reviewnospace: The order, range and quality of these collections are incredible. I hadn't considered a visit here but am glad we did. A great story of art, major pieces and the influence of the greats on others. A great gift shop too.
titleopinion: Astounding collection . The order, range and quality of these collections are incredible. I hadn't considered a visit here but am glad we did. A great story of art, major pieces and the influence of the greats on others. A great gift shop too.

quote: Private museum. Very interesting (for a fee)
reviewnospace: It has a very interesting collection of paintings, from Romanesque style to modern art. It is very complete. It has all the year very interesting temporary exhibitions. There is one single disadvantage: it is a private museum, it costs from 8 to 10 euros to access. If you are in Madrid only one time, it deserves be visited.
titleopinion: Private museum. Very interesting (for a fee). It has a very interesting collection of paintings, from Romanesque style to modern art. It is very complete. It has all the year very interesting temporary exhibitions. There is one single disadvantage: it is a private museum, it costs from 8 to 10 euros to access. If you are in Madrid only one time, it deserves be visited.

reviewnospace:
Whilst the Prado is a wonderful museum, as we had young children with us we decided we should visit a museum that was on a younger person scale.
The Thyssen museum turned out to be perfectly doable. The permanent exhibition covers 3 walkable floors with a great range of old masters as well as modern 20th century art which our youngster found most interesting.
The three main floors are walkable in a couple of hours with a great variety of art work that kept all of us engaged.
There were a couple of temporary exhibitions available that were at an additional cost which we decided not to see. And with our 7 year old the 2hours spent on the main floors was perfect.
There is a good cafe on site that serves great cake, tea coffee etc and there is also the obligatory gift shop.
This is a great little museum that will take around half a day to visit and is well worth the time.
titleopinion: An afternoon of culture . Whilst the Prado is a wonderful museum, as we had young children with us we decided we should visit a museum that was on a younger person scale.  The Thyssen museum turned out to be perfectly doable. The permanent exhibition covers 3 walkable floors with a great range of old masters as well as modern 20th century art which our youngster found most interesting. The three main floors are walkable in a couple of hours with a great variety of art work that kept all of us engaged. There were a couple of temporary exhibitions available that were at an additional cost which we decided not to see. And with our 7 year old the 2hours spent on the main floors was perfect. There is a good cafe on site that serves great cake, tea coffee etc and there is also the obligatory gift shop. This is a great little museum that will take around half a day to visit and is well worth the time.

reviewnospace: The Thyssen Museum is beautiful - the building itself is like a piece of art. The privately-assembled collection is stunning, with key pieces spanning 700 years from pre-Renaissance to modern. The collection also displays great taste - this is not a place that displays mediocre pieces just because they were acquired. The cafe is very nice, and a great place to have lunch if your visit spans that timeframe.
titleopinion: A must for art lovers. The Thyssen Museum is beautiful - the building itself is like a piece of art. The privately-assembled collection is stunning, with key pieces spanning 700 years from pre-Renaissance to modern. The collection also displays great taste - this is not a place that displays mediocre pieces just because they were acquired. The cafe is very nice, and a great place to have lunch if your visit spans that timeframe.

quote: Must to visit while in Madrid
reviewnospace: The best thing to do is to just make a line instead of taking a tour. The lines go fast and the cost is much better. The entrance is 7Euros for seniors.
titleopinion: Must to visit while in Madrid. The best thing to do is to just make a line instead of taking a tour. The lines go fast and the cost is much better. The entrance is 7Euros for seniors.

quote: Little Bit of Culture Goes a Long Way
reviewnospace: This museum packs some great works in a tidy little package. While I'm not an expert art lover (far from it), the organization of pieces seems very logical and the space provides ample room for pondering pieces or meandering among them. We meandered, pondered, and loved it.
titleopinion: Little Bit of Culture Goes a Long Way. This museum packs some great works in a tidy little package. While I'm not an expert art lover (far from it), the organization of pieces seems very logical and the space provides ample room for pondering pieces or meandering among them. We meandered, pondered, and loved it.

reviewnospace: very popular gallery full of art of many styles and nationalities. There is so much here there must be something for every taste. It was extremely popular on the day we visited and indeed we were able to lose four hours here without being ware of the time passing. Very glad that seating provided to enable extended appreciation and a rest for weary feet!
titleopinion: extremely interesting museum. very popular gallery full of art of many styles and nationalities. There is so much here there must be something for every taste. It was extremely popular on the day we visited and indeed we were able to lose four hours here without being ware of the time passing. Very glad that seating provided to enable extended appreciation and a rest for weary feet!

reviewnospace: Not as enormous as the Prado, it's more accessible and also less overwhelming so in some ways a nicer visit. Many fantastic items in the collection - enough to enjoy over several visits - and pleasant though very inefficient gift shop. On a rainy day it was possible to get in here quite quickly, when the queue for the Prado was half the way down the street, but the smallish cafe was overwhelmed by the demand when it was impossible to sit outside.
titleopinion: huge and varied collection. Not as enormous as the Prado, it's more accessible and also less overwhelming so in some ways a nicer visit. Many fantastic items in the collection - enough to enjoy over several visits - and pleasant though very inefficient gift shop. On a rainy day it was possible to get in here quite quickly, when the queue for the Prado was half the way down the street, but the smallish cafe was overwhelmed by the demand when it was impossible to sit outside.

reviewnospace:
Change every so often, but has some of the best art.in Europe.
Of Course , you will like it more or less if the artist is the kind you like or not,
But always the best. Enjoy it.
titleopinion: Excelent Museum.. Change every so often, but has some of the best art.in Europe. Of Course , you will like it more or less if the artist is the kind you like or not,  But always the best. Enjoy it.

reviewnospace: Loved this place and the way it is set up. Strolling and enjoying the fantastic collections of art was a perfect way to spend the afternoon.
titleopinion: Great museum. Loved this place and the way it is set up. Strolling and enjoying the fantastic collections of art was a perfect way to spend the afternoon.

reviewnospace: I would take two separate visits to do the Thyssen-Bornemisza justice. Quite a lot to see in one visit. The bustling indoor/ outdoor cafe was great following our museum visit.
titleopinion: First visit September 2015. I would take two separate visits to do the Thyssen-Bornemisza justice. Quite a lot to see in one visit. The bustling indoor/ outdoor cafe was great following our museum visit.

reviewnospace: My husband and I enjoyed the Thyssen more than the Prado. The art was more vivid, vibrant and upbeat. We tend to prefer Cezanne over Gaudi. Crowded but not overwhelming and a good size, not exhausting. Very enjoyable.
titleopinion: Vibrant. My husband and I enjoyed the Thyssen more than the Prado. The art was more vivid, vibrant and upbeat. We tend to prefer Cezanne over Gaudi. Crowded but not overwhelming and a good size, not exhausting. Very enjoyable.

reviewnospace: This is my favorite museum in Madrid. The richness of the collection is amazing. One of the most important museums in Europe
titleopinion: My favorite museum in Madrid. This is my favorite museum in Madrid. The richness of the collection is amazing. One of the most important museums in Europe

reviewnospace: This is an awesome museum! Give yourself plenty of time to see all of the incredible art. We weren't expecting this! Better than the Louvre or the Orsay.
titleopinion: Our favorite museum!. This is an awesome museum! Give yourself plenty of time to see all of the incredible art. We weren't expecting this! Better than the Louvre or the Orsay.

reviewnospace: Probably the fourth time I've been here. It was one if the first museum that introduced me to art history since the collection covers pretty much everything from the quattrocento up to pop art. Definitely a must if you are visiting Madrid
titleopinion: Adoro!. Probably the fourth time I've been here. It was one if the first museum that introduced me to art history since the collection covers pretty much everything from the quattrocento up to pop art. Definitely a must if you are visiting Madrid

reviewnospace: Take your time and enjoy seeing the various eras of great artists. Just looking at the lighting of the old Dutch masters was stunning. And always a treat to see works by familiar artists who have pieces one can only see here. Come early when it opens to avoid groups and crowds.
titleopinion: Art lovers heaven. Take your time and enjoy seeing the various eras of great artists. Just looking at the lighting of the old Dutch masters was stunning. And always a treat to see works by familiar artists who have pieces one can only see here. Come early when it opens to avoid groups and crowds.

reviewnospace: Great museum! Tremendous variety! Magnificent Expressionist and Impressionist paintings. A special treat for my wife and I who happen to be from Pennsylvania and have visited the Brandywine Museum numerous times was the spectacular temporary exhibit of works by Andrew and Jamie Wyeth.
titleopinion: Don't miss it. Great museum! Tremendous variety! Magnificent Expressionist and Impressionist paintings. A special treat for my wife and I who happen to be from Pennsylvania and have visited the Brandywine Museum numerous times was the spectacular temporary exhibit of works by Andrew and Jamie Wyeth.

quote: Such Glorious Work , But the Museum Makes you Work for it !
reviewnospace: Beware. This Museum as paintings by Masters and Masterworks that you never seen. But try and make sense of the installations and you will go crazy. Best just to go with it as it comes and not try to chase down all of the paintings of an era or all of a certain artist- it's too exhausting. Not a visitor friendly museum despite its ample space and knock out work. This museum needs at least two days, and pace yourself even so..
titleopinion: Such Glorious Work , But the Museum Makes you Work for it !. Beware. This Museum as paintings by Masters and Masterworks that you never seen. But try and make sense of the installations and you will go crazy. Best just to go with it as it comes and not try to chase down all of the paintings of an era or all of a certain artist- it's too exhausting. Not a visitor friendly museum despite its ample space and knock out work. This museum needs at least two days, and pace yourself even so..

quote: Vast collection of paintings, free entrance on Mondays
reviewnospace: Ranging from the 15th century masterpieces all the way to the pop art and surrealists of the mid 20th century, this museum is a must visit for every art lover. The upper floors represent the older paintings so if you are more interested in more contemporary pieces, start from the level 0 up. This way you won't get exhausted before finding that Miro or Dali painting.
titleopinion: Vast collection of paintings, free entrance on Mondays. Ranging from the 15th century masterpieces all the way to the pop art and surrealists of the mid 20th century, this museum is a must visit for every art lover. The upper floors represent the older paintings so if you are more interested in more contemporary pieces, start from the level 0 up. This way you won't get exhausted before finding that Miro or Dali painting.

reviewnospace: My wife and I visited the Thyssen Museum and saw two good exhibitions. The first exhibition was Madrid Realists and showed the work of artists who painted scenes like photographs. The second show was about Andrew and Jamie Wyeth, two well known American painters. Both exhibitions were quite educational.
titleopinion: Good Exhibitions. My wife and I visited the Thyssen Museum and saw two good exhibitions. The first exhibition was Madrid Realists and showed the work of artists who painted scenes like photographs. The second show was about Andrew and Jamie Wyeth, two well known American painters. Both exhibitions were quite educational.

quote: This appears as Royal Palace review. Please correct.
reviewnospace: Your web has confused my review of the Thyssen museum with a review of the Royal Palace, which I did not review. Please correct this error.
titleopinion: This appears as Royal Palace review. Please correct.. Your web has confused my review of the Thyssen museum with a review of the Royal Palace, which I did not review. Please correct this error.

reviewnospace: Fantastic privately assembled art collection affording us to view masterpieces by Titian, Goya, Van Goh and Picasso. Truly a wonderful way to spend an afternoobn
titleopinion: Amazing Collection. Fantastic privately assembled art collection affording us to view masterpieces by Titian, Goya, Van Goh and Picasso. Truly a wonderful way to spend an afternoobn

reviewnospace: Maybe more manageable than the Prado but still full of beautiful and historic works of art. Well worth a visit.
titleopinion: Another lovely museum. Maybe more manageable than the Prado but still full of beautiful and historic works of art. Well worth a visit.

reviewnospace: Prado is great but this is my favorite museum in Madrid by a wide margin. Great pieces, great lighting, a really nice mix of old and more modern. Great way to spend a day. Only wish is that it were easier to get into the temporary expo. Other than that, perfect.
titleopinion: My favorite. Prado is great but this is my favorite museum in Madrid by a wide margin. Great pieces, great lighting, a really nice mix of old and more modern. Great way to spend a day. Only wish is that it were easier to get into the temporary expo. Other than that, perfect.

reviewnospace: This museum has a wonderful collection of paintings from Renoir, Pissarro, Monet, Degas, van Gogh, Cézanne, O'Keeffe, just to name a few. When I visited there was a temporary exhibition about Andrew and Jamie Wyeth, absolutely spectacular.
titleopinion: Must See!. This museum has a wonderful collection of paintings from Renoir, Pissarro, Monet, Degas, van Gogh, Cézanne, O'Keeffe, just to name a few. When I visited there was a temporary exhibition about Andrew and Jamie Wyeth, absolutely spectacular.

quote: Great collection in a good museum
reviewnospace:
Great contemporary collection downstairs, on the 1st impressionist and romantics, to the 2nd floor housing the more mundane religious portraits. Nice building. Experience is slightly spoilt by the ticketing system. Once you have visited the ground floor you come back to the lobby where you have to queue again. A number of people were showing there stamped tickets to move to the elevator, but an extremely rude lady will ensure no one gets through. The actual ticket lady seems nice and then simply waves you through!
Also a warning, the complete 'full' admission ticket is not 'full'! To see the current exhibitions you will pay the same price again. Not well advertised.
What is a fantastic museum with some beautiful pieces and collections is let down by the most inane aspects of simply running a museum.
titleopinion: Great collection in a good museum. Great contemporary collection downstairs, on the 1st impressionist and romantics, to the 2nd floor housing the more mundane religious portraits. Nice building. Experience is slightly spoilt by the ticketing system. Once you have visited the ground floor you come back to the lobby where you have to queue again. A number of people were showing there stamped tickets to move to the elevator, but an extremely rude lady will ensure no one gets through. The actual ticket lady seems nice and then simply waves you through!  Also a warning, the complete 'full' admission ticket is not 'full'! To see the current exhibitions you will pay the same price again. Not well advertised. What is a fantastic museum with some beautiful pieces and collections is let down by the most inane aspects of simply running a museum.

quote: Great collection, like an art history book
reviewnospace: Covers a great deal of styles and time periods. For someone who wants an introduction to art this is a perfect collection. Thoroughly enjoyed the museum, well laid out. Being from Montana USA was happily surprised to see a Charles M Russell painting. I highly recommend this museum.
titleopinion: Great collection, like an art history book. Covers a great deal of styles and time periods. For someone who wants an introduction to art this is a perfect collection. Thoroughly enjoyed the museum, well laid out. Being from Montana USA was happily surprised to see a Charles M Russell painting. I highly recommend this museum.

quote: Unexpected highlight of our trip to Madrid
reviewnospace: We visited this museum on the last day of our trip and found it to be our favorite of all the great sites in Madrid. It was easy to manage in a few hours and held a great variety of lesser known works of many famous artists. Don't miss it!
titleopinion: Unexpected highlight of our trip to Madrid. We visited this museum on the last day of our trip and found it to be our favorite of all the great sites in Madrid. It was easy to manage in a few hours and held a great variety of lesser known works of many famous artists. Don't miss it!

quote: Great collection covering a broad range of era and styles, and a modern, well lit building.
reviewnospace: We spent a day in Madrid during a holiday and Spain, and had an hour to visit this collection - it was far too little time. It is a great collection, covering a broad range of subject, era and style well displayed in a modern and well lit building. Worth spending several sessions over a number of days.
titleopinion: Great collection covering a broad range of era and styles, and a modern, well lit building.. We spent a day in Madrid during a holiday and Spain, and had an hour to visit this collection - it was far too little time. It is a great collection, covering a broad range of subject, era and style well displayed in a modern and well lit building. Worth spending several sessions over a number of days.

reviewnospace: A great collection of art. Get there early and partly avoid the crowds (at mid-day you almost have to elbow your way). Some impressive paintings from all periods and many artists. Also some nice exhibitions besides the permanent display.
titleopinion: Classic museum. A great collection of art. Get there early and partly avoid the crowds (at mid-day you almost have to elbow your way). Some impressive paintings from all periods and many artists. Also some nice exhibitions besides the permanent display.

reviewnospace: paintings in this museum are excellent, a lot of very famous authors have their work here, I very much liked
titleopinion: like paintings. paintings in this museum are excellent, a lot of very famous authors have their work here, I very much liked

reviewnospace: A wonderful collection, in my view the best in Madrid. Well laid out, great building and fabulous art. What more could you want?
titleopinion: Amazing. A wonderful collection, in my view the best in Madrid. Well laid out, great building and fabulous art. What more could you want?

reviewnospace: This privately sources collection covers a broad and surprising range. Easily spent several hours here and still did not cover it all. Did it without audio guide but would possibly re think this if we return
titleopinion: A fantastic art collection . This privately sources collection covers a broad and surprising range. Easily spent several hours here and still did not cover it all. Did it without audio guide but would possibly re think this if we return

reviewnospace: So much art - I'd say the best way to tackle it would be an hour and a half a day over at least 5 days.
titleopinion: mind blowing. So much art - I'd say the best way to tackle it would be an hour and a half a day over at least 5 days.

reviewnospace: Gigantic art gallery with wide range of work to view. No queue to get in, entry price seemed fair, easy to walk around and not too crowded. Peaceful and good facilities. Some famous artists but no 'wow' moments for me in terms of the works we saw. Our favourite was the Hopper sailing picture.
titleopinion: Huge collection and easily accessible. Gigantic art gallery with wide range of work to view. No queue to get in, entry price seemed fair, easy to walk around and not too crowded. Peaceful and good facilities. Some famous artists but no 'wow' moments for me in terms of the works we saw. Our favourite was the Hopper sailing picture.

reviewnospace: This museum might just eclipse the Prado. It is one of the worlds most exceptional private collections. The collection comprises 1 or several paintings from most of the great Western artists from medieval times through 2000. Almost every painting is a masterpiece!
titleopinion: Amazing Museum. This museum might just eclipse the Prado. It is one of the worlds most exceptional private collections. The collection comprises 1 or several paintings from most of the great Western artists from medieval times through 2000. Almost every painting is a masterpiece!

reviewnospace:
It is located just in the opposite side of Prado museum. So, there is no reason not to visit here after/before visiting the Prado. Of course, I recommend to visit here after the Prado, as you can easily access this museum than the Prado.
Its garden is also beautiful.
titleopinion: Hidden gem? no well-known gem !!!. It is located just in the opposite side of Prado museum. So, there is no reason not to visit here after/before visiting the Prado. Of course, I recommend to visit here after the Prado, as you can easily access this museum than the Prado. Its garden is also beautiful.

reviewnospace: Hundreds of familiar artists and paintings. Loved the range. Picasso, Renoir, Estes, Degas, Canaletto. Well arranged and accessible.
titleopinion: Worth a visit. Hundreds of familiar artists and paintings. Loved the range. Picasso, Renoir, Estes, Degas, Canaletto. Well arranged and accessible.

reviewnospace:
Went on the free day and time Monday from 12 to 4 p.m. There was a long line outside and around the corner but once the museum opened it was very fast to enter.
Incredible collection of impressionists, many which are not so well known since most people see the ones in Paris. Rembrandt self-portrait and van Goghs I have never seen highlights. Shop interesting if a bit narrow and crowded.
titleopinion: Amazing collections. Went on the free day and time Monday from 12 to 4 p.m. There was a long line outside and around the corner but once the museum opened it was very fast to enter.  Incredible collection of impressionists, many which are not so well known since most people see the ones in Paris. Rembrandt self-portrait and van Goghs I have never seen highlights. Shop interesting if a bit narrow and crowded.

reviewnospace: If you like artists such as Henri Matisse, this museum is the place you want to go. The private collection is impressive, and it is even free on Monday.
titleopinion: Great private collection of masterpieces. If you like artists such as Henri Matisse, this museum is the place you want to go. The private collection is impressive, and it is even free on Monday.

reviewnospace: Nice museum, great art collection with more variety then the Prado. The exposition is set up in a nice way which makes it easy to stroll through the museum and see everything.
titleopinion: Nice collection!. Nice museum, great art collection with more variety then the Prado. The exposition is set up in a nice way which makes it easy to stroll through the museum and see everything.

reviewnospace:
They told us 2 hours to get through it with headset but it talkes much longer.
We went to lunch and came back with 2.5 hours till closing and we rushed through a lot of it and still missed an entire floor - Please leave yourself 4 hours for this one.
OR skip to the stuff you want to see most.
titleopinion: Takes more than 2 hours. They told us 2 hours to get through it with headset but it talkes much longer. We went to lunch and came back with 2.5 hours till closing and we rushed through a lot of it and still missed an entire floor - Please leave yourself 4 hours for this one. reviewnospace: Madrid is lucky to be home to this wonderful museum. Every time we visit it there is something more to see. The permanent collection is wonderful but this time the Realists of Madrid was exquisite.
titleopinion: One of the best. Madrid is lucky to be home to this wonderful museum. Every time we visit it there is something more to see. The permanent collection is wonderful but this time the Realists of Madrid was exquisite.

reviewnospace: A superb collection - incorrect information online!!! it is free on Mondays and not on Sundays so be aware of this - we read on TA that it is free on Sundays so went specifically on Sunday when it was packed and of course were made aware that the free day is Monday!!!! Anyway worth the entrance fee for the permanent collection which is outstanding. Highly recommend
titleopinion: What an amazing collection. A superb collection - incorrect information online!!! it is free on Mondays and not on Sundays so be aware of this - we read on TA that it is free on Sundays so went specifically on Sunday when it was packed and of course were made aware that the free day is Monday!!!! Anyway worth the entrance fee for the permanent collection which is outstanding. Highly recommend

reviewnospace: In many ways this is better than the Prado a more varied selection of paintings and easier to walk round.
titleopinion: A must if visiting Madrid. In many ways this is better than the Prado a more varied selection of paintings and easier to walk round.

reviewnospace:
I thought the layout was outstanding. Instead of starting with the oldest pictures visitors were taken through 19th and 20th century on the ground floor for starters which provided an immediate contrast to the art seen earlier in the Prado. I immediately identified with the themes of my lifetime instead of much older pictures on the higher floors which came from a time when religion heavily influenced everything.

The lunch in the restaurant was excellent and good value.
titleopinion: A Gem of a Museum. I thought the layout was outstanding. Instead of starting with the oldest pictures visitors were taken through 19th and 20th century on the ground floor for starters which provided an immediate contrast to the art seen earlier in the Prado. I immediately identified with the themes of my lifetime instead of much older pictures on the higher floors which came from a time when religion heavily influenced everything.   The lunch in the restaurant was excellent and good value.

quote: One of the best art collection in the world
reviewnospace: Visiting museums is one of our passions, this one is our favorite in Spain, we absolutely appreciate the opportunity to enjoy such an amazing paintings. The layout of the museum invite you to visit over 500 years of outstanding pieces of art. The ambiance is welcoming and they did an amazing job with the lighting, perfect combination with the natural light. You will need sometime to enjoy your visit so plan to make a stop in the little cafe they have, you will not be disappointed.
titleopinion: One of the best art collection in the world. Visiting museums is one of our passions, this one is our favorite in Spain, we absolutely appreciate the opportunity to enjoy such an amazing paintings. The layout of the museum invite you to visit over 500 years of outstanding pieces of art. The ambiance is welcoming and they did an amazing job with the lighting, perfect combination with the natural light. You will need sometime to enjoy your visit so plan to make a stop in the little cafe they have, you will not be disappointed.

reviewnospace: Unquestionably one of the best art museums I have visited. Starting on the third floor with early works (13th century) and progressing downstairs to late 20th century it is filled with simply wonderful works by such artists as Caravaggio, Chagall, Gauguin, Bacon, and Degas. Well worth a visit
titleopinion: Simply Outstanding. Unquestionably one of the best art museums I have visited. Starting on the third floor with early works (13th century) and progressing downstairs to late 20th century it is filled with simply wonderful works by such artists as Caravaggio, Chagall, Gauguin, Bacon, and Degas. Well worth a visit

reviewnospace: Had a good visit to this museum lots of interesting works arranged in an accessible way. Visited the "still life from Madrid" this was great . The museum was a well organised place the art is well hung and you can get up quite close to the pictures. Audio guides were available but we didn't bother and were fine .
titleopinion: Interesting gallery. Had a good visit to this museum lots of interesting works arranged in an accessible way. Visited the  still life from Madrid  this was great . The museum was a well organised place the art is well hung and you can get up quite close to the pictures. Audio guides were available but we didn't bother and were fine .

reviewnospace:
As a none art lover I spent 3 hours wandering around this fine gallery. The Thyssen has more 19th & 20th century art, which I find far more interesting. There was an excellent temporary exhibition on, 20th century realism, which I enjoyed greatly.
The gallery chronologically starting on the top floor.

Following my visit I thought I'd have a snack in the cafe, sitting out on the terrace, in the sunshine, I'd say don't bother, over priced & poor quality, coffee is good but expensive, head for La Mallorquina in Plaza Puerta del Sol, 5 minute wander up the Calle Mayor, inexpensive great quality cakes.

reviewnospace: One of the essential points of our program in Madrid was to visit the Prado museum. And we even didn't know (to our big shame) about existence of such a beautiful place as Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum. We were very impressed of richness and diversity of the museum's collection. It is located directly across the street from the Prado and definitely deserves your attention.
titleopinion: We loved it!. One of the essential points of our program in Madrid was to visit the Prado museum. And we even didn't know (to our big shame) about existence of such a beautiful place as Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum. We were very impressed of richness and diversity of the museum's collection. It is located directly across the street from the Prado and definitely deserves your attention.

quote: Possibly the best gallery in the world
reviewnospace:
We had come to Madrid to visit the Prado, which has of course an extraordinary collection. We were less aware of the Museo Thyssen, but on visiting were completely in awe. First of all they hold the most fabulous private collection of Western Art, European and North American, covering from the Italian Primitives to Bacon, Auerbach and Freud. Secondly, it is housed in the most fabulously appointed museum where there is space for you and the collection to breathe, and where everything can be seen at leisure and peace. Thirdly, ii is wonderfully curated. The explanatory texts are clear and helpful, the publications are of the highest quality, and the underlying academic rigour clear,y world class.

This Museum is clearly a labour of love for the Thyssen-Bornemisza family and they deserve the very highest praise for what they have created. Next time I go to Madrid it will be first and foremost to relax and enjoy this Museum.

reviewnospace: This is one of the three top museums in Madrid and worth visiting. The collection has more contemporary pieces in addition to the usual traditional pieces. The space is architecturally lovely and the size of the collection is manageable in a couple of hours.

reviewnospace: Amazing pieces from a great range of periods, styles and artists. I would definitely go back for another walk round.

reviewnospace: While the larger Prado is far better known I loved the variety and quality of paintings in this almost adjacent museum. Right now they have a spectacular Wyeth review. Worth 4-5 hours minimun

reviewnospace: This collection definitely has a different feel than del Prado. Lots of landscapes and modern pieces. Don't miss this one!
titleopinion: Great Museum.. This collection definitely has a different feel than del Prado. Lots of landscapes and modern pieces. Don't miss this one!

reviewnospace: I visited on Sunday and found the crowds manageable, but that may be different when more tourists are visiting. Photos are allowed, but no flash. As a 68-year-old, I presented my driver's license to get a reduced admission price. I like the arrangement of paintings according to the period of time and also the country where painted (for example, early 1900s in Europe with those paintings of the Americas in a separate room). I enjoyed being able to get close enough to see the brush strokes used to create a certain effect in the painting. If I had time, I would return. If you have difficulty walking, you can borrow a wheelchair free of charge from the cloakroom - there is a bench in the middle of many rooms, but seating may become more limited with more people.

You almost walk by the entrance but this was one Museo I was left wanting to return too

reviewnospace:
We visited the Thyssen on a Monday, which is their free day. They are open from 12-4, and we arrived at 2PM which was perfect; the lines had died down, and it allowed us 2 hours to see the collection which was plenty.

They have some nice artwork but the collections seemed disorganized to me. Part of the reason is that the building contains 2 collections, and the artists overlap in each. So you think you've seen the impressionists and then you go to a separate wing of the building and the art timeline starts over again.

Well worth seeing!

reviewnospace: I was truly impressed by this collection. Not my beloved Musee D'Orsay but a wonderful option when in Madrid. Pieces from the 13/14th century to modern day. Many of the familiar names: Picasso, El Greco, Cezanne, Sisley, Degas, Liechtenstein, and many more. It's a very complete story of the progression of art, ever changing but still imitating in the best way. I'll be back!

reviewnospace: This is an absolutely fabulous collection, that includes representative paintings from te late middle ages to the present. The cafeteria is good and not-too-expensive, so when you get museum feet you can stop for a snack and a coffee or a soda and go back to the looking.

reviewnospace: We spent over 4 hours strolling through the Thyssen. The way that it is laid out makes it easy to follow the room numbers and it is thoughtfully laid out to work if you follow that order. A fantastic range and probably the best in Madrid if you aren't too sure if an art gallery is for you.

quote: Terrific Former Private Art Collection - Large and Impressive
reviewnospace:
The second most amazing thing about the Museo Thyssen-Bornemisza is that something this extensive and of such quality was once a private collection. The most amazing thing, and much to all of our benefit, is that as a result of the generosity of those private owners, we all can now enjoy it.

The Museo Thyssen-Bornemisza would be an excellent museum anywhere, and stands up very well in a city that hosts so much great art. We were aware before we arrived that it held numerous great works of art, but even we were surprised at how much of it there was.

The building itself is very well designed and the art is displayed in well-lit comfortable galleries. They let you take photographs (no flash, of course), but you really don’t need to as they have much of it in quality images on line.

The museum houses great and significant pieces from multiple eras. Many of the highlights are set forth in the museum map, but they include old masters such as Hans Holbein the Younger, Albrecht Durer, Caravaggio, Canaletto, Rubens, and Rembrandt. Most of the collection appears to be of Impressionist, Post-Impressionist, and more modern works that include Corot, Renoir, Rodin, Degas, van Gogh, Juan Gris, Edward Hopper, Kandinsky, Dali, and Roy Lichtenstein. You should recognize several of the paintings and possibly the most familiar would be Picasso’s Harlequin with a Mirror, the Holbein portrait of Henry VIII (you may have seen in a history book, if nowhere else), and Rembrandt’s self-portrait wearing a hat.

They also have changing exhibits and the one on display during our visit was on Spanish Realism. These pieces were more modern and less familiar, but demonstrate plainly that art is alive and well in Madrid.

If you are in Madrid, you will definitely want to visit this exquisite collection.
titleopinion: Terrific Former Private Art Collection - Large and Impressive. They also have changing exhibits and the one on display during our visit was on Spanish Realism. These pieces were more modern and less familiar, but demonstrate plainly that art is alive and well in Madrid.  If you are in Madrid, you will definitely want to visit this exquisite collection.

All the must see paintings are here in this collection, less known than the Prado but worthwhile!

reviewnospace: Just across the Prado, you have the Thyssen museum. What started as a private collection, has become one of the most beautiful museums of Madrid. There's a lot of variety in the artpieces, so be sure to do the museum chronologically. What I like most about this museum is the fact that there are so many different styles and so many great artworks (this may also be a reason not to like the museum, because there are so many different artist from every period, but not a lot from the same). Still, this is one of my favourite museums in Madrid and a must-see (don't be scared of the entrance fee, it's worth it!)

quote: Great museum, not too big, some great masterpieces, excellent shop, free on Monday
reviewnospace:
Great museum, well laid out, a stupendous Rembrandt self portrait and some wonderful surprises like a Georgia O'Keefe and a portrait of Henry VIII. The modern paintings are brilliant.
The only problem is that it's free on Mondays but they close their paid exhibitions because the general collection is free.
Shame, they had a Wyeth exhibition I would have happily paid to see. Oh well.
The shop is great, give yourself some time there too.
But when the museum shuts, wow do they clear those galleries, keep an eye on the time because there is no sneaking past anyone for a glimpse of that Picasso you've been waiting all your life to see, forget it, they will send you down the stairs with looks of disdain that the Spanish are good at. The museum has an excellent online virtual reality app which means you can decide what you don't want to miss long before you get there.

reviewnospace: Of all the private galleries in the world, you had to walk into mine ! Play it, Sam ! Sorry for the odd connection, but this gallery is SUPERB ! Again, arrive early to avoid the crowds which grow during the day (but not oppressively). Start on the 2nd floor, as recommended, and find gem after gem. In particular, the Corregio portrait of a scholar in room 6 (Villahermosa gallery) took my breath away. And there is more, as you progress into the 'new' wing for the more modern art (in fact, skip the Reina Sofia modern art gallery and do with this excellent collection). We started at 10:00 am, stopped for lunch for 45 minutes (very good food - and they even have a maître d' to show you to the table ! That's class !) - and only left at 3 pm as we had to pack before flying out.

reviewnospace:
Close to the Prado, a short walk along the Paseo del Prado, is situated the Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum known simply as the "Thyssen". Here, in a modern building, you will find one of the world’s most impressive private art collections.

Spread over three floors, this impressive art collection allows you to progress from medieval art on the third floor to twentieth century art on the ground floor. In addition the Thyssen regularly has temporary exhibitions. During my visit I was fortunate to catch both the Wyatt and the Madrid Realists exhibitions which were inspiring.

Indeed, the Thyssen is a treasure of a gallery and certainly worth a visit. It also has a restaurant and shop where you can buy souvenirs to take home to remind you of your time at this wonderful art museum.
titleopinion: Impressive Art Collection. Close to the Prado, a short walk along the Paseo del Prado, is situated the Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum known simply as the  Thyssen . Here, in a modern building, you will find one of the world’s most impressive private art collections.   Spread over three floors, this impressive art collection allows you to progress from medieval art on the third floor to twentieth century art on the ground floor. In addition the Thyssen regularly has temporary exhibitions. During my visit I was fortunate to catch both the Wyatt and the Madrid Realists exhibitions which were inspiring.   Indeed, the Thyssen is a treasure of a gallery and certainly worth a visit. It also has a restaurant and shop where you can buy souvenirs to take home to remind you of your time at this wonderful art museum.

titleopinion: Amazing. I love this museum. Good location and always new things. I recommend it after Reina Sofía and Prado. Nearby palace hotel and cibeles

reviewnospace:
Staying for a long weekend my wife and I decided to visit 1 Art gallery and chose Thyssen over Prado based on the reviews found on Tripadvisor and were happy with our decision.

We started from the more contemporary paintings found on the ground floor and worked up which proved to be our only mistake as I got a little bored on the top floor and perhaps didn't appreciate most of the gloomy religious art and dark portraiture displayed. I found the older works too heavy and a little boring, perhaps there were no greater subjects to study 700 years back but an uplifting scene might not have hurt every now and again! Perhaps the early Dutch and Flemish masters weren't interested in making their commissions light hearted.

I'm deliberately being provocative but the top floors didn't move me and I could have avoided the oldest canvas's altogether.

All the big hitters can be found as you work from the top floor through the ages of style and influence. Degas, Monet, Picasso, Rembrandt, Lichtenstein and Renoir are amongst those represented. I especially enjoyed the less celebrated impressionist artists and the more contemporary surrealist paintings, cubism and pop-art were fun too.

Set aside 3 hours for a leisurely tour or 3:10 if you wish to dash through the oppressive work from 1400 onwards!
titleopinion: Outstanding Private collection of Art. reviewnospace: Please allow some time for the superb Rothco. There is so much to see you will need to plan your time carefully
titleopinion: Too much to see. Please allow some time for the superb Rothco. There is so much to see you will need to plan your time carefully

reviewnospace:
This is an excellent collection and should be on any itinerary when in Madrid. It is perhaps too overwhelming to do justice to it in one afternoon. The entrance fee includes a map of the gallery. I would suggest studying it for a while and plan the periods and artists you most want to see before embarking on your route. The gallery people suggest going straight to floor 2 and working your way down chronologically through the collection. This sounds sensible but there is danger of fatigue setting in by floor 0.
They do let you photograph the works as long as you don't use flash. This is very useful if you run out of time.
Overall, some great works and other works by relatively lesser known artists that will delight.
titleopinion: Must not be missed. This is an excellent collection and should be on any itinerary when in Madrid. It is perhaps too overwhelming to do justice to it in one afternoon. The gallery people suggest going straight to floor 2 and working your way down chronologically through the collection. This sounds sensible but there is danger of fatigue setting in by floor 0.  They do let you photograph the works as long as you don't use flash. This is very useful if you run out of time. Overall, some great works and other works by relatively lesser known artists that will delight.

A great thing about this museum is that photos are permitted. Get your cameras ready!

quote: One of the best collections I have ever seen!

It was in my mind the best of the big three in Madrid. I saw more in the two hours I wandered around and enjoyed what I saw. The collection bridges the gap from the Prado great masters and the Reina Sofia modernists. Well worth a visit and free with the Madrid Card.

reviewnospace:
This museum has a wide variety of art that is sure to please. From 14th cetury to Carravagio, to more modern artists, the collection is well displayed with good signage. The facility is fine for people with limited mobility. The treat older folks well inSpain. Here are some suggestions.

You can easily take a subway to the Banco de Spain stop. There is then about a 10-15 minute slow walk to the museum which will be on your right. If you continue in the same direction, you will run into the Prado accross the wide street.

Second, don't plan on seeing both museums in one day. Plan one a day.

The have a decent cafeteria where you can rest, drink and/eat. Pastries are very good.

Third, wear comfortable footware

Get the audio guide, its very helpful.
titleopinion: Worth a visit. This museum has a wide variety of art that is sure to please. From 14th cetury to Carravagio, to more modern artists, the collection is well displayed with good signage. There is then about a 10-15 minute slow walk to the museum which will be on your right. If you continue in the same direction, you will run into the Prado accross the wide street.   Second, don't plan on seeing both museums in one day. Plan one a day.  The have a decent cafeteria where you can rest, drink and/eat. Pastries are very good. reviewnospace:
Both the Prado and the Thyssen are must-visit museums if you are in Madrid. The Thyssen offers a broad range of works from Dutch masters, to Monet, to Picasso, to Roy Lichtenstein... something for everyone. The audio guide adds many interesting points.

I've been to visit before, and I think you should re-visit, as you may see something you haven't before. For example, I REALLY enjoyed the Richard Estes paintings this time. I never really appreciated the detail in his work. Really stunning!

Also a painting by Simone Martini dating back to the 1200's !!! Many older Italian masters that I love, With a pretty decent collection of impressionist. I am not an art scholar by any means, I like what I like, and I realize Monet is impressionist I just can't through him in with modern art, even a sculpture by Bernini. If you are in Madid don't miss this the Thyssen.

One must thank Baroness Thyssen for sharing her private collection with the world. A gem.

location: Sant Cugat del Vallès, Catalonia, Spain
quote: Art that spans a range of tastes
reviewnospace:
By far the most enjoyable art gallery here in Madrid as it has it houses a nice range of different artistic styles. When we visited there was a special temper exhibition of Madrid Realists. Thought this exhibition in particular was fantastic, a nice introduction to the artists here. It was was very popular so if you plan to go before it finishes I'd go early to avoid the crowd, we went round at 10am and didn't have to queue but when we left the queue was massive. I went with two Dutch teenagers and they were quite happy to see a lot of famous Dutch artists there.

We would also recommend the cafe.

reviewnospace: We started on the second floor with the earliest pictures and worked our way down towards the ultra-modern. The art is superb and has been lovingly collected. This is a lovely gallery to visit, from the tubs of camellias in the entrance courtyard to the restaurant which has excellent acoustics and isn't noisy.

quote: Beautiful collection for at least 3 hours

Especially wide selection of dutch and flemish paintings of 16-17th centuries and impressionists of late 1800-ties . Not overloaded with religious thematic. Really great experience, reserve at least 3 hours of your time for this.

reviewnospace: This museum is well organized and the items well described in English. The art works are highly worth seeing, if not necessarily the masterworks of the period. reviewnospace: This once-private collection is perhaps the best cross-section of western art in the world. Every big name is represented by at least one piece. A truly wonderful gallery, but not quite large enough to keep you there all day. They let you take photos, too (no flash).

reviewnospace:

reccomendation: buy the 3 museums ticket for 27 euros or so, it is valid for once year and within this year one entrance for each of the three museums: this once, Prado and Reina Sofia.

quote: An excellent collection in space of elitism
reviewnospace: Wonderful collection. The entrance is expensive (12€/person), so we choose to go on a monday from 12:00 to 16:00, because it's free. At 12:00 the queue to enter was amazingly huge, from the door until the restaurant "100 Montaditos" in Plaza de las Cortes. We quit and came back at 14:30, and we entered without queue, but we had less time to visit than we'd like to. Very crowded, the exhibition rooms, the shop... Even the toilets were crowded. At 15:45 the staff started to close the rooms, sending everybody out, so the queue on the cloakroom was just incredible. If you have money you should choose a regular day and pay the entrance, and you'll have a quiet visit. if you don't, this is what expects you. So, in this museum we see how (once again) art is for an elite that can pay to enjoy it.
titleopinion: An excellent collection in space of elitism. Wonderful collection. The entrance is expensive (12€/person), so we choose to go on a monday from 12:00 to 16:00, because it's free. At 12:00 the queue to enter was amazingly huge, from the door until the restaurant  100 Montaditos  in Plaza de las Cortes. We quit and came back at 14:30, and we entered without queue, but we had less time to visit than we'd like to. Very crowded, the exhibition rooms, the shop... Even the toilets were crowded. At 15:45 the staff started to close the rooms, sending everybody out, so the queue on the cloakroom was just incredible. If you have money you should choose a regular day and pay the entrance, and you'll have a quiet visit. if you don't, this is what expects you. So, in this museum we see how (once again) art is for an elite that can pay to enjoy it.

quote: Fantastic museum, take your time to enjoy

A wonderful collection of art. If you can make it during one of the free-entry times, you'll save a lot of Euros, but it will be more crowded and might not be enough time for you to see everything. Great representations of so many periods of art. This is a gem in the world of art!

Nice gift shop, too.

quote: Very nice museum with a range of artists
reviewnospace: We came here on a Sunday. We were probably queuing for tickets for 10 minutes. They advise you to start with the early european masters. They have a good selection but I was most impressed with the impressionists. They have several Monet, Degas, and Pissaro. Their 20th century art is also well represented, with several Chagall, a Dali and Picasso. The museum is well laid out. I would definitely recommend a visit.

reviewnospace: Whether you a fan of modern or classic art, this gallery has it all. Monet, Van Gogh, Goya, Rubens, Caravaggio. Check website for free entry at the moment it is 12:00-16:00 on a Monday. Also has the benefit of being over the road from the Prado.

reviewnospace: MTB is one of the mot impressive art collections in the world. For the Spanish cultural heritage is a pride that Madrid was the chosen see for install the collection. Thyssen Collection complete the lacks in the Spanish museums with hundred of masterpieces from XIX and XX centuries. Our Museums have fantastic collections with Medieval, Renaissance and baroque pieces but the inexistent collectors activity in the XIX or XX suppose a lack in our collections for Impressionist, Expressionist or Avantgarde art. Imprescindible!!!

reviewnospace: wonderful collection of modern and older paintings from all over Europe and some from America. Essential viewing for art lovers!
titleopinion: major art collection.. wonderful collection of modern and older paintings from all over Europe and some from America. Essential viewing for art lovers!

reviewnospace: So, it's a slightly biased view of the Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum. I came here after shelling out €14 at the Prado, and having walked around 5 hours. So, I came here and sat down inside - it was fantastic! I could recover, relax, and gaze at the art on the ground floor. Did I want to pay €12 at the TBM and walk around another 3 hours? No way. But, it proved a good time just looking and relaxing and it was free. Art purists may prove stuck-up and criticize, but life is more than a rip-off where you exhaust yourself into heart attack mode. Some of the best things in life are free.
titleopinion: Very nice, relaxing interior. So, it's a slightly biased view of the Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum. I came here after shelling out €14 at the Prado, and having walked around 5 hours. So, I came here and sat down inside - it was fantastic! I could recover, relax, and gaze at the art on the ground floor. Did I want to pay €12 at the TBM and walk around another 3 hours? No way. But, it proved a good time just looking and relaxing and it was free. Art purists may prove stuck-up and criticize, but life is more than a rip-off where you exhaust yourself into heart attack mode. Some of the best things in life are free.

quote: Newish Art Kid On The Block
reviewnospace: I have visited this part of the art triangle in Madrid twice now; once when it initially opened and again today. I thoroughly enjoyed myself. The layout is a bit higglety-pigglety: you sort of come upon things randomly. I'm not sure why exhibits aren't grouped together thematically or by epoch or by art movement (well, there is a loose sort of arrangement but for example you will find Picassos spread throughout the building; there are expressionist pictures in the expressionist section but also in other sections…) But nonetheless it all makes for a diverting afternoon; especially if, like me, you're looking for something to do as it pours down relentless rain.
titleopinion: Newish Art Kid On The Block. I have visited this part of the art triangle in Madrid twice now; once when it initially opened and again today. I thoroughly enjoyed myself. The layout is a bit higglety-pigglety: you sort of come upon things randomly. I'm not sure why exhibits aren't grouped together thematically or by epoch or by art movement (well, there is a loose sort of arrangement but for example you will find Picassos spread throughout the building; there are expressionist pictures in the expressionist section but also in other sections…) But nonetheless it all makes for a diverting afternoon; especially if, like me, you're looking for something to do as it pours down relentless rain.

reviewnospace:

A small tip. There is a ticket which is 51€ for 2 persons, and includes a free entrance for one year to this Museum as well the Prado and Reina Sofia arts Museum ( Guernica) .

reviewnospace: The thing that surprised me about the Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum is that it does indeed have paintings by Renoir, Degas, Toulouse-Lautrec, Kandinsky, Durer, Van Gogh, Cezanne, Monet, Picasso...but many of the paintings in this collection are from less well represented periods in the artists' portfolio. For example, the Picasso is Harlequin with a Mirror, from 1923, which looks nothing like Picasso's later, and more famous, works; similarly, of the 5 van Goghs in the collection, only one of them has the swirly lines and thick gobs of paint that are so characteristic of many of van Gogh's most famous paintings - one of the other 4 is a drawing titled "The Potato Eaters" and is as un-van Gogh as you can get from the likes of Starry Night etc. This, I think, is the strength of the Thyssen-Bornemisza: you get to see a greater breadth of the output from famous artists than you may see in other larger galleries that go for the crowd-drawing big pieces.
titleopinion: Lesser-known paintings by well-known artists. The thing that surprised me about the Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum is that it does indeed have paintings by Renoir, Degas, Toulouse-Lautrec, Kandinsky, Durer, Van Gogh, Cezanne, Monet, Picasso...but many of the paintings in this collection are from less well represented periods in the artists' portfolio. For example, the Picasso is Harlequin with a Mirror, from 1923, which looks nothing like Picasso's later, and more famous, works; similarly, of the 5 van Goghs in the collection, only one of them has the swirly lines and thick gobs of paint that are so characteristic of many of van Gogh's most famous paintings - one of the other 4 is a drawing titled  The Potato Eaters  and is as un-van Gogh as you can get from the likes of Starry Night etc. This, I think, is the strength of the Thyssen-Bornemisza: you get to see a greater breadth of the output from famous artists than you may see in other larger galleries that go for the crowd-drawing big pieces.

reviewnospace:

Madrid has other collections on offer but overall this was my favorite visit.

quote: One of My Favorite Art Museums Ever!
reviewnospace: We had our first visit to the Thyseen-Bornemisza Museum yesterday, and it is now firmly in the ranks of our very favorite art museums. Great collections of art from all over Europe and America, mostly 17th - early 20th century. Very well curated, thoughtfully arranged, simply a great collection of art. Hard to believe that this was basically one family's art collection. (Can you hear the Baron saying, "Yes, that Caravaggio would look very nice over the couch."?)

Very much worth seen.

quote: One of three world-class art museums in Madrid
reviewnospace: This grew out of a private collection (hence the name). The wife of the couple had the passion to collect art, and the taste (and the euros) to assemble this huge, eclectic collection. It's mostly painting, from Medieval through modern, and features occasional special exhibits (Munch while we were there). It's small enough to do in a day (unlike the Prado or the Louvre), and should not be missed if you're an art lover.

titleopinion: A must when you are in Madrid. An outstanding private museum with 2 distinct wings. The collection ranges from Classical to Modern with works representing all the important painters. On Mondays admission is free.

reviewnospace:
The museum has a great collection of Impressionism art. The collection is extensive and if you love art a must trip

Nice visit

reviewnospace: Visited here on this occasion as there was a special exhibition by Edward Munch. A chance to view some of his true works of art including The Scream.

reviewnospace: This was a great museum choice for us - - it features the Masters, organized chronologically, from over the centuries and is well laid out. It seems more accessible than the Prado and offers and great overview from across geographies and centuries.

reviewnospace: I prefer modern art so I decided to skip prado and go to the Reina Sofia and thyssen. I got an audio guide at both places but I didn't use it for every single painting. Still, it's good to know more. I wish I had started at the ground level and worked my way up. I would have ended with the classical works this way, instead of beginning with them. I went on Dec 24 and the museum was closing early at 3pm, so I barely got a chance to see the works at the ground level. I also missed the museum shop, which I hear is really cool. Spotted some interesting necklaces in the window. It was amazing to see the dancing ballerina painting by Edgar degas and my first egon schiele.

reviewnospace: The Tyssen Museum is a gem. Make sure to rent the audio tour to get the most of this museum. Expect to spend at least four to five hours. The Thyssen has a very nice restaurant on site, for a quick tapa, coffee, or vino. My 16 year old daughter especially enjoyed this museum.

reviewnospace: We saw the Munch Exhibition and enjoyed it. This artist started out with melancholy themes in his career. Later he went to more colorful paintings. My favorite painting in the exhibition was Two Girls on the Bridge.

reviewnospace: Ever better....terrific permanent museum with outstanding periodic shows....Wonderful collection and space.

quote: Good museum in the Prado area
reviewnospace: This WA the first of four museums in Madrid we visited over a two day period, it is a great collection of predominantly 19 th and 20th century pieces very much Madrid's answer to the frack collection in New York. Good for an hour or so but not one to spend a day in
titleopinion: Good museum in the Prado area. reviewnospace: The collection of paintings is magnificent. It is hard to believe that this collection belonged to a private couple as it is so diverse and so good!
titleopinion: Best art in Madrid. The collection of paintings is magnificent. It is hard to believe that this collection belonged to a private couple as it is so diverse and so good!

reviewnospace:
This is another world class hotel with beautiful paintings by the Masters. Easy access and very good painting, it is well worth the visit.
The Thyssen family were all mixed up with the nazi movement in pre- war Germany and one of the Thyssens helped Hitler to power. So even though there is still resentment, this museum helps a lot to restore faith in human kindness and goodwill.
titleopinion: The Thyssen Museum in Madrid. This is another world class hotel with beautiful paintings by the Masters. Easy access and very good painting, it is well worth the visit. The Thyssen family were all mixed up with the nazi movement in pre- war Germany and one of the Thyssens helped Hitler to power. So even though there is still resentment, this museum helps a lot to restore faith in human kindness and goodwill.

quote: In any other city, this is a 5 star attraction
reviewnospace:
But, then, this is Madrid! Madrid is blessed with some absolutely great art museums--however, the Prado really is THE museum to see if you are pressed for time. This is one of the top three you can visit on a walking tour of less than one mile. Unfortunately, you will not be able to do all of them in the same day because there is so much to see at each one.

The collection has outstanding works that are readily recognized by anyone with an interest in art. Even if you are not all that interested, it is worth trip to see some excellent examples of what good pieces should look like. Too many museums have marginal pieces of major artists on prominent display. NOT HERE!

The museum is located close to many hotels and is an easy walk from good eating and drinking spots. The nearby park is beautiful.
titleopinion: In any other city, this is a 5 star attraction. But, then, this is Madrid! Madrid is blessed with some absolutely great art museums--however, the Prado really is THE museum to see if you are pressed for time. The collection has outstanding works that are readily recognized by anyone with an interest in art. Even if you are not all that interested, it is worth trip to see some excellent examples of what good pieces should look like. Too many museums have marginal pieces of major artists on prominent display. NOT HERE!  The museum is located close to many hotels and is an easy walk from good eating and drinking spots. The nearby park is beautiful.

reviewnospace: one of the best collection of modern art in madrid. very close to the Prado Museum, is a great option to complete your cultural experience in the city

reviewnospace: The great thing about his museum is that it reflects the taste and approach of the collector(s); it has some truly outstanding works and is well worth planning to visit for a whole day (we had a lovely lunch in the restaurant, half way through our visit).

reviewnospace: Great museum. One of the top 50 in the world, and just across the street from the Prado which is a top 10 gallery. Don't try to do them both in one day. Your feet will not thank you. Take three days and do Reina Sophia, Prado and Thyssen. It's a cultural feast. Speaking of eating, the restaurant at the Thyssen is not bad at all, for a museum restaurant.

reviewnospace: this museum has a very nice collection from the 13th to the late 20th century. Get an audio guide before your tour, then you can fully understand the main characteristics of different genres as well as the transition periods. I definitely recommend it!

reviewnospace: In a bright, new building, this collection features something for everyone. Master paintings spanning three centuries presented in clean, modern galleries. Most of the greats are here, as well as a few surprises, and it is much more accessible and more fun than the Prado! We went twice and would be happy to go again.

We went twice and would be happy to go again.

reviewnospace: An excellent private museum with a wide variety of paintings from 1400 to the 70s. These are presented in a historical and geographical order. Of particular interest the XIX century American paintings that are rarely present in European museums. It takes 3 hours to visit the museum without too much hurry. The paintings are shown in wide spaces allowing full fruition. Among the masterpieces, a Caravaggio (Santa Catarina) a few remarkable Peto, Jesus in The Temple by Dürer, the Waterloo bridge by Derain, Antonello da Messina 's young man.

quote: A gem of a museum with a wonderful collection, but again absolutely no photos--who makes up such a rule?
reviewnospace: Located just a short walk from the Prado, the collection is exhibited on three levels. The English pamphlet states, "Still photography and videotaping: Non-flash photography is permitted inside the museum" but when I tried to take a few snaps with my i-phone the guards came down on me like a ton of bricks! The collection is arranged in chronological order, giving one a sense of the development of Western painting. I think that one should visit this collection before visiting the Prado in order to gain a better understanding of that development which begins with the Italian primitives and ends with European Post-war Abstract and Figurative Art. In addition to works by the younger Holbein, Caravaggio, Rubens, Rembrandt, and Corot, there is a wonderful collection of late 19th century French paintings--Degas, Monet, Renoir, and Vincent van Gogh.

quote: Add this one to your list
reviewnospace: Bought the carte arte. Only Prado had queues though it was good to just walk into the museums without going through the ticket office. This was the last visit of the three and I was glad that they were done in the order of Prado, Sofia and then Thyssen. This was the best in my view. Great variety of artists, well laid out, not too large, and you can take photos without using a flash. Far better for memories of a holiday. If you need to chose between the three due to time constraints, put this one on your list!

quote: What a Great Way to Spend the Day
reviewnospace: I loved the Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum. What an amazing collection! Beautiful paintings, displayed well, in a setting with great lighting. The building is well-laid out, signage is good, the galleries are comfortable, and there are plenty of clean restrooms. Their shop is excellent! Entrance with the Madrid Card is easy: no need to go to ticket window, they just scan your card at the entrance to the collection. Plan to spend several hours here.
titleopinion: What a Great Way to Spend the Day. I loved the Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum. What an amazing collection! Beautiful paintings, displayed well, in a setting with great lighting. The building is well-laid out, signage is good, the galleries are comfortable, and there are plenty of clean restrooms. Their shop is excellent! Entrance with the Madrid Card is easy: no need to go to ticket window, they just scan your card at the entrance to the collection. Plan to spend several hours here.

reviewnospace: this musem is well located in the centre of madrid. it has a general and several temporary exhibits. it is quite big with 3 floors to investigate. it has several types of art from different periods and there are several famous artists featured picasso, degas etc so it could suit all tastes. the entry on certain days/ hours is free to the general exhibit and this makes the visit good value, the temporary exhibits have fees. i would avoid free visits during the holidays if you can its very busy and not pleasant or relaxing.

quote: Visited for the temporary Edvard Munch Exhibit - recommended
reviewnospace: I visited Thyssen-Bornemisza specifically for the temporary Munch exhibit - definitely worth spending the time to visit. I knew of Munch for "The Scream" but not much else. The exhibit offered a deeper view of his talents, his challenges, and the range of his work. I decided to buy a ticket that included the rest of the museum and didn't find it as rewarding. It may have been too much for me after spending the morning at the Prado, but I would spend additional time there vs. this one if you're pressed for time. It is a beautiful space.

It may have been too much for me after spending the morning at the Prado, but I would spend additional time there vs. this one if you're pressed for time. It is a beautiful space.

quote: A very accessible exhibition. This is how I would like a museum to be.
reviewnospace: (Free entrance on Monday to the permanent exhibition) Madrid has more than a few museums. If you are deep into art you probably know what each of them has to offer. If you are not then you're probably wondering to which to go, how much will you spend there and where you'll enjoy your time most. At the Thyssen the permanent exhibition is planned perfectly. Three floors, each dedicated to a different period of contemporary art. Great narration that takes you through the different phases or these period using the paintings in the exhibition. Great if you don't have any background in art and probably great if you do as it puts everything on the timeline. You'll need 3-4 hours to go slowly through it all or less if you'll just browse. There are other temporary exhibitions available as well.
