I also found their cafe and gift shop to offer better than expected quality. I admit, I wondered if each thing offered were personally approved by the woman behind the museum's collection. I am never know but, in my humble opinion, well done!

reviewnospace: This gallery was marvelous. Many styles of paintings were displayed and most exhibits also had English notes attached. The gallery was particularly well laid out.
titleopinion: Madrid adventures. This gallery was marvelous. Many styles of paintings were displayed and most exhibits also had English notes attached. The gallery was particularly well laid out.

quote: Put it first on your list
reviewnospace:
We visited on the 4th day of our trip and after the Prado and other tourist activities and so were a bit tired. Definitely make it your first stop if you are keen on art as there is such a variety there and it makes such a good introduction....you can 'specialise' later at the Prado.
We had booked tickets online for the Munch exhibition which was very interesting and well displayed . Despite numbers being controlled it still felt a bit crowded compared to all the other galleries.
titleopinion: Put it first on your list. We visited on the 4th day of our trip and after the Prado and other tourist activities and so were a bit tired. Definitely make it your first stop if you are keen on art as there is such a variety there and it makes such a good introduction....you can 'specialise' later at the Prado.  We had booked tickets online for the Munch exhibition which was very interesting and well displayed . Despite numbers being controlled it still felt a bit crowded compared to all the other galleries.

reviewnospace: This museum is open between 12-4pm on Mondays -free entry; other days there is a reasonable charge. The collection is a private collection acquired by the state and has some beautiful works. 13th century-20th century paintings, some of which are quite famous (Henry VIII by Hans Holbein for example). Galleries are spacious which allows for relaxed viewing without too many people. Collections are easy to find, unlike the Prado. Was a highlight of our visit to Madrid.
titleopinion: Beautiful collection, easy to view. This museum is open between 12-4pm on Mondays -free entry; other days there is a reasonable charge. The collection is a private collection acquired by the state and has some beautiful works. 13th century-20th century paintings, some of which are quite famous (Henry VIII by Hans Holbein for example). Galleries are spacious which allows for relaxed viewing without too many people. Collections are easy to find, unlike the Prado. Was a highlight of our visit to Madrid.

reviewnospace:
I never thought I would end up saying this but visit this museum rather than the Prado if you only have time in Madrid to visit one of them.

Unlike the Prado, you are allowed to take photos (without flash) throughout the museum and the collection of paintings is huge. It really is a world class museum. What we liked too was the fact that, although you can get close up to the paintings, they enforce peace and quiet in the galleries. No mobile phones - and anyone trying to talk loudly into one is soon given a hard time. Very civilised.

The museum can not rival the number of paintings by Goya and Velazquez in the Prado but they display an incredibly varied selection of work from artists all over the world.
titleopinion: A world class art collection. I never thought I would end up saying this but visit this museum rather than the Prado if you only have time in Madrid to visit one of them.  Unlike the Prado, you are allowed to take photos (without flash) throughout the museum and the collection of paintings is huge. It really is a world class museum. What we liked too was the fact that, although you can get close up to the paintings, they enforce peace and quiet in the galleries. No mobile phones - and anyone trying to talk loudly into one is soon given a hard time. Very civilised.  The museum can not rival the number of paintings by Goya and Velazquez in the Prado but they display an incredibly varied selection of work from artists all over the world.

reviewnospace: Wow! What a nice surprise, given that we hadn't heard of this museum before arriving in Madrid. Definitely a must-see, it's very conveniently laid out and is an impressive collection.
titleopinion: Don't miss it!. Wow! What a nice surprise, given that we hadn't heard of this museum before arriving in Madrid. Definitely a must-see, it's very conveniently laid out and is an impressive collection.

reviewnospace: Madrid is renowned for its good art museums. This museum will not disappoint. Its collection includes pieces from the greatest artists, such as Goya, Picasso, Dali and Rembrandt. The museum is currently hosting the Edvard Munch exhibition. Since entry numbers are limited, I recommend you purchase the entry tickets online to avoid disappointment!
titleopinion: Not to be missed!. Madrid is renowned for its good art museums. This museum will not disappoint. Its collection includes pieces from the greatest artists, such as Goya, Picasso, Dali and Rembrandt. The museum is currently hosting the Edvard Munch exhibition. Since entry numbers are limited, I recommend you purchase the entry tickets online to avoid disappointment!

quote: The Thyssen - treasure house to rival the best
reviewnospace:
The Thyssen is a huge museum, or more accurately, gallery, though not rivalling the Prado in size. But t if you want a primer in modern art this is the place to come. There are a few examples of all the most highly regarded artists of the 19th and 20th centuries, collected by Baron Thyssen and his wife.

However, for those who enjoy work of an earlier vintage, there is plenty here to enjoy as well. Medieval and Renaissance art is well represented.

So a visit to the Thyssen is a positive feast for the eyes while the excellent restaurant provides similar pleasure for the stomach. While the Prado offers classical riches and the Reina Sofia the best of modern art, the beautifully housed and displayed work in the Thyssen should not be overlooked.
titleopinion: The Thyssen - treasure house to rival the best. The Thyssen is a huge museum, or more accurately, gallery, though not rivalling the Prado in size. But t if you want a primer in modern art this is the place to come. There are a few examples of all the most highly regarded artists of the 19th and 20th centuries, collected by Baron Thyssen and his wife.  However, for those who enjoy work of an earlier vintage, there is plenty here to enjoy as well. Medieval and Renaissance art is well represented.  So a visit to the Thyssen is a positive feast for the eyes while the excellent restaurant provides similar pleasure for the stomach. While the Prado offers classical riches and the Reina Sofia the best of modern art, the beautifully housed and displayed work in the Thyssen should not be overlooked.

reviewnospace: this is one of the big 3 museums in Madrid, and worth much of a day. the collections span the range of western art, and there is a surprising amount of American art represented, rather unusual for a European museum. if there is one thing wrong, it is the need for so many of the paintings to be cleaned of old varnish. however, there are many significant paintings worthy of a visit. they also have a fine cafe and good amenities. there are two special exhibit spaces, currently devoted to Vogue magazine photography and Munch. clearly worth a visit for anyone traveling to Madrid.
titleopinion: major collection worth a visit. this is one of the big 3 museums in Madrid, and worth much of a day. the collections span the range of western art, and there is a surprising amount of American art represented, rather unusual for a European museum. if there is one thing wrong, it is the need for so many of the paintings to be cleaned of old varnish. however, there are many significant paintings worthy of a visit. they also have a fine cafe and good amenities. there are two special exhibit spaces, currently devoted to Vogue magazine photography and Munch. clearly worth a visit for anyone traveling to Madrid.

quote: A superb counterpoint to The Prado with a more open yet intimate feel to it.
reviewnospace:
Located close to the Plaza de Neptuno the Thyssen Museum is an art gallery offering a private collection to public viewing that represents a counterpoint to the extensive galleries of the Prado, just a few minute’s walk away. The Museum derives from the aspirations of Baron Hans Heinrich Thyssen –Bornemisza (whose portrait hangs in one of the final rooms) and his father sharing not only a love of art but a desire to make it available to all those who share it with them.

Even if you don’t have quite their passion you will find many works, primarily painted but also sculpture and tapestries that you will probably recognise from books, posters and illustrations. They include the well known portrait of Henry VIII by Hans Holbein, a self portrait by Rembrandt’s and work by Rubens, Cezanne, Van Gogh, Picasso, Gauguin, Renoir and a host of others displayed over three floors in numerous rooms and arranged by period, subject and geographical origin so you will find rooms devoted 20th century North American works as well as others displaying 17th century still life and Pop Art for example and it is possible to follow a route that takes in as much or as little as you like best started by heading to upper floor, Level 2 and working down, passing from the earliest works to the more modern and abstract.

The Museum Shop offers guides including a very useful pocket sized book describing 62 of the works on display, not unlike the pocket guide available from the Prado detailing 50 famous masterpieces. However, the Museum also provides a free leaflet that you should make a point of picking up on your way in. This excellent little guide offers basic information on the Museum itself and both a route to follow through it to see 23 paintings and one sculpture that take in both the famous and a good representative sample of period and style. This ‘simple’ little guide is excellent and the result of a great deal of thought. Handsets are also available offering an audio commentary.

As for the Museum itself I would have to say that having visited both the Prado and the Thyssen I felt the latter displayed its collection to better effect and enjoyed the visit more. Others may disagree but for me it had a lighter, more open and more intimate feel to it. Another bonus from my viewpoint and possibly yours is that unlike the Prado the Thyssen permits photography (but be careful to switch your flash off).

General admission to the Museum is normally €10 with reductions for some groups but it is free to all on Mondays and free at all times to those who can demonstrate they are unemployed and for accompanied children under 12. Opening times are from 10:00 – 19:00 from Tuesday to Sunday and from 12:00 – 16:00 on Mondays. The Museum shop is also fairly extensive with a range of items to suit pretty much any budget.

I hope you found this of some help and that you enjoy your visit as much as we enjoyed ours.

reviewnospace: Decided to tour the subject before Prado and happy we did. Very good variety of art collection (largely paintings vs sculptures). Three levels plus basement and there is something for everyone. Purchase Madrid Card and avoid lines for ticket.

reviewnospace: The best museum in the city !!! The building is great,the art is spectacular if you love Picasso,Chagal,a Renoir and arts of that genre and quality and the very best part,THEY ALLOW YOU TO TAKE PICTURES WITHOUT A FLASH AND YOU CAN GET AS CLOSE TO THE ART AS YOU LIKE !!!!!! quote: A world class museum that complements the Prado
reviewnospace: My wife and I very much enjoy paintings from the Romantic and Impressionist periods. To our surprise, such art that is not found at the Prado. The Thyssen has many such paintings, including some superb Monet and Van Gogh pieces. This museum also has its fair share of pre-Renaissance and Renaissance era paintings and many modern 20th century works. Included at this time is a special exhibit of Munch paintings that is very popular. Our experience here was all the more pleasant because the Thyssen does not draw the crowds found at the Prado. That said, we also visited the Prado and enjoyed its many works, but not the crowds.

Included at this time is a special exhibit of Munch paintings that is very popular. Our experience here was all the more pleasant because the Thyssen does not draw the crowds found at the Prado. That said, we also visited the Prado and enjoyed its many works, but not the crowds.

reviewnospace: An eclectic collection of masterpieces that covers a range of art styles and eras. Of the trio of art galleries in Madrid, it is here that I spent the most time - I could have stayed much longer if I'd had longer in Madrid!

quote: Don't miss this while in Madrid!
reviewnospace: A different perspective than the Prado. Go here if you are tired of overwhelming crowds and like to savor your art.
titleopinion: Don't miss this while in Madrid!. A different perspective than the Prado. Go here if you are tired of overwhelming crowds and like to savor your art.

reviewnospace: Two trips here and I still want another - the progression in the collections from medieval to modernity is well paced, and thought provoking
titleopinion: well worth a visit. Two trips here and I still want another - the progression in the collections from medieval to modernity is well paced, and thought provoking

reviewnospace: A magnificent collection of European painting in a beautiful space. Masterpieces and great thematic series work such as landscapes from the Netherlands. High culture.
titleopinion: High culture. A magnificent collection of European painting in a beautiful space. Masterpieces and great thematic series work such as landscapes from the Netherlands. High culture.

reviewnospace: Nice museum with a fairly good collection of impressionists and also nice place to have lunch after your visit.

reviewnospace: Easy to find enjoyable time spent viewing known and unknown art work. Particularly enjoyed the newly opened Edvard Munch Exhibition.
titleopinion: Edvard Munch Exhibition. Easy to find enjoyable time spent viewing known and unknown art work. Particularly enjoyed the newly opened Edvard Munch Exhibition.

quote: A delightful mixture of classic and modern
reviewnospace: Splendid collection , very different from the paintings you will see at Prado. Best represented is the Renaissance but, the predominant is the Modern Painting section. A must see for all the true art lovers.
titleopinion: A delightful mixture of classic and modern. Splendid collection , very different from the paintings you will see at Prado. Best represented is the Renaissance but, the predominant is the Modern Painting section. A must see for all the true art lovers.

reviewnospace: Well worth visiting. A remarkable collection spanning centuries. There's very little information about how the collection came together though, which is a shame.
titleopinion: Worth the visit. Well worth visiting. A remarkable collection spanning centuries. There's very little information about how the collection came together though, which is a shame.

reviewnospace: This Museum is Simply Superb. It has a ton of Spanish Painters. The variety is also diverse with many Impressionist Paintings from Great Painters. What I liked most of this Place what that I was Able to Take Pictures Freely. It has many great Paintings and it is worth your time while in Madrid if you love Spanish and Impressionist Paintings.

reviewnospace: This museum presents stunning masterpiece after stunning masterpiece in collections that span many centuries of Western art. I went to Madrid to see the Prado. I happened into this one, and it blew my mind. Sure, go to the Prado, of course. Its collection of Spanish art is important and exceptional. But be sure to add this museum to your itinerary. It is a gem. Some of its paintings continue to linger in my memory.

It is a gem. Some of its paintings continue to linger in my memory.

reviewnospace: We had some spare time and visited this art museum for a couple of hours. We only intended to stay an hour and could easily have spent even longer.
titleopinion: Lots to see. We had some spare time and visited this art museum for a couple of hours. We only intended to stay an hour and could easily have spent even longer.

reviewnospace: Enjoyed museum very much, new expositions and a nice store for not expensive souvenirs. Discounts for retired people.
titleopinion: Interesting Museum. Enjoyed museum very much, new expositions and a nice store for not expensive souvenirs. Discounts for retired people.

reviewnospace: You can leave you bags in the cloak room, and there is an audio device available but it's not really well explained about how to use it. Cost €5, that's not a deposit. But has a lot of great art, if you are interested

very good organisation and easy access to some very famous painters ,

quote: Magnificent collection from a great philanthropist
reviewnospace:
The Thyssen-Bornemisza museum while much smaller than the Prado is impressive because it was the collection of a single man.
When you keep this in mind you realize that it was one of the great art collections of the world. The building has a good flow and the paintings are all well organized and displayed.

Many paintings such as from Emil Nolde that you would not find in other museums.

Many paintings such as from Emil Nolde that you would not find in other museums.

reviewnospace: Walking along Madrid's lovely Paseo de Prado recently, we were surprised to see that there was an Edvard Munch exhibition in the Museo Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum. Being Norway-based, we were delighted to have an opportunity to see this major exhition titled Edvard Munch Archetypes in Madrid. There were many works from the Munch Museum in Oslo but also from many other major art institutions as well as private collections around the world. We were most impressed!
titleopinion: MUNCH IN MADRID. Walking along Madrid's lovely Paseo de Prado recently, we were surprised to see that there was an Edvard Munch exhibition in the Museo Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum. Being Norway-based, we were delighted to have an opportunity to see this major exhition titled Edvard Munch Archetypes in Madrid. There were many works from the Munch Museum in Oslo but also from many other major art institutions as well as private collections around the world. We were most impressed!

quote: My favourite of the 'big three' museums in Madrid
reviewnospace: This is a fabulous gallery and I would consider it an essential part of any visit to Madrid. It has art from medieval times through to the 20th century, with a focus on 19th and 20th century works. On the day that we visited it was quite (compared to London museum standards) so really easy to wander around and appreciate all the art works. Don't miss it.

It has art from medieval times through to the 20th century, with a focus on 19th and 20th century works. On the day that we visited it was quite (compared to London museum standards) so really easy to wander around and appreciate all the art works. Don't miss it.

reviewnospace: Spent an enjoyable 5hrs wandering through the collection with a pleasant rest break in the cafeteria. Pictures are well curated and information on audioguide is excellent. Only downside was getting the audioguide to work. You gave to press numbers 2 or 3 times to get them to play. In the end, I got frustrated and ignored. Not as crowded as Prado and good seating so you can sit and enjoy.
titleopinion: Excellent collection. Spent an enjoyable 5hrs wandering through the collection with a pleasant rest break in the cafeteria. Pictures are well curated and information on audioguide is excellent. Only downside was getting the audioguide to work. You gave to press numbers 2 or 3 times to get them to play. In the end, I got frustrated and ignored. Not as crowded as Prado and good seating so you can sit and enjoy.

reviewnospace:
Here is one of my favourite place in madrid.
Begin with medieval paintings and end with contemporary works.
It was great to see the paintings in this way.
titleopinion: WOW!. Here is one of my favourite place in madrid.  Begin with medieval paintings and end with contemporary works.  It was great to see the paintings in this way.

quote: One of the big 3 in Madrid
reviewnospace: A private collection filled with all the great painters everyone knows and loves. It is also a chance to see other lesser-known painters who have a place in art history. It is a breath of fresh air after the "heavy" works that fill the Prado. A beautiful museum somewhat less frequented than the Prado. Not crowded at all on a Saturday morning. So glad we visited, even when we had already seen so much art in Spain.
titleopinion: One of the big 3 in Madrid. A private collection filled with all the great painters everyone knows and loves. A beautiful museum somewhat less frequented than the Prado. Not crowded at all on a Saturday morning. So glad we visited, even when we had already seen so much art in Spain.

reviewnospace:
This museum is free on Monday from 12.00 to 4pm. I arrived at 11.40am & already the queue was enormous, but it moved really quickly & I was inside by 12.05.
The modern collection is the highlight for me. Some wonderful Impressionist works including the best Manet portrait I have seen (of an equestrian woman). Great German Expressionist paintings, lovely Rodin sculptures, some fascinating early realistic Kandinsky & this is just so he tip of the iceberg. The earlier collection has Canaletto, Rembrandt, a large Flemish collection..... You need 2.5 hours just to see the modern collection alone. There are lots of seats, which makes the visit much less tiring. Highly recommended.

Great German Expressionist paintings, lovely Rodin sculptures, some fascinating early realistic Kandinsky & this is just so he tip of the iceberg. The earlier collection has Canaletto, Rembrandt, a large Flemish collection..... You need 2.5 hours just to see the modern collection alone. quote: Bring comfy shoes and plenty of time
reviewnospace: Great collection of European art. The entrance is free on mondays, but better come before 12 to get a good spot in line. I suggest bringing a small bottle of water in a small bag (a bigger one must be left in storage) because we finished completely dehydrated after 3 hours.

reviewnospace: We loved this museum. Modest entry charge and a great variety of paintings to see. Don't miss the cafe as this is great too. The museum shop also offers a range of gifts and mementos to bring away.

reviewnospace: This is an incredible collection of famous modern paintings in a great building. Unlike the Prado I took advantage of the free entrance at 7.00 pm as the queue was far shorter. I was able to sit opposite the entrance having a bite to eat and a beer while the queue quickly cleared meaning I got in about 7.15 without having to queue. This left plenty of time to do a tour of the salons before closing at 9.00.

reviewnospace: Nice mix of interesting paintings from ancient to modern paintings. Tickets queue is not that long so you can just buy the tickets there in the museum.

reviewnospace: What a delightful surprise! We visited primarily because we had purchased a multi-museum pass to see the Prado and Reina Sofia. We expected a much smaller, less distinguished collection--but even though many works were on loan, the Thyssen still offered a fantastic selection of impressionist and modern art. Fans of more traditional art will not be disappointed, either--the collections spans centuries of some of the most well-known art and artists. It's also a lovely building very near the other two major museums. If I had researched more in advance, we would've set aside a bit more time to browse the modern collections. Highly recommended!

We expected a much smaller, less distinguished collection--but even though many works were on loan, the Thyssen still offered a fantastic selection of impressionist and modern art. Fans of more traditional art will not be disappointed, either--the collections spans centuries of some of the most well-known art and artists. It's also a lovely building very near the other two major museums. If I had researched more in advance, we would've set aside a bit more time to browse the modern collections. Highly recommended!

reviewnospace: A wonderful collection covering the history of Western Art with the second collection of largely more modern art from Thyseeen's widow. Worth a full day to enjoy properly. Unless you love Goya and Velasquez, make this your first gallery priority in Madrid
titleopinion: Better than the Prado. A wonderful collection covering the history of Western Art with the second collection of largely more modern art from Thyseeen's widow. Worth a full day to enjoy properly. Unless you love Goya and Velasquez, make this your first gallery priority in Madrid

quote: Don't miss great arts you may not know. Lesser works by the greats!
reviewnospace: We enjoyed this museum for its wide variety and the spanning of the ages. It is well layed out and keeps you moving because you never know what the next room brings. Many arts from all of the eras and the audio guide a must. It doesn't take long to see the two floors, so much fun. Better gift selection than Prado.
titleopinion: Don't miss great arts you may not know. Lesser works by the greats!. We enjoyed this museum for its wide variety and the spanning of the ages. It is well layed out and keeps you moving because you never know what the next room brings. Many arts from all of the eras and the audio guide a must. It doesn't take long to see the two floors, so much fun. Better gift selection than Prado.

reviewnospace: It was easy to get around and follow the development and history of art. Photos allowed (non-flash). Helpful staff. There was enough detail - but not too much - covering the last 700 years or so of art, and thus made it easy to understand how art has evolved over the centuries.
titleopinion: Excellent, even for non-specialists. It was easy to get around and follow the development and history of art. Photos allowed (non-flash). Helpful staff. There was enough detail - but not too much - covering the last 700 years or so of art, and thus made it easy to understand how art has evolved over the centuries.

reviewnospace:
While the Prado is actually a bit overwhelming with all the old master pieces the museum is perfect and easy to visit and enjoy.
You can wander through it in one meandering path seeing all rooms and glide through the history of Art from medieval time up to the present in a roughly chronological order seeing some great works on your way.
Best of all taking pictures is allowed so iI created myself a wonderful slide show as a background for my computer
titleopinion: Perfect Museum. While the Prado is actually a bit overwhelming with all the old master pieces the museum is perfect and easy to visit and enjoy.  You can wander through it in one meandering path seeing all rooms and glide through the history of Art from medieval time up to the present in a roughly chronological order seeing some great works on your way. Best of all taking pictures is allowed so iI created myself a wonderful slide show as a background for my computer

quote: Beautiful art collection and beautiful museum
reviewnospace: This is a beautiful museum and I would say number 3 of the top 4 museums in Madrid. It takes about half a day to visit. Collection spans art history. Beautiful cafe. Best gift shop of all the museums.
titleopinion: Beautiful art collection and beautiful museum. This is a beautiful museum and I would say number 3 of the top 4 museums in Madrid. It takes about half a day to visit. Collection spans art history. Beautiful cafe. Best gift shop of all the museums.

reviewnospace: You wonder whether the rapid accumulation of this collection ad as much to do with its variety as the taste of the benefactors. Regardless it's a beautiful property and the art is accessible and engaging. The bistro is a good spot to nourish yourself physically in between floors or before going on the Prado.
titleopinion: Eclectic, almost eccentric. You wonder whether the rapid accumulation of this collection ad as much to do with its variety as the taste of the benefactors. Regardless it's a beautiful property and the art is accessible and engaging. The bistro is a good spot to nourish yourself physically in between floors or before going on the Prado.

reviewnospace: TripAdvisor has been pushing me to review this attraction. It is breathtaking. It should be high on anyone's' list. However, I am at a loss as to what to say that hasn't been said. Go if you can. It is all it is cracked up to be.
titleopinion: Breath taikng collection. TripAdvisor has been pushing me to review this attraction. It is breathtaking. It should be high on anyone's' list. However, I am at a loss as to what to say that hasn't been said. Go if you can. It is all it is cracked up to be.

reviewnospace: This is really a nice place to spend some hours. Nice view from the café terrace as well! The whole experience is great.
titleopinion: Lovely museum and great café. This is really a nice place to spend some hours. Nice view from the café terrace as well! The whole experience is great.

reviewnospace:
This is a smaller museum (can be toured in a couple of hours or a morning) than those near by (Queen Sofia and Prado), Its collection covers several centuries of paintings in a very nice building.

If you like museums don´t miss it.

reviewnospace: Great selection of some fine art . Very comfortable museum and a good coffee shop . Not too crowded and centrally situated . There is something appealing for everyone here!
titleopinion: Some superb art on show. Great selection of some fine art . Very comfortable museum and a good coffee shop . Not too crowded and centrally situated . There is something appealing for everyone here!

quote: Don’t miss the 'Vogue like a painting'
reviewnospace:
This exhibition is exeptional.
It merges art and fashion thru photography that is really unique.
The photographers took the ideas from known paintings.
I specific loved Tim Walker's works.
The Vogue archive is a gem.
This exhibition will be open until Oct 12th 2015

reviewnospace: Thysenn museum holds a very big and nice collection of art combining modern art with classical pieces. the museum is spacious and the paintings are well assembled in groups. Also has a very nice cafeteria.
titleopinion: My favorite museum in Madrid. Thysenn museum holds a very big and nice collection of art combining modern art with classical pieces. the museum is spacious and the paintings are well assembled in groups. Also has a very nice cafeteria.

reviewnospace: While not as large as the Prado, this museum offers a very good collection of art from the 13th century through the present day. Contains some outstanding works!
titleopinion: LITTLE KNOWN GEM............................................. While not as large as the Prado, this museum offers a very good collection of art from the 13th century through the present day. Contains some outstanding works!

reviewnospace: This was the first museum we went to, because we did not have a lot of time in madrid, we decided to go to this one and the Prado. Needless to say the Prado seemed like a nicer museum and more tourist friendly, especially for someone like me who knows absolutely zero about art. Really did enjoy the audio tour to learn more about the collections.
titleopinion: Enjoyed Prado more. This was the first museum we went to, because we did not have a lot of time in madrid, we decided to go to this one and the Prado. Needless to say the Prado seemed like a nicer museum and more tourist friendly, especially for someone like me who knows absolutely zero about art. Really did enjoy the audio tour to learn more about the collections.

quote: well displayed Art and not overcrowded
reviewnospace: Beautiful to walk through (warm colors kind of relax) and you´ll find some nice surprises. Do get the entrance for all three museums since they are all in walking distance: Prado, Reina Sofia and this one.
titleopinion: well displayed Art and not overcrowded. Beautiful to walk through (warm colors kind of relax) and you´ll find some nice surprises. Do get the entrance for all three museums since they are all in walking distance: Prado, Reina Sofia and this one.

reviewnospace: Having visited and enjoyed the Museo Reina Sofia and paid due homage to the Museo del Prado, we were bowled over by the Museo Thyssen-Bornemisva. If your favourite style is heavy classic then Museo del Prado must not be missed but if you prefer the Impressionists and more contemporary works, or a good representative collection spanning 17th to 19th century continental work, and are short of time or boot leather, then we would say forget del Prado and major on the amazing and beautifully displayed Thyssen-Bornemisva collections nearby, followed by the impressive Reina Sofia with Picasso’s powerful Guernica as its central attraction but with also a fascinating collection of works by Miró, Dali and others, not to mention an extensive display of more recent pieces by Spanish artists, and some haunting black and white films from the period of the civil war and WWII.
titleopinion: Bowled over. Having visited and enjoyed the Museo Reina Sofia and paid due homage to the Museo del Prado, we were bowled over by the Museo Thyssen-Bornemisva. If your favourite style is heavy classic then Museo del Prado must not be missed but if you prefer the Impressionists and more contemporary works, or a good representative collection spanning 17th to 19th century continental work, and are short of time or boot leather, then we would say forget del Prado and major on the amazing and beautifully displayed Thyssen-Bornemisva collections nearby, followed by the impressive Reina Sofia with Picasso’s powerful Guernica as its central attraction but with also a fascinating collection of works by Miró, Dali and others, not to mention an extensive display of more recent pieces by Spanish artists, and some haunting black and white films from the period of the civil war and WWII.

reviewnospace: Mesmerizing collection of art including works by some of the best painters of all centu-ries. Interesting temporary exhibit on science and art. It’s always a pleasure to come back to this museum
titleopinion: Spendid. Mesmerizing collection of art including works by some of the best painters of all centu-ries. Interesting temporary exhibit on science and art. It’s always a pleasure to come back to this museum

quote: a leisurely morning in Museo Thyssen-Bornemisza
reviewnospace: A nice variety of paintings on display, with room to stand back and appreciate them. Nice exhibition space also, Vogue exhibition on display during my visit, the exhibition was well put together and worth viewing if you can. The Museo Thyssen-Bornemisza is an excellent choice for spending a leisurely couple of hours
titleopinion: a leisurely morning in Museo Thyssen-Bornemisza. A nice variety of paintings on display, with room to stand back and appreciate them. quote: A great collection of European painters
reviewnospace: Gorgeous collection of Impressionist and other European painters. Get to it on the Hop-On-Hop-Off bus.
titleopinion: A great collection of European painters. Gorgeous collection of Impressionist and other European painters. Get to it on the Hop-On-Hop-Off bus.

reviewnospace: For lovers of Art from 13th to late 20th century including masterpieces by most of the renowned European artists. All displayed in an excellent setting of linked rooms. We thought it was easily superior to the other 2 art museums of Madrid. There was no queue when we visited on a Saturday morning and the galleries were not crowded so it was a pleasure to visit. A minimum of 3 hours for a reasonable and audio guide provides an excellent commentary
titleopinion: GREAT ART COLLECTION. For lovers of Art from 13th to late 20th century including masterpieces by most of the renowned European artists. All displayed in an excellent setting of linked rooms. We thought it was easily superior to the other 2 art museums of Madrid. There was no queue when we visited on a Saturday morning and the galleries were not crowded so it was a pleasure to visit. A minimum of 3 hours for a reasonable and audio guide provides an excellent commentary

reviewnospace: Varied collection of art work, from 15 th to 19 th century. 10euros entrance fee. A pleasure to walk around and view the different works. Went Sunday morning and there were no crowds, so we could look at the artist works without feeling like we had to move on. Art appreciation at your leisure.
titleopinion: Close up. Varied collection of art work, from 15 th to 19 th century. 10euros entrance fee. A pleasure to walk around and view the different works. Went Sunday morning and there were no crowds, so we could look at the artist works without feeling like we had to move on. Art appreciation at your leisure.

reviewnospace: Completing the big three (we did this one last) art museums, this was a nice ending. The Reina Sofia is modern, the Prado is huge, but the Thyssen is charming with its impressionist collection. In the words of one guide, it's "major works by minor artists and minor works by major artists." Incredibly easy to navigate - start on the top floor and follow the rooms in order across and down each floor. They are in chronological order.
titleopinion: A different take on art. Completing the big three (we did this one last) art museums, this was a nice ending. The Reina Sofia is modern, the Prado is huge, but the Thyssen is charming with its impressionist collection. In the words of one guide, it's  major works by minor artists and minor works by major artists.  Incredibly easy to navigate - start on the top floor and follow the rooms in order across and down each floor. They are in chronological order.

quote: be sure to visit the 2nd floor of the restaurant
reviewnospace:
This is a great museum with a lot of 18th - 20th century works. If you love the impressionists, this is a must see museum. And we visited on Monday - admission is free!! Bonus!
Also be sure to visit the upstairs of the restaurant. You can have a glass of wine and literally put your feet up. A very tranquil and zen space!!! don't miss it.

reviewnospace: What a great museum and fabulous collections. Well laid out and a fine way to spend several hours in Madrid.
titleopinion: A wonderful museum. What a great museum and fabulous collections. Well laid out and a fine way to spend several hours in Madrid.

location: Indian Rocks Beach, Florida, United States
reviewnospace: This is a collection of some of the finest works of art for Western Culture. Starting from early medieval times right on to the modern era. I was pleasantly surprised to find a great painting of Cosimo de' Medici by Bronzino ... I sat in awe gazing at the simple majesty of the portrait of the man who ushered modern civilization! Included is a fine collection of French Impressionism to include Toulouse Lautrec, as well some Russian Constructivist artists. There was a lovely Picasso Harlequin ... just to mention a few ...
titleopinion: Amazing Discovery (for me)!. This is a collection of some of the finest works of art for Western Culture. Starting from early medieval times right on to the modern era. Included is a fine collection of French Impressionism to include Toulouse Lautrec, as well some Russian Constructivist artists. There was a lovely Picasso Harlequin ... just to mention a few ...

reviewnospace: An absolutely lovely museum with a fantastic collection of top level Impressionist paintings that isn't as crowded as the Prado and can be viewed in a leisurely, calming atmosphere.
titleopinion: Great Impressionist collection. An absolutely lovely museum with a fantastic collection of top level Impressionist paintings that isn't as crowded as the Prado and can be viewed in a leisurely, calming atmosphere.

reviewnospace: This is a surprisingly comprehensive look at Western painting that even has rooms of German expressionist works and a nice sample of Hudson River School painters (not what I was expecting in a European museum). Could be seen in two very fast-paced hours, but three or more would be much better. There's enough here that it's probably best to not try to see it the same the day you go to the Prado.

reviewnospace: Give yourself plenty of time - they close early, give you the bum's rush and bolt out of there! Must be happy hour somewhere near by!

reviewnospace: This museum is very well organized, especially compared to the Prado. While the paintings are not as recognizable as those in the Prado or other major museums in Europe, the museum's pieces are just as outstanding. In addition, there's no crowding of the paintings. In short, a lovely place and well worth the time. Moreover, it's open on Mondays, with free admission from noon until 4:00 p.m.

reviewnospace: Do not miss this museum. I almost skipped it because I was museumed out, but so glad I went. It is full of a wide variety of painting treasure and is full of wonderful things. Not included on museum pass, but well, well worth the 10 euros.

took the teenager to the vogue like a painting exhibit, and also to the permanent collection.

quote: Spend an afternoon at Thyssen-Bornemisza museum
reviewnospace: Thyssen Bornemisza Museum is great museum to visit. Just enough of various styles of painting to make it possible to take in the whole museum without being overwhelmed. Monday afternoons are free after 12.00 noon. Don't be put off by the long queue - it moves really quickly once they open the doors. The Impressionist collection was good. The building style is grand and complements the exhibition. Recommended.

reviewnospace: This was the only museum that we went to during our last trip to Madrid. Nicely laid out, not crowded the day we were there, reasonable entrance fees and so many paintings by our favourite Impressionist painters on display.
titleopinion: Worth every Euro!. This was the only museum that we went to during our last trip to Madrid. Nicely laid out, not crowded the day we were there, reasonable entrance fees and so many paintings by our favourite Impressionist painters on display.

reviewnospace:
I had the opportunity to visit the museum on a Thursday afternoon, so a perfect time with not so many people around.
Let's start from the temporary exhibition: the Vogue like a painting. Absolutely stunning photos from the Vogue catalog where the authors tried to mimic the essence of a painting, via colors and posing. Some of them were really amazing!
About the permanent collection, instead, starting from the 2nd floor we can savor the evolution of the art, mainly paintings, through 7 centuries, from the religious icons on wood to the sometimes inexplicableness of modern art. Some great pieces, a lot of great names, Stendhal syndrome is always around the corner.
titleopinion: That's a museum!. I had the opportunity to visit the museum on a Thursday afternoon, so a perfect time with not so many people around. About the permanent collection, instead, starting from the 2nd floor we can savor the evolution of the art, mainly paintings, through 7 centuries, from the religious icons on wood to the sometimes inexplicableness of modern art. Some great pieces, a lot of great names, Stendhal syndrome is always around the corner.

reviewnospace: What a collection. A history of art in one place with the best museum cafe. Good walk around commentary as well. Could spend a whole day. Unlike other galleries it has plenty of places to sit and take the weight off. Must see in Madrid
titleopinion: Fantastic visit. What a collection. A history of art in one place with the best museum cafe. Good walk around commentary as well. Could spend a whole day. Unlike other galleries it has plenty of places to sit and take the weight off. Must see in Madrid

reviewnospace: One of the best art galleries I've ever been to. A real pleasure to be so close to some of my favourite art works.
titleopinion: Art lovers paradise. One of the best art galleries I've ever been to. A real pleasure to be so close to some of my favourite art works.

reviewnospace: Take the full pass if you prefer modern art and photographs this is the place for you, i remember i paid 12 euros for the full pass also u can take photos unlike other museums i advice to check the museum's shop nice stuff not expensive

quote: So many works of art by famous artists.
reviewnospace: Quite a lengthy stroll around this museum to see many, many great works of art, all by artists you will have heard of, many you will recognise. Well worth the sore feet . I just wish the people at the cash desks could have been more welcoming.

reviewnospace:
This is worth a visit!

reviewnospace: stunning buiding, great exhibits, gardens and rest area, a little oasis on the prado walk. Well worth a visit

reviewnospace: We had not planned to visit this museum due to the relevance El Prado and Reina Sofia have. Howver, because we wanted to see one of Degas' paintings decide to buy tickets. It is a very formal and classy place with paintings from other famous artists like Picasso, Dali, Monet, Reubens, Van Gogh, and many other famous ones. It is well run and organized. The store is one of the best museum shops we've visited, and don't miss the terrace restaurant for an after visit snack or full lunch. Prices are reasonable for both museum entrance and food. The location is perfect if you are already set on El Prado or Sofía.

reviewnospace:
We visited this gallery and were quite pleased that we did !

First of all its a nice walk down a tree lined boulevard ..continue on and you are at the Prado. It's an easy size to,navigate In a few hours..not at all overwhelming. Plus you can leave it was go back behind a block or two blocks and find a few lovely rooftop terrace bars for a nice glass of wine and to rest your weary feet ! ( Tartan Roof .. Circulars de Bellas Artes ) if it's busy with an event ..look across the street ..hotel on the corner has a nice one as well) Certainly this Gallwry is worth a visit !

quote: BEST museum of the Golden Triangle
reviewnospace: As the title says; I extremely loved my time at Thyssen, unfortunately I only got to spend an hour or so there because I entered late on a Monday (which is free to the public from 1200 to 1600). Every art I saw just made me fall in love with this place even more, the scenery arts were simply amazing. I would love to go back there and spend a few more hours! A MUST MUST MUST visit!

reviewnospace: We visited Madrid especially to see the Zurbaran Exhibit because many of the paintings in the exhibit had never been exhibited in Spain before. At the end of the War of Independence, the French troops ransacked the art in Seville's churches and monasteries and brought the art to Paris. Over the years this was sold individually to museums and individuals. Zurbaran was one of the best artists of Spain and this exhibition proves it. It was thoroughly enjoyable.

reviewnospace: There is less of a sense here of a museum as an educational construct and more an interesting collection by an individual. That said it is an amazing collection and wonderful that it is accessible to the public. Some wonderful works by major artists and a must to complete your art education. A map of the floors is available and the recommended approach is to start at the top. We missed this initially and went through the ground floor and had to go back in at the entry. Not a problem but a bit confusing. Temporary exhibitions are not included on the Art Pass for the big three but you can pay separately if interested. We tried the café to get a coffee but so busy we left without ordering.

quote: A worthy cousin to the Prado
reviewnospace: Not on the same level, of course, but interesting in its own eclectic way. It was interesting to see so many paintings in the style of their more famous examples- it really showed how painters copied what was successful and how accreditation must be so difficult with unsigned discoveries.

quote: Must be one of the best galleries in the world!
reviewnospace: Several people ( including many Spanish) advised us to visit this collection and we were not disappointed! The art is beautifully displayed, and physically accessible. There is something from every era and there wasn't one piece that disappointed. Indeed it was difficult to choose what NOT to look at, because the quality of the collection was so good. The audio tour was excellent, however, and helped us to navigate the wonders of this museo, so we would recommend getting the audio tour. If it was a choice between the Prado and this museo, I would definitely choose this. The restaurant/ cafe is pleasant and not overpriced, as well.

quote: Favourite of the Madrid triangle museums
reviewnospace:
A lovely building amended and expanded as the collection has grown. Good disability access points all round.
A lovely peaceful cafe area above the lower gardens.
Confusing layout, it appears all Madrid museums should be viewed top to bottom.
If you are a fan of A time period you'll get your fix here. Renaissance through to pop culture.
Some fantastic works of art on show, sadly way too many out on loan when we visited so don't visit with a specific work of art in mind as it might not be there, go for the general cover of an artist.
Missing a few notable artists, Monet for example, a good few British artists also missing.
Free wifi as you go round left me sitting for some time consuming art and reading all the internet could tell me about the artist, I really enjoyed learning in front of the art. Plenty of places to sit to do this too.
I would rate this museum highly, but for so much art being out on loan, a tiny replacement in its place really isn't a good substitute.

reviewnospace: We saved money by buying a combo ticket that also included the Prado and the Reina Sofia. We spent over 6 hours at the museum, including over an hour at the cafe. We had a terrific meal there and took advantage of a MasterCard special to get free dessert. The museum itself is a comfortable temperature and bright and relatively modern. The exterior is not exciting, but the courtyard is nice. Although, the sign says to stay off the grass.The art spans the 13th to early 20th centuries, which is a lot to cover, but it does it well. There are some wonderful pieces by Holbein, van Gogh, Chagall, Hockney and more. They let you take photographs without a flash.

quote: The crown jewel of art museums
reviewnospace:
Give yourself one long day in the city - 2 nights - 1 day. Or two if you have it. But not 5 like I had, unless you can afford the best hotel in town.

Suggested tour:
Pack a picnic lunch and head out early. See the Guernica first while you are fresh and skip the rest of the Reina Sophia (unless you like Renaissance art). Then slip over to the National Museum of Natural Sciences (esp if you are traveling with children - dinosaurs and stuffed animals - well done) A good break from art museums. Then trip through the National Archaeological Museum, that does a great job of showing cultural change over time and the development of art on the Iberian Peninsula.

Take your lunch to the Botanical Gardens and eat hearty for the final leg of your day - Museo Thyssen-Bornemisza. Here you will sit on comfortable settees and wonder at the walls filled with modern greats and early masters. Wander aimlessly through the galleries and repeat over and over in the same gallery.

This art museum should be the crown in Madrid's gallery listings. I spent 2.5 hours there in just a few of the modern galleries. The place was modern, well-organized and the collections made sense, reflecting the interests of the man who had amassed it. I felt drunk and full of privilege when I left this museum, happy to know in one place so much great art was being held in trust for the people of the world.

Then trip through the National Archaeological Museum, that does a great job of showing cultural change over time and the development of art on the Iberian Peninsula.   Take your lunch to the Botanical Gardens and eat hearty for the final leg of your day - Museo Thyssen-Bornemisza. Here you will sit on comfortable settees and wonder at the walls filled with modern greats and early masters. Wander aimlessly through the galleries and repeat over and over in the same gallery.  This art museum should be the crown in Madrid's gallery listings. I spent 2.5 hours there in just a few of the modern galleries. The place was modern, well-organized and the collections made sense, reflecting the interests of the man who had amassed it. I felt drunk and full of privilege when I left this museum, happy to know in one place so much great art was being held in trust for the people of the world.

reviewnospace: Comprehensive collection, about 1.5 floor of Old Masters and 1 floor of Modern Masters. The Old Masters houses most important painters, but only meager examples of their work. Other than that, there are a lot of works by lesser known painters. The Modern Masters holds more big names, but then again, modern art is ridiculous. This museum is not worth it, just go to the Prado and Reina Sofia if art is your thang.
titleopinion: Comprehensive but nothing really spectacular. Comprehensive collection, about 1.5 floor of Old Masters and 1 floor of Modern Masters. The Old Masters houses most important painters, but only meager examples of their work. Other than that, there are a lot of works by lesser known painters. The Modern Masters holds more big names, but then again, modern art is ridiculous. This museum is not worth it, just go to the Prado and Reina Sofia if art is your thang.

reviewnospace:
We visited this art museum on a weekday afternoon in September. There were no lines for tickets and the museum itself was very uncrowded. This may be because it is the junior member of the big three art museums in Madrid. Not only is it less crowded but is smaller and less overwhelming. Two-three hours is sufficient but certainly not an exhaustive visit. However,Mitch is very easy to pick and choose.
Now to the collection: as mentioned it is eclectic. The old masters are there, including Rubens, Titian, and Rembrandt. There is also a nice selection of 18th century works. Visitors will love the fairly large collection of impressionist works. All the greats are there in multiples. Always the favorite, Van Gogh, but some beautiful Renoir, Degas, Manet, Monet, etc. it is not the Musee D'Orsay in Paris but it is wonderful. And you have each piece to yourself. Finally there is a fair amount of modern works. Picassos, of course, but Brach, Dali, Miro, Kandinsky, and Lichtenstein, to name a few.
I highly recommend this highly representative collection in a great setting. As an aside, the cafe was elegant and inviting with very good and extensive menu.
titleopinion: Excellent and eclectic collection. We visited this art museum on a weekday afternoon in September. There were no lines for tickets and the museum itself was very uncrowded. There's also a big gift shop and you can print or order for home delivery a reproduction of any of the paintings!

The entrance is free on Mondays between 12 and 16.

I popped in on impulse and had a tasty sandwich which was on the 'snack' menu but there are larger options too. The coca cola was ice cold and the service quick. Now I can't wait to visit the museum...

The Thyssen-Bornemisza collection os impressive, particularly with respect to its wide span over five centuries. I am personally not too thrilled about religious art and renaissance painers (2nd floor) but I enjoyed the first floor and the ground floor where modern works can be found.
Tip: Mondays 12h-16h the entrance is free.

quote: Some excellent exhibits and a pleasant few hours to find some gems. Something for everyone.
reviewnospace: We recently visited this Art Museum and I really enjoyed it. The only thing I could fault was the lack of direction to some of the exhibits. You are given the floor plan so you can find your way through each exhibit area - this is fine. However, it lacks any detail on what type of exhibit ( ie, modern, classic, etc ) is in each area until you actually arrive into the room. ( I didn't hire a walkthrough speakerphone so I don't know if this gives any extra information on the whereabouts of the pieces or just information on the exhibit pieces). We visited on Monday 24th August so entry was free from 12.00 to 16.00 ; as is the case for all Mondays, as this time period is sponsored by Mastercard. I would recommend this museum to everyone and hope to get back there again. It will be easier to find my way to the areas that interest me most next time.
titleopinion: Some excellent exhibits and a pleasant few hours to find some gems. Something for everyone.. We recently visited this Art Museum and I really enjoyed it. However, it lacks any detail on what type of exhibit ( ie, modern, classic, etc ) is in each area until you actually arrive into the room. ( I didn't hire a walkthrough speakerphone so I don't know if this gives any extra information on the whereabouts of the pieces or just information on the exhibit pieces). We visited on Monday 24th August so entry was free from 12.00 to 16.00 ; as is the case for all Mondays, as this time period is sponsored by Mastercard. I would recommend this museum to everyone and hope to get back there again. It will be easier to find my way to the areas that interest me most next time.

reviewnospace: from the get go , the standard exposition is free and yes that includes the Goya , 2 or 3 very large floors of tones of history, it's really easy to find and maybe at 10 to 20 minutes from El Retiro at foot. I'm not going to tell you a lot about the history and the art you can find in this museum because I'm really not a fan but if i had the option to go back in time , i will still go again, it's really beautiful

reviewnospace: Located essentially "kitty corner" across from the Prado, it's a modern, well curated art museum. Not overwhelming like the Prado due to its more manageable size (but don't miss the Prado), it has a collection of historic and contemporary art. Also has a nice gift shop and cafe/restaurant. Highly recommend it.
titleopinion: A delightful art museum!. Located essentially  kitty corner  across from the Prado, it's a modern, well curated art museum. Not overwhelming like the Prado due to its more manageable size (but don't miss the Prado), it has a collection of historic and contemporary art. Also has a nice gift shop and cafe/restaurant. Highly recommend it.

quote: Beautiful gallery, free on Monday afternoons, highly recommended!
reviewnospace:
Beautiful petite gallery filled with treasures. We went on a Monday afternoon as it was free entry, just a 15 minute walk from our hotel in front of the Palace Real.
Even on a free afternoon in August we walked straight in, no queuing. There we're enough people milling round but not so many you couldn't get. Clear view of each piece and enjoy the art.
The gallery is artfully curated. All the pieces are positioned at eye level on a good space of wall, very few had barriers in front, and I don't think any were behind glass or lights. The largest pieces had their own wall and it wasn't so crowded that we couldn't stand back and take in the whole piece.
We particularly loved the colour of the walls which seemed to set off every piece just beautifully. It was a sort of apricot Tuscan sunset colour - which you wouldn't expect to work so well - and added a warmth and coziness to the many small rooms of the gallery.
Well worth the visit.
Our 13 year old wasn't too happy with the idea - boring annoying parents!! But she admitted afterwards she enjoyed it.
Highly recommended and not too heavy for the casual visitor.
titleopinion: Beautiful gallery, free on Monday afternoons, highly recommended!. Beautiful petite gallery filled with treasures. We went on a Monday afternoon as it was free entry, just a 15 minute walk from our hotel in front of the Palace Real. Even on a free afternoon in August we walked straight in, no queuing. All the pieces are positioned at eye level on a good space of wall, very few had barriers in front, and I don't think any were behind glass or lights. The largest pieces had their own wall and it wasn't so crowded that we couldn't stand back and take in the whole piece. We particularly loved the colour of the walls which seemed to set off every piece just beautifully. It was a sort of apricot Tuscan sunset colour - which you wouldn't expect to work so well - and added a warmth and coziness to the many small rooms of the gallery. Well worth the visit. Our 13 year old wasn't too happy with the idea - boring annoying parents!! But she admitted afterwards she enjoyed it. Highly recommended and not too heavy for the casual visitor.

reviewnospace:
This place is amazing for the range of art on display. Even more amazing is the art is so accessible, non flash photography is allowed!
You'll need a few hours to do it justice.
titleopinion: Another must see. This place is amazing for the range of art on display. Even more amazing is the art is so accessible, non flash photography is allowed! You'll need a few hours to do it justice.

quote: Amazing private collection turned over to Spain
reviewnospace:
So many different styles and eras of painting that is represented. The Spain masters, Goya, Velasquez, but impressionists, like Gauguin, Matisse and even two rooms of American masters, like Singer Sargent.

Also went to the Prado, and really like descriptions of each work.
titleopinion: Amazing private collection turned over to Spain. So many different styles and eras of painting that is represented. The Spain masters, Goya, Velasquez, but impressionists, like Gauguin, Matisse and even two rooms of American masters, like Singer Sargent.   Also went to the Prado, and really like descriptions of each work.

reviewnospace: Loved this Museum. Good mix of Modern and Classic art. Especially worth it if you go during the free hours
titleopinion: All kinds of art. Loved this Museum. Good mix of Modern and Classic art. Especially worth it if you go during the free hours

reviewnospace: Visiting this museum was like walking in the history of art. Amazing collection, beautifully set. I was really very happy to have chosen to visit this museum during my short stay at Madrid. Do not miss it!
titleopinion: Amazing museum!. Visiting this museum was like walking in the history of art. Amazing collection, beautifully set. I was really very happy to have chosen to visit this museum during my short stay at Madrid. Do not miss it!

reviewnospace: I enjoyed the Thyssen gallery, on the top floors you have some typical classic art to enjoy, before working your way down to view some more modern art. There are couple of really nice pieces in here by Linder, Dali and Lautrec - and loads more!! Go on a Monday afternoon when the entrance is free!
titleopinion: Pretty interesting gallery. I enjoyed the Thyssen gallery, on the top floors you have some typical classic art to enjoy, before working your way down to view some more modern art. There are couple of really nice pieces in here by Linder, Dali and Lautrec - and loads more!! Go on a Monday afternoon when the entrance is free!

quote: Free on Mondays starting at 12 noon
reviewnospace: Great collection..eclectic and interesting. A definite visit. Remember entrance is free on Mondays starting at 12 noon and it is open until 4 pm. We got there around 11:45 a.m. and had to wait about 10 minutes until we were inside so not a big deal at all.

We got there around 11:45 a.m. and had to wait about 10 minutes until we were inside so not a big deal at all.

quote: The third of the big museums but equally good
reviewnospace: When we were planning to visit Madrid's museums we thought this one would be not up to the level to the other two Prado and Reina Sofia, but we are amazed, it as good as the others and enormously rich. Do not miss . The best way to do it, a day for a museum, so if you have three days - devote half a day to each of them.

quote: Nice way to spend an afternoon
reviewnospace:
An enjoyable afternoon spent visiting this impressive museum. Starts in chronological order from 3rd floor, who it progressively reveals the changing subject matter and styles from 1400-1900's.
We spent 3 hrs visiting this museum, but could have easily stayed longer. It closed at 7pm, unlike the Prado which closes at 8pm. If using a Madrid Card there is free entry to permanent collection but not the temporary exhibition.

reviewnospace: Brilliant for kids as there is such a wide range of styles and paintings. Really well priced and not that busy when we went
titleopinion: Great all round gallery. Brilliant for kids as there is such a wide range of styles and paintings. Really well priced and not that busy when we went

reviewnospace: A must see! This is a true gem among art museums ,with its impressive and educational collection paintings!
titleopinion: A Must See. A must see! This is a true gem among art museums ,with its impressive and educational collection paintings!

reviewnospace: Brilliant museum with a wide range of work. You are sure to find something that makes you go "Wow". Also has a great restaurant!
titleopinion: A great museum.. Brilliant museum with a wide range of work. You are sure to find something that makes you go  Wow . Also has a great restaurant!

reviewnospace: Myself, husband and two teenage boys visited recently after debating which of the art museums to go to. We chose this one as we felt it offered the biggest variety of European art. It cost 38 euros for the four of us to enter the resident art exhibition which was set over 3 floors, as well as the 'Vogue like a painting' exhibition (which I really liked). A welcomed chance to cool down from the heat of Madrid. Hint- start on the top floor for chronological age order of art, taking about 3 hours to see both exhibitions. A little disappointed that the Monet paintings were on loan, but nevertheless a great opportunity for us to experience art from the 16th century onwards.

A little disappointed that the Monet paintings were on loan, but nevertheless a great opportunity for us to experience art from the 16th century onwards.

reviewnospace: Wonderful, judicious and tasteful selection of European & North American works. Enjoyably curated ( other than too many paintings under glass). Plenty of space to appreciate the art, in an attractive classical building. A good shop and modern cafe round things off well. Highly recommended.
titleopinion: Definitive private art collection. Wonderful, judicious and tasteful selection of European & North American works. Enjoyably curated ( other than too many paintings under glass). Plenty of space to appreciate the art, in an attractive classical building. A good shop and modern cafe round things off well. Highly recommended.

quote: A mysterious and intriguing journey through the centuries of western art
reviewnospace: I only had time to visit one of the great museums of Madrid and think i made the correct choice. I hope to get back and visit the others In time but the Thyssen was one of the most relaxing experiences of the holiday. I was travelling solo so could really give time where i wanted. Though not overly knowledgeable in the arts my little knowledge was nice bumped by the fantastic audio guides which are brief but informative. A must see if you have an interest in art, if not then its a waste.

quote: Massive and impressive permanent collection and great special exhibits
reviewnospace:
The Thyssen-Borneemisza is located in "Museum Row," very close to El Prado and the Reina Sofia (as well as the smaller, but well worthwhile Museo Caixa).
We were warmly helped by a very friendly staff-member. She asked some questions and suggested that of the different special exhibits showing, we would probably enjoy the Raoul Dufy one most. Excellent recommendation! Though I was familiar with some of Dufy's work, I did not appreciate the depth of his talent, the variety of media in which he worked, and his wide range of styles. A super exhibit. My mom enjoyed the audio guide (and the nifty Dufy eyeglass case I bought for her- while buying a Dufy place-mat for myself in the small Dufy gift-shop at the end of the exhibit).
We spent a couple hours in the
We spent quite a while in the expansive permanent collection. Plenty of well-know artists, a few masterpieces, and a broad collection of 19th Century American paintings. Hard to believe such a large collection was assembled by private parties.
Great gift shop, too!

quote: Enthralling art museum in lovely Madrid
reviewnospace: When I knew I would be in Madrid for work I looked on line for the most important art galleries and this was reported as near or at the top. Once I arrived I saw exactly what other reviewers meant: it houses astonishing art, laid out room after room, and displayed in a beautiful building, itself a work of art--I especially liked the salmon-pink tone of the interior. Apparently known as the Golden Triangle of Art as it is one of the 3 national galleries-- the other two being the Prado and Reina Sofia-- the Thyssen was my favorite of the three. It was once the second largest private collection in the world. Be prepared to spend countless hours. When I finally left the building I realized half a day had gone by. Really worth a visit if you love art.

quote: Lovely museum, no queue or large crowd even during the free periods on Mondays
reviewnospace: I was expecting to be in and out quite quickly but I got quite immersed in it and spent about two and a half hours. It's bigger than I'd thought. It was great not to have to queue, I went at 1pm (it's free on Mondays from 12 noon till 4pm) and it wasn't that busy either. Pleasantly surprised and easier to get to than the other two museums that make up the big three!

reviewnospace:
This is one of Madrid's best museums by far. It is also my favorite. With Prado and Reina Sofía, it is one of the 3 important museums in Madrid. The Prado, we all know, will always be the Prado - but you need tons of time to see it all and distribution, logistics, etc.are not easy if you are not familiar with it.
Thyssen-Bornemisza collection has wonderful paintings - probably one of the best private collections in the world and it also houses fantastic exhibitions. The building is beautiful, the art works are well organized (you can visit one floor at a time) and feature art works from the 13th to late 20th.Century. It is definitely a MUST if you visit Madrid. Free entrance on Monday afternoons and don't forget to visit the shop. If you take the time, you'll find beautiful presents to take home for reasonable price.
titleopinion: The apple of my eye.. This is one of Madrid's best museums by far. It is also my favorite. With Prado and Reina Sofía, it is one of the 3 important museums in Madrid. reviewnospace:
Having been to many major museums in the world , including intimate knowledge of New Yorks finest , and as a lover of impressionist art , I found this collection to be extraordinary and quite a surprise .
Very happy I skipped a return to the Prado and enjoyed this instead . Wow .

Having been to many major museums in the world , including intimate knowledge of New Yorks finest , and as a lover of impressionist art , I found this collection to be extraordinary and quite a surprise . reviewnospace: I came upon upon this art gallery quite by accident on a Monday afternoon. It so happened that after 12:00 pm you get in free instead of the normal price. There is an excellent selection of portraits and paintings to view and the museum itself is just off the Castellana

reviewnospace:
This was the last of the big 3(Prado, Reina Sofia and Museo Thyssen) which we visited. It was also my favourite. Perhaps this was because it was a collection of different paintings from different genres of painting. It was an eclectic mix. This was all free as
the Thyssen family had intended in their quest to bring art to the masses.. In contrast the Vogue Collection which was not free was a damp sqib in comparison to the great masters.
titleopinion: My Favourite Museum in Madrid. This was the last of the big 3(Prado, Reina Sofia and Museo Thyssen) which we visited. It was also my favourite. This was all free as the Thyssen family had intended in their quest to bring art to the masses.. In contrast the Vogue Collection which was not free was a damp sqib in comparison to the great masters.

reviewnospace: In spite of what Rick Steeves says about this museum "major works by minor artists and minor works by major artists", we liked it a lot. It's not as all-encompassing as the Reina Sofia, but many of the paintings are very interesting. There are many artists represented, and this is a museum well worth visiting to get a feel for artwork from people you might not know, but who are worthy of getting to know.

reviewnospace: The people who loves different diferent periods of art will discover in this museum paintings from the oldest collections and most recent ones to. I recomend that you start you journey from the top floor and visit the ground floor at the finish so you can enjoy the tour as a travelling between the ages.

quote: The history of western art in 3 hours
reviewnospace: This is an amazing collection that allows one to view how western art has developed over the past five centuries. It has its fair share of master pieces but more importantly it covers almost every element of how art thought has progressed. If you are an art neophyte like me, its a college course with the real stuff in front of you. Absolutely not to be missed

quote: Paintings and culture in Madrid City Center
reviewnospace: It is a very nice place to enjoy pictures from painter that are really important in art history. It is close to Museo del Padro and Museo Reina Sofía, so if you go to the Thyssen you can visit the other two as well, the problem is that you have a lot to see and probably you will need more than one day for doing this.

reviewnospace: This private collection covers 800 years of history of paintings ranging from Simone Martini and Duccio to Rauschenberg and Aurbach. Notable are early paintings of Van Gogh, Gauguin and other impressionists before they developed their own style. Not to be missed is the Zurbaràn show that brought important paintings from around the world. Need at least two hours.
titleopinion: Very Important Museum!. This private collection covers 800 years of history of paintings ranging from Simone Martini and Duccio to Rauschenberg and Aurbach. Notable are early paintings of Van Gogh, Gauguin and other impressionists before they developed their own style. Not to be missed is the Zurbaràn show that brought important paintings from around the world. Need at least two hours.

reviewnospace: With seven centuries inner one roof, allow yourself the time to dwell on the pieces and try to absorb a fantastic visage through the evolution of European painting and ultimately modern art. Audio guides are pretty good.
titleopinion: Two hours was not enough. With seven centuries inner one roof, allow yourself the time to dwell on the pieces and try to absorb a fantastic visage through the evolution of European painting and ultimately modern art. Audio guides are pretty good.

reviewnospace: This was definitely my favorite of the museums in Madrid. Even though they tell you start on the 2nd floor, start at the 1st floor so that you are not too tired to see the amazing impressionist collection!

quote: The best private gallery ,, and different
reviewnospace: OK, so you have been to lots of galleries and have be in a little overcome with endless depictions of religious sceness and iconography,, tired of endless corridors of Renaissance art ,,, maybe you like that ,,, but after I while I tire of it. This place is the BEST gallery I have ever been to, if you want to go to a gallery where in just one room Van Gophs, Renoir, Pissaro, Whistler, Degas all hang together then this is it - is a great collection , something for everyone,, and the terrace cafe outside is well worth a stop ( it's nowhere near as expensive as it looks , sandwich and 2 drinks € 10 )

quote: Excellent Museum - well worth entrance fee
reviewnospace: This museum was my favourite , even over the El Prado. The entrance when you walk in had HUGE paintings of the Royal Family and of the Benefactor family as well. The museum was clean and well kept, the staff were very friendly and they have the capability of printing out your favourite picture downstairs , so you can frame it when you get home. Some of the artwork brought us to tears....allow a good four hours. We did not rush through this museum.
titleopinion: Excellent Museum - well worth entrance fee. This museum was my favourite , even over the El Prado. The entrance when you walk in had HUGE paintings of the Royal Family and of the Benefactor family as well. The museum was clean and well kept, the staff were very friendly and they have the capability of printing out your favourite picture downstairs , so you can frame it when you get home. Some of the artwork brought us to tears....allow a good four hours. We did not rush through this museum.

quote: On my list of top museums!
reviewnospace:
This was by far the best art museum I have been to, and well worth the time spent to look around. I paid only 12 e to see both the general collection and one exhibit. I love the way the gallery was laid out, so that comparisons could be made between the artists and time periods. The museum is also not so large that it is daunting, which is nice.
The highlight of my museum trip, however, was the Vogue exhibit which is there for a few more months I believe. Whoever put this exhibition together did a fantastic job. If you like fashion photography ( and even if you don't), this is a must see. There is also one video installation and two garments to see. Great care was taken in painting the walls in order to best showcase each work.
titleopinion: On my list of top museums!. This was by far the best art museum I have been to, and well worth the time spent to look around. Whoever put this exhibition together did a fantastic job. If you like fashion photography ( and even if you don't), this is a must see. There is also one video installation and two garments to see. Great care was taken in painting the walls in order to best showcase each work.

reviewnospace: This was an eclectic collection of art, but it was fun to visit. We went on a free evening, so it was definitely worth it to see great works of art at no cost. There isn't much of a logic to how the museum is laid out because it is the Thyssen family's personal collection. There are definitely notable paintings there by artists such as Degas, Van Gogh, and Dali, but you have to search for them.

It was great and everyone got something out of it. It is not crowded and plenty of light to see the paintings and not feel like a crowded museum.
