quote: Great Museum with a Great FREE Time
reviewnospace: jThis museum, just up the street from the PRADO, is another great museum in Madrid. The museum features top notch artist with some of their best paintings plus the museum has a very generous free time. We arrived in Madrid on our way back to the airport and had time to take advantage of the FREE time. This museum is almost as great as the PRADO and that's saying a lot for me!

reviewnospace: Gorgeous collection of paintings. Out of the 3 main galleries this was my favourite. Its free to get in from 12pm on a Monday until 4pm, the queues go around the block but move fast. Really well worth seeing!

reviewnospace: Spent a wonderful 2/3 hours wandering amongst this amazing private collection good to get in early had some galleries to myself , plenty of space which was a change to the London galleries where it can be very busy, good coffee and shop plus opposite the Retiro Park.

Very close look and photography are allowed, in opposition to Prado

reviewnospace: Once private collection which is beautifully displayed and gives a quick run through of Western European Art with quite a few master-pieces on the way. Really needs two visits as old masters took the whole day and didn't have energy to do more than glance at what looked like very interesting collection of Impressionists. Temporary Exhibition on Zuburan was a real eye opener and excellent introduction to this lesser known artist. Very good audio guide, Café a bit disappointing as it was "wait to be seated" and seemed to be only lunches when all we wanted was frequent coffee and snacks!

reviewnospace:
For anybody with a good eye for art and style, this amazing sanctuary is the place to go. I have seen the permanent collections several times throughout the years, in good company or on my own. It has evolved with the times so positively that visitors are instantly taken by the wonderful paintings and the perfect way in which they are presented.

Temporary exhibitions are a good excuse to go back and re-visit parts of the collection which deserve more attention depending on the weather and your mood. And celebrate its existence in the restaurant or the chill-out.

I must confess I was not a big fan of Zurbaran's yesterday. Am converted today. It is definitely, as the museum advertises, "a new view", the kind of view that sticks in your eyes to remind you that chapter of the evolution of the great Spanish painters. It explains a lot about the great masters who followed the footsteps of Francisco and Juan Zurbaran.

Overall a thrilling display of good taste. Can't wait to enjoy it again.

reviewnospace: We bought a Paseo Art ticket for 26euros and visited the 3 big galleries in Madrid, one each day. This was my favourite. It was interesting to see the huge variety of art all in one gallery. We used the audio guide which made it even more enjoyable.

reviewnospace: This wonderful gallery with its beautifully hung works is an absolute must. We confined ourselves to early European paintings -Renaissance and Baroque. There are so many outstanding works by all the great artists and by some perhaps lesser known artists too. A superb visit and not as overwhelming as the Prado. We chose one of the free entry slots but it wasn't too crowded. Highly recommended.

reviewnospace: While not as extensive a collection s the Prado this is amazing when you consider that it was a private collection. Here as in the Prado the descriptions of the paintings are expansive and in English.
titleopinion: Worth a visit. While not as extensive a collection s the Prado this is amazing when you consider that it was a private collection. Here as in the Prado the descriptions of the paintings are expansive and in English.

reviewnospace: Everyone's heard of the Prado, everyone needs to hear about the Thyssen. The art was well organized and included work by the masters, including one of my faves, Carravagio. I also learned about excellent, little known North American painters. I like that they've tried to modernize the experience by allowing you to dress up like one of the paintings and take a selfie. Very clever. I will definitely visit this museum when I return to Madrid.
titleopinion: Beautiful Art, Will Definitely Return. Everyone's heard of the Prado, everyone needs to hear about the Thyssen. The art was well organized and included work by the masters, including one of my faves, Carravagio. I also learned about excellent, little known North American painters. I like that they've tried to modernize the experience by allowing you to dress up like one of the paintings and take a selfie. Very clever. I will definitely visit this museum when I return to Madrid.

quote: A "Must See" among the museums of Madrid
reviewnospace:
This is a delightful museum and my favorite in Madrid. The permanent collection spans 7 centuries. If you love art, this is a great place to visit--especially for modern art. They even have a few art pieces from Der Blaue Reiter. To me, this is a must see.
The museum is well laid out and the brochure is informative. Taking photos without flash is allowed. There is a nice gift shop. The restaurant/cafe attached to this museum has a very nice modern setting which offers a smaller, but well-prepared, range of items--from an outstanding cup of coffee to simple sandwiches to more complex culinary creations like roasted duck--and very good service.
titleopinion: A  Must See  among the museums of Madrid. This is a delightful museum and my favorite in Madrid. The permanent collection spans 7 centuries. If you love art, this is a great place to visit--especially for modern art. They even have a few art pieces from Der Blaue Reiter. To me, this is a must see. The museum is well laid out and the brochure is informative. Taking photos without flash is allowed. There is a nice gift shop. The restaurant/cafe attached to this museum has a very nice modern setting which offers a smaller, but well-prepared, range of items--from an outstanding cup of coffee to simple sandwiches to more complex culinary creations like roasted duck--and very good service.

quote: What a contrast to the Prado
reviewnospace: After our visit to the Prado, we went to this nearby museum. Quite a difference. The brochure is excellent, giving a detailed layout of the various rooms and their content. Each room is large and well lit with a large bench in the middle to rest or contemplate an interesting painting. The collection is just as interesting as the Prado, is well organized, and includes quite a few North American artists up through the 1940s. Another plus: there is a very nice clean and bright cafe to rest and refresh after a lot of art.

This is a very thorough art collection, one of the best in the world. It's not too big to take it all in at once, but if possible, try coming in the morning and then taking a break for lunch. Enjoy.

quote: Great European art across the centuries
reviewnospace: Probably my favorite art gallery. An excellent collection of painting from European and some American art across the centuries. Some of my favorite German Expressionist paintings. It is worth a visit to Madrid just to see them.

reviewnospace: Fantastic art collection spanning middle ages through contemporary. They even had an interactive #selfie section where you can imitate a painting, by sitting in front of a canvas and put on similar vestments the sitter in two particular paintings wear. A must see for art lovers!

reviewnospace: We primarily went to see a Dufy exhibition but of course also went around the permanent collection. We absolutely loved both the Dufy and the rest, and can't think of a more pleasant way to spend a few hours. The museum shop is also extremely good.

quote: The equal of the other two greats
reviewnospace: We scored three-for-one tickets at our hotel: the Prado (with a special Goya exhibition), the Reina Sofia, and the Thyssen-Bornemisza. We saw them in that order, with a few days between each museum so as not to overtax our brains and eyeballs. Well, as my title says, this museum is the equal of the other two. Although it tends to more contemporary works, the Thyssen also reaches back further in time and across continents to bring in American, British, French, and Russian masters to form a most satisfying collection. Plus, this was the only museum that allowed us to photograph the art. Again, a must see for art lovers.
titleopinion: The equal of the other two greats. We scored three-for-one tickets at our hotel: the Prado (with a special Goya exhibition), the Reina Sofia, and the Thyssen-Bornemisza. We saw them in that order, with a few days between each museum so as not to overtax our brains and eyeballs. Well, as my title says, this museum is the equal of the other two. Although it tends to more contemporary works, the Thyssen also reaches back further in time and across continents to bring in American, British, French, and Russian masters to form a most satisfying collection. Plus, this was the only museum that allowed us to photograph the art. Again, a must see for art lovers.

reviewnospace: I enjoy going to museums, particularly smaller museums with excellent art collections. The Thyssen-Bornemisza fit the bill perfectly. The large home that now shows the family's extensive collection is a perfect size. You can slowly stroll through the rooms and gaze at the art without feeling that you must keep moving quickly to be sure to hit the "must see's". There were so many pleasant surprises as I wandered through the rooms -- art and artists that I immediately recognized and art and artists with whom I was not familiar. I went on a Saturday and was quite surprised by how uncrowded the museum was -- there was no problem in getting "up close and personal" (up to the ropes) to look at the paintings. I loved how the collection spanned many years and was filled with Impressionists, post-Impressionists, and more contemporary works.
titleopinion: LOVED the Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum!. I enjoy going to museums, particularly smaller museums with excellent art collections. The Thyssen-Bornemisza fit the bill perfectly. The large home that now shows the family's extensive collection is a perfect size. There were so many pleasant surprises as I wandered through the rooms -- art and artists that I immediately recognized and art and artists with whom I was not familiar. I went on a Saturday and was quite surprised by how uncrowded the museum was -- there was no problem in getting  up close and personal  (up to the ropes) to look at the paintings. I loved how the collection spanned many years and was filled with Impressionists, post-Impressionists, and more contemporary works.

quote: Solid representation of European painting from the Middle Ages to recent years
reviewnospace: After kind of a disappointing experience with the Prado, we were a little gun-shy about this smaller collection, so we went on free day (Monday from 12-4PM). The collection is quite good, with a number of interesting pieces covering the medieval to the contemporary period. Interestingly, there were only a handful of sculptures.

Sadly some of the most famous pieces were out on loan but that didn't matter too much. Lovely little garden, fabulous gift shop.

reviewnospace: Situated just across the road from the Prada this museum is well worth a visit. They have a permanent exhibition but usually there is a visiting exhibition as well. The collection is quite eclectic but includes some real treats - Miro, Degas, Renoir, Picasso, Van Gogh.
titleopinion: A great private collection. Situated just across the road from the Prada this museum is well worth a visit. They have a permanent exhibition but usually there is a visiting exhibition as well. The collection is quite eclectic but includes some real treats - Miro, Degas, Renoir, Picasso, Van Gogh.

reviewnospace:
Enter a large courtyard and you enter the world of a fabulous art collection. In fact track down the Lucian Freud painting of the Baron Thyssen-Bornemisza. This small painting was almost worth the price of admission. But no, carry on through the three story building to get a glimpse of some masterful works such as the intricate portrait of Giovanna Tornabuoni by Ghirlandaio to a beautiful pastoral by Van Gogh or Rauschenberg's take on Goya's "La Desnuda Maja". The German Baron has a great collection of German Expressionist paintings, plus many requisite Spanish painters, from Miro, Picasso, Goya and El Greco. Almost an endless feeling of amazement here.

Then there were two added shows (extra admission) for a wonderful Dufy show and Paul Delvaux (ran out of time). The real gem was a show of self portraits which included a Max Beckmann, Egon Schiele, Rembrandt and a very important Lucian Freud with his children (frightening).

I arrived late just before closing so I was on a mission. Didn't see the cafe but really glad to see this collection.
titleopinion: WOW!. Enter a large courtyard and you enter the world of a fabulous art collection. In fact track down the Lucian Freud painting of the Baron Thyssen-Bornemisza. The German Baron has a great collection of German Expressionist paintings, plus many requisite Spanish painters, from Miro, Picasso, Goya and El Greco. Almost an endless feeling of amazement here. quote: You could spend a whole day there
reviewnospace:
It is a beautiful museum and if you are interested in 19th,20th and 21st-century arts, this is the place to go. Make sure you have enough time for their 'regular' collection and watch out for temporary exhibitions (usually there are at least two).

The museum shop is also worth visiting. The only place to be avoided is the cafetéria, which offers average food with poor service at exorbitant prices.
titleopinion: You could spend a whole day there. It is a beautiful museum and if you are interested in 19th,20th and 21st-century arts, this is the place to go. Make sure you have enough time for their 'regular' collection and watch out for temporary exhibitions (usually there are at least two).   The museum shop is also worth visiting. The only place to be avoided is the cafetéria, which offers average food with poor service at exorbitant prices.

quote: I love Degas and I love this museum
reviewnospace: Small, but very nice museum! I love, love, love Degas and I really loved this museum. Definitely would recommend if you're in Madrid

reviewnospace: Great art collection; I only had time to focus on Impressionist art, and the Raoul Dufy exhibit, which was amazing.
titleopinion: Opportunity to see Dufy exhibit. Great art collection; I only had time to focus on Impressionist art, and the Raoul Dufy exhibit, which was amazing.

reviewnospace: Wonderful collection and beautiful building. This was by far my favorite museum in Madrid. I would advise everyone to spend more time here than in the Prado. Also, they have a nice cafe with an outdoor seating area. Even if you are not visiting the museum it's a nice spot for a drink. It's right across from the Prado so skip the restaurant there and come here instead.
titleopinion: Absolutely loved this museum. Wonderful collection and beautiful building. This was by far my favorite museum in Madrid. I would advise everyone to spend more time here than in the Prado. Also, they have a nice cafe with an outdoor seating area. Even if you are not visiting the museum it's a nice spot for a drink. It's right across from the Prado so skip the restaurant there and come here instead.

quote: May Be The Best Small Museum Anywhere!!
reviewnospace:
First, I must admit to being a tremendous advocate of Impressionist art and this collection is about the finest I've seen. What is tremendous is that they focus on minor works by major artists, and major works by minor artists. So, you are afforded a look at some work that you've never seen in books; some is of a different scale (imagine an Albert Bierstadt that is only about 18 inches wide!), some is a different style. You can get within inches of a piece to see detail without setting off alarms. There aren't huge crowds to contend with. You can photograph works or you can buy prints.
They also have an exceptional restaurant with a wide selection of food at incredible prices and you can either eat inside or sit on a wonderful terrace.
DO NOT MISS THIS PLACE!!!

titleopinion: Great paintings and superb terrace. Loved the art- great Impressionist paintings especially and housed in a bright, light gallery that is not us dull or somber as others in Madrid. The terrace is a wonderfully stylish place for drinks or God with great views across to the park.

quote: A great gallery for mixed tastes
reviewnospace: We enjoyed this gallery as it's easy to cover in a few hours, but it's strength is in the mix of types of art, from classic religious paintings to more modern impressionist works.
titleopinion: A great gallery for mixed tastes. We enjoyed this gallery as it's easy to cover in a few hours, but it's strength is in the mix of types of art, from classic religious paintings to more modern impressionist works.

quote: A private collection beyond anything what you ever seen
reviewnospace: This collection is located in a very modern and light environment. This makes that the work of arts are very agreable to admire. What is most striking is that you get a walk through the history of both historic and modern art. From Rubens to Andy Warhall... Take a bit of time to visit this collection. My sun of 12 learnt here to appreciate art.

reviewnospace: Compared to the larger collections in the major museums of Europe, this small museum's offerings will equally please your eye and retain your attention. A not to be missed attraction in Madrid for the art connoisseur.
titleopinion: Great, Often Overlooked. Compared to the larger collections in the major museums of Europe, this small museum's offerings will equally please your eye and retain your attention. A not to be missed attraction in Madrid for the art connoisseur.

reviewnospace: Make sure you visit all Three museums in the area. Here is another famous place to see fine art. Afterwards you can rest and have a little lunch in their restaurant.
titleopinion: Another Great Museum to visit.. Make sure you visit all Three museums in the area. Here is another famous place to see fine art. Afterwards you can rest and have a little lunch in their restaurant.

reviewnospace: It's hard to imagine that the Thyssen collection was the private property of one man. It is very extensive and includes early works from the 14th century, through to an amazing collection of people like Picasso and Braque. Well worth a visit.
titleopinion: A Private Collection!. It's hard to imagine that the Thyssen collection was the private property of one man. It is very extensive and includes early works from the 14th century, through to an amazing collection of people like Picasso and Braque. Well worth a visit.

quote: Collected by Baron and Barroness Thyssen
reviewnospace: An interesting and personal collection of excellent art. The husband and wife have slightly different tastes, so the two collection complement each other. Some absolute stunners.
titleopinion: Collected by Baron and Barroness Thyssen. An interesting and personal collection of excellent art. The husband and wife have slightly different tastes, so the two collection complement each other. Some absolute stunners.

quote: Excellent Collection from A to Z

titleopinion: excellent museum. Cleverly laid out on 3 floors. Superb displays including Van Gogh, Dali and Caravaggio. Nice restaurant but food was fairly bland for the

reviewnospace:
I visited this museum on my own and I have to say that it was one of the best parts of my trip to Madrid.

I've spent 3 hours in there and I could have spent more, but I've reached the closing time. So, I would suggest to interested readers to allow 5 hours for a thorough visit.

The quality and quantity of the paintings is amazing. I am not an art expert, however you don't need to have studied art in order to enjoy these paintings. I will not go into details, you can just search for the list of painters that are represented in the museum.

I would also recommend the audio guide and the museum guide for a better understanding of the paintings.

Totally recommended!
titleopinion: Great collection of paintings!. I visited this museum on my own and I have to say that it was one of the best parts of my trip to Madrid.   I've spent 3 hours in there and I could have spent more, but I've reached the closing time. So, I would suggest to interested readers to allow 5 hours for a thorough visit.  The quality and quantity of the paintings is amazing. I am not an art expert, however you don't need to have studied art in order to enjoy these paintings. I will not go into details, you can just search for the list of painters that are represented in the museum.   I would also recommend the audio guide and the museum guide for a better understanding of the paintings.   Totally recommended!

reviewnospace: This is a large collection and part of the Trinity of art museums in Madrid. We bought tickets a couple of days in advance to avoid the entrance lines, but these were not terrible. Some interesting impressionist works, good examples of 19th century and 20th century movements that was very educational. It has a broad collection with many artists. Was surprised how many paintings from the Hudson School were in the collection.

reviewnospace: We concentrated mostly on the wonderful Dufy that was on during our visit ,but the museum is delightful with lovely outside refreshment area .Manages to feel relaxed and peaceful even when busy .

reviewnospace: I was very brave and did 2 galleries in a row - started with Prado and then to the Thyssen. Many have heard about how magnificent the Prado is, and it is. My happy surprise was the wealth of impressionist are the Thyssen has - I was thrilled to see Van Gogh's, Pissarro's, Renoir's....this was a fabulous find. No line up, and no struggel to get close to the paintings, the place was empty compared to the Prado. SO worth a visit.

Many have heard about how magnificent the Prado is, and it is. No line up, and no struggel to get close to the paintings, the place was empty compared to the Prado. SO worth a visit.

quote: Outstanding collection from old to new
reviewnospace: I usually prefer the old masters, but was quite impressed with the caliber of the modern art here. Really la creme de la creme of the big names. We started in the morning, had a leisurely lunch and returned in the pm. Glad we had time for one day here and one at the Prado. Doing both in one day would be too much. Unless you really love the old masters and only have one museum day, consider here instead of the Prado, as there's great variety of eras and styles.
titleopinion: Outstanding collection from old to new. I usually prefer the old masters, but was quite impressed with the caliber of the modern art here. Really la creme de la creme of the big names. We started in the morning, had a leisurely lunch and returned in the pm. Glad we had time for one day here and one at the Prado. Doing both in one day would be too much. Unless you really love the old masters and only have one museum day, consider here instead of the Prado, as there's great variety of eras and styles.

reviewnospace: This fantastic collection encompasses works of art from Old Masters to Impressionists. The gallery is organised over 3 floors and each floor contains a series of smaller galleries devoted to a particular era or type of painting. EU citizens get reduced entry fee (show driving licence or passport). There is something for everyone here. Canaletto to Gaugin, Reubens to Munch, Gainsborough to Luce. Sergeant to Degas. Old Italian masters vie with Flemish notables. Picasso competes with Brach. Absolutely stunningly!! There is a lovely wee cafe with both indoor and outdoor seating areas. We just had a sandwich and a beer which was tasty and not too expensive. Definitely worth a visit. Lots of seats to enjoy contemplative study of the paintings or simply to have a rest as you do the long walk round!
titleopinion: Eclectic collection brilliantly showcased.. This fantastic collection encompasses works of art from Old Masters to Impressionists. The gallery is organised over 3 floors and each floor contains a series of smaller galleries devoted to a particular era or type of painting. EU citizens get reduced entry fee (show driving licence or passport). There is something for everyone here. Canaletto to Gaugin, Reubens to Munch, Gainsborough to Luce. Sergeant to Degas. Old Italian masters vie with Flemish notables. Picasso competes with Brach. Absolutely stunningly!! There is a lovely wee cafe with both indoor and outdoor seating areas. We just had a sandwich and a beer which was tasty and not too expensive. Definitely worth a visit. Lots of seats to enjoy contemplative study of the paintings or simply to have a rest as you do the long walk round!

quote: Many important artists and some important works by them
reviewnospace: Interesting museum that is a must see for visitors to Madrid who are interested in art. The newer part has a cross section of art by great artists which shows some of the limitations on what was available for purchase over the past 30 or so years. Nice cafe at the side of the museum.

The newer part has a cross section of art by great artists which shows some of the limitations on what was available for purchase over the past 30 or so years. Nice cafe at the side of the museum.

quote: A comprehensive review of western art
reviewnospace: Well presented, the museum, leads the visitor through time and the development of western art. For the novice, the audio tour is very helpful.
titleopinion: A comprehensive review of western art. Well presented, the museum, leads the visitor through time and the development of western art. For the novice, the audio tour is very helpful.

reviewnospace: Nice mix of art. The general admission price was good and allowed viewing of 3 floors of different periods of work. Spent a couple of hours and that was perfect for me.
titleopinion: Nice Afternoon Browse. Nice mix of art. The general admission price was good and allowed viewing of 3 floors of different periods of work. Spent a couple of hours and that was perfect for me.

reviewnospace: The Dufy exhibition in the temporary exhibition space is stunning. Get a combined ticket for it plus the permanent exhibition. There is a good cafe and restaurant in the gallery so have several breaks during your visit.

reviewnospace: An enjoyable collection overlapping the same artists/period as the Prado, but with more emphasis on contemporary art.

reviewnospace: This is one of the best private collections in the world. Paintings from the medieval ages to now. Nice garden with bar, and a good museum gift shop.

quote: Might be the best museum I've ever visited
reviewnospace:
This is one of the best art museums in the world. Why? It has just the right size for a museum, not too big, not too small and it offers a superb cross section view into the world of art spanning many decades.

It's like walking in a history of art book. Simply superb and very highly recommended.

reviewnospace: The Thyssen offers an excellent permanent collection as well as interesting temporary exhibits.It is a good place to check out if you are looking to get out of heat day.It is worth noting that museum has free admission to the permanent collection on Monday afternoons

reviewnospace: This is an excellent musuem. Has a variety of works from the middle ages to modern art. I recommend taking the audio guide which adds interesting facts and insights. The Dufy exhibition is very nice. Worth the additional 2€ ( it is small - don't expect too much - but lovely). The café had nice coffee and tasty almond cake - though rather expensive. We went to the Prado and Reina Sofia musueums which are wonderful too, but if you have time for only one museum- go to this one.

reviewnospace: The layout and the fewer crowds compared with the Prado made the visit to the Thyssen much more enjoyable. The works of art are laid out chronologically and there are some really nice works of art. One not to be missed.
titleopinion: Great art galley. The layout and the fewer crowds compared with the Prado made the visit to the Thyssen much more enjoyable. The works of art are laid out chronologically and there are some really nice works of art. One not to be missed.

reviewnospace: Great collection of wonderful art! So amazing to think one family put this together. Examples from every great artist! Wonderful collection
titleopinion: Stunning Gallery. Great collection of wonderful art! So amazing to think one family put this together. Examples from every great artist! Wonderful collection

reviewnospace: This museum is one of the best, if not the best in Madrid. The Thyssen collection is very eclectic, from old Italian masters to modern expressionist artists. The gallery has a cheerful and peaceful allure. An entire day does not suffice to admire and appreciate all it contains. A must!
titleopinion: An Absolute Must See. This museum is one of the best, if not the best in Madrid. The Thyssen collection is very eclectic, from old Italian masters to modern expressionist artists. The gallery has a cheerful and peaceful allure. An entire day does not suffice to admire and appreciate all it contains. A must!

reviewnospace:
I've now been to this museum, the Prado, and the Reina Sofia, and this was definitely my favourite. First of all, it's small enough that, in a matter of hours, you can see the permanent collection. Especially at the Prado, this is simply not feasible, and you feel overwhelmed. Thus, I feel it's a lot more "friendly" toward visitors.

Second: I think there's a much greater breadth of art here than you'd get at either the Prado or the Reina Sofia, even if the depth is not so impressive. For someone like myself, who doesn't really know that much about the finer points of art and the various styles and periods, I found that much more interesting, because it allowed me to compare and contrast different styles and different periods more easily. If you are interested in one thing specifically, this may not be as much to your liking. For me, having everything from 14th century religious artwork, to the stunning landscapes of Canaletto, to Van Gogh, to Picasso and Miro, was fantastic.

I get the feeling that, if only because it's the newest of the three, this museum is probably the most overlooked, but in retrospect I'd probably pick this one first in the absence of any other factors. This is a very enjoyable museum to visit, and should not be missed.
titleopinion: World class, yet approchable. I've now been to this museum, the Prado, and the Reina Sofia, and this was definitely my favourite. First of all, it's small enough that, in a matter of hours, you can see the permanent collection. Especially at the Prado, this is simply not feasible, and you feel overwhelmed. Thus, I feel it's a lot more  friendly  toward visitors.  Second: I think there's a much greater breadth of art here than you'd get at either the Prado or the Reina Sofia, even if the depth is not so impressive. For someone like myself, who doesn't really know that much about the finer points of art and the various styles and periods, I found that much more interesting, because it allowed me to compare and contrast different styles and different periods more easily. If you are interested in one thing specifically, this may not be as much to your liking. For me, having everything from 14th century religious artwork, to the stunning landscapes of Canaletto, to Van Gogh, to Picasso and Miro, was fantastic.  I get the feeling that, if only because it's the newest of the three, this museum is probably the most overlooked, but in retrospect I'd probably pick this one first in the absence of any other factors. This is a very enjoyable museum to visit, and should not be missed.

reviewnospace: I hadn't even picked this on my 'to consider' list for when we visited Madrid for four days. We ended up going because it was free to visit (between 12-4) on Monday. What a shame and I'm glad we went, the collection of art work (only main galleries were open) is truly stunning, well laid out and welcoming. I loved the Canaletto's room but there are lots of famous artists exhibited here in a very varied collection. Would recommend.
titleopinion: Wonderfully organised collection of art. I hadn't even picked this on my 'to consider' list for when we visited Madrid for four days. We ended up going because it was free to visit (between 12-4) on Monday. What a shame and I'm glad we went, the collection of art work (only main galleries were open) is truly stunning, well laid out and welcoming. I loved the Canaletto's room but there are lots of famous artists exhibited here in a very varied collection. Would recommend.

reviewnospace: Excellent impressionists and other modern artists. Not so gloomy and boring as Prado. Free access in the evening.
titleopinion: Light and moody. Excellent impressionists and other modern artists. Not so gloomy and boring as Prado. Free access in the evening.

reviewnospace: Very well layed out and we got good advice to go in the afternoon as the mornings are full of groups. We did not book and were able to walk in without any line up for tickets at 2 pm. and a leisurely 2-3 hours was well spent. Reduced ticket price for over 65 without the need of a an EU passport like some other miseums and galleries in Spain. Very much enjoyed the late 19th and early 20th century paintings. it is nice that you can take photos as the Prado does not allow it. The modern offerings do reflect a personal taste and some quite bizarre subjects.

quote: Wonderful collection of world class art
reviewnospace: I liked wandering around this Museum. It was very well laid out and arranged according to floors and collections. I also loved the interior courtyard - overall it was a lovely place to visit
titleopinion: Wonderful collection of world class art. I liked wandering around this Museum. It was very well laid out and arranged according to floors and collections. I also loved the interior courtyard - overall it was a lovely place to visit

reviewnospace: The collection in this museum was amazing, so vast. Much of the art was acquired in the last few decades. there are selected works by a number of the finest artists. Takes a good 3 hrs to see it all.

quote: Great masters exhibition not to be missed
reviewnospace: Restaurant served excellent quality food. Layout easy to follow. The monets on display were breath taking. I went on Monday apparently entry is free every monday
titleopinion: Great masters exhibition not to be missed. Restaurant served excellent quality food. Layout easy to follow. The monets on display were breath taking. I went on Monday apparently entry is free every monday

quote: Unbelievable survey of art from 1300s to present
reviewnospace: Amazing collection, and relatively few people -- it was actually possible to get close to the art, and have a seat, while experiencing great works!
titleopinion: Unbelievable survey of art from 1300s to present. Amazing collection, and relatively few people -- it was actually possible to get close to the art, and have a seat, while experiencing great works!

reviewnospace: One of the most interesting art collections in Europe . Especially the Baronesse's private collection contains wonderful pieces with extraordinary framework. Very nice restaurant, also with tables outside.
titleopinion: Wonderful collection. One of the most interesting art collections in Europe . Especially the Baronesse's private collection contains wonderful pieces with extraordinary framework. Very nice restaurant, also with tables outside.

reviewnospace:
It is hard to believe that this was assembled as a private collection. So many important paintings that essentially create a storybook of art. Don't miss Picasso's "Harlequin with a Mirror" which I believe is on the Ground floor. Edward Hopper's "Hotel Room" is also worth a good look. Other artsists: Rembrandt, Degas, Cézanne, Gauguin, Van Gogh, Miro, Dali, Bacon, Paul Klee, Rothko.

Contrary to what one of the other reviewers said, you won't find the Guernica here.. that is over at the Reina Sofia (another must see museum).

They have lockers to store bags and such. You'll need 1 Euro but you will get it back when you reopen the locker with the provided key.
titleopinion: Thyssen-Bornemisza is magnificent. It is hard to believe that this was assembled as a private collection. So many important paintings that essentially create a storybook of art. Don't miss Picasso's  Harlequin with a Mirror  which I believe is on the Ground floor. Edward Hopper's  Hotel Room  is also worth a good look. Other artsists: Rembrandt, Degas, Cézanne, Gauguin, Van Gogh, Miro, Dali, Bacon, Paul Klee, Rothko.  Contrary to what one of the other reviewers said, you won't find the Guernica here.. that is over at the Reina Sofia (another must see museum).  They have lockers to store bags and such. You'll need 1 Euro but you will get it back when you reopen the locker with the provided key.

reviewnospace: This is a lovely Museum in Madrid. Allow a couple of hours to do it justice, but even then you won't see a fraction of this amazing private collection.
titleopinion: Another must see in Madrid. This is a lovely Museum in Madrid. Allow a couple of hours to do it justice, but even then you won't see a fraction of this amazing private collection.

reviewnospace: The collection in this museum was not one of my favorites. It is amazing, in that much of the art was acquired in the last few decades. It is well organized but it clearly reflects one person's taste. In spite of my criticism, there are selected works by a number of the finest artists. In addition, the temporary exhibits were excellent. The Dufy exhibit was outstanding. There was an additional charge for this, and another charge for the Delvaux exhibit which we did not have time to visit. This was an expensive museum and I rank it after the Prado and the Reina Sofia, but if you have the time and money (and especially if there are interesting temporary shows) don't miss it.
titleopinion: Museum good, temporary exhibits excellent. The collection in this museum was not one of my favorites. It is amazing, in that much of the art was acquired in the last few decades. It is well organized but it clearly reflects one person's taste. In spite of my criticism, there are selected works by a number of the finest artists. In addition, the temporary exhibits were excellent. The Dufy exhibit was outstanding. There was an additional charge for this, and another charge for the Delvaux exhibit which we did not have time to visit. This was an expensive museum and I rank it after the Prado and the Reina Sofia, but if you have the time and money (and especially if there are interesting temporary shows) don't miss it.

reviewnospace: This museum has everything and all sorts of art. Very interesting collection and you will enjoy it allot. Spare 2 - 3 hours for the visit and look for the special exhibition as they are very interesting.
titleopinion: Has everything. This museum has everything and all sorts of art. Very interesting collection and you will enjoy it allot. Spare 2 - 3 hours for the visit and look for the special exhibition as they are very interesting.

reviewnospace:
I got in with free admission on Monday (thanks Mastercard for sponsoring). I arrived 45 minutes before openning and the line was short, but grew quickly. I spent 3 hours wandering around.

The collection is a mix of works from the 13th-20th century (oldest on the top floor, newest on the ground). I wasn't too into the really medieval stuff but the modern collection had me awestruck. There are some beautiful pieces.

Definitely worth a visit!

reviewnospace: Its hard to believe but this was my favorite museum in a city know for great museum. The best part is the museum is organized by Time and art movement.

reviewnospace: This was our first Museum in Madrid and my favorite. It is always interesting to me how someone can "collect" using their own preferences and years later, the collection is of great interest to the masses. I loved this museum because it was so "manageable" and yet covered so many styles.

reviewnospace: An extraordinary collection from medieval to modern. It wasn't very crowded when I visited (October) and it was just full of surprises and delights. Allow a long morning, with a coffee break in the museum café, followed by a nice, late lunch.

quote: Huge collection, current Delvaux exhibition well worth a visit
reviewnospace: This museum is housed in a lovely building which shows off a huge collection of art both classic and modern. We went to see the Delvaux exhibition and it did not dissapoint. Because there's so much to see its worth the money and a good way to spend a couple of hours escaping the hot Madrid sun! Worth noting is that It's open on a Sunday but closed Monday.
titleopinion: Huge collection, current Delvaux exhibition well worth a visit. This museum is housed in a lovely building which shows off a huge collection of art both classic and modern. We went to see the Delvaux exhibition and it did not dissapoint. Because there's so much to see its worth the money and a good way to spend a couple of hours escaping the hot Madrid sun! Worth noting is that It's open on a Sunday but closed Monday.

reviewnospace: The least famous of the three major Madrid galleries, the Thyssen is my personal favourite. Some of the paintings on display are truly breathtaking. The queues are short and the staff are attentive and it's definitely got the best restaurant/ cafe of the three. A couple of hours that you won't forget.
titleopinion: Brilliant art in beautiful surroundings . The least famous of the three major Madrid galleries, the Thyssen is my personal favourite. Some of the paintings on display are truly breathtaking. The queues are short and the staff are attentive and it's definitely got the best restaurant/ cafe of the three. A couple of hours that you won't forget.

quote: One of the best in Madrid
reviewnospace: It was one of the biggest private collections in the world. A great collection, one day is not enough. Don't forget to have lunch on the terrace of the beautiful Museumcafé
titleopinion: One of the best in Madrid. It was one of the biggest private collections in the world. A great collection, one day is not enough. Don't forget to have lunch on the terrace of the beautiful Museumcafé

reviewnospace:
Went along to this museum on a sunday, it was quiet and we didn't have to wait at all.

I found the collection quite diverse and engaging, particularly the modern portion of the Museum on level 0. Personally I preferred this museum to the Prado.
titleopinion: Worth a visit!. Went along to this museum on a sunday, it was quiet and we didn't have to wait at all.  I found the collection quite diverse and engaging, particularly the modern portion of the Museum on level 0. Personally I preferred this museum to the Prado.

reviewnospace:
It is free on. Monday. The permanent collection is not at par with other museums.
Is you have little time skip thi one or go on Mondays that is free.
Special exhibits some times are OK
titleopinion: So so. It is free on. Monday. The permanent collection is not at par with other museums. Is you have little time skip thi one or go on Mondays that is free. Special exhibits some times are OK

reviewnospace: free entrance on Monday afternoon! Mind the clock though, as the newer art (eg Dalí) comes all the way at the end.
titleopinion: Save the best for last. free entrance on Monday afternoon! Mind the clock though, as the newer art (eg Dalí) comes all the way at the end.

reviewnospace: The works are arranged by time periods permitting a continuous flow demonstrating the changes in style and technique with the progress of time. Very well done! Rent a headset!
titleopinion: Fabulous!. The works are arranged by time periods permitting a continuous flow demonstrating the changes in style and technique with the progress of time. Very well done! Rent a headset!

quote: Fills in the Blanks that the Prado does not
reviewnospace: Really enjoyed my time here....good selection of Impressionist painters, even North American....the Prado has a wondrous selection of Spanish artists whereas the Thyssen has a very varied selection of work from around the world. Be sure to go.
titleopinion: Fills in the Blanks that the Prado does not. Really enjoyed my time here....good selection of Impressionist painters, even North American....the Prado has a wondrous selection of Spanish artists whereas the Thyssen has a very varied selection of work from around the world. Be sure to go.

reviewnospace: ... of paintings, from "primitive"/gothic to very modern ones; a good stopover but if You really want to see and enjoy all the paintings, You need a lot of time (half a day? for art aficionados - more;)
titleopinion: Magnificent collection.... ... of paintings, from  primitive /gothic to very modern ones; a good stopover but if You really want to see and enjoy all the paintings, You need a lot of time (half a day? for art aficionados - more;)

reviewnospace: A really large collection laid out in a way where you can see how painting developed with time, influence and style, even if you are learning about art (like me). Dependent on your favourite time/style you will like different areas better, but it is easy for you to find the ones you like. Some stunning paintings and as usual in Madrid excellent facilities.
titleopinion: Great selection and experience. A really large collection laid out in a way where you can see how painting developed with time, influence and style, even if you are learning about art (like me). Dependent on your favourite time/style you will like different areas better, but it is easy for you to find the ones you like. Some stunning paintings and as usual in Madrid excellent facilities.

reviewnospace: I hadn't expected very much from the Thyssen, but it is a really lovely afternoon of discovery. The set up in fantastic and lots to see, I had no idea they had such a range of old masters (1600s) to beautiful modern pieces. Not sure how much kids would enjoy, but for my boyfriend and I it was great.
titleopinion: A wonderful find. I hadn't expected very much from the Thyssen, but it is a really lovely afternoon of discovery. The set up in fantastic and lots to see, I had no idea they had such a range of old masters (1600s) to beautiful modern pieces. Not sure how much kids would enjoy, but for my boyfriend and I it was great.

quote: Even for a non art person excellent
reviewnospace:
Prado had a huge queue, only had time for one of them so Thyssen it was.

As a non art cognoscenti person, the art is just fantastic. Three choices were on, did two, took me about two hours. There are audio guides too, which in retrospect I should have used
titleopinion: Even for a non art person excellent. Prado had a huge queue, only had time for one of them so Thyssen it was.   As a non art cognoscenti person, the art is just fantastic. Three choices were on, did two, took me about two hours. There are audio guides too, which in retrospect I should have used

quote: Probably the best organized Art museum I have been in in a long time
reviewnospace:
The Museum is near the Prado and seldom has queues to get in.
I would seriously recommend taking the audio guide as it is well done.
The collection is impressive as is the manner in which it is organized and presented. It is a wonderful Museum, a hidden gem I would add.
titleopinion: Probably the best organized Art museum I have been in in a long time. The Museum is near the Prado and seldom has queues to get in. I would seriously recommend taking the audio guide as it is well done. The collection is impressive as is the manner in which it is organized and presented. It is a wonderful Museum, a hidden gem I would add.

reviewnospace: Didn't know what to expect after going to the Prado and Reina Sofia galleries and was surprised to see a varied, and well known, collection of art. I especially liked the early 20th century paintings.
titleopinion: A pleasant surprise.. Didn't know what to expect after going to the Prado and Reina Sofia galleries and was surprised to see a varied, and well known, collection of art. I especially liked the early 20th century paintings.

reviewnospace: This museum has a mixture of the old (1600s) to the modern. The paintings which are included in the general fee of 10 euros each are on the first and second floors. There are exhibitions on the ground floor which cost extra, approx 7 euros each extra. This makes it an expensive visit for the family. We were a group of four adults. Still if you enjoy art then it is worth a visit.
titleopinion: For the art lover. This museum has a mixture of the old (1600s) to the modern. The paintings which are included in the general fee of 10 euros each are on the first and second floors. There are exhibitions on the ground floor which cost extra, approx 7 euros each extra. This makes it an expensive visit for the family. We were a group of four adults. Still if you enjoy art then it is worth a visit.

reviewnospace: You will be more than impressed with this collection! From Pollock to Picasso, there's something for every art lover here.
titleopinion: Amazing Art Collection. You will be more than impressed with this collection! From Pollock to Picasso, there's something for every art lover here.

quote: The most 'accessible' art museum in Madrid Miminum 2 hours. Magnificant
reviewnospace: You will need a floor plan but the museum has been designed with some care so it is easier to see everything. It is on a smaller scale than the Prado or the Reina Sofia but this meant it was less overwhelming and had more of a friendly feel. The art work was outstanding, afterwards we felt we had got more out of the experience than the other two larger art collections - the floor guide gives you their top 25 but there is just so much more.
titleopinion: The most 'accessible' art museum in Madrid Miminum 2 hours. Magnificant. You will need a floor plan but the museum has been designed with some care so it is easier to see everything. It is on a smaller scale than the Prado or the Reina Sofia but this meant it was less overwhelming and had more of a friendly feel. The art work was outstanding, afterwards we felt we had got more out of the experience than the other two larger art collections - the floor guide gives you their top 25 but there is just so much more.

quote: Very good high quality museum with a broadbcollection
reviewnospace: Excellent museum, also if you are short in time, you can make a fast tour. I like the old dutch master paintings , but also the modern art collection was great
titleopinion: Very good high quality museum with a broadbcollection. Excellent museum, also if you are short in time, you can make a fast tour. I like the old dutch master paintings , but also the modern art collection was great

quote: Quite outstanding collection of memorable paintings
reviewnospace: Visited the day before the Prado . This former private collection now in national control whets the appetite for the larger national collection. Shows the care and vision of the family who bought the paintings and the breadth of their collection rivals many elsewhere in Europe. Allow a half day to explore and buy the guide to get the most of the exhibitions. We ate in the café which was reasonable and refilled one's energy level. Buy the combined ticket to save queuing at the Prado
titleopinion: Quite outstanding collection of memorable paintings. Visited the day before the Prado . This former private collection now in national control whets the appetite for the larger national collection. Shows the care and vision of the family who bought the paintings and the breadth of their collection rivals many elsewhere in Europe. Allow a half day to explore and buy the guide to get the most of the exhibitions. We ate in the café which was reasonable and refilled one's energy level. Buy the combined ticket to save queuing at the Prado

reviewnospace: Very well-designed building. The thematic exhibitions, transparent. My Favorite MUSEUM in Madrid. I've been here three times, I can only recommend. Young and old, everyone
titleopinion: Fantastic Museum. Very well-designed building. The thematic exhibitions, transparent. My Favorite MUSEUM in Madrid. I've been here three times, I can only recommend. Young and old, everyone

reviewnospace: Download the app to your smartphone (about $6). Get a map. Wander through the galleries and enjoy the history and insights of the art. I spent 2 hours, could have spent more. Give yourself enough time to be amazed and reflectful.
titleopinion: Enjoyable afternoon art. Download the app to your smartphone (about $6). Get a map. Wander through the galleries and enjoy the history and insights of the art. I spent 2 hours, could have spent more. Give yourself enough time to be amazed and reflectful.

reviewnospace: I came here with my art class and saw a bunch of pieces. What stuck out in my mind were the paintings with floating baby angel heads, creepy Renaissance babies, and the modern art. I do not have a preference for Renaissance baby paintings. My housemate happened to talk about them profusely before I went to the museum. Other than that, it is a museum worth visiting.
titleopinion: Renaissance Babies and Picasso. I came here with my art class and saw a bunch of pieces. What stuck out in my mind were the paintings with floating baby angel heads, creepy Renaissance babies, and the modern art. I do not have a preference for Renaissance baby paintings. My housemate happened to talk about them profusely before I went to the museum. Other than that, it is a museum worth visiting.

reviewnospace: Whilst I enjoyed the other art galleries, this was by far the best. Amazing pieces, great artists and because it's a collection, the finest has been chosen for it. It didn't leave me feeling as if I've had enough art for a decade.
titleopinion: Best Museum. Whilst I enjoyed the other art galleries, this was by far the best. Amazing pieces, great artists and because it's a collection, the finest has been chosen for it. It didn't leave me feeling as if I've had enough art for a decade.

reviewnospace: We thoroughly enjoyed our visit to this museum. Although small it had beautiful exhibits. I would start on the top floor of the museum, as there is quite a bit to see but some of the more famous exhibits are on the top floor. There was a cafe on site but we found it a bit expensive.
titleopinion: Small but perfectly formed museum. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit to this museum. Although small it had beautiful exhibits. I would start on the top floor of the museum, as there is quite a bit to see but some of the more famous exhibits are on the top floor. There was a cafe on site but we found it a bit expensive.

reviewnospace: The Prado is the museum that everyone knows but the Thyssen is fabulous and more manageable. We had an excellent breakfast sitting outside the restaurant in early morning sunshine. The Raoul Dufy exhibition currently showing is stunning, the paintings in the last room took my breath away. It is very civilized that the museum gives you separate tickets for the Dufy and the main collection which enabled us to have a mental break, take a walk in the Retiro park and grab lunch at a restaurant before heading back into the museum to enjoy the rest of the museum. A brilliant day!
titleopinion: Don't miss this. The Prado is the museum that everyone knows but the Thyssen is fabulous and more manageable. We had an excellent breakfast sitting outside the restaurant in early morning sunshine. The Raoul Dufy exhibition currently showing is stunning, the paintings in the last room took my breath away. It is very civilized that the museum gives you separate tickets for the Dufy and the main collection which enabled us to have a mental break, take a walk in the Retiro park and grab lunch at a restaurant before heading back into the museum to enjoy the rest of the museum. A brilliant day!

reviewnospace: Delvaux and Duffy are top but the permanent exhibition is also very diversified and high quality. On monday, the entrance is free. To do
titleopinion: High quality exhibition. Delvaux and Duffy are top but the permanent exhibition is also very diversified and high quality. On monday, the entrance is free. To do

reviewnospace: The Thyssen is bewildering in the extent of its collections. Room after room of artists you are familiar and lots that you may not have heard of. Be prepared to walk and walk, to stop and stop. The place is so big that I'm not sure that I would recommend the use of the electronic audio guide. Just let your eye grab the occasional painting that you like and stop and stare. Get up close and 'smell' the paint. The one thing that takes a little from your visit is the apparent boredom of the many attendants who seem to take little interest in the viewers, no matter how lost they may look. It's a fascinating visit and you should allow yourself at least half a day.
titleopinion: A Great Art Gallery. The Thyssen is bewildering in the extent of its collections. Room after room of artists you are familiar and lots that you may not have heard of. Be prepared to walk and walk, to stop and stop. The place is so big that I'm not sure that I would recommend the use of the electronic audio guide. Just let your eye grab the occasional painting that you like and stop and stare. Get up close and 'smell' the paint. The one thing that takes a little from your visit is the apparent boredom of the many attendants who seem to take little interest in the viewers, no matter how lost they may look. It's a fascinating visit and you should allow yourself at least half a day.

reviewnospace:
I'd rate this above average but below very good, alas trip advisor don't list this rating.
At €10 each excluding special exhibitions it's a fair price for a European art museum.
The setting is lovely, green grass, colourful borders, seating and an elegant facade to the building.
The art is thoughtfully curated, making sense as you walk the suggested route, however I found the lighting on the pictures behind glass too bright, the light reflections detracting from the art.
The shop, toilets and visitor areas are all bright, clean and modern.
titleopinion: Good. I'd rate this above average but below very good, alas trip advisor don't list this rating. At €10 each excluding special exhibitions it's a fair price for a European art museum. The setting is lovely, green grass, colourful borders, seating and an elegant facade to the building. The art is thoughtfully curated, making sense as you walk the suggested route, however I found the lighting on the pictures behind glass too bright, the light reflections detracting from the art. The shop, toilets and visitor areas are all bright, clean and modern.

reviewnospace: The Thyssen is a great museum but if you are not visiting the permanent collection then it depends on the exhibitions that are on when you visit. Still it is always nice to visit here. The only drawback is the price that in my opinion is exccesive.
titleopinion: Great exhibitions. The Thyssen is a great museum but if you are not visiting the permanent collection then it depends on the exhibitions that are on when you visit. Still it is always nice to visit here. The only drawback is the price that in my opinion is exccesive.

reviewnospace: Excellent art museum in downtown Madrid. In Paseo del Prado, opposite the Prado Museum and the Botanical Garden. It has an excellent collection of art pieces of painting and sculpture, with reliefs and abundant material Golden Age of Art in Spain. It is possible to see in one day but it is recommended to go two to fully enjoy it.
titleopinion: Excellent art museum. Excellent art museum in downtown Madrid. In Paseo del Prado, opposite the Prado Museum and the Botanical Garden. It has an excellent collection of art pieces of painting and sculpture, with reliefs and abundant material Golden Age of Art in Spain. It is possible to see in one day but it is recommended to go two to fully enjoy it.

reviewnospace: We just returned from an enjoyable time at the Thyssen. Apart from what has been stated in other reviews, we would add: The Dufy exhibit was presented on bright blue walls, which set his work off well, and for an extra 3 Euros, one can have an audio guide. For this, as well as the rest of the museum, there was plenty of space and time to study pieces without interruption. For fun, there is one area for adults to dress in costume, mimicking a nearby portrait,and to pose whilst seated in front of a "frame" for friends to photograph. Nice touch of humour. Well-stocked gift shop with imaginative items, cafe is reasonably priced with plenty of indoor and outdoor eating. Worth a visit, especially when free!
titleopinion: Well Presented Art. We just returned from an enjoyable time at the Thyssen. Apart from what has been stated in other reviews, we would add: The Dufy exhibit was presented on bright blue walls, which set his work off well, and for an extra 3 Euros, one can have an audio guide. For this, as well as the rest of the museum, there was plenty of space and time to study pieces without interruption. For fun, there is one area for adults to dress in costume, mimicking a nearby portrait,and to pose whilst seated in front of a  frame  for friends to photograph. Nice touch of humour. Well-stocked gift shop with imaginative items, cafe is reasonably priced with plenty of indoor and outdoor eating. Worth a visit, especially when free!

reviewnospace: A great Museum, all the art work is from a private collection, so you won´t be able to find many paintings by the most famous painters, worth the visit
titleopinion: Different. A great Museum, all the art work is from a private collection, so you won´t be able to find many paintings by the most famous painters, worth the visit

reviewnospace: A beautiful museum that gave you a lot to see without being too overwhelming. A nice historical context that allows it to present a variety of styles and periods at the same time. Also it was free on Sunday afternoon; we were only sorry the Dufy exhibition was closed that day.
titleopinion: just right. A beautiful museum that gave you a lot to see without being too overwhelming. A nice historical context that allows it to present a variety of styles and periods at the same time. Also it was free on Sunday afternoon; we were only sorry the Dufy exhibition was closed that day.

reviewnospace:
I love museums. Is my passion, lifestyle and hobby. Thos museum is one of my favourites in madrid. Everybody should come here. Its a possibility
to know morw about history and old days culture. Its not expensive, expositions are worth every cent. Well, I am museum maniac and I can say
that this museum is very good. I dont need even guide, everything is explained here no matter where you will go.

reviewnospace:
We visited over 10 years ago and thought this might spoil the experience.

They have added new facilities for visitors including a very nice restaurant.

We mainly visited the galleries with impressionist work and also the renaissance period. We were not disappointed.
titleopinion: Exceeded expectations . We visited over 10 years ago and thought this might spoil the experience.  They have added new facilities for visitors including a very nice restaurant.  We mainly visited the galleries with impressionist work and also the renaissance period. We were not disappointed.

reviewnospace:
During a holiday in Madrid we went to the Prado, Reina Sofia and this art gallery. This one has to be my favourite. It just had all the kind or art that I particularly like.

Firstly there were some wonderful mediaeval paintings that just amaze you in the clarity after all those hundreds of years. There are also a lot of impressionist paintings including Van Gogh, Degas, Pissarro etc. also there are modern paintings by Hopper, Hockney, and earlier 20th century such as Picasso. All in all the most amazing collection across a wide range of styles and periods.

The plan that you can pick up helps you to see the highlights of the collection. As with the other main galleries you need to be selective so the plan is a great help in choosing where to spend the bulk of your time.
titleopinion: Fantastic art gallery. During a holiday in Madrid we went to the Prado, Reina Sofia and this art gallery. This one has to be my favourite. It just had all the kind or art that I particularly like.   Firstly there were some wonderful mediaeval paintings that just amaze you in the clarity after all those hundreds of years. There are also a lot of impressionist paintings including Van Gogh, Degas, Pissarro etc. also there are modern paintings by Hopper, Hockney, and earlier 20th century such as Picasso. All in all the most amazing collection across a wide range of styles and periods.   The plan that you can pick up helps you to see the highlights of the collection. As with the other main galleries you need to be selective so the plan is a great help in choosing where to spend the bulk of your time.

reviewnospace:
We saw two special exhibitions (Dufy, Delvaux) - but there's also a great permanent collection.
Restaurant for lunch was really good.
titleopinion: Definitely worth a visit. We saw two special exhibitions (Dufy, Delvaux) - but there's also a great permanent collection. Restaurant for lunch was really good.

reviewnospace: I enjoyed my visit to this gallery. Lots to see and more varied pieces of art. It was good to see religious arts rescued from old churches along with modern art works. The Thyssen is smaller than the Prado and has a lovely restaurant. with out door tables.
titleopinion: Lovely gallery. I enjoyed my visit to this gallery. Lots to see and more varied pieces of art. It was good to see religious arts rescued from old churches along with modern art works. The Thyssen is smaller than the Prado and has a lovely restaurant. with out door tables.

reviewnospace: Unlike the Prado with all its great and large works of art, this museum guides you along the history of painting through some truly masterworks. The exhibition is very well organized and the audio guide is excellent. We truly loved this museum and its selection of masterpieces. Truly worth visiting.
titleopinion: Best museum in Madrid. Unlike the Prado with all its great and large works of art, this museum guides you along the history of painting through some truly masterworks. The exhibition is very well organized and the audio guide is excellent. We truly loved this museum and its selection of masterpieces. Truly worth visiting.

reviewnospace: Something for everyone here, a fantastic collection, well worth seeing even if the entrance fee is a bit pricey.
titleopinion: Wonderful Eclectic Collection. Something for everyone here, a fantastic collection, well worth seeing even if the entrance fee is a bit pricey.

quote: Nice transition to complete your Prado visit
reviewnospace: As known to all, this is one of Madrid's holy trinity of art collections. It's located a very short walk away from the Prado and so if you have the energy left after a Prado visit, this will offer you interesting insights into how visual art developed over the centuries, particularly the themes and focus. Museum itself is substantially large, with several galleries, so be prepared to spend some time. There's a cafeteria beside the entrance too, if you wish to power up before the visit.
titleopinion: Nice transition to complete your Prado visit. As known to all, this is one of Madrid's holy trinity of art collections. It's located a very short walk away from the Prado and so if you have the energy left after a Prado visit, this will offer you interesting insights into how visual art developed over the centuries, particularly the themes and focus. Museum itself is substantially large, with several galleries, so be prepared to spend some time. There's a cafeteria beside the entrance too, if you wish to power up before the visit.

reviewnospace:
The collection has enormous diversity in style and age and yet seems unified. As if the pieces have lived with each other for a long time and have become friends.
A collection as good as this will attract crowds and it certainly did the day we attended. Fellow viewers were polite and respected each another. Maybe we were just lucky, there was nothing like the chaos of the Prada. No children’s groups, no tour groups elbowing their way in front of you.
Best gallery in Madrid I say! If you only have time for one, make it the Thyssen.
By the way, if you are over 65 they do concession fares for everything in Spain. You need i.d. though.
titleopinion: Madrid's best.. The collection has enormous diversity in style and age and yet seems unified. As if the pieces have lived with each other for a long time and have become friends.  A collection as good as this will attract crowds and it certainly did the day we attended. Fellow viewers were polite and respected each another. Maybe we were just lucky, there was nothing like the chaos of the Prada. No children’s groups, no tour groups elbowing their way in front of you.  Best gallery in Madrid I say! If you only have time for one, make it the Thyssen.  By the way, if you are over 65 they do concession fares for everything in Spain. You need i.d. though.

reviewnospace: This is a remarkable private art collection, donated to the public fairly recently. It really covers a lot of ground and is small enough to take in, in one visit. Nice cafe makes an easy snack or light meal for your tour.
titleopinion: Great museum.. This is a remarkable private art collection, donated to the public fairly recently. It really covers a lot of ground and is small enough to take in, in one visit. Nice cafe makes an easy snack or light meal for your tour.

reviewnospace: The one museum not to miss in Madrid. We loved it! Impressionists, post expressionists and Renaissance also. Beautifully explained also!
titleopinion: Amazing!. The one museum not to miss in Madrid. We loved it! Impressionists, post expressionists and Renaissance also. Beautifully explained also!

quote: One of the most important museums nationwide.
reviewnospace:
One of the most important museums nationwide. It has permanent exhibitions of the museum itself and the Carmenn Cervera and temporary exhibitions.
Recommended buying tickets in advance online or by phone to avoid running out of them and / or unwanted lines. If you run away from the crowds, better to go during the week, to better enjoy the art.
In addition to the exhibition halls has other services like restaurant-terrace, café and bookstore.

It has permanent exhibitions of the museum itself and the Carmenn Cervera and temporary exhibitions. Recommended buying tickets in advance online or by phone to avoid running out of them and / or unwanted lines. If you run away from the crowds, better to go during the week, to better enjoy the art. In addition to the exhibition halls has other services like restaurant-terrace, café and bookstore.

reviewnospace: If you only have time to visit one art museum in Madrid make it this one ... Smaller than the Prado and much less crowded - this collection was originally in private hands but obviously has been put together with a massive budget and panache. The audio guides are extremely helpful and the range of painting cover almost everything from early Italian up to later 20th century. The onsite cafe is modern and stylish - a good place to chill out and relax. We will certainly return on our next trip to Madrid.
titleopinion: Simply Wonderful. If you only have time to visit one art museum in Madrid make it this one ... Smaller than the Prado and much less crowded - this collection was originally in private hands but obviously has been put together with a massive budget and panache. The audio guides are extremely helpful and the range of painting cover almost everything from early Italian up to later 20th century. The onsite cafe is modern and stylish - a good place to chill out and relax. We will certainly return on our next trip to Madrid.

reviewnospace: My husband and I happened upon this museum on a stroll through the city when we visited Madrid in 2009. (I didn't visit in April 2014. I couldn't choose a date earlier than this one.) This museum wasn't mentioned in the guide book we had purchased. On a whim, we decided to go in and check it out. To this day, the Museo Thyssen-Bornemisza is one of our most cherished memories of our visit to Madrid. We recommend this museum to anyone who tells us they are visiting Madrid. What makes the museum even more impressive is that the pieces are those of a private collector. We also saw a traveling Henri Matisse exhibit. Plan to spend at least half a day to take in the museum's massive collection, especially if it has a traveling exhibit.

I couldn't choose a date earlier than this one.) This museum wasn't mentioned in the guide book we had purchased. On a whim, we decided to go in and check it out. To this day, the Museo Thyssen-Bornemisza is one of our most cherished memories of our visit to Madrid. We recommend this museum to anyone who tells us they are visiting Madrid. What makes the museum even more impressive is that the pieces are those of a private collector. We also saw a traveling Henri Matisse exhibit. Plan to spend at least half a day to take in the museum's massive collection, especially if it has a traveling exhibit.

reviewnospace: Although not quite as famous as the Prado and, to be honest, with not quite the range of art, the feel of the Museum is much better than the Prado. The staff are helpful and all large rooms have seats to relax and take in the paintings. The collection is extensive with some very significant pieces included. You will need somewhat more than half a day, there is a good cafeteria/restaurant if a little pricey.
titleopinion: Not to be missed. Although not quite as famous as the Prado and, to be honest, with not quite the range of art, the feel of the Museum is much better than the Prado. The staff are helpful and all large rooms have seats to relax and take in the paintings. The collection is extensive with some very significant pieces included. You will need somewhat more than half a day, there is a good cafeteria/restaurant if a little pricey.

titleopinion: if you like art its a must. I would advise a guide. Mr. Hernan satt to be ecact. You wont be sorry. Then you can still stay on and browse to your hearts content.

reviewnospace:
This gallery is somewhat of a bridge between the more traditionalist artwork on display at the Prado and the modern works found in the Rena Sofia.

The Thyssen-Bornemisza has paintings dating from the medieval period right up to the present day and as such provides a snapshot of art over the past eight hundred years. There are few world famous works on display (the portrait of Henry VIII by Holbien being one of the more well known) but there is a fine selection of pictures from many schools of painting. My favourites were the impressionists and some fine 20th century pieces.

Something for everyone here so well worth a vist. Allow at least two hours.
titleopinion: Ecclectic Mix. This gallery is somewhat of a bridge between the more traditionalist artwork on display at the Prado and the modern works found in the Rena Sofia.  The Thyssen-Bornemisza has paintings dating from the medieval period right up to the present day and as such provides a snapshot of art over the past eight hundred years. There are few world famous works on display (the portrait of Henry VIII by Holbien being one of the more well known) but there is a fine selection of pictures from many schools of painting. My favourites were the impressionists and some fine 20th century pieces.  Something for everyone here so well worth a vist. Allow at least two hours.

reviewnospace:
With the scope of museums available in Madrid, you could miss out on the centrally located and gently-scaled Thyseen-Bornemisza -- which would be a mistake.
The range and quality of the works are very appealing -- the feeling is that those doing the acquisitions had a punch-list to be represented by one or two choices.
Familiar and old-favorite pieces to recognize would range from the four gorgeous Rodin marbles in the entrance hall to the Holbein portrait of Henry VIII, one of Hopper's great hotel rooms, and a spectacular Picasso clown.
The displays and arrangements are convenient and accessible -- not so as to be tiring as with the giants.
titleopinion: A One-Stop Art History Course. With the scope of museums available in Madrid, you could miss out on the centrally located and gently-scaled Thyseen-Bornemisza -- which would be a mistake.  The range and quality of the works are very appealing -- the feeling is that those doing the acquisitions had a punch-list to be represented by one or two choices. Familiar and old-favorite pieces to recognize would range from the four gorgeous Rodin marbles in the entrance hall to the Holbein portrait of Henry VIII, one of Hopper's great hotel rooms, and a spectacular Picasso clown. The displays and arrangements are convenient and accessible -- not so as to be tiring as with the giants.

reviewnospace:
This is one of the three major art museums in Madrid. Its focus is wider than that of the Prado (a vital collection of international and Spanish art) and the Sophia Reina (modern art, largely 20th century), in that its collection spans a thousand years.

Many of the times in the collection are atypical examples of an artist"s oeuvre. I especially noted many pre 1891 Gaugins and early Munchs. But if you want to do an arts appreciation course in one day, you could do a lot worse than this collection.

In my visit there were also great retrospectives of the works of Dufy and Paul Delvaux.
titleopinion: Diverse and eclectic collection. This is one of the three major art museums in Madrid. Its focus is wider than that of the Prado (a vital collection of international and Spanish art) and the Sophia Reina (modern art, largely 20th century), in that its collection spans a thousand years.  Many of the times in the collection are atypical examples of an artist s oeuvre. I especially noted many pre 1891 Gaugins and early Munchs. But if you want to do an arts appreciation course in one day, you could do a lot worse than this collection.  In my visit there were also great retrospectives of the works of Dufy and Paul Delvaux.

Too many works to single out any in particular (I will say I always like to see a Caravaggio, and there is one!), but especially liked the fact it is not too crowded and you can photogragh (without flash). A very comprehensive and well laid out museum.
