reviewnospace:
We were delighted that our stay n Madrid coincided with a major Delvaux exhibition. We very much enjoy his work and haven’t seen overly amounts of it in International galleries. So it was a wonderful opportunity.

Many of his paintings are intriguing. One called Dialogue shows two young women engaging in and posing as anything but.

The breadth and quality of the permanent collection is astonishing, a master-class in art down the centuries. All the chief exemplars are here, El Greco, Canaletto, Caravaggio’s Saint Catherine of Alexandria, Hopper, Degas, Van Gogh, and Kandinsky. And many more. Wonderful.

reviewnospace:
The collection of mostly European paintings is organized chronologically from the 13th century to 20th century. Not only are there the 'names' we all know such as Rembrandt, Pissaro, Picasso, etc. but many lesser-known, yet exceptional artists. The thorough exploration of styles, subjects and variations in each period shows that individual artists do not create in in isolation. In addition, the exhibits give the visitor a real sense of the concerns of the time, and also how similar subjects have been treated over hundreds of years.
The walls throughout are a lovely peach/rose plaster that invites the visitor to linger, as opposed to stark white or saturated color some other museums use.
Restrooms are few and difficult to find, and there could be more benches for resting and pondering the artwork.
The highlight: we were almost about to leave when we saw someone veering away down a corridor...
The collection of 19th-20th century works on the main floor are almost hidden down a hallway next to the main staircase, and not to be missed!
Enjoy a small bite and coffee in the adjacent cafe. They have a neat button gizmo that lets your server know when you want service or the bill.
titleopinion: Don't misss the first floor!. The collection of mostly European paintings is organized chronologically from the 13th century to 20th century. The thorough exploration of styles, subjects and variations in each period shows that individual artists do not create in in isolation. reviewnospace: This museum is massive and is confusingly divided into two sections - the permanent collection with rooms numbered and then the Carmen collection with rooms labelled alphabetically. Generally speaking most of the outstanding works are in the permanent numbered collection but there are some very fine paintings in the other collection: indeed in their own summary of the 100 most outstanding works inm the gallery the curators have chosen 39 from the Carmen rooms. Attempting to see both halves is a daunting task so some homework on the web site before a visit might be useful. This museum has been criticised for holding the best works of second rate artists and mediocre works of the greatest artists. This is unfair. There are some magnificient works here, from Duccio in the 14th century right up to brilliant works by Lucien Freud, Raschenburg et. The museum is spacious, well lit, and the works well labelled, and the cafe is good. It requires a significant amount of time 3 hours at least? to do it justice.

reviewnospace: I loved this gallery. It has thousands of paintings from all over the world and lots of different periods. The paintings aren't set out in any seemingly logical order, but the order they are in works. I would truly recommend this place to anyone who has an interest in art.
titleopinion: An amazing gallery. I loved this gallery. It has thousands of paintings from all over the world and lots of different periods. reviewnospace:
this was my second time in madrid, and i didn't make it to this museum the first time. what a mistake! it's the largest private collection of art in the world, now in the possession of the spanish government. it provides an unbelievable tour through the history of western art, from late byzantine (13th century) through late 20th century. particular strengths are medieval and early modern and then modernism from the french impressionists through the german expressionists. what's especially great is how incredibly well organized it is, how it leads you through that history. and the lighting is fantastic. there are few museums in the world where it's so EASY to look at the art and to spend time in front of paintings.

there's a nice restaurant, too, and a fun shop.

this museum is absolutely not to be missed.
titleopinion: wonderful!. this was my second time in madrid, and i didn't make it to this museum the first time. what a mistake! it's the largest private collection of art in the world, now in the possession of the spanish government. it provides an unbelievable tour through the history of western art, from late byzantine (13th century) through late 20th century. particular strengths are medieval and early modern and then modernism from the french impressionists through the german expressionists. what's especially great is how incredibly well organized it is, how it leads you through that history. and the lighting is fantastic. there are few museums in the world where it's so EASY to look at the art and to spend time in front of paintings.  there's a nice restaurant, too, and a fun shop.  this museum is absolutely not to be missed.

quote: Great museum. Nice mixture of era's and styles. This was my favorite in Madrid.

reviewnospace:
If you are in Madrid you definitely need to see the Golden Triangle of Art: Prado, Reina Sofia and Thyssen-Bornemisza.
I have to say, that out of the three, Thyssen-Bornemisza was my favourite. I love the impressionists' work, so this museum scores points with me by displaying paintings by Monet, Renoir, Manet, Pissaro, Degas, Sisley, Morisot.
The building isn't as big as the Prado, which makes this collection even more impressive... so many important painters, from every movement, so many beautiful paintings gathered in a building much smaller than the Prado or the Reina Sofia.

Also, the visit is included in the Madrid Card, as well as the visit to the other 2 important art museums. There are also free visiting hours, but they didn't match our schedule so we preferred to use the Madrid Card.
titleopinion: Beautiful art collection. If you are in Madrid you definitely need to see the Golden Triangle of Art: Prado, Reina Sofia and Thyssen-Bornemisza.  I have to say, that out of the three, Thyssen-Bornemisza was my favourite. I love the impressionists' work, so this museum scores points with me by displaying paintings by Monet, Renoir, Manet, Pissaro, Degas, Sisley, Morisot. The building isn't as big as the Prado, which makes this collection even more impressive... so many important painters, from every movement, so many beautiful paintings gathered in a building much smaller than the Prado or the Reina Sofia.  Also, the visit is included in the Madrid Card, as well as the visit to the other 2 important art museums. There are also free visiting hours, but they didn't match our schedule so we preferred to use the Madrid Card.

reviewnospace: We went to The Thyssen on a Monday and it was free. The museum opens at noon and there is a line to get in so go a bit early. The museum has a lovely collection that is expansive - from flemish to impressionist to modern. El Greco to Degas to Edward Hopper to David Hockey. This kept it very interesting to me and I enjoyed every room. They also have a nice cafe in a great surrounding for a light lunch.
titleopinion: A great art collection. We went to The Thyssen on a Monday and it was free. The museum opens at noon and there is a line to get in so go a bit early. The museum has a lovely collection that is expansive - from flemish to impressionist to modern. El Greco to Degas to Edward Hopper to David Hockey. This kept it very interesting to me and I enjoyed every room. They also have a nice cafe in a great surrounding for a light lunch.

titleopinion: Beautiful. Beautifully balanced elegant cuisine. The berry soup was a delight the duck and steak delicious.international appeal in a modern airy restaurant

reviewnospace:
My sister & I visited this museum whilst on holiday in Madrid. This museum is one of the three in 'Triangle of Art' on Paseo del Prado. The art is the largest private collection in Europe and there is a lot to see, however the building is spacious with plenty of light and easy to navigate. There is a self-portraits exhibition running until 7th June 2015 with examples by Rembrandt, Steen and Freud. The self-portraits exhibition is located on the first floor balcony and free entry.

For the permanent collection only, the fee is 10 Euros and 7 Euros for over 65s with ID proof (students get the lower price).

Allow at least 3 hours for the visit of the museum and then visit the restaurant/coffee shop, located on the ground floor, for coffee/tea, sandwiches or pastries. I would recommend the apple cake (absolutely delicious).

The gift shop, located on the ground floor, sells books, prints and a very good range of souvenirs related to the collection and reasonable priced. The gift shop is one of the best I have been, as good as National Trust gift shops in the UK.

I would definitely recommend a visit to the Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum.
titleopinion: A Great Museum/Gallery to Visit. My sister & I visited this museum whilst on holiday in Madrid. This museum is one of the three in 'Triangle of Art' on Paseo del Prado. The art is the largest private collection in Europe and there is a lot to see, however the building is spacious with plenty of light and easy to navigate. There is a self-portraits exhibition running until 7th June 2015 with examples by Rembrandt, Steen and Freud. The self-portraits exhibition is located on the first floor balcony and free entry.  For the permanent collection only, the fee is 10 Euros and 7 Euros for over 65s with ID proof (students get the lower price).  Allow at least 3 hours for the visit of the museum and then visit the restaurant/coffee shop, located on the ground floor, for coffee/tea, sandwiches or pastries. I would recommend the apple cake (absolutely delicious).  The gift shop, located on the ground floor, sells books, prints and a very good range of souvenirs related to the collection and reasonable priced. The gift shop is one of the best I have been, as good as National Trust gift shops in the UK.  I would definitely recommend a visit to the Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum.

reviewnospace:
The artworks in the TBM are arranged over two floors and are displayed, generally, in chronological order. The visitor therefore gets a crash course in the history of painting from about the 13th century to the present day.
This is one of the most accessible (in every respect) galleries I have ever visited.
Allow at least 3 hours, or even better 4 hours and visit the very stylish restaurant/coffee shop for a pick me up between seeing the main collection and the Carmen Thyssen-Bornemisza collection.
The Prado has a much larger (but mainly Spanish school) collection but the TBM has a far more eclectic collection and represents art from around the world.

quote: Best private art collection in Europe
reviewnospace:
This museum is right across the street from its most famous cousin, the Prado.
It is extremely user friendly....large galleries and an amazing collection of all types of art from all periods.
Two really caught my attention: Gilbert Stuart's portrait of George Washington's cook! Now if Dolly Madison had not saved George's portrait from the burning White House during the War of 1812, would George's cook made it on the dollar!
;-)

The other is John Singer Sargent's portrait of the Duchess of Sutherland, 1909. Massive, imposing, and powerful.
All the modern art greats you have come to know including Rauschenberg's Maja,influenced by his time in Japan.
titleopinion: Best private art collection in Europe. This museum is right across the street from its most famous cousin, the Prado. Now if Dolly Madison had not saved George's portrait from the burning White House during the War of 1812, would George's cook made it on the dollar! ;-)  The other is John Singer Sargent's portrait of the Duchess of Sutherland, 1909. Massive, imposing, and powerful. All the modern art greats you have come to know including Rauschenberg's Maja,influenced by his time in Japan.

quote: Best of all worlds - a great place to visit.
reviewnospace:
T-B M is a welcome breath of fresh air after visiting the Prado and Reina Sofia. Some classical art, some contemporary and fresh exhibits. If the Prado is papa bear, and Reina Sofia Mama, then you got it...
I found the layout easy to traverse, the information ample and the staff pretty helpful. All 3 top museums are within a small area, but do yourself a favor, don't try to do more than 2 in one day or your head might explode. By the way, the gift shop in the T-B M is one of the nicest I've experienced short of NYC.

The audio guide is set up in an odd way and if your first language is not Spanish and that of the museum staff is not your language then it gets easy to be confused. Don't expect a sympathetic hearing when you return your audio-guide asking for a refund because you were unable to use it.
A minor blip in a brilliant experience overall.

quote: Impressive Collection of 13th to 20th Century Art!
reviewnospace: Not my favorite; she 'loved it'...this amazing family collection over two generations is now Spanish state-owned, displayed in a converted palace (across from Ritz Hotel, minutes walk from the Prado). Some of painting's top names from Durer to Dali are here with Rembrandt, Renoir, Rubens, and Van Gogh, plus Picasso, also on display. There are English brochures and audio guides available (for us tourists not Spanish-fluent), and also an excellent cafe-restaurant on site. Free on Monday afternoons, 10 or 7 Euros otherwise (over 65 w/proof, students get the lower).

It's paintings are displayed on 3 floors and clearly labelled so you can single out which artists, countries or movements you want to focus on quite easily. It' a great collection ,with something for everyone.I wasn't impressed by the food and drink in the cafe though.
titleopinion: Preferred it to The Prado. This is a very well laid out art gallery ,which, like many of the Madrid museums provides free access many afternoons,check the website for details. It's paintings are displayed on 3 floors and clearly labelled so you can single out which artists, countries or movements you want to focus on quite easily. It' a great collection ,with something for everyone.I wasn't impressed by the food and drink in the cafe though.

reviewnospace: If you like religious art from the 16th, 17th and 18th century the better known gallery is fine... if you like a broader brush approach this is fantastic... covers five centuries with some fabulous impressionist and modernist work - something for everyone and definitely not 'dry and stuffy' .... free entry on Mondays.
titleopinion: Better than the other one. If you like religious art from the 16th, 17th and 18th century the better known gallery is fine... if you like a broader brush approach this is fantastic... covers five centuries with some fabulous impressionist and modernist work - something for everyone and definitely not 'dry and stuffy' .... free entry on Mondays.

reviewnospace: This art gallery is a good size to enable to you go round in a couple of hours. The two separate collections are very interesting and there is a good variety.
titleopinion: A nice collection. This art gallery is a good size to enable to you go round in a couple of hours. The two separate collections are very interesting and there is a good variety.

reviewnospace: A great and diverse permanent collection of modern art. Diverse subject, diverse styles. So much to contemplate ... how I ad other view and interpret the world. We saw and excellent, temporary exhibition of Dufy's work capturing the Mediterranean atmosphere and bringing it to a dull winter day in Madrid. Best seen on a day separate from visiting other art galleries nearby.

reviewnospace: Excellent collection. More impressionist and a broader collection than the Prado. Had the feeling that the artists were a little less well known, but the collector has brought together an outstanding collection that clearly rivals its next door neighbour. For depth and surprise it beats it.

reviewnospace: Beautiful collection of paintings. If you start at the 2nd floor you will walk thru the collection in chronological order. Really great to see the art evolve and change during time.

reviewnospace: My 25 year old son and I very much enjoyed this museum. After Prado and Sofia we seriously debated going to a third museum but were so pleased we did. Great collection and well organized. Highly recommended!

quote: Fabulous and full of surprises! Must-go after Prado.
reviewnospace: This once private collection contains pieces from Medieval times till now. The idea of the wealth of this family is just as astounding as their collection. Loved so many pieces, especially the Ghirlandio, but fabulous surprises too, like the Cornell boxes, and George Washington's cook by Gilbert Stuart! It is literally catty-corner to the Prado. And they LET you PHOTOGRAPH any pieces you want!!!!!!

reviewnospace: This is a lovely museum with art to please all tastes. We went on a winter Thursday afternoon and it wasn't too crowded. The layout of the museum is spacious, the building itself is beautiful. Visiting is a great way to escape the hustle and bustle of Madrid and spend a peaceful afternoon. Also, the museum shop sells gorgeous jewelry and other unique souvenirs.

There were a few trips taking place with younger children and teenagers but this did not interfere with our time, but sometimes they got a little loud!

reviewnospace: This was my favourite gallery. I preferred it to the Prado and the Reina Sofia. Art by all the famous artists. reviewnospace: This is a museum that should not be missed if you like paintings by the masters. There are many paintings in many rooms and this can be overwhelming (I always leave museums exhausted) but stop for a moment and close your eyes and relax. Then continue your journey through this world class museum.

reviewnospace:
A wonderful collection and gallery in a beautiful mansion. With marvellous examples from the history of art, it's on a more achievable scale than the nearby Prado and you can go round in 2 or 3 hours having seen some of the greatest art in the world.

I really can't recommend highly enough, but I would like to add as another review has, that the reception staff are abrupt to the point of rudeness and if bags have to be left in a cloakroom, then it would be better to be informed of this when buying your ticket rather than them watching you disappear only to have to return to ask where the cloakroom is, when sent back by her colleague.
titleopinion: Superb gallery. A wonderful collection and gallery in a beautiful mansion. reviewnospace: If you're in Madrid you cannot miss these treasures, especially Rembrandt's painting, Impresionism and German Expresionism. And of course Dali's iconic canvas! Cafeteria is not great, but the bookshop is! Marvellous publications, catalogues and toys for children...(or yourself!)

quote: Rude & poorly trained staff in such a prestigious institution
reviewnospace: Great collection of art but very rude staff particularly at ticket counter. Doesn't set good tone for rest of trip. There's no point upsetting paying customers who provide their livelihood especially in a country where unemployment is high and it's tough to get another job. The economy of Spain relies on tourism and it doesn't cost anything to be polite to tourists.

reviewnospace: While the Prado is the major museum in Madrid, don't miss the Thyssen Bornemisza just across the street. It's almost like a very three floor large gallery. Start at the top and wander through rooms of European art from the 1200-1400s and end on the first floor with 20th century abstracts from the more modern masters. Download the museum app before your visit or use the audio tour to get the insights on everything.

reviewnospace:

The facility provides the perfect backdrop for an exceptional collection

quote: Just superb, needs more than one visit.
reviewnospace: The Prado may be the most famous art gallery in Madrid but on no account miss going to the Thyssen-Bornemisza. It is incredible to imagine that the vast array of paintings displayed here was originally a private collection. The permanent exhibition covers a vast time range beginning in the 14th century and ending in the 20th. There are paintings by Goya, Velasquez and El Greco, of course but also others by Pissaro, Monet, Seurat, Sisley,,Degas, Caravaggio, Titian etc, etc etc! The presentation is more modern than that of the Prado and more or less in chronological order. We hired the excellent audioguides and began at the beginning. After what had felt like a few minutes we realised that we had been in the museum for more than two hours and that we could not possibly see everything in the time available. We therefore cherry picked some of the paintings by painters we already knew and admired whilst at the same time began planning our next visit. We are not art experts or historians but we found that the descriptions on the audioguide met our purposes superbly. Very highly recommended.
titleopinion: Just superb, needs more than one visit.. The Prado may be the most famous art gallery in Madrid but on no account miss going to the Thyssen-Bornemisza. It is incredible to imagine that the vast array of paintings displayed here was originally a private collection. The presentation is more modern than that of the Prado and more or less in chronological order. We hired the excellent audioguides and began at the beginning. After what had felt like a few minutes we realised that we had been in the museum for more than two hours and that we could not possibly see everything in the time available. We are not art experts or historians but we found that the descriptions on the audioguide met our purposes superbly. Very highly recommended.

reviewnospace: If you are in Madrid on a Monday, don’t forget to check out this museum because entrance is free from 12 noon to 4 pm. It is also open from Tuesday to Sunday from 10 am to 7pm (during summer, i.e. July & August, Tuesday to Saturday it is open from 10am to 11pm). It has a vast art collection from the Byzantine era until the 20th century. Entrance fee is 10 Euros but you can get the Paseo del Arte ticket for 25.60 Euros and this allows you to visit the Prado and Reina Sofia museums as well.
titleopinion: An Impressive Art Collection. If you are in Madrid on a Monday, don’t forget to check out this museum because entrance is free from 12 noon to 4 pm. It is also open from Tuesday to Sunday from 10 am to 7pm (during summer, i.e. July & August, Tuesday to Saturday it is open from 10am to 11pm). It has a vast art collection from the Byzantine era until the 20th century. Entrance fee is 10 Euros but you can get the Paseo del Arte ticket for 25.60 Euros and this allows you to visit the Prado and Reina Sofia museums as well.

reviewnospace:
Although the Prado museum is much bigger, considered to be more imponrtant and it's structure is way more imposing and holds way more heritage, the Thyssen-Bornemisza is a one-of museum. The majority of its collection comes from the Thyssen-Bornemisza family, a detail that gives the museum a mojo, just like the Frick Collection in New York.

Truth be told, there is some controversy regarding all the links between the Thryssen family and the Nazis back in the date, but this didn't take any millimeter away from the pleasure I had visiting this museum.

Don't forget to visit the Reina Sofia museum to complete the circuit, these 3 are amongst the most important museums of Europe.

Beware of the time table, the museum is open for free at some specific times.

reviewnospace:
This museum has an incredible collection of well-known artists from a variety of genres (impressionists, surrealists, expressionists, cubists, etc.), which worked perfectly for my friend and I who have vastly different tastes in art.
Additionally, this museum introduced me to several fantastic artists whose work I had never come across before anywhere else. Be sure to give yourself several hours for this museum- I could have stayed there all day.

There is normally a 9 euro fee for students to enter; however, the museum is free to everyone between 12 and 4pm on Mondays so I would recommend aiming to see it during this time if possible because the queues were not bad at all.

location: Central Mexico and Gulf Coast, Mexico
reviewnospace: When in Madrid, there are three museums you ought to enjoy: El Prado, Reina Sofía and Thyssen-Bornemisza. This last one has a perfect art collection that starts at 12th century. A great collection of Catholic art, it also has avant garde movements as Fauvism, and contemporaneity art. A must.

quote: One of the best art museums anywhere
reviewnospace: This museum is well worth a visit. It is an eclectic private collection which includes an amazing number of wonderful art pieces from 1300 until the 1900s. There are old masters, impressionists, Hudson River School artists as well as avant garde pieces. It is a history museum for 700 years of art. It is easy to tour and offers many many different rooms and spaces which allow you to view art without a crowded feeling. If you love art... you will love this museum.

reviewnospace: Everytime I go to Madrid there is always an amazing exhibit! One of the best museums in town. There might be long lines so you might want to ask the hotel concierge for tickets or pop in the museum and see if you can buy tickets for a later time so you won't wait there.

reviewnospace:
I don't like the classic arts, so the 2nd floor was almost whole a waste; but a good part of 1st floor and almost all of the ground one are a great treat - absolutely worth your time and a little penny.
Plus the temporary exhibitions are also often really good.
titleopinion: just skip the 2nd floor. reviewnospace: Less crowded than the Reina Sofia or Prado museums but with its share of masterpieces and some quirky choices showing early and unusual works by masters. A lithograph of the Potato Eaters by Van Gogh showing his mastery as a draughtsman long before he set the world alight as a colourist: Toulouse Lautrec's "The Jockeys" may have shown Jack Yeats the way with his work of the same name, and so different from the Paris Nightlife work with which Lautrec is identified. Art apart the restaurant serves excellent food with minimal fuss - worth in our case splashing out a bit for truly memorable dishes - 'sensational' is strictly correct for a seafood dish of cod , mussels, algae and more which smelled and tasted as if it had just that minute emerged from the sea.

reviewnospace:
I will confess that art museums are not my thing, so I will write this from my partner’s perspective. She found the collection very interesting with many notable artists displaying their obvious works of art and the not so obvious. For example a Gainsborough portrait, rather than a landscape. Her one disappointment was that there were no paintings by Titian on display.

So, this is a fine art collection and definitely worth a visit. We were here for almost 3 hours! Top tip, find out when the museum is open for free to save yourself some money.

quote: The Best Art Gallery in Madrid
reviewnospace:
Madrid is blessed with three world class art galleries the Prado, Sofia Reina and the Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum. My favourite is the Thyssen. Firstly, it's sheer diversity of art from 14th century to modern art with practically every major artist represented, means that no matter your taste in art there is something there for you! My favourites; Canaletto, Renoir, Monet, Schiele & Dali were all there.
Secondly, I have a 3 hour attention span in a gallery, if I stay longer I get tired and everything seems to merge and I do not appreciate it fully. I managed to see all the art I was interested in and then some in under 3 hours.
The gift shop is excellent, by far the best selection of items with extensive book collects in both Spanish and English.

My favourites; Canaletto, Renoir, Monet, Schiele & Dali were all there. Secondly, I have a 3 hour attention span in a gallery, if I stay longer I get tired and everything seems to merge and I do not appreciate it fully. I managed to see all the art I was interested in and then some in under 3 hours. The gift shop is excellent, by far the best selection of items with extensive book collects in both Spanish and English.

reviewnospace: The Museo Thyssen-Bornemisza, which contains one of the worlds foremost and most distinguished private art collections, opened on 8th October 1992. Acquired over two generations, the collection is directly linked to the names of Heinrich Thyssen-Bornemisza and Hans Heinrich Thyssen-Bornemisza. The most important group of paintings gathered together by the Thyssen-Bornemisza family was acquired by the Spanish state in July 1993 and spans a period dating from the late 13th century to the 1980s. In 1992 this historic collection was installed in the Palacio de Villahermosa after the buildings conversion into a museum by the architect Rafael Moneo.
titleopinion: MUSEO THYSSEN-BORNEMISZA. The Museo Thyssen-Bornemisza, which contains one of the worlds foremost and most distinguished private art collections, opened on 8th October 1992. The most important group of paintings gathered together by the Thyssen-Bornemisza family was acquired by the Spanish state in July 1993 and spans a period dating from the late 13th century to the 1980s. In 1992 this historic collection was installed in the Palacio de Villahermosa after the buildings conversion into a museum by the architect Rafael Moneo.

quote: Recollection and Comparison with The Prado
reviewnospace: The museum content cover "newer" art (but not modern). It is almost across a side street from the Villa Real Hotel. It is light, refreshing and was newly remodeled in 2000. We mention this because it is "easy" to "BAG" this site on the same day you start or finish up in the Prado, just to the East about 500 meters away from the Thyssen.

reviewnospace:
Was able to visit the Givenchy exhibit. What a treat!!!! Done with great style and respect to the master, his creations and his vision.
Also the American Impressionism exhibit and a small Van Gogh exhibit of pieces owned by the museum.

Done with great style and respect to the master, his creations and his vision. Also the American Impressionism exhibit and a small Van Gogh exhibit of pieces owned by the museum.

reviewnospace: Wow, what a collection...after a day at the Prado clear your head with a stunning collection of art from Renaissance to contemporary....in addition to permanent collection, there are several temporary special exhibitions.
titleopinion: Not to be missed!. Wow, what a collection...after a day at the Prado clear your head with a stunning collection of art from Renaissance to contemporary....in addition to permanent collection, there are several temporary special exhibitions.

reviewnospace: Great museum you can visit for free every Monday after 12 until 16. One of the best of the world with Monet, Manet, Van Gogh, Cezanne, Picasso, Klimt, ...
titleopinion: House of masterpieces. Great museum you can visit for free every Monday after 12 until 16. One of the best of the world with Monet, Manet, Van Gogh, Cezanne, Picasso, Klimt, ...

reviewnospace:
The Bornemisza-Thyssen Museum is one of 3 museums located in the "Golden Triangle of Art" in the Paseo del Prado area. The other 2 are the Del Prado and the Sofia Reina national art museums. You can purchase a ticket to cover all three. We visited the Del Prado one day and the Bornemisza the next. The collections for both are extensive so we spent about 3 hours in each museum.

The art collection at the Bornemisza is housed in the Villahermosa Palace which is one of the most important buildings in Madrid in respect of palatial architecture. it was originally a private collection begun by Heinrich, Baron Bornemisza-Thyssen in the 1920s. He collected works of the Old Masters. Later, his son, Hans Heinrich, the next Baron Bornemisza-Thyssen took over the collection and expanded it with art pieces from the 19th and 20th centuries. The collection spans about eight centuries of European art and when as a private collection was once the 2nd largest in the world behind the British Royal art collection.

We took photos without flash and you are politely reminded by the docents at each location if by chance you forget. There is a good reason for this as it helps protect the paintings from damage.

Some paintings we viewed: St Michael Expelling Lucifer and the Rebellious Angels from Heaven by Peter Paul Reubens; Still Life with Fruit by Louise Moillon; A Bouquet of Chamomile, French Roses and other Flowers by Jean-Baptiste Monnoyer; Boy in a Turban by Michel Sweerts; The Machine Drill by Franticek Kupka; The Madonna of the Village by Marc Chagall and Thank You by Richard Lindner.

If you are in Madrid, give the Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum a try, you could learn a lot about European art through the ages.
titleopinion: Outstanding & Impressive. The Bornemisza-Thyssen Museum is one of 3 museums located in the  Golden Triangle of Art  in the Paseo del Prado area. The other 2 are the Del Prado and the Sofia Reina national art museums. You can purchase a ticket to cover all three. We visited the Del Prado one day and the Bornemisza the next. The collections for both are extensive so we spent about 3 hours in each museum.  The art collection at the Bornemisza is housed in the Villahermosa Palace which is one of the most important buildings in Madrid in respect of palatial architecture. it was originally a private collection begun by Heinrich, Baron Bornemisza-Thyssen in the 1920s. He collected works of the Old Masters. Later, his son, Hans Heinrich, the next Baron Bornemisza-Thyssen took over the collection and expanded it with art pieces from the 19th and 20th centuries. The collection spans about eight centuries of European art and when as a private collection was once the 2nd largest in the world behind the British Royal art collection.  We took photos without flash and you are politely reminded by the docents at each location if by chance you forget. There is a good reason for this as it helps protect the paintings from damage.   Some paintings we viewed: St Michael Expelling Lucifer and the Rebellious Angels from Heaven by Peter Paul Reubens; Still Life with Fruit by Louise Moillon; A Bouquet of Chamomile, French Roses and other Flowers by Jean-Baptiste Monnoyer; Boy in a Turban by Michel Sweerts; The Machine Drill by Franticek Kupka; The Madonna of the Village by Marc Chagall and Thank You by Richard Lindner.  If you are in Madrid, give the Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum a try, you could learn a lot about European art through the ages.

reviewnospace: Impressive, huge European art collection from medieval art all the way to modernism! Start on the 2nd floor and work your way down. A marvellous journey through masterpieces of all ages. If you plan on going to the Prado and the Reina Sofia as well, get a joint admission ticket to the three, it is cheaper. There is also a time when you can get in for free, Just check on their site! Ah, photos are allowed...
titleopinion: BEST MUSEUM IN MADRID!. Impressive, huge European art collection from medieval art all the way to modernism! Start on the 2nd floor and work your way down. A marvellous journey through masterpieces of all ages. If you plan on going to the Prado and the Reina Sofia as well, get a joint admission ticket to the three, it is cheaper. There is also a time when you can get in for free, Just check on their site! Ah, photos are allowed...

reviewnospace: This private collection is breath-taking. And the building itself is a gem. The eating options are in a glassed in area above a planted entrance and look out across the [silenced by the glass] urban sidewalk and road bustle of Madrid. The fresh food is simple and well prepared. The service is pleasant. And weather permitting the outdoor terrace offers that variation. At drinks time, it is a cosmpolitan crowd. And by drinks time, my mind was so filled with beautifl painting and scultpure than a great seat and a great glass of wine were the perfect way to let me absorb them before heading out to the lively city.

quote: New year break away in Madrid.
reviewnospace: We were invited to this museum to see this collection on show. It was unbelievable the whole area was great to see. I love to visit museums and see collections on show.
titleopinion: New year break away in Madrid.. We were invited to this museum to see this collection on show. It was unbelievable the whole area was great to see. I love to visit museums and see collections on show.

reviewnospace: The current exhibition of American impressionist painters was a new and exciting revelation for me - highly recommended.
titleopinion: American impressionism at its best. The current exhibition of American impressionist painters was a new and exciting revelation for me - highly recommended.

reviewnospace: Through a long time journey, this museum offers pieces of arts from different centuries as a kaleidocope of human imagination and art
titleopinion: From middle-age to modern times. Through a long time journey, this museum offers pieces of arts from different centuries as a kaleidocope of human imagination and art

reviewnospace:
If "Less is more" is your motto, then I'd recommend the Thyssen-Bornemisza museum over the Prado. Baron Thyssen and his wife Carmen have a vast collection of art starting with religious medieval art all the way to modernism. They seem to have managed to collect the finest pieces from each period. Every work of art is a gem! Start on the 2nd floor and work your way down .. Don't forget the Van Gogh room before leaving, it is kind of hidden.
Also liked the temporary exhibition about Berlin art very much.
This is a very comprehensive museum if you want to get an overview of predominantly European art through the centuries. Ideal for art students and amateurs like me.
titleopinion: Thyssen-Bornemisza: Best museum in Madrid!. If  Less is more  is your motto, then I'd recommend the Thyssen-Bornemisza museum over the Prado. Baron Thyssen and his wife Carmen have a vast collection of art starting with religious medieval art all the way to modernism. They seem to have managed to collect the finest pieces from each period. Every work of art is a gem! Start on the 2nd floor and work your way down .. Don't forget the Van Gogh room before leaving, it is kind of hidden. Also liked the temporary exhibition about Berlin art very much. This is a very comprehensive museum if you want to get an overview of predominantly European art through the centuries. Ideal for art students and amateurs like me.

reviewnospace: All of the museums are so close together! I bought the "pass" so that helps avoid the lines. The "free" hours can be quite crowded with locals but give yourself enough time to enjoy the museum. I also did the audio guide here and I'd do it again! Enjoy!

reviewnospace: Very much enjoyed viewing this private collection with many masters included. Appreciated touring with my family viewing works in chronological order, as that is how the museum is organized

This one also has very interesting themed expositions, that sometimes form part of an international travelling exposition, like the one about Hopper, which was great!

reviewnospace: This Museum is not the biggest one or the best well known but indeed one of the places you cannot miss when visiting Madrid. Location is perfect, permanent collections are just great and you have to check temporary collections as they can show pieces you could only dream of. Hopper for instance was just amazing....

reviewnospace:
We did not know what to expect from this museum, but, WOW!. It is fantastic. When we were there there was a showing of Giverny's
fashion throughout the years. This was truly fascinating. Very interesting to see phtotos and then the actual garment beside it. Wonderful exhibition.

Their is also an amazing way to get prints on canvas or paper there. You pick the painting you want (there are quite a few to pick from) and within a few minutes it is done on a printer that gives you a very fine print. I got one and it is lovely.

Great privately owned museum!!!

quote: Don't miss this great Art Museum
reviewnospace: Such a small treasure that often gets missed by everyone wanting to see the Prado. Great impressionist art, modern, and a great collection of the Dutch Master's of Light.
titleopinion: Don't miss this great Art Museum. Such a small treasure that often gets missed by everyone wanting to see the Prado. Great impressionist art, modern, and a great collection of the Dutch Master's of Light.

reviewnospace: So far I have visited this museum three times - which means every time I visited Madrid, I went to this museum. It is definitely more boutique as compared with Prado, but I seriously love this one more, not only because here you don't have so many people and can really spend as much time as you'd like in front of your favourite paintings, but also because of the selection: so diversified and so artistically representative in its respective genres. Also here you can take pictures! Definitely a great place to visit and their outdoor coffee house can be very pleasant in warmer days.

reviewnospace: This along with the Prado and Reina Sofia museums is a must if you are an art lover. The modern art collection is fantastic is thorough, and the timeline in which is organized is also very intelligent.
titleopinion: Splendid. This along with the Prado and Reina Sofia museums is a must if you are an art lover. The modern art collection is fantastic is thorough, and the timeline in which is organized is also very intelligent.

reviewnospace: Overwhelming private collection. Needs more than one visit to do it justice. Taking each room at a time is a fascinating chronicle of milestones in art. However dipping into key highlights may be the only option if your visit is constrained by time.
titleopinion: Journey through art history . Overwhelming private collection. Needs more than one visit to do it justice. Taking each room at a time is a fascinating chronicle of milestones in art. However dipping into key highlights may be the only option if your visit is constrained by time.

quote: One of the most important galleries in Madrid
reviewnospace: One of the most important galleries in Madrid where you'll surely find several masterworks, but besides that the gallery host not so high impact rotating collections so be sure to check their website first to see if you're interested.
titleopinion: One of the most important galleries in Madrid. One of the most important galleries in Madrid where you'll surely find several masterworks, but besides that the gallery host not so high impact rotating collections so be sure to check their website first to see if you're interested.

reviewnospace:
Anyone who is in Madrid who is interested in art should come here. You would really need two days to see the whole thing. Sincé we are more interested in 19th and 20th century painting than in some of the other styles on display, we started at the end and did the tour backwards as far as the Dutch Golden Age. By then we'd been overwhelmed by art. It was all great.

If you plan to see the Prado and the Reina Sofia as well, you can get a discount on a joint admission ticket to the three. That's a very good deal. In addition, there are often very good temporary exhibits at the Thyssen.

Come early, the lines can be long. WARNING: Pickpockets and scam artists work the tourist áreas in Madrid. Keep an eye on your belongings, especially while waiting in line.

One complaint: Don't go to the museum café. It is way overpriced.

reviewnospace: Really interesting to show how art has developed across the centuries. Starts with medieval and has pictures right through to the Twentieth Century. Great for someone who enjoys art without being an aficionado.

reviewnospace: Unlike the larger and more magnificent Prado, the Thyssen-Bornemisza is a pleasure to see because it's small, but still holds beautiful pieces. One can visit and see everything in 2 hours, giving the spectator room to both marvel, but not exhaust oneself.

reviewnospace: After understanding how/where to go to the selected floors/rooms you have decided to visit, it is really appreciated that the paintings are not too close the ones to the others, being hanged up at the same height - the visitor's average eyes ... Nice impressionist/post impressionism paintings in particular
titleopinion: Nice Paintings ... very well presented. quote: Allow plenty of time, but don't miss.
reviewnospace:
This is a huge and magnificent collection. The building is modern and perfect for the display of paintings. I visited in November so there were no problems with crowds. Two exhibitions, American impressionists, and the Givenchy dresses and gowns, were both first rate.
The earliest works are on the top floor and work their way through art history to contemporary on ground level. If time is limited, choose your particular field and enjoy!
The museum is open most days until 7.00pm and photography is allowed.
I didn't go to the restaurant but friends who did said it was excellent.
titleopinion: Allow plenty of time, but don't miss.. This is a huge and magnificent collection. The building is modern and perfect for the display of paintings. I visited in November so there were no problems with crowds. Two exhibitions, American impressionists, and the Givenchy dresses and gowns, were both first rate. The earliest works are on the top floor and work their way through art history to contemporary on ground level. If time is limited, choose your particular field and enjoy!  The museum is open most days until 7.00pm and photography is allowed. I didn't go to the restaurant but friends who did said it was excellent.

quote: A tour-de-force through 700 years of painting
reviewnospace: The Thyssen Barons amassed a truly astounding collection of artworks from the early Gothic period to the later part of the 20th century. Masterpieces abound, so it is worth your while to go carefully through the many rooms where the paintings are beautifully displayed. The audio guide commentary for once is worthwhile (if not free of hokey aspects). You will encounter all the great masters of Western art and marvel at the good collectors's fortunes of the Thyssen family.

quote: Not nearly as stuffy as Prado
reviewnospace:
This collection is much better if you like Monnet, Renoir, Pissarro, Picasso, Gris.

Catch Streets and Faces of Berlin before it closes next month on Jan 25th (Grosz, Kirchner, Dix, Schad).

reviewnospace:
My wife and I enjoyed very much the Givenchy Exhibition. We saw some of the most beautiful dresses that Givenchy designed. Very important were the dresses worn by Jackie Kennedy and Audrey Hepburn in her movies.

There was also a very good exhibition of American impressionists. I enjoyed seeing the paintings of John Singer Sargent.

Very important were the dresses worn by Jackie Kennedy and Audrey Hepburn in her movies.  There was also a very good exhibition of American impressionists. I enjoyed seeing the paintings of John Singer Sargent.

quote: Return visit to an old favourite

titleopinion: Return visit to an old favourite. Another outstanding collection of art in Madrid. The 20th century is very well represented. My particular personal favourites are the Georgia O'Keefe's and the Michael Andrews  Portrait of Timothy Wehrens .

reviewnospace: i have seen references to this museum for alot of the great art in the world and it did not disappoint, it is quite large and has a terrific gift shop as well
titleopinion: well worth the stop. i have seen references to this museum for alot of the great art in the world and it did not disappoint, it is quite large and has a terrific gift shop as well

quote: A beatiful museum with a great overview
reviewnospace: This museum is after a private collection and you can find masterpieces from middle age to XX century. Use the map to follow the chronological path between styles and ages. Lot of light and space to admire the artwork.
titleopinion: A beatiful museum with a great overview. This museum is after a private collection and you can find masterpieces from middle age to XX century. Use the map to follow the chronological path between styles and ages. Lot of light and space to admire the artwork.

reviewnospace: when walking through the museum I had this feeling that T-B collector (and his wife later on) had a gifted eye when choosing each painting, and was collecting for pleasure, not for investing and this shows! I had a surprisingly nice feeling when wandering in the museum, just like he must have felt among his treasures.

quote: Enjoyed 25th Anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall Exhibit
reviewnospace: The Permanent Collection is enough to draw you in (Rodin, Picasso, Rubens, Chagall, etc...) but I also enjoyed the display of 20th century German artists in celebration of the 25th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall. This display is included in the price of your ticket as well.
titleopinion: Enjoyed 25th Anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall Exhibit. The Permanent Collection is enough to draw you in (Rodin, Picasso, Rubens, Chagall, etc...) but I also enjoyed the display of 20th century German artists in celebration of the 25th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall. This display is included in the price of your ticket as well.

reviewnospace: We visited the exhibit covering unrest in Spain from the 1800's to the end of WWII. The exhibit was revealing & disturbing, depicting violence & unrest among Europeans from the invasion of Napoleon through the Spanish Revolution & WWII. Includes Picasso's "Guernica" mural.
titleopinion: Upheaval in Spain. We visited the exhibit covering unrest in Spain from the 1800's to the end of WWII. The exhibit was revealing & disturbing, depicting violence & unrest among Europeans from the invasion of Napoleon through the Spanish Revolution & WWII. Includes Picasso's  Guernica  mural.

reviewnospace:
The museum was only slightly eclipsed by the main, larger Prado Museum, but stood its own with an impressive set of paintings. Highlights would be early European paintings (particularly Italian, English and German), as well as Impressionist and Post-Impressionist works by artists like Claude Monet and Vincent van Gogh. Good display of Spanish works too, including by the great Picasso.

Tip to visitors: If you intend to visit all three art museums, do buy a combined "3-in-1" Madrid Art pass for a small discount. You don't have to visit all three in a day, so don't worry :)
titleopinion: Runner-Up of the Big 3. The museum was only slightly eclipsed by the main, larger Prado Museum, but stood its own with an impressive set of paintings. Highlights would be early European paintings (particularly Italian, English and German), as well as Impressionist and Post-Impressionist works by artists like Claude Monet and Vincent van Gogh. Good display of Spanish works too, including by the great Picasso.  Tip to visitors: If you intend to visit all three art museums, do buy a combined  3-in-1  Madrid Art pass for a small discount. You don't have to visit all three in a day, so don't worry :)

reviewnospace: I know everyone raves about Prado, but for me, this museum had the biggest emotional impact. The impressionists are amazing. I have to say that I do not remember looking at a painting and starting to cry. until today The Impressionist of America were on display as well as Renoir, Degas, Cassat, and then of course the floor for Andrew Wyeth and did I mention Picasso and Dali and Goya? Oh my goodness, it is so moving to see the real thing. Smaller or sometimes larger, never disappointing. So many rooms. Take your time, take a break, and then continue. It is worth taking the day or the best part of it.

reviewnospace: This is probably the best museum in Madrid. It many examples of popular artists. I hear it is very crowded in season.
titleopinion: A great museum.. This is probably the best museum in Madrid. It many examples of popular artists. I hear it is very crowded in season.

reviewnospace: I had no idea what a vast collection of art this family had accumulated - first the father and son Thyssen-Bornemiszas, then the son's wife, Carmen. Interestingly the building is structured to "segregate" her collection from the two men's. One visit can't deal with this museum. One should at least spend a whole day to savour the range - tiny medieval religious paintings, a Holbein Henry VIII, an in-your-face feisty Caravaggio and tons of Impressionists, both familiar and unfamiliar - not to mention a quite esoteric collection of American landscape artists, nearly all of whom I had never heard of before. A day here is great. There is a wonderful café/restaurant, offering everything from cups of coffee and snacks to rather wonderful full meals. It is a must on any visit to Madrid.

One should at least spend a whole day to savour the range - tiny medieval religious paintings, a Holbein Henry VIII, an in-your-face feisty Caravaggio and tons of Impressionists, both familiar and unfamiliar - not to mention a quite esoteric collection of American landscape artists, nearly all of whom I had never heard of before. A day here is great. There is a wonderful café/restaurant, offering everything from cups of coffee and snacks to rather wonderful full meals. It is a must on any visit to Madrid.

quote: A beautifully curated collection of stunning art
reviewnospace: I'm positive The Prado is superb but I was poorly on Prado day. The Thyssen was therefore something of a substitute. I needn't have worried - it is magnificent. The main collection is presented on 2 floors in chronological order from early 17th Century to the present day. The space and lighting is incredible. Whizzing around an exhibition with lunch and a plane home on the agenda isn't the most conducive to art appreciation, but it is gripping, arresting and entirely worthwhile. Don't miss it.

Whizzing around an exhibition with lunch and a plane home on the agenda isn't the most conducive to art appreciation, but it is gripping, arresting and entirely worthwhile. Don't miss it.

reviewnospace: If you don't have the time, energy or interest of doing the Prado and the Museum of Modern Art, the Thyssen-Bornemisza is a good compromise. Start on the second floor and work your way down. The Museum is on a more modest, human scale and you don't get a sensory overload as you do when there are thousands of art works to view. The permanent exhibition takes you through a history of Westwrn painting and has some impressive works. The staff are a bit snotty but easily ignored.

reviewnospace: Lovely collection, not as grand as the Prado, but impressive and worth a visit none the less. We did it the wrong way around and the experience was quite jarring.

reviewnospace: Eclectic but well organized collection. Personal taste, but we liked the modern European sections more than the American collection. As mentioned elsewhere, nicely complements the Prado and Sophia nearby.

reviewnospace:
We took advantage of a rainy March day to finally try and “conquer” the last of Madrid’s world-class museum trio (after I’d seen the Prado and the Reina Sofia MNCARS on a previous trip).

We started our discovery with paintings from the turn of the century on the ground floor including a temporary exhibit of El Greco showing in just a couple of paintings the range of his development. Then we found our way upstairs where we started with the oldest works of art in the museum from the 14th century and stumbling across a few works that appeared startlingly modern (Bramantino’s Christo resucitado and Uccello’s La Curcifixión con la Virgen, los santos Juanes y san Franciso).

After an hour of wandering from one room to the next we arrived in the 18th century, only to discover that there was yet another collection, the one that the Baroness Carmen Thyssen Bornemisza had begun herself. And there we could only fleetingly glance at so many beautiful Impressionist and Expressionist paintings.

Later back in the hotel I downloaded the fantastic free Android app and was delighted to find details – albeit only in Spanish – about all of the paintings we had looked at or at least the ones we could remember or had been captured on our tablet cameras and had piqued our interest.

Although we fully failed in our attempt to “conquer” the Thyssen Bornemisza – a museum that takes many a visit to fully appreciate – we’ll be coming back, and once Madrid becomes our home away from home, we’ll no doubt become two of the Amigos with annual passes.
titleopinion: a lifetime (experience) of art. We took advantage of a rainy March day to finally try and “conquer” the last of Madrid’s world-class museum trio (after I’d seen the Prado and the Reina Sofia MNCARS on a previous trip).  We started our discovery with paintings from the turn of the century on the ground floor including a temporary exhibit of El Greco showing in just a couple of paintings the range of his development. Then we found our way upstairs where we started with the oldest works of art in the museum from the 14th century and stumbling across a few works that appeared startlingly modern (Bramantino’s Christo resucitado and Uccello’s La Curcifixión con la Virgen, los santos Juanes y san Franciso).   After an hour of wandering from one room to the next we arrived in the 18th century, only to discover that there was yet another collection, the one that the Baroness Carmen Thyssen Bornemisza had begun herself. And there we could only fleetingly glance at so many beautiful Impressionist and Expressionist paintings.   Later back in the hotel I downloaded the fantastic free Android app and was delighted to find details – albeit only in Spanish – about all of the paintings we had looked at or at least the ones we could remember or had been captured on our tablet cameras and had piqued our interest.  Although we fully failed in our attempt to “conquer” the Thyssen Bornemisza – a museum that takes many a visit to fully appreciate – we’ll be coming back, and once Madrid becomes our home away from home, we’ll no doubt become two of the Amigos with annual passes.

reviewnospace: This museum is by far the best art museum in Madrid, and possibly in Spain. You hear all about the Prado, but if you really want to enjoy your visit and see some fantastic art, this is the museum to go to. An enormous and wonderful collection that (at the time of our visit in Nov 14) had fantastic temporary exhibits to complement it. Many different types of art, styles, and artists. Make this museum your first stop in Madrid to ensure you can experience it all. Wonderful visit!

reviewnospace:
The Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum derives its name from its namesake Baron, who began collecting art in the 1930's by taking advantage of the Depression of that era in the U.S. and its impact on the rich and famous there. Needing cash, many U.S. ex-millionaires and other art collectors found a ready buyer for their art in Switzerland's Baron Thyssen-Bornemisza. Over time, as the Baron's son and second wife (a former Miss Spain) joined him in collecting, this marvelous collection grew to over 1,600 paintings representing seven centuries of art. Following a dispute in Switzerland over the housing of the collection, the family brought a good portion of the collection to Spain, where the Spanish government provided a building practically across the street from the Prado. The Spanish government has since purchased the entire collection.

The artwork in Thyssen-Bornemisza complements what you'll see at the Prado and Reina Sofia, making it an equally important stop on the Paseo del Prado. Where the Prado lacks Impressionists, Thy-Bor fills it in. More Spanish artists -- El Greco, Picasso, Dali. Dutch, German and other areas weakly treated elsewhere get more play here. And the "modern" art collection is manageable -- won't leave you in a daze as we found at Reina Sofia.

Bottom line, this is a gem of a museum with art worth seeing. General admission is 10 euros, plus any special exhibitions you might want to see or an audio guide. On a budget? Check the website for discounts for seniors, students, fine art teachers, internet tickets, etc., at www.museothyssen.org - or show up on a Monday between noon and 4:00 p.m. for free admission. Enjoy!

Over time, as the Baron's son and second wife (a former Miss Spain) joined him in collecting, this marvelous collection grew to over 1,600 paintings representing seven centuries of art. Following a dispute in Switzerland over the housing of the collection, the family brought a good portion of the collection to Spain, where the Spanish government provided a building practically across the street from the Prado. The Spanish government has since purchased the entire collection.  The artwork in Thyssen-Bornemisza complements what you'll see at the Prado and Reina Sofia, making it an equally important stop on the Paseo del Prado. Where the Prado lacks Impressionists, Thy-Bor fills it in. More Spanish artists -- El Greco, Picasso, Dali. Dutch, German and other areas weakly treated elsewhere get more play here. And the  modern  art collection is manageable -- won't leave you in a daze as we found at Reina Sofia.  Bottom line, this is a gem of a museum with art worth seeing. quote: Fills in the gaps at the Prado
reviewnospace: Great section on Impressionists. The Prado stops long before this. This museum is the private collection of a Thyssen father and son. It has a bit of art from every century. The son married a former Miss Spain who persuaded him to put his collection here after Lugano rejected his building plans. He died in 2002 and she donated 200 more paintings in 2004. With the Prado across the street and the Reina Sofia a short walk away, you can get an Art education in a couple days.
titleopinion: Fills in the gaps at the Prado. Great section on Impressionists. The Prado stops long before this. This museum is the private collection of a Thyssen father and son. It has a bit of art from every century. The son married a former Miss Spain who persuaded him to put his collection here after Lugano rejected his building plans. He died in 2002 and she donated 200 more paintings in 2004. With the Prado across the street and the Reina Sofia a short walk away, you can get an Art education in a couple days.

reviewnospace: This private collection is displayed in a unique fashion ~ the works range from the 13 century to the late 20th century, and cover most of the major periods and artistic styles of each period. They are displayed chronologically, which creates a very interesting stroll through art history. We have had the good fortune to visit many wonderful museums around the globe, and I thought the audio guide here was exceptional. I learned allot, and because of the information presented I was better able to make a connection to the piece and the artist that I was viewing. And because each piece was hand-selected for a personal collection, it is thoughtfully and thoroughly compiled, and has the feel of being lovingly created ~ We enjoyed our time here very much.

Visiting during a sunny day should be great also, since there is a beautiful terrace to have lunch in the garden.

quote: A museum that little boys enjoy too
reviewnospace:
Not a single doubt. Museo del Prado, just in front of Thyssen is superior if we speak only about quantity and quality of exhibitions. Actually, el Prado is one of the best in the world. In a little space, you have el Prado, Reina Sofia (Modern Art) and Thyssen. If you like painting, don't lose any of them. If you don't have time for visiting the three, go to El Prado...unless you cannot pass without visiting a myth that is in any of the others. That happens, for instance, with people that above any other thing, want to visit "Guernica", that is in Reina Sofía...finally, if you go with kids...try Thyssen.

Thyssen Museum has been very good at playing its cards. They have very often splendid temporal exhibitions and, at the same time, they have created a children-friendly environment.

If someone can anticipate an exact day for the visit with weeks in advance, a good experience for children is hiring a visit specific for them. They are going to see only a few paintings (about ten) inviting the children to see some details that can be interesting starting in them the taste for the painting. After that, they are driven to the workshop in the underground where they can play games painting. It's a nice experience for them.

Anyway, if you can, don't choose. Take it all.

Essentially, the art is beautiful: my favourite pieces were the set of Lucian Freud paintings, but there is an expansive range of styles and genres that can be found throughout the rooms. Furthermore, these wonderful collections can be seen for free on Mondays - what more could you want?

reviewnospace: We found the collection quite interesting and found the collection fo modern art to be quite good. The museum itself is specious and easy to navigate.
titleopinion: Interesting collection. We found the collection quite interesting and found the collection fo modern art to be quite good. The museum itself is specious and easy to navigate.

reviewnospace:
Allow 3-4 hours to go round three floors with hundreds of great paintings on display. Nearly every major artist you can think of is represented, and many less well known (to me anyway) but fine. A few gaps e.g. Turner, Seurat, Manet.... but hey, an extraordinarily rich array all the same, and you can find other works in the Prado and the Reina Sofia nearby.
The Thyssen is on Paseo del Prado. Tip: free entry on Monday 12–4pm, a queue of about 200m to get in but it moved quickly.
titleopinion: Remarkably rich collection. Allow 3-4 hours to go round three floors with hundreds of great paintings on display. Nearly every major artist you can think of is represented, and many less well known (to me anyway) but fine. reviewnospace: A quote I heard aptly describes the museum: minor works by major artists, major works by minor artists. Museum is easy to follow and has a good audio guide. There was a Givenchy exhibition when I was there (excellent!), but I had to pay general admission, exhibition museum,, and audio guide. A total of 23 euro. If you are really into art like I am, go. If not, you can skip it.
titleopinion: Expensive, but worth a look. A quote I heard aptly describes the museum: minor works by major artists, major works by minor artists. Museum is easy to follow and has a good audio guide. reviewnospace:
An excellent collection of fashion - worn by Audrey Hepburn., Duchess of Windsor, Jackie Kennedy, and other film stars.

Reasonable entry price and free entry into the permanent collection ( also wonderful)
Well set out with space for extended viewing - although we suspected later view times were fuller.
titleopinion: Hubert Givenchy fashion collection. An excellent collection of fashion - worn by Audrey Hepburn., Duchess of Windsor, Jackie Kennedy, and other film stars.  Reasonable entry price and free entry into the permanent collection ( also wonderful) Well set out with space for extended viewing - although we suspected later view times were fuller.

quote: Amazing collection of modern art and older art
reviewnospace: Great museum, well organized, with good audioguide. Excellent collection! One of the the "can't miss" museums in Madrid.
titleopinion: Amazing collection of modern art and older art. Great museum, well organized, with good audioguide. Excellent collection! One of the the  can't miss  museums in Madrid.

quote: Thyssen - a wonderful visit for all 6 of us.
reviewnospace: The Thiessen-Bornemisza Museum was the best experience of 3 art galleries in Madrid for us. We enjoyed the layout of the rooms with ample time and space to view the magnificent collection of all art periods of the last 400 years. We were surprised on the depth of the collection, which was largely due to Thyssen's wife. The Orangerie in Paris is another that compares with this if yu like impressionism and cubism, etc. We went back a second time on the same day to view again some of the collection. I would say the gift shop was only partially satisfying. On the whole I recommend visitors to add this to their must list if they like visual art. Two of us also enjoyed the special Givenchy exhibit of famous celebrity dresses and clothing.
titleopinion: Thyssen - a wonderful visit for all 6 of us.. The Thiessen-Bornemisza Museum was the best experience of 3 art galleries in Madrid for us. We enjoyed the layout of the rooms with ample time and space to view the magnificent collection of all art periods of the last 400 years. We were surprised on the depth of the collection, which was largely due to Thyssen's wife. reviewnospace:
This museum has a shockingly deep and high quality collection. Highly recommended.

I suggest the Paseo del Arte ticket, which gets you into the three big art museums. Be careful when you buy the ticket online that you have to collect the ticket at the museum from whose website you bought it.
titleopinion: As good as the Prado.. This museum has a shockingly deep and high quality collection. Highly recommended.  I suggest the Paseo del Arte ticket, which gets you into the three big art museums. Be careful when you buy the ticket online that you have to collect the ticket at the museum from whose website you bought it.

reviewnospace: Excellent selection of art on display, but the Roy Lichtenstein is away on loan at the moment. I really liked the Berlin exhibition they have on at the moment.
titleopinion: Head straight for the 1900's. Excellent selection of art on display, but the Roy Lichtenstein is away on loan at the moment. I really liked the Berlin exhibition they have on at the moment.

quote: Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum is a must visit
reviewnospace: The vast private collection of the Thyssen Museum covers three floors and several centuries. From Baroque to Pop Art and everything in between, There's Dali, Rembrandt, Liechtenstein, Monet, and countless other artist to admire and appreciate. It's free on Mondays from 12 noon - 4 pm. I only gave it four stars and not five, because their gift shop, for me, is crammed and subpar, and for their lack of vision and planning with regards to the public latrine. However, the Thyssen is a great way to spend a few hours

Free wardrobe.

quote: One of the best museums I have ever visited
reviewnospace: The Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum brings together a huge and beautiful collection of art works covering various eras and styles. Many important pieces are featured in the permanent collection, but on my visit I had the opportunity to see two touching temporary exhibits. One gathered creations of Givenchy, which allowed me to get a sense of the historical importance of his creations and how he has influenced an entire era. The other was about the American impressionism bringing works of one of my favorite artists, Mary Cassat, among other American artists.
titleopinion: One of the best museums I have ever visited. The Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum brings together a huge and beautiful collection of art works covering various eras and styles. Many important pieces are featured in the permanent collection, but on my visit I had the opportunity to see two touching temporary exhibits. One gathered creations of Givenchy, which allowed me to get a sense of the historical importance of his creations and how he has influenced an entire era. The other was about the American impressionism bringing works of one of my favorite artists, Mary Cassat, among other American artists.

reviewnospace: We spent a very enjoyable few hours at this museum, and we are not big museum people. First we went to the exhibit about Givenchy, which was very interesting because of the quotes, the fashion and the pictures of Audrey Hepburn and the other women he outfitted. Then we had lunch in the cafeteria, which was very good! We regrouped and went back to see the American Impressionism exhibit, and then upstairs for some modern art. Nothing too heavy, we just walked around and looked at some great paintings - Picasso, Pisarro, Chagall, Frank, Lautrec, etc. It's not overwhelming and it's not so huge that you get lost. The gift shop is also nice. Perfect for a few hours' visit.
titleopinion: Beautiful museum. We spent a very enjoyable few hours at this museum, and we are not big museum people. First we went to the exhibit about Givenchy, which was very interesting because of the quotes, the fashion and the pictures of Audrey Hepburn and the other women he outfitted. Then we had lunch in the cafeteria, which was very good! We regrouped and went back to see the American Impressionism exhibit, and then upstairs for some modern art. Nothing too heavy, we just walked around and looked at some great paintings - Picasso, Pisarro, Chagall, Frank, Lautrec, etc. It's not overwhelming and it's not so huge that you get lost. The gift shop is also nice. Perfect for a few hours' visit.

reviewnospace: The audio guide is great for interesting background and insights. Great shop with many ides for gifts and good book selection. The cafe is mediocre. Sandwiches are disappointing. Good wines, hot chocolate and cake. Many toilets
titleopinion: Joyous. The audio guide is great for interesting background and insights. Great shop with many ides for gifts and good book selection. The cafe is mediocre. Sandwiches are disappointing. Good wines, hot chocolate and cake. Many toilets

reviewnospace: Went on Monday, it was free, except for the special exhiIbition-Givenchy which I skipped. It was wonderful to see the extensive personal collection. I enjoyed seeing the many land and seascapes from many different countries and artists. The special American impressionism exhibition was quite good with several pics for most artists. Very enjoyable.
titleopinion: Wonderful. Went on Monday, it was free, except for the special exhiIbition-Givenchy which I skipped. It was wonderful to see the extensive personal collection. I enjoyed seeing the many land and seascapes from many different countries and artists. The special American impressionism exhibition was quite good with several pics for most artists. Very enjoyable.

reviewnospace: This stunning collection of works runs across three floors and is displayed beautifully. A varied mix of artists and genres so there really is something to suit everyone's tastes.
titleopinion: Lovely collection, beautifully displayed. This stunning collection of works runs across three floors and is displayed beautifully. A varied mix of artists and genres so there really is something to suit everyone's tastes.

quote: Madrids answer to the Orsay in Paris
reviewnospace:
If the Prado is a mini Louvre then the Tyssen is Madrid's Orsay.
Amazing collection with a heavy tilt towards both ends-of-the-timeline. 1400 to 1600 masters and modern 20th century pieces all in the same place. This museum covers 600 years of art like few others! A must see in Madrid.
titleopinion: Madrids answer to the Orsay in Paris. If the Prado is a mini Louvre then the Tyssen is Madrid's Orsay. Amazing collection with a heavy tilt towards both ends-of-the-timeline. 1400 to 1600 masters and modern 20th century pieces all in the same place. This museum covers 600 years of art like few others! A must see in Madrid.

reviewnospace: It is overshadowed by the Prado, but has a nice selection of art and is definately worth a look. I happened to see it on a Monday afternoon when it was free, so even better. Unlike the Prado it is nicely laid out so you can walk through the whole thing in order without missing rooms if you want. The free map and guide to some of the more significant works is nice, and photography is allowed.
titleopinion: Worth a look. It is overshadowed by the Prado, but has a nice selection of art and is definately worth a look. reviewnospace: This museum is brilliant. It is perfect for people that might find the Prado too overwhelming.This museum has wverything from classical paintings to picassos and dalis.A ver very enjoyable day out.

reviewnospace:
This is a god collection of art and reflects the fact that it was originally a private collection rather than a national collection. Like the Prado, it was disappointing to see so many pictures out on loan and nothing to temporaily fill that gap on the wall. Both museums have more than enough in storage to hang something temporarily when something goes on loan.

The audio guide is definitely worth having.
titleopinion: Well worth a visit. This is a god collection of art and reflects the fact that it was originally a private collection rather than a national collection. Like the Prado, it was disappointing to see so many pictures out on loan and nothing to temporaily fill that gap on the wall. Both museums have more than enough in storage to hang something temporarily when something goes on loan.  The audio guide is definitely worth having.

reviewnospace:
Very enjoyable, a good selection of different periods and artists. We stayed more or less in the 19 th century and forward, but they do have primitive and 15 th century, etc.
Our most interesting feature was the Givenchy temporary exhibit, it was fascinating and wonderful!!!
titleopinion: Good selection of artworks. Very enjoyable, a good selection of different periods and artists. We stayed more or less in the 19 th century and forward, but they do have primitive and 15 th century, etc. Our most interesting feature was the Givenchy temporary exhibit, it was fascinating and wonderful!!!

reviewnospace: We had gone to see the Givenchy exhibition, but unfortunately we had not checked the opening date & were too early. So instead we saw the exhibition of English Victorian paintings. This was very well laid out with good labels & introduced us to painters we had not come across before. I thought it was very interesting to look at this very English group of painters from a European perspective, & consequently learnt a lot. This gallery is much easier to get around than the vast Prado. As a bonus it has an excellent café with indoor & outdoor (shaded) seating & superb choice of food & drink. A great place to recharge the batteries.

reviewnospace: Beautifully laid out. Not austere and poorly lit like too many museums, plus friendly and informative staff.

reviewnospace: Amazing collection and even more incredible that it is privately owned! The Thyssen has pieces from every major artist since the Renaissance. Not the most major artworks, but the big names - Raphael, Caravaggio, Durer, Rembrandt, El Greco, Goya, and on and on and on! If you are an art-lover, plan for several hours here!

The layout and lighting were excellent, the cafeteria worth eating at so we could continue with our visit without looking for a cafe.
