reviewnospace: A wonderful collection of old and new.. I thoroughly enjoyed my time there, a leisurely 3 hours. Highly recommended.
titleopinion: Lovely museum. A wonderful collection of old and new.. I thoroughly enjoyed my time there, a leisurely 3 hours. Highly recommended.

reviewnospace: Absolutely loved it! Funny, but this collection was more according to my taste than Prado - somehow offered more variety of stiles. And it has impressionists, what else can you wish :)
titleopinion: Love it!. Absolutely loved it! Funny, but this collection was more according to my taste than Prado - somehow offered more variety of stiles. And it has impressionists, what else can you wish :)

reviewnospace: Another must-see if you are in Madrid. Be sure to wear comfortable shoes because the museum did not have many places to sit in the exhibit areas.
titleopinion: Lovely museum. Another must-see if you are in Madrid. Be sure to wear comfortable shoes because the museum did not have many places to sit in the exhibit areas.

quote: Wonderful venue for so much art
reviewnospace: When you want something more manageable than The Prato, try The Thyssen. This is a marvelous museum that showcases the paintings. Look at the museum map and plan your viewing, maybe from the top floor down. Don't miss the Edward Hopper's (no relation) and the Finneger's. Discover your favorites, it will be a joy not a trek.
titleopinion: Wonderful venue for so much art. When you want something more manageable than The Prato, try The Thyssen. This is a marvelous museum that showcases the paintings. Look at the museum map and plan your viewing, maybe from the top floor down. Don't miss the Edward Hopper's (no relation) and the Finneger's. Discover your favorites, it will be a joy not a trek.

reviewnospace: don't have time to write so much. don't have time to write so much. don't have time to write so much.
titleopinion: not to be missed. don't have time to write so much. don't have time to write so much. don't have time to write so much.

reviewnospace: This museum takes you through time and the different schools of work. Very educating. It is an exceptional collection that has something that will appeal to everyone.
titleopinion: A great all round collection. This museum takes you through time and the different schools of work. Very educating. It is an exceptional collection that has something that will appeal to everyone.

quote: A replenish to an art afternoon
reviewnospace: Since I am more familiar with later than 16th century art, I would even prefer Thyssen to Prado. And also, it's quieter than Prado! The way of exhibiting is a little confusing, since the pathes are little bit like puzzles with painting on both sides, but I can still enjoy. Recommand the beautiful garden outside and to sip a coffee there. the museum shop is also superbe. And again, I recomment the visiting sequence as Prado-Thyssen-Reina Sofia.
titleopinion: A replenish to an art afternoon. Since I am more familiar with later than 16th century art, I would even prefer Thyssen to Prado. And also, it's quieter than Prado! The way of exhibiting is a little confusing, since the pathes are little bit like puzzles with painting on both sides, but I can still enjoy. Recommand the beautiful garden outside and to sip a coffee there. the museum shop is also superbe. And again, I recomment the visiting sequence as Prado-Thyssen-Reina Sofia.

reviewnospace: There are really two collections here. Baron Thyssen was from a family of art collectors and he carried on the tradition. His wife also collected and had a somewhat more modern eye. The museum is a real treat!! Very well layer out and lots of surprises.
titleopinion: His and Hers!!. There are really two collections here. Baron Thyssen was from a family of art collectors and he carried on the tradition. His wife also collected and had a somewhat more modern eye. The museum is a real treat!! Very well layer out and lots of surprises.

quote: The most amazing private collection ever
reviewnospace:
After the crowds in the Prado the Thyssen seemed almost empty. The rooms are chronologically arranged, from around 1400 to the present day. I had no idea what they had, and I was totally amazed by the quality of the art.
You need at least half a day to just walk through, so plan to take lunch in the new restaurant.
titleopinion: The most amazing private collection ever. After the crowds in the Prado the Thyssen seemed almost empty. The rooms are chronologically arranged, from around 1400 to the present day. I had no idea what they had, and I was totally amazed by the quality of the art.  You need at least half a day to just walk through, so plan to take lunch in the new restaurant.

reviewnospace: My wife and I loved this art gallery, more space and less people than the Prado and a fabulous impressionist collection of paintings. For us this was second only to the Musee D'Orsay in Paris for impressionist works.
titleopinion: Fabulous allery. My wife and I loved this art gallery, more space and less people than the Prado and a fabulous impressionist collection of paintings. For us this was second only to the Musee D'Orsay in Paris for impressionist works.

quote: Wonderful collection, avoid Mondays if you're an enthusiast
reviewnospace:
First of all, let me say that I unreservedly recommend that you go to the Thyssen. As with every art museum, there are plenty of things to walk on by, but the collection as a whole is excellent and very well-presented. Several great pieces by Freud, Pissarro, Rodin (and a million others). I went to the Pop Art Myths temporary exhibition and would definitely recommend it if you're a pop art fan (give it a miss if you're not that bothered).

All that being said, I foolishly did not check opening times/days and went on a Monday, when admission is free and I really wish I hadn't. The crowds were very big and there were lots of people in front of the paintings taking pictures with their iPads, which is something that detracts significantly from my enjoyment. It's absolutely wonderful that the museum has the free day, but if you like a museum that's a bit more sparsely populated, then I think it's well worth the price of admission to go another day of the week when crowds will likely be thinner.
titleopinion: Wonderful collection, avoid Mondays if you're an enthusiast. First of all, let me say that I unreservedly recommend that you go to the Thyssen. As with every art museum, there are plenty of things to walk on by, but the collection as a whole is excellent and very well-presented. Several great pieces by Freud, Pissarro, Rodin (and a million others). I went to the Pop Art Myths temporary exhibition and would definitely recommend it if you're a pop art fan (give it a miss if you're not that bothered).  All that being said, I foolishly did not check opening times/days and went on a Monday, when admission is free and I really wish I hadn't. The crowds were very big and there were lots of people in front of the paintings taking pictures with their iPads, which is something that detracts significantly from my enjoyment. It's absolutely wonderful that the museum has the free day, but if you like a museum that's a bit more sparsely populated, then I think it's well worth the price of admission to go another day of the week when crowds will likely be thinner.

reviewnospace: If you don't have a lot of time, this is the perfect museum. The museum is Located on Paseo del Prado, which is a great place to take a stroll. The temporary exhibits are usually wonderful, we were there in May and were fortunate to see the Cezanne exhibit. The museum is closed on Mondays. Tickets can be purchased in advance and there are special rates for senior citizens and other groups.
titleopinion: Elegant Location, Great Collections. If you don't have a lot of time, this is the perfect museum. The museum is Located on Paseo del Prado, which is a great place to take a stroll. The temporary exhibits are usually wonderful, we were there in May and were fortunate to see the Cezanne exhibit. The museum is closed on Mondays. Tickets can be purchased in advance and there are special rates for senior citizens and other groups.

reviewnospace: Beautiful museum, grear works, especially Expresionist period. But, most of all I enjoyed great Caravaggio‘s painting Catherine of Sinai! Don‘t miss the restaurant, pleasant atmosphere and very Good menu. Daily visit, be prepared for this gem!
titleopinion: Great collection. Beautiful museum, grear works, especially Expresionist period. But, most of all I enjoyed great Caravaggio‘s painting Catherine of Sinai! Don‘t miss the restaurant, pleasant atmosphere and very Good menu. Daily visit, be prepared for this gem!

reviewnospace: The first time, I only had 2 hours; then 2 hours at the Pissarro exhibit. I immediately knew that I had to return. WOW! The second visit was better than the first. I had brought my husband with me to share the experience. We walked and looked, had lunch and walked and ogled each piece of art. What a great place filled with color. Of course, the first time in Madrid, one must go to the Prado, but do leave time to come here. It is just across the street. As someone on some review said, "the lesser known works of the most well-known artists and the best known works of the lesser-known artists. What a colorful delight!
titleopinion: Fantastic visual experience!. The first time, I only had 2 hours; then 2 hours at the Pissarro exhibit. I immediately knew that I had to return. WOW! The second visit was better than the first. I had brought my husband with me to share the experience. We walked and looked, had lunch and walked and ogled each piece of art. What a great place filled with color. Of course, the first time in Madrid, one must go to the Prado, but do leave time to come here. It is just across the street. As someone on some review said,  the lesser known works of the most well-known artists and the best known works of the lesser-known artists. What a colorful delight!

reviewnospace: What a place - so much to see, all different periods covered, loads of fine works from great artists - the perfect gallery. Nice café too and the pop art exhibition was fabulous
titleopinion: Great gallery. What a place - so much to see, all different periods covered, loads of fine works from great artists - the perfect gallery. Nice café too and the pop art exhibition was fabulous

reviewnospace: Wide range of food and drinks. Busy but plenty of space. What's not to like if exhausted and hungry! Sensational museum kept us going until we dropped. The museum restaurant restored our faith in food-on-the-go.
titleopinion: Tasty Thyssen. Wide range of food and drinks. Busy but plenty of space. What's not to like if exhausted and hungry! Sensational museum kept us going until we dropped. The museum restaurant restored our faith in food-on-the-go.

quote: Amazing collection of art throught the ages
reviewnospace: Fantastic collection of paintings- like a history of art display going from the 14th century until early 20th century. Almost every artist is represented here- highlights were the Hans Holbein painting of Henry VIII, Caravaggio's St Catherine, and great collection of impressionist works (Van Gogh, Monet, Degas). Also a pop art temporary exhibition on too- lots of Warhol and Lichtenstein.
titleopinion: Amazing collection of art throught the ages. Fantastic collection of paintings- like a history of art display going from the 14th century until early 20th century. Almost every artist is represented here- highlights were the Hans Holbein painting of Henry VIII, Caravaggio's St Catherine, and great collection of impressionist works (Van Gogh, Monet, Degas). Also a pop art temporary exhibition on too- lots of Warhol and Lichtenstein.

quote: Better than the Prado, that's pretty good
reviewnospace: Modern art covers a broad period of time at the Thyssen. The Thyssen is basically on two floors. You'll need 2 to 3 hours to enjoy. I liked this museum better than the Prado. I like modern art. I have to admit that I don't always understand modern art. The Thyssen has audio tour devices. I stopped listening to my device. I found it distracting.

reviewnospace:
I'm not into art at all, and in fact try to avoid it where possible, however we thought we would at least try this or Prado given their significance.

Firstly we were lucky that when we went to visit it was free entry (between 12.00 and 16.00 on Mondays), which cheered me up as I was not looking forward to this museum.

However, I am suprised at how much I enjoyed this museum; I think it was mainly that there were loads of famous artists' painting on display (that even I had heard of) and there was not simply loads of paintings by few artists. There were a few bizarre things on display but you can just look at the things that are intresting to you and we ended up spending a few hours here.

Therefore, even if you are not into art I would recommend because, like me, you might be suprised.

reviewnospace: A good museum with nice pieces, though quite a few were missing and I would have actually liked to see those.

reviewnospace: Lovely art gallery with good impressionist section. Nice cafe. Do the modern wing first and work your way down if you prefer impressionists.

reviewnospace: By little I mean compared to Prado. We spent about 3 hours there and I wish we had a couple more. The collection seems to complement Prado's collection very well. Audio guides are a great way to find out more about paintings.
titleopinion: Great Little Museum. By little I mean compared to Prado. We spent about 3 hours there and I wish we had a couple more. The collection seems to complement Prado's collection very well. Audio guides are a great way to find out more about paintings.

reviewnospace: Madrid has some of the finest museums in the world and this is another of them. It is located on Paseo del Prado very close to the Prado itself so makes a perfect duo to visit in a day. The collection began as one of the largest and best private collections anywhere and once established in Madrid, was eventually purchased entirely by the Spanish government. Although smaller than the Prado, the quality of works and range of schools covered is truly excellent. Another absolute "must see" in Madrid. There is also an allied collection in Barcelona at Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya.
titleopinion: An absolute gem!. Madrid has some of the finest museums in the world and this is another of them. Although smaller than the Prado, the quality of works and range of schools covered is truly excellent. Another absolute  must see  in Madrid. There is also an allied collection in Barcelona at Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya.

reviewnospace: Where can you find so many wonderful paintings from the most famous painters in one building. At one point I found at least ten pieces of two hundred year old paintings of the most brilliant painters of the world!

quote: A place not to be missed

reviewnospace: Unusual to go to a museum with such a diversity of art over the years. It is nicely organized and worth a visit. If you have time only for 2 museums, I would go to the Prado and Sophia but if you have time for all three a must see.

reviewnospace: I visited this museum while studying abroad in June 2012. We went as a class excursion, and I am so glad they made us go! Otherwise, I probably would not have ventured inside. We spent maybe an hour inside, but I could have stayed much longer. I'm not well schooled in art, but it was easy for me to appreciate the works held in this museum. Spanish greats as well as other European artists, from maybe the 13th century to 20th century, hitting a number of genres of art. Impressive collection, and even though there is an entrance fee, they have a free entrance time on Mondays.

reviewnospace: Probably the best art collection I've seen. It just seems to get everything right. Some of the most important and most awesome early 20th century European paintings are here and curated with intelligence. The work is shown so you get a feel for context and style - they're not hung according to "theme" or some other artificial category. The effect on the viewer then is really stimulating reflecting the taste and passion of the collector himself. The final room ("contemporary work") disappoints a bit but this gallery and collection are stunning. The gift shop is eclectic and fun too with good quality merchandise on sale.

The effect on the viewer then is really stimulating reflecting the taste and passion of the collector himself. The final room ( contemporary work ) disappoints a bit but this gallery and collection are stunning. The gift shop is eclectic and fun too with good quality merchandise on sale.

quote: Our first visit-not enough time to enjoy it all!
reviewnospace: Wonderful museum with a wonderful collection. We spent three hours in the museum and ver not able to visit all the galleries. A return visit is a must!

reviewnospace: I went on the free Monday from noon to 4pm. The regular museum was free, no lines. I had to pay for the Pop exhibit and the audio guide. I listened to every audio number in the guide and still only spent an hour in the exhibit. Loved all the Warhols, Hockney,Rauchenburg etc. great colors, size, statements on society. I took a quick pass through the museum after the exhibit. I prefer the colorful more abstract paintings. The museum guide is easy to follow with numbered rooms so you can find your favorite artists or periods. nice gift shop and restaurant, though a little pricey. I went to Doloros Tavern on Jesus Calle around the corner for a tapas and Cana. €4.

quote: Nice but they moved Lichtenstein which was annoying
reviewnospace:
They have a Pop Art exhibit going on and we saw the main gallery. One of the pieces we wanted to see was a Lichtenstein which was in their brochure, once we got there and saw the whole gallery we looked for it and could not find it.

After asking, they said they moved it to the Pop Art exhibit temporarily and we would have to pay $11 euro to see it. I was so angry that they wouldn't tell people that beforehand.

reviewnospace: Lots of gorgeous paintings. Most chosen for their prettiness. Still, I enjoyed it more than the Prado
titleopinion: Beauty in spades. Lots of gorgeous paintings. Most chosen for their prettiness. Still, I enjoyed it more than the Prado

reviewnospace: Another great museum in Madrid. Get the Paseo del arte so that you can pay 25 euros for the Prado, the Thyssen, and the Reine Sofia. I would not go to the Thyssen on the same day as the Prado--your head might explode. What a great, well-laid out museum with really extraordinary art. It is across the street from the Prado. The Thyssen has a great outdoor café that looks out over the Paseo del Prado. This is a must see...it has a Caravaggio that is extraordinary.

quote: A lovely overview of the history of Art.
reviewnospace: A lovely collection of Art through the ages, well laid out and easy to follow. I did see a review saying that if you have seen this Thyssen then it spoils the one in Malaga but they are different and both worth a visit. The Madrid shows many different styles from different ages and movements whereas the Malaga Thyssen concentrates more on Spanish painting with some wonderful portraits of Spanish life.

reviewnospace: A great collection and a beautiful museum. A definite must for all art lovers visiting Madrid. Not far from the Prado. Be sure to not skip it.

quote: Current Pop Art exhibition a must
reviewnospace: Loved the permanent collection, ticked a lot of boxes as Van Gogh, Picasso, Monet, Rembrandt all present. But the temporary collection (check website for dates) blew us away. Its a Pop Art exhibition, featuring artists such as Andy Warhol. Items on show from many different countries. My daughter even got her own 'Andy Warhol' done of herself. Can also recommend the cafe. Good food and child friendly service.

reviewnospace: The masterpieces on display are remarkable. The varied collection is even more interesting than I had first thought. The museum is eclectic enough to hold not only my attention but that of my 13 and 14 year old children. They loved the temp exhibit on POP art and I enjoyed the range of styles and periods on display. The museum is the perfect size and not overwhelming to the senses. We enjoyed the day looking at all the museum had to offer and even took a break for lunch in their fantastic cafe. I have not seen such a great collection of German expressionist works in quite a while ,so that was a real surprise.

quote: NOT CLOSED on Monday! In fact, FREE on Mondays from 12-4.
reviewnospace:
Don't be put off by what you might see here on TripAdvisor. The museum is open on Monday and actually has free admission from 1200-1600 hours on Mondays only. Check the website.

Terrific museum. Even better for free!
titleopinion: NOT CLOSED on Monday! In fact, FREE on Mondays from 12-4.. Don't be put off by what you might see here on TripAdvisor. The museum is open on Monday and actually has free admission from 1200-1600 hours on Mondays only. Check the website.  Terrific museum. Even better for free!

reviewnospace: A beautiful space and wonderful selection of paintings. We spent about 4 hours at the museum. A wide range of impressionist paintings, and some wonderful modern art. Highly recommended.
titleopinion: Wonderful Collection; Worth Seeing. A beautiful space and wonderful selection of paintings. We spent about 4 hours at the museum. A wide range of impressionist paintings, and some wonderful modern art. Highly recommended.

reviewnospace: The Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum is right across the street from the Prado, but don't try and do both in one day! The entrance is on the main avenue, but don't expect to find a large sign pointing the way - just look for the open gate and the small sign on the wall. I purchased the three museum pass online in advance (recommended), and I didn't have to wait in line to enter. The collection is eclectic, covering not only European paintings but a surprising number from the US, including works by Homer, Sargent, Heade, Hopper, and even Romare Bearden. Although the masterpieces aren't as plentiful here as at the Prado, you will still want to look for Holbein's "Portrait of Henry VIII," Rembrandt's "Self-Portrait Wearing a Hat and Two Chains," Hopper's "Hotel Room," and Durer's "Jesus Among the Doctors." A small cafe is in the facility, but there are plenty of other eateries right along the avenue.
titleopinion: Surprisingly Varied Collection. The Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum is right across the street from the Prado, but don't try and do both in one day! The entrance is on the main avenue, but don't expect to find a large sign pointing the way - just look for the open gate and the small sign on the wall. I purchased the three museum pass online in advance (recommended), and I didn't have to wait in line to enter. The collection is eclectic, covering not only European paintings but a surprising number from the US, including works by Homer, Sargent, Heade, Hopper, and even Romare Bearden. Although the masterpieces aren't as plentiful here as at the Prado, you will still want to look for Holbein's  Portrait of Henry VIII,  Rembrandt's  Self-Portrait Wearing a Hat and Two Chains,  Hopper's  Hotel Room,  and Durer's  Jesus Among the Doctors.  A small cafe is in the facility, but there are plenty of other eateries right along the avenue.

reviewnospace:
What I liked most is that the collection covers examples from many eras and the museum layout is basically chronological. So if you are most interested in one or a few periods, it is easy to get to those galleries. It may not have the most famous works but it includes representative pieces by the very famous and the not so famous. A special exhibit of Dario de Regoyos, an impressionist I had never heard of, was very well done and educational.

The layout is easy to navigate (get a map) and it is not so big to be overwhelming and tiring. allow at least two hours -- four is better if you really enjoy art. The pieces are described in Spanish and English. The ones on the audio guide clearly marked.
Many rooms have benchs where you can rest --- a major shortcoming of the Reina Sofia museum, which I found very tiring and elderly unfriendly. (Ask for the senior discount if you're 65+.)
There is a nice indoor/outdoor cafeteria with typical overpriced food and understaffed service.
titleopinion: A gem worth a visit. What I liked most is that the collection covers examples from many eras and the museum layout is basically chronological. There is a nice indoor/outdoor cafeteria with typical overpriced food and understaffed service.

reviewnospace: one of the big 3 art galleries in Madrid ……saw it first and ws certainly not disappointed …to me it was a smaller , more concise version of the Prado
titleopinion: enjoyed. one of the big 3 art galleries in Madrid ……saw it first and ws certainly not disappointed …to me it was a smaller , more concise version of the Prado

quote: Excellent collection from the 1300's to the 20th century.
reviewnospace:
The great thing about the Thyssen is that it includes an excellent example or two by most of the great artists spanning 700 years.
In the bigger museums, such as the Prado or the National Gallery in London, there are so many paintings that in a single visit, you can realistically only view paintings of one genre or era.
titleopinion: Excellent collection from the 1300's to the 20th century.. The great thing about the Thyssen is that it includes an excellent example or two by most of the great artists spanning 700 years. In the bigger museums, such as the Prado or the National Gallery in London, there are so many paintings that in a single visit, you can realistically only view paintings of one genre or era.

reviewnospace: This collection spans the eras from before the Renaissance to the modern age. It reflects the eye and wealth of its patrons who collected this art and we are fortunate to be able to enjoy it in an elegantly designed building which is light and airy. This is a must see museum. The gift shop, too, is worth a visit as they have various items crafted from local artists and artisans which are inspired by works in the museum.
titleopinion: My favorite Madrid museum. This collection spans the eras from before the Renaissance to the modern age. It reflects the eye and wealth of its patrons who collected this art and we are fortunate to be able to enjoy it in an elegantly designed building which is light and airy. This is a must see museum. The gift shop, too, is worth a visit as they have various items crafted from local artists and artisans which are inspired by works in the museum.

reviewnospace: I agree with other recent contributors. This may well be the best and most enjoyable of Madrid's galleries. The collection is truly fabulous and not overwhelming as it can be in other galleries, especially if you go early as we did when there was barely a soul around. There are some truly wonderful works here by many major artists and they demand to be seen. The current Pop exhibition is a lot of fun too. Again, I agree with an early contributor about how refreshing it is to be able to take photos in the gallery, excluding the Pop exhibition. A bouquet for the staff members here too: we spoke to a few of them and they were wonderfully polite and helpful. This was the best gift shop we'd seen in Madrid too, and approaching the lofty standards set by the Met and the Frick in New York. All in all, our visit here was a very happy one and we'd heartily recommend this gallery to any visitor to Madrid.
titleopinion: A Must Do. I agree with other recent contributors. This may well be the best and most enjoyable of Madrid's galleries. The collection is truly fabulous and not overwhelming as it can be in other galleries, especially if you go early as we did when there was barely a soul around. All in all, our visit here was a very happy one and we'd heartily recommend this gallery to any visitor to Madrid.

reviewnospace: I was there during June and it was one of my favorite museums in Madrid ! Unfortunately, I was there just before the Pop Art exhibition so I didn't get to see that one (starts June 10th). If you want contemporary variety, with beautiful pieces and a nice atmosphere, this museum is for you ! You'll get to see Picasso, Miro, Monet, Degas, Van Gogh and so on... Free on mondays, and 7 euros for others (students included), you shouldn't miss it if you go to Madrid.
titleopinion: Wonderful museum. I was there during June and it was one of my favorite museums in Madrid ! Unfortunately, I was there just before the Pop Art exhibition so I didn't get to see that one (starts June 10th). If you want contemporary variety, with beautiful pieces and a nice atmosphere, this museum is for you ! You'll get to see Picasso, Miro, Monet, Degas, Van Gogh and so on... Free on mondays, and 7 euros for others (students included), you shouldn't miss it if you go to Madrid.

reviewnospace:
Brilliant gallery set in beautiful gardens. As with all museums & galleries in Madrid, you have to pay to get in. However, on Mondays the gallery is only open 12-4pm and is free to access the permanent collection.
They've got Dalí, Picasso, Litchenstein, Monet - in fact the list is pretty impressive for a private collection. The 4 hours is the perfect amount of time to see what's on offer and even though I went in June, wasn't too busy to negatively impact the visit.
titleopinion: Free Mondays. Brilliant gallery set in beautiful gardens. As with all museums & galleries in Madrid, you have to pay to get in. However, on Mondays the gallery is only open 12-4pm and is free to access the permanent collection.  They've got Dalí, Picasso, Litchenstein, Monet - in fact the list is pretty impressive for a private collection. The 4 hours is the perfect amount of time to see what's on offer and even though I went in June, wasn't too busy to negatively impact the visit.

reviewnospace: I know the Prado is supposed to be the best, but my personal preference was the Thyssen. This was a private collection given to Spain and it is amazing. As we strolled through it, I kept thinking, "Wow, they have a (fill in the blank for a famous master)!" And then we'd see another from the same artist and maybe two or three more. Many art museums are like mazes - this one is very easy to walk through. My only complaint was that it would have been wonderful to visit several times and appreciate it one floor at a time because there are so many worthwhile rooms to visit. We felt rushed and couldn't give our attention to all of the works like we would have liked. Best time to go is when it's free - all 3 art museums have free entrance at specific times/days.
titleopinion: The best of the three. I know the Prado is supposed to be the best, but my personal preference was the Thyssen. This was a private collection given to Spain and it is amazing. As we strolled through it, I kept thinking,  Wow, they have a (fill in the blank for a famous master)!  And then we'd see another from the same artist and maybe two or three more. My only complaint was that it would have been wonderful to visit several times and appreciate it one floor at a time because there are so many worthwhile rooms to visit. We felt rushed and couldn't give our attention to all of the works like we would have liked. Best time to go is when it's free - all 3 art museums have free entrance at specific times/days.

quote: A treasure and the best-kept secret in Madrid!
reviewnospace: We knew to go to the Prado but read about the Thyssen online and decided at the last minute to go with no idea how wonderful it is. It is worth hours of your time. We were so surprised to see the scope of this collection and the how wonderfully presented. A real gem!
titleopinion: A treasure and the best-kept secret in Madrid!. We knew to go to the Prado but read about the Thyssen online and decided at the last minute to go with no idea how wonderful it is. It is worth hours of your time. We were so surprised to see the scope of this collection and the how wonderfully presented. A real gem!

reviewnospace:
This Museum / Gallery, located almost beside "The Neptune Fountain" is one of "The Holy Trinity" of Art venues in Madrid, the other two, of course, being the 'Reina and the 'Prado. All three have their distinctive features, and in this instance, one of the most notable elements is the relaxed atmosphere.

What's on view here to-day is essentially a representative sample of the work of almost every important European Painter from the 13th to the 21st century, arguably an eclectic collection, assembled privately by wealthy patrons, and bought by the Spanish government in 1993.

You can view a collection like this in various ways : for example, if you want to go from the oldest works to the most modern, you can start on the 2nd Floor and work your way down the building. Another route - which we followed - is to take the Museum's own Directory leaflet, scan the selection of works highlighted there, mark the ones which most appeal, and sequentially view them, diverting along the way as other paintings catch the eye.

Following this approach, we greatly enjoyed our ramble around the 'Thyssen. Amongst the individual works we particularly appreciated were the Rembrandt "Self-Portrait" & Canaletto's "St. Mark's Square" on Level 2, as well as Vincent van Gogh's "Les Vessenots" on Level 1.

We noted, by the way, the room numbers are more clearly displayed, in most instances, than at the much larger 'Prado. On the other hand, the descriptive information beside each painting is extremely limited.

We didn't particularly warm to the appearance of the Cafe, which is in a separate block, but we did purchase a few souvenir items in the well-stocked Museum Shop. Overall, we quite enjoyed our visit.

reviewnospace: On a recent trip to Madrid, this was our favourite gallery. It is an amazing collection of modern art and has marvels at every turn. At 9.50am there was hardly any queue. We opted for the Paseo del art which gives you one visit to each of the Prado, Thyssen and the Reina Sofia for 25.60 euros. This also allowed us to use the ticket holder entrance at the Prado and avoid the ticket queues.
titleopinion: wonderful gallery. On a recent trip to Madrid, this was our favourite gallery. It is an amazing collection of modern art and has marvels at every turn. At 9.50am there was hardly any queue. We opted for the Paseo del art which gives you one visit to each of the Prado, Thyssen and the Reina Sofia for 25.60 euros. This also allowed us to use the ticket holder entrance at the Prado and avoid the ticket queues.

reviewnospace: great visit to this museum.. a lot of interesting art... love the Degas ballerina..also saw and temporary Cezanne exhibit ..spend few lovely hours in this museum
titleopinion: great museum. great visit to this museum.. a lot of interesting art... love the Degas ballerina..also saw and temporary Cezanne exhibit ..spend few lovely hours in this museum

reviewnospace:
One more fabulous place not to be missed in Madrid.
Furthermore pictures are allowed (without flash of course) which is real great and unexpected in such a museum.
The restaurant is nice and exellent.
titleopinion: Fantastic collection. One more fabulous place not to be missed in Madrid. Furthermore pictures are allowed (without flash of course) which is real great and unexpected in such a museum. The restaurant is nice and exellent.

quote: A Museum With Something for Everyone
reviewnospace: Unlike the Prado, which primarily contains more classic art, and the Reina Sofia, which is exclusively modern art, the Thyssen presents a wide representation of art from every period. This diverse collection even includes North American art. After visiting, I felt I had seen a little something from every artistic style. I found the galleries to be logically presented on chronological and geographical bases. The museum is definitely worth visiting.
titleopinion: A Museum With Something for Everyone. Unlike the Prado, which primarily contains more classic art, and the Reina Sofia, which is exclusively modern art, the Thyssen presents a wide representation of art from every period. This diverse collection even includes North American art. After visiting, I felt I had seen a little something from every artistic style. I found the galleries to be logically presented on chronological and geographical bases. The museum is definitely worth visiting.

quote: Disappointing apart from the Cezanne exhibition
reviewnospace: The eclectic paintings here seem to be of varied qualities - as someone has said bad paintings by good artists and good paintings by indifferent artists. An interesting collection of 19th century American landscapes though. The visit was rescued for me by a temporary exhibition of Cezanne paintings that was excellent.
titleopinion: Disappointing apart from the Cezanne exhibition. The eclectic paintings here seem to be of varied qualities - as someone has said bad paintings by good artists and good paintings by indifferent artists. An interesting collection of 19th century American landscapes though. The visit was rescued for me by a temporary exhibition of Cezanne paintings that was excellent.

reviewnospace: We have been told to visit this museum by the hotel so we tried it. We spent the whole day there and we were impressed with the artwork especially the modern artists like Picasso.
titleopinion: great show at the museum. We have been told to visit this museum by the hotel so we tried it. We spent the whole day there and we were impressed with the artwork especially the modern artists like Picasso.

reviewnospace: Museum is very extensive and far over shadows the Prado. Easy access to all areas within museum. The breath of coverage as for paintings is phenomenal and in keeping with a large city museum
titleopinion: One of the Best. Museum is very extensive and far over shadows the Prado. Easy access to all areas within museum. The breath of coverage as for paintings is phenomenal and in keeping with a large city museum

reviewnospace: This gallery has a wide range of art from different eras. The building is well designed and well lit. It is a manageable size. I would recommend it for any art lover visiting Madrid
titleopinion: A good mix. This gallery has a wide range of art from different eras. The building is well designed and well lit. It is a manageable size. I would recommend it for any art lover visiting Madrid

reviewnospace: Went here on Monday afternoon (free of charge) and was surprised how quiet it is. Very nice and beautiful collection of a wide variety of art in a great setting.lots of masterpieces to see and feels less fussy than the overcrowded prado. A real must do in Madrid!
titleopinion: Better than Prado. Went here on Monday afternoon (free of charge) and was surprised how quiet it is. Very nice and beautiful collection of a wide variety of art in a great setting.lots of masterpieces to see and feels less fussy than the overcrowded prado. A real must do in Madrid!

reviewnospace: This museum offers a nice variety of art work- renaissance, classical, impressionism, some abstract. It's also not overwhelming. I think there is a fee but we went there when it was International Museum weekend, so our entry was free. The atmosphere is relaxing and it was quite a pleasant visit. Nice museum shop too. The café museum, a bit pricey but very nice setting. Good place for a break.
titleopinion: Great collection of artwork. This museum offers a nice variety of art work- renaissance, classical, impressionism, some abstract. It's also not overwhelming. I think there is a fee but we went there when it was International Museum weekend, so our entry was free. The atmosphere is relaxing and it was quite a pleasant visit. Nice museum shop too. The café museum, a bit pricey but very nice setting. Good place for a break.

reviewnospace: One of the most enjoyable and diverse collections we've ever seen. The place was as impressive as the art. Madrid's art museums are at least equal to Paris.
titleopinion: Absolute gem. One of the most enjoyable and diverse collections we've ever seen. The place was as impressive as the art. Madrid's art museums are at least equal to Paris.

reviewnospace: Their Cezanne exhibition is an outstanding example of how a good curator can make you think about this artist from a new and different perspective. The museum's regular collection is also not to be missed.
titleopinion: A gem of a museum. Their Cezanne exhibition is an outstanding example of how a good curator can make you think about this artist from a new and different perspective. The museum's regular collection is also not to be missed.

reviewnospace: Go to the second floor and work your way down. I found the early works less interesting but the museum gives an excellent overview of European art across almost a thousand years. Look out for works by Max Beckmann and Robert Delauney
titleopinion: Huge Museum - some unbelievable works. Go to the second floor and work your way down. I found the early works less interesting but the museum gives an excellent overview of European art across almost a thousand years. Look out for works by Max Beckmann and Robert Delauney

reviewnospace: This was a real surprise after our research showed it was always second to Prado on must-see lists. Arrived mid afternoon, no queue and entered as seniors. Layout is easy to follow and with the audio-guides we had the most amazing afternoon of wonderment. Decided to do only 2 of the 3 levels and were completely knocked out by the range of artists and works that we had not seen nor heard of. Decided to pay second visit on return to Madrid in 2 weeks time and complete the 3rd level.
titleopinion: An amazing museum. This was a real surprise after our research showed it was always second to Prado on must-see lists. Arrived mid afternoon, no queue and entered as seniors. Layout is easy to follow and with the audio-guides we had the most amazing afternoon of wonderment. Decided to do only 2 of the 3 levels and were completely knocked out by the range of artists and works that we had not seen nor heard of. Decided to pay second visit on return to Madrid in 2 weeks time and complete the 3rd level.

reviewnospace: It's hard to believe that two people owned all this art. There is art from many eras but the 19th and 20th century is strong and like a survey course. Worth the effort.
titleopinion: A wonderful museum. It's hard to believe that two people owned all this art. There is art from many eras but the 19th and 20th century is strong and like a survey course. Worth the effort.

reviewnospace: The museum is not overwhelming but some pre-visit study is recommended so that one can concentrate on a section - which we did for the early impressionists. There were some Monets, a Courbet and others. However the standard curse of Madrid museums and galleries was the dreadfully long queue for admission with only one till manned and up to 50 people wanting to get in. perhaps they don't want you to visit?
titleopinion: Be selctive. The museum is not overwhelming but some pre-visit study is recommended so that one can concentrate on a section - which we did for the early impressionists. There were some Monets, a Courbet and others. However the standard curse of Madrid museums and galleries was the dreadfully long queue for admission with only one till manned and up to 50 people wanting to get in. perhaps they don't want you to visit?

quote: The last great private art collection of Europe
reviewnospace: The art collection that Baron Thyssen and his wife Carmen managed to compile is truly stunning - quite possibly the last private collection in Europe to offer a full survey of western art history from the late Middle Ages till the early twentieth century (and somewhat beyond). The presentation in this purpose-build museum is superb. There is also an attractive shop and the staff throughout the museum is helpful and friendly - with the exception of the restaurant, where we had a really poor service twice.
titleopinion: The last great private art collection of Europe. The art collection that Baron Thyssen and his wife Carmen managed to compile is truly stunning - quite possibly the last private collection in Europe to offer a full survey of western art history from the late Middle Ages till the early twentieth century (and somewhat beyond). The presentation in this purpose-build museum is superb. There is also an attractive shop and the staff throughout the museum is helpful and friendly - with the exception of the restaurant, where we had a really poor service twice.

reviewnospace: Of the three art galleries within a mile of each other in Madrid, I think this one was the best. Unlike the Prado, which is huge, this is a compact collection, exhibited in chronological order, starting with the 1300's and going right through to the modern day. Around every corner there seemed to be a masterpiece, from artists such as Gaugin, Durer, Manet, van Gogh, Gris, Matisse, Renoir, Caneletto, Bacon, Dali, and many many more.
titleopinion: Superb collection. Of the three art galleries within a mile of each other in Madrid, I think this one was the best. Unlike the Prado, which is huge, this is a compact collection, exhibited in chronological order, starting with the 1300's and going right through to the modern day. Around every corner there seemed to be a masterpiece, from artists such as Gaugin, Durer, Manet, van Gogh, Gris, Matisse, Renoir, Caneletto, Bacon, Dali, and many many more.

quote: Simply the best, better than El Prado
reviewnospace: This Museum is simply great as it is very well kept and has been designed in quite a modern way. Every area leads you naturally to the other and there is a toilet practically every 30 metres. It leads you from old paintings to modern ones, the natural progression is amazing, full of detail. Incredible exhibitions like Cezanne and De Regoyos and its gift shop is the best I've seen in a Museum. It had a kids section, a cooking section linked to Art, books, posters, you could even print your own poster in the size you wanted, framed or not. Kudos to Tita Cervera and the way she shares her collection. As she says, Art belongs to everyone and it deserves to be shared, not to be kept to oneself.
titleopinion: Simply the best, better than El Prado. This Museum is simply great as it is very well kept and has been designed in quite a modern way. reviewnospace: The breadth of art was amazing and just kept you enthralled from start to end. The restaurant at the end was very good also. It was an excellent choice and we were glad we chose this over others as we only had 3 days in madrid.
titleopinion: A really great choice!. The breadth of art was amazing and just kept you enthralled from start to end. The restaurant at the end was very good also. It was an excellent choice and we were glad we chose this over others as we only had 3 days in madrid.

reviewnospace: You need a lot of time for this museum. It is exhausting in a good way. Make sure you have enough time to see the incredible collection.
titleopinion: Brilliant Museum. You need a lot of time for this museum. It is exhausting in a good way. Make sure you have enough time to see the incredible collection.

reviewnospace: This was the best laid-out museum I've ever been to. Impressionism, romanticism, cubism, and even pop art. Everything is well labelled, divided into small groups, and even lots of benches to sit and admire. Great gift shop as well. Only negative is that there are several special exhibits which must be bought separately. I bought a ticket for the permanent collection, and although it was great, there were many paintings that had been moved to one of the special exhibits. They had even noted on the wall which paintings were moved, so you would be persuaded to spend more money to go see them.
titleopinion: best in Madrid. This was the best laid-out museum I've ever been to. Impressionism, romanticism, cubism, and even pop art. Everything is well labelled, divided into small groups, and even lots of benches to sit and admire. Great gift shop as well. Only negative is that there are several special exhibits which must be bought separately. I bought a ticket for the permanent collection, and although it was great, there were many paintings that had been moved to one of the special exhibits. They had even noted on the wall which paintings were moved, so you would be persuaded to spend more money to go see them.

reviewnospace: Not as well known as the Prado but just across the street and filled with great art, with more of a focus on the more modern ~1850-1950 time frame, which I really like. This was my favorite art stop in Spain.
titleopinion: Modern art marvel. Not as well known as the Prado but just across the street and filled with great art, with more of a focus on the more modern ~1850-1950 time frame, which I really like. This was my favorite art stop in Spain.

reviewnospace:
Lovely place to relax outsider the gallery. Fantastic range if art work and at a reasonable price. Defo worth getting hot pass that allows entrance into the main three galleries, will save you about 12 euros in total... But only if u want to visit all three galleries.
Toilets everywhere and benches throughout so is ok to visit if you have children or carrying round a bump.
titleopinion: Excellent art gallery. Lovely place to relax outsider the gallery. Fantastic range if art work and at a reasonable price. Defo worth getting hot pass that allows entrance into the main three galleries, will save you about 12 euros in total... But only if u want to visit all three galleries. Toilets everywhere and benches throughout so is ok to visit if you have children or carrying round a bump.

quote: Must Add to Your Museum List
reviewnospace:
Everyone in Madrid says that you can't miss the Thyssen museum. They are very proud to have "one of the world's most distinguished private art collections" which was acquired over two generations of the Thyssen-Bornemisza family. If you don't know who they are (I didn't before I went) wiki them because they have an interesting family story and you learn how the private collection made it to Spain.

The museum has three floors and a special exhibition space (I saw the Cezanne exhibit which was great). Take your time to go through the museum. The museum isn't big so it feels more manageable than the Prado.
titleopinion: Must Add to Your Museum List. Everyone in Madrid says that you can't miss the Thyssen museum. The museum has three floors and a special exhibition space (I saw the Cezanne exhibit which was great). Take your time to go through the museum. The museum isn't big so it feels more manageable than the Prado.

reviewnospace: We went there twice - for the permanent exhibition and for Cezanne. Loved the place even more than Prado. Make sure you take the audio-guide. It's like 5 euro extra, but definitely worth it!
titleopinion: A must-see in Madrid. We went there twice - for the permanent exhibition and for Cezanne. Loved the place even more than Prado. Make sure you take the audio-guide. It's like 5 euro extra, but definitely worth it!

reviewnospace: An excellent collection across all of the ages with some particularly memorable impressionist paintings and modern 20th century works.
titleopinion: Well laid out museum. An excellent collection across all of the ages with some particularly memorable impressionist paintings and modern 20th century works.

reviewnospace: The cache of art here is magnificent. The other great part about this museum is the staff seems to really care that visitors enjoy their experience at the museum. We used the audioguide, which is very valuable because there is so much to see here.
titleopinion: Great museum/great staff. The cache of art here is magnificent. The other great part about this museum is the staff seems to really care that visitors enjoy their experience at the museum. We used the audioguide, which is very valuable because there is so much to see here.

quote: Overwhelming, enjoyable, maybe go a few times to really explore it
reviewnospace: I've really enjoyed the Thyssen Museum, but do definitely agree that one needs to go perhaps several times to really appreciate its different collections.
titleopinion: Overwhelming, enjoyable, maybe go a few times to really explore it. I've really enjoyed the Thyssen Museum, but do definitely agree that one needs to go perhaps several times to really appreciate its different collections.

reviewnospace: A wonderful opportunity to see early works of the greats and see how they developed ...Chagall, Picasso, Monet etc.
titleopinion: Early Masters. A wonderful opportunity to see early works of the greats and see how they developed ...Chagall, Picasso, Monet etc.

reviewnospace:
For anyone who wants to see a glorious museum but something just a little less daunting than the Prado, this is many people's favourite in Madrid.

It has a wonderful span of masterpieces from early Italian right up to the latest modern art. The pictures are beautifully displayed in light uncluttered galleries (with plenty of seats - bliss!). I needed two visits to do proper justice to the collection. I felt that the original collection by Baron Thyssen was stronger than the later additions by his wife, but that may be down to personal taste: mine, his and hers.

Added attractions are a very chic café with surprisingly reasonable prices, a very nice shop and pleasant, helpful staff. For anyone who enjoys great art in a fabulous setting, there could not be a better place to spend some happy hours.
titleopinion: Super Gallery. For anyone who wants to see a glorious museum but something just a little less daunting than the Prado, this is many people's favourite in Madrid.  It has a wonderful span of masterpieces from early Italian right up to the latest modern art. The pictures are beautifully displayed in light uncluttered galleries (with plenty of seats - bliss!). I needed two visits to do proper justice to the collection. I felt that the original collection by Baron Thyssen was stronger than the later additions by his wife, but that may be down to personal taste: mine, his and hers.  Added attractions are a very chic café with surprisingly reasonable prices, a very nice shop and pleasant, helpful staff. For anyone who enjoys great art in a fabulous setting, there could not be a better place to spend some happy hours.

quote: Third visit but still very enjoyable

titleopinion: Third visit but still very enjoyable. Its an Art Gallery so theres not much more to be said about it. The on site shop is expensive but thats normal for galleries and museums

reviewnospace: The Thyssen museum has an excellent collection of artwork although most of them are done by lesser known artists. However, it is never crowded and easy to spend as much time as you like studying the artwork as opposed to getting pushed through by the crowds at the Prado. It is well worth the visit. We actually made two visits there on the same trip to Madrid.

reviewnospace: This is the combined private collection of an old established family, one side focused more on the "classic" while the other side focused more on the modern . . . PLUS, when we visited, there was the added benefit of a special Cézanne exhibition that was just so special . . .

reviewnospace: what a gem of an art museum. I loved all of it, but absolutely loved the Baroness' collection. The size of the museum and the collection was my favorite of the 3 large art museums in Madrid.
titleopinion: a gem. what a gem of an art museum. I loved all of it, but absolutely loved the Baroness' collection. The size of the museum and the collection was my favorite of the 3 large art museums in Madrid.

quote: The name itself makes me happy
reviewnospace: I don't know why exactly but I enjoyed both of my visits to the Thyssen. Maybe it was the space itself. It felt welcoming and seemed eager to show off its assortment of much loved denizens. For a fine-art starved American, I think this place is a fine example that could teach a thing or three to all these people calling themselves 'curators'. If only they would pay attention. Also, I giggled every time a person walked by wearing a peach coloured shirt or trousers.. For they were unknowingly trying to blend in just a bit too much with the place.
titleopinion: The name itself makes me happy. I don't know why exactly but I enjoyed both of my visits to the Thyssen. Maybe it was the space itself. It felt welcoming and seemed eager to show off its assortment of much loved denizens. For a fine-art starved American, I think this place is a fine example that could teach a thing or three to all these people calling themselves 'curators'. If only they would pay attention. Also, I giggled every time a person walked by wearing a peach coloured shirt or trousers.. For they were unknowingly trying to blend in just a bit too much with the place.

reviewnospace:
The Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum contains a very good selection painting from late Medieval to German expressionism, a remarkable acheivement considering that it was assembled privately in less than 100 years.

Many of the major artists are represented at the Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum but what is interesting is that although all the pieces are good, you do not see the true masterpieces by the big names. For example, there is nothing wrong with the Rembrandt's Self Portrait (wearing a hat and two chains) or Caravaggio's St Catherine but it is not quite the Man in the Golden Helmet or te Supper at Emmaus.

However what you do get absolute first rate pieces by more obscure names. The portrait of Giovanna Tornabuoni by Ghirlandaio or Portrait of a Man by Messina. It is surprising how good they are and one wonders if they painted a few more like these (or if a few more survived) they would certainly be as well known by the public as Rembrandt or Caravaggio.

An excellent collection and highly recommended.
titleopinion: Succinct summary of Western Art. The Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum contains a very good selection painting from late Medieval to German expressionism, a remarkable acheivement considering that it was assembled privately in less than 100 years.  Many of the major artists are represented at the Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum but what is interesting is that although all the pieces are good, you do not see the true masterpieces by the big names. For example, there is nothing wrong with the Rembrandt's Self Portrait (wearing a hat and two chains) or Caravaggio's St Catherine but it is not quite the Man in the Golden Helmet or te Supper at Emmaus.  However what you do get absolute first rate pieces by more obscure names. The portrait of Giovanna Tornabuoni by Ghirlandaio or Portrait of a Man by Messina. It is surprising how good they are and one wonders if they painted a few more like these (or if a few more survived) they would certainly be as well known by the public as Rembrandt or Caravaggio.  An excellent collection and highly recommended.

reviewnospace: Interesting collection by the Thyssen=Bornemisza father/son/wife including a superb German modernism collection, especially Die Brucke. On the other hand, the French Impressionist collection was strangely installed with Bonnard, Pissarro, and Degas together and at times other pairings that didn't make sense to me. Some great Italian Renaissance and Northern Renaissance works plus wonderful medieval ones. Worth a visit.
titleopinion: Great German Modernism. Interesting collection by the Thyssen=Bornemisza father/son/wife including a superb German modernism collection, especially Die Brucke. On the other hand, the French Impressionist collection was strangely installed with Bonnard, Pissarro, and Degas together and at times other pairings that didn't make sense to me. Some great Italian Renaissance and Northern Renaissance works plus wonderful medieval ones. Worth a visit.

quote: One of the worlds great collections
reviewnospace:
It has been 15 years since my last visit to the Thyssen and it has developed significantly over this time. I love post impressionism and the beginnings of modern art and this collection has key examples from all of the movements from the beginning of the 20th century. To see work by Larianov and Goncherova Tatlin and Malevich alongside Kandinsky and Chagall was so exciting. I could go on about a remarkable collection simply and beautifully presented in a way that makes some quite challenging art really accessible.
Then you can make your way to the really lovely cafe and relax

reviewnospace:
Cezanne was one of the great French painters of the 19th century. The public knows little about this artist and this exhibition corrects that perception.

These were my favorite paintings:
1. Boy Resting
2. The Bare Trees at Jas de Bouffan
3. Forest Interior
4. Still Life with Flowers and Fruits
5. House in Provence
6. Hillside in Provence
7. Mount Sainte-Victoire

reviewnospace: I was not expecting to see a Francis Bacon when I entered one of the rooms of the Thyssen, only to turn around to be slapped in the face by a Lucian Freud! I was left reeling when I left the Thyssen I must say.. Their selection of works is exceptional, clearly displayed in an wonderful environment.

I was left reeling when I left the Thyssen I must say.. Their selection of works is exceptional, clearly displayed in an wonderful environment.

Lots of Goya and Picasso.

reviewnospace:

GJS

quote: Great museum - better than the Prado
reviewnospace:
We visited the museum on a Monday afternoon when entry was free for four hours.
We enjoyed it more than the Prado - the paintings in general were more to our taste; and it was a much better layout than the Prado. There were clears maps on each floor and it was easy to see where you were and to make sure you saw everything.
And it was less than 5 minutes from our hotel which was a bonus!

quote: Fantastic collection, great historical relevant overview of centuries of painting
reviewnospace: Not to be missed this smaller museum (compared to Prado & Reina Sofia that is) in Madrid. Beautiful collection, some masterpiecs tha give visitors an excellent overview of the history of western painting of some 6 centuries. Several highlight are presented in a free leaflet which will guide you through the museum if you just want to make sure you don't miss these. Remarkable and very sympathetic : free admission on monday afternoon for everybody, and...free admission for jobless anytime. That's what I consider culture !

reviewnospace: We loved this museum. It was especially fun to find some works of the "Hudson River School" painted just a few miles from our home in Salem, Massachusetts. We also enjoyed the fact that except for the special Cezanne exhibit we were allowed to take photos. So much easier to share with friends on FaceBook and the like, which benefits the museums which allow this practice. Glad this museum is more progressive than the Prado.

reviewnospace:
The collection is interesting in that even though it spans from the XIII C upwards to Pop Art (just a couple of the latter), it is centered around not religious art pieces mostly from Germany and Central Europe. It is not an easy collection for everybody, and in my opinion, tries to encompass a pretty ambitious chunk of art history.
If your visit in Madrid is short, aim for the temporary exhibits, right now a gorgeously presented Cezanne collection. You'll get a feel of the museum, enjoy a smaller sample of art and maybe have coffee at the beautiful garden café.
Students, teachers and over 65: bring ID (mandatory) for discounts. Free Mondays noon to 4pm.
titleopinion: Best for temporary exhibits. reviewnospace: Manageable, part palace and part new addition, with interesting special exhibits (we saw Cezanne). The museum contains both contemporary and earlier works, including a lot of famous Spanish artists.
titleopinion: My favorite in Madrid. Manageable, part palace and part new addition, with interesting special exhibits (we saw Cezanne). The museum contains both contemporary and earlier works, including a lot of famous Spanish artists.

reviewnospace:
There are two separate tickets, one for the Cezanne exhibit and one for the permanent collection. Because of that I opted to visit the museum on two occasions so as not to get "arted out."

The Cezanne Exhibit helped to illuminate the motivation and context for his work, however there are big crowds, even with timed entry. I went back and forth several times throughout the exhibit in order to dodge the large groups.

The permanent collection is vast in its scope and requires several hours to see all of it. Private collections are always fascinating not only in terms of viewing individual pieces, but what they say collectively about the owner's taste, preferences and personality. That said, the collection of Baron Thyssen is much more interesting that that of his widow, Tita Cervera, who preferred "pretty" over substance.
titleopinion: Impressive Collection. There are two separate tickets, one for the Cezanne exhibit and one for the permanent collection. Because of that I opted to visit the museum on two occasions so as not to get  arted out.    The Cezanne Exhibit helped to illuminate the motivation and context for his work, however there are big crowds, even with timed entry. I went back and forth several times throughout the exhibit in order to dodge the large groups.   The permanent collection is vast in its scope and requires several hours to see all of it. Private collections are always fascinating not only in terms of viewing individual pieces, but what they say collectively about the owner's taste, preferences and personality. That said, the collection of Baron Thyssen is much more interesting that that of his widow, Tita Cervera, who preferred  pretty  over substance.

quote: An unusual and incredibly broad collection.
reviewnospace:
I have been here several times before but came this time with a family member who had never been in Madrid. It's an amazing museum - not only one of everything (that is, a sort of historical collection of every important European or American artist since forever) but also a lot of works by people in their school and then some less well know but very interesting works by the masters themselves. There's a remarkable collection of 19th century American paintings.

I didn't have time to go to the temporary exhibits this time, but they looked interesting.

Being more prosaic, the café is also excellent...
titleopinion: An unusual and incredibly broad collection.. I have been here several times before but came this time with a family member who had never been in Madrid. It's an amazing museum - not only one of everything (that is, a sort of historical collection of every important European or American artist since forever) but also a lot of works by people in their school and then some less well know but very interesting works by the masters themselves. There's a remarkable collection of 19th century American paintings.   I didn't have time to go to the temporary exhibits this time, but they looked interesting.  Being more prosaic, the café is also excellent...

quote: A personal collection of the highest order.
reviewnospace:
Even though a number of the paintings in the collection were not on show as they have been loaned out to other international exhibitions, itself a measure of the quality of this collection, there was enough to see and to admire in this superb gallery and collection. Start at the top! It was not crowded even though there were lots of tourists and young folk wandering around as there is space and the paintings are well-spaced out.
It is fascinating and comprehensive and a joy to look at.

reviewnospace: Museum is free Mondays 1200-1600. We saw the special limited Cezanne exhibit which was great but overcrowded. Can buy the 3 museum psckage fir 20 percent savings. Huge breath to collection. All different time periods/styles/artists presented. Very limited information given on each piece. Should get the audio guide. Lunch offerings at the cafe consisted almost entirely of sandwiches. Beautiful grounds and building. Dont miss it!
titleopinion: Fantastic. Huge variety.. Museum is free Mondays 1200-1600. We saw the special limited Cezanne exhibit which was great but overcrowded. Should get the audio guide. Lunch offerings at the cafe consisted almost entirely of sandwiches. Beautiful grounds and building. Dont miss it!

reviewnospace: We really liked it. Saw several impressionists, as well as Dali. There was a temporary exhibition of Cezanne, which we enjoyed as well.
titleopinion: Good Museum of Paintings: 14th-20th century. We really liked it. Saw several impressionists, as well as Dali. There was a temporary exhibition of Cezanne, which we enjoyed as well.

reviewnospace:
This museum is very famous in Spain, but I think mainly because of Mrs. Cervera's (widow of Baron Thyssen) life in the press.
It is a collection of quite old dull paintings. If you know a lot about art it might be worth it, but I hardly knew any of the painters.
Better go to Reina Sofia or the Prado.
titleopinion: Boring for modern art lovers. This museum is very famous in Spain, but I think mainly because of Mrs. Cervera's (widow of Baron Thyssen) life in the press. It is a collection of quite old dull paintings. If you know a lot about art it might be worth it, but I hardly knew any of the painters. Better go to Reina Sofia or the Prado.

reviewnospace: If you fancy art, this is a must-to-check out place. The museum is so big in every aspect that even 3 visits will not do it proper justice. To best enjoy it, come when the crowds subside, i.e. after 3 pm and take it slowly and in portions. Otherwise you risk overdoing it with subsequent headache and tiredness.
titleopinion: Another killer museum. If you fancy art, this is a must-to-check out place. The museum is so big in every aspect that even 3 visits will not do it proper justice. To best enjoy it, come when the crowds subside, i.e. after 3 pm and take it slowly and in portions. Otherwise you risk overdoing it with subsequent headache and tiredness.

reviewnospace:
This is a great gallery: a personal collection of the highest quality with some memorable special exhibitions, the latest of which, "Cezanne: Site/ Non site" is one of the best. It's on until May 18th. Cost: 11 euros, but it was well worth an extra 3 euros for the headphones/music and explanation. The Cezanne exhibition was really breathtaking and informative!
The special exhibitions tend to take about an hour and a half, but the static collection could take several hours: best to specialise and cherry-pick really.
The Museum is on the Castellana, an easy and nice walk from Sol past Spain's parliament building, el Palacio de las Cortes. Great places to stroll (and enjoy food and drink, of course!) abound in this part of Madrid!
titleopinion: Cezanne's the man!. Great places to stroll (and enjoy food and drink, of course!) abound in this part of Madrid!

reviewnospace: This museum houses more contemporary artists, which I prefer and I was not disappointed. Be sure to get your tickets ahead of time if possible as this is a busy, smaller collection. Going early in the day is probably better than mid-day.
titleopinion: Outstanding Private Collection. This museum houses more contemporary artists, which I prefer and I was not disappointed. Be sure to get your tickets ahead of time if possible as this is a busy, smaller collection. Going early in the day is probably better than mid-day.

reviewnospace: This has to be one of the best art museums I have visited, and I've visited a few! Just the right size so you are able to see it all and fantastic art to view.
titleopinion: Unmissable. This has to be one of the best art museums I have visited, and I've visited a few! Just the right size so you are able to see it all and fantastic art to view.

quote: Great art collection but come when free . . . .
reviewnospace:
This is wonderful art collection amassed by rich european industrialist's wife. . . .. it is worth a visit but remember it has impressive collection of lesser works from the masters and masterpieces from lesser artists and that isnt a knock as I feel Prado and Centro de Arte Reina Sofia are better etc . . . .

Tip: Open Monday and Free Mondays 12:00-16:00

reviewnospace: Both the permanent and the temporary collections are great. Very convenient location close to many amenities. Online tickets facilities allow to plan any visit in advance. A must in any visit to Madrid
titleopinion: A must!. Both the permanent and the temporary collections are great. Very convenient location close to many amenities. Online tickets facilities allow to plan any visit in advance. A must in any visit to Madrid

reviewnospace:
It is full of fantastic collections, both temporary and permanent.
The size is also good; it's not too much to take in at once.
Nice café!
titleopinion: One of the best museums. It is full of fantastic collections, both temporary and permanent.  The size is also good; it's not too much to take in at once. Nice café!

quote: Cannot compete with Prado Museum, but smth VERY close
reviewnospace:
Great collection of art starting from XIII century - Renaissance, Mannerism, the Baroque, Rococo, Romanticism and the art of the 19th and 20th centuries up to Pop Art. The last one personally I don't like, but it did not spoil my impression from the museum :)
Pay attention to the thematic exhibitions, mainly they are interesting and well-done

reviewnospace: The museum lies between Reina Sofia and Prado, what could be called the Museum Triangle. One can walk from Reina Sofia to Thyssen and then to the Prado. This is a private collection dontaed by the matriarch of the Thyssen family. It is a wonderful collections of all Masters. I find it a relaxing Museum as it is not overwhelming, It has a little of everything.

I find it a relaxing Museum as it is not overwhelming, It has a little of everything.

reviewnospace: Lovely light modern gallery with nice cafe and shop. Permanent exhibition is wonderful and the Cezanne exhibition which is on at the moment is out of this world.
titleopinion: Fantastic Cezanne exhibition.. Lovely light modern gallery with nice cafe and shop. Permanent exhibition is wonderful and the Cezanne exhibition which is on at the moment is out of this world.

quote: Fantastic art museum worth visiting when in Madrid
reviewnospace:
I was with my wife and teenager daughters in Madrid for my birthday. I had been thinking of an attraction that all could enjoy. Not easy with teenagers... My decision fell on Thyssen-Bornemisza. I had booked the tickets online, so we could just leave or jackets in the wardrobe and pass directly. The museum has different areas with art from different centuries and countries. I personally enjoyed the 20th century, contemporary art the best. The collection is great and the museum is well organized. Everybody enjoyed.

I would suggest to select some parts of the museum. Otherwise it´s too much to see.

The museum is part of the three Madrid art treasure (together with Prado and Reina Sofia). They are all in walking distance from each other in the south of the city, not far from main station Atocha.
