The museum is part of the three Madrid art treasure (together with Prado and Reina Sofia). They are all in walking distance from each other in the south of the city, not far from main station Atocha.

reviewnospace: Arrived in Madrid expecting to enjoy the Prado and Reina Sofia museums, but this was actually our favorite. It was not as crowded and easier to navigate. Wished we could have seen the Cezanne - but loved the primary collection. Especially for teenagers, I think this museum is wonderful dose of art - with variety so they can find what feels relevant. Highly recommend!!!!
titleopinion: Favorite Museum!. Arrived in Madrid expecting to enjoy the Prado and Reina Sofia museums, but this was actually our favorite. It was not as crowded and easier to navigate. Wished we could have seen the Cezanne - but loved the primary collection. Especially for teenagers, I think this museum is wonderful dose of art - with variety so they can find what feels relevant. Highly recommend!!!!

quote: One of the best art collections in the world
reviewnospace: Even without seeing the special exhibits (currently Cezanne), this museum has enough art spanning hundreds of centuries to transfix even the most jaded museum-goer. The 14C-15C religious paintings are outstanding, the German Expressionists and 20C paintings just as good. It took us 5.5 hours to wander through, with a 30 min. Break for a glass of cava in the pleasant, airy cafeteria. Honestly, our favourite museum in Madrid.
titleopinion: One of the best art collections in the world. Even without seeing the special exhibits (currently Cezanne), this museum has enough art spanning hundreds of centuries to transfix even the most jaded museum-goer. The 14C-15C religious paintings are outstanding, the German Expressionists and 20C paintings just as good. It took us 5.5 hours to wander through, with a 30 min. Break for a glass of cava in the pleasant, airy cafeteria. Honestly, our favourite museum in Madrid.

quote: Totally fantastic, I chose it over the Prado
reviewnospace: Although the Prado is Madrid's most famous museum, I chose the Thyssen-Bornemisza and I am glad I did. I went there twice; once for the temporary Cezanne exhibit (beautiful) and again for the permanent exhibit. I loved the Impressionists especially; and this museum was walking distance from my hotel. I recommend it to anyone who loves art especially that of the Impressionists and later.
titleopinion: Totally fantastic, I chose it over the Prado. Although the Prado is Madrid's most famous museum, I chose the Thyssen-Bornemisza and I am glad I did. I went there twice; once for the temporary Cezanne exhibit (beautiful) and again for the permanent exhibit. I loved the Impressionists especially; and this museum was walking distance from my hotel. I recommend it to anyone who loves art especially that of the Impressionists and later.

quote: fantastic collection - one of the must sees in Madrid
reviewnospace:
The Thyssen-Bornemisza collection is mainly modern art - you can find all the major modern artists there. Very impressive, not too crowded. When I was there, they had a Cezanne exhibition - a very clever way to expose his pictures, worth a visit (if it's still on).
For me, this museum was one of the highlights in Madrid.
titleopinion: fantastic collection - one of the must sees in Madrid. The Thyssen-Bornemisza collection is mainly modern art - you can find all the major modern artists there. Very impressive, not too crowded. When I was there, they had a Cezanne exhibition - a very clever way to expose his pictures, worth a visit (if it's still on). For me, this museum was one of the highlights in Madrid.

reviewnospace:
A very wet late March day in Madrid was saved by seeing this collection.

Whilst many times larger than the Frick in New York, there is that same feeling of sharing a collector's passion. Some great early works; impressionist works including two wonderful Pissaros; a Holman Hunt that came as a complete and welcome surprise; Dutch seascapes; Lautrec. I could go on listing the jewels hiding here.

Not sure we liked the great lady's choice of colour for the walls but that is a minor gripe. For the next month or two you get a Cezanne exhibition as well as the collection. Book in advance for this or you may queue for quite a long time. We took a late lunch in the gallery cafe. It was just what we wanted. Thoroughly recommended.
titleopinion: A wonderful collection. A very wet late March day in Madrid was saved by seeing this collection.   Whilst many times larger than the Frick in New York, there is that same feeling of sharing a collector's passion. Some great early works; impressionist works including two wonderful Pissaros; a Holman Hunt that came as a complete and welcome surprise; Dutch seascapes; Lautrec. I could go on listing the jewels hiding here.  Not sure we liked the great lady's choice of colour for the walls but that is a minor gripe. For the next month or two you get a Cezanne exhibition as well as the collection. Book in advance for this or you may queue for quite a long time. We took a late lunch in the gallery cafe. It was just what we wanted. Thoroughly recommended.

reviewnospace: Similar to the Musee d'Orsay, but without the spectacular works that are in Paris. An amazing collection and worth seeing. A beautiful modern museum, just across from the Prado.
titleopinion: Modern art. Similar to the Musee d'Orsay, but without the spectacular works that are in Paris. An amazing collection and worth seeing. A beautiful modern museum, just across from the Prado.

reviewnospace: Around the circle from the Prado, this museum is not to be missed by those who love classic art with a bit of the modern.
titleopinion: Wonderful museum. Around the circle from the Prado, this museum is not to be missed by those who love classic art with a bit of the modern.

reviewnospace: The most interesting part of this museum is the fact that all the art used to belong to 2 people - Thyssen and Bornemisza. The building is also an attraction - big open rooms, nicely laid out and decorated. At times, you feel that you are in a luxury hotel in a tropical location. Highlights for us were impressionists - Monet, Manet, Picasso, Renoir, Van Gogh, Dali, Rubens, Rembrandt, and Degas. The admission fee was 10 euros for the adults, 7 euros for the kids (aged 14 and 18), plus 4 euros each for the audio guides (we love these -highly recommended - you get so much more out of what you are seeing if you have them - the history of the painting, the artist, the cultural context, the response, etc). For this fee, we could see the 1st and 2nd floors with the permanent collection. We could not see Floor 0 with the temporary collection. The best part about this museum from the point of view of our 14 year old son with sore feet was that there were benches to sit on about every other room. This was not the case at the Queen Sophia Art Centre that we saw earlier. The giftshop was also very good. We thoroughly enjoyed this museum.
titleopinion: Beautiful art, beautiful building!. The most interesting part of this museum is the fact that all the art used to belong to 2 people - Thyssen and Bornemisza. The building is also an attraction - big open rooms, nicely laid out and decorated. At times, you feel that you are in a luxury hotel in a tropical location. For this fee, we could see the 1st and 2nd floors with the permanent collection. We could not see Floor 0 with the temporary collection. The best part about this museum from the point of view of our 14 year old son with sore feet was that there were benches to sit on about every other room. This was not the case at the Queen Sophia Art Centre that we saw earlier. The giftshop was also very good. We thoroughly enjoyed this museum.

reviewnospace: Beautifully displayed art masterpieces in a quiet setting with art from all ages on different levels
titleopinion: Quiet uncrowded and charming. Beautifully displayed art masterpieces in a quiet setting with art from all ages on different levels

reviewnospace: Great experience, solid collection of works. Worth seeing. Particularly good temporary expo of works by Cezanne.
titleopinion: Well organised. Great experience, solid collection of works. Worth seeing. Particularly good temporary expo of works by Cezanne.

quote: So much art accumulated in so short a time.
reviewnospace: If you wanted to see a complete collection of European and American Art from the old masters to modernism - look no further.
titleopinion: So much art accumulated in so short a time.. If you wanted to see a complete collection of European and American Art from the old masters to modernism - look no further.

reviewnospace:
This is magnificent art collection in a wonderful setting. The pictures are displayed over three floors in a logical & simple way. The older works on the top floor, the contemporary on the ground, so if you are looking to view a particular era it is very easy to do. The gallery is light & airy & provides plenty of benches. I found the English language plan & guide informative & easy to follow.
On the ground floor there is the temporary exhibition space which at the time of my visit had a Cezanne exhibition which was predictably crowded, as opposed to the regular exhibition.
The restaurant was excellent, clean, well organised table service, good selection - far superior to either The Prado or Reina Sofia.
The icing on the cake? €7 entrance for over 65 !!
titleopinion: Wonderful, número uno gallery.. This is magnificent art collection in a wonderful setting. The pictures are displayed over three floors in a logical & simple way. The older works on the top floor, the contemporary on the ground, so if you are looking to view a particular era it is very easy to do. The gallery is light & airy & provides plenty of benches. I found the English language plan & guide informative & easy to follow. On the ground floor there is the temporary exhibition space which at the time of my visit had a Cezanne exhibition which was predictably crowded, as opposed to the regular exhibition.  The restaurant was excellent, clean, well organised table service, good selection - far superior to either The Prado or Reina Sofia. The icing on the cake? €7 entrance for over 65 !!

reviewnospace: An amazing collection of beautiful art that must not be missed when visiting Madrid. a highlight of our visit. Give at least a day (it really deserves days).
titleopinion: Not to be missed. An amazing collection of beautiful art that must not be missed when visiting Madrid. a highlight of our visit. Give at least a day (it really deserves days).

reviewnospace: we went to see the Cezanne exhibition here and it really was an international affair except for France who leant nothing to this exhibition sadly as this is where many of his greatest works were done and still remain! Spain did its best to show off his best works to the world ! Well don Thyssen gallery !!! if you can get to it do, its essential to book before hand !!! the entrance is a little convoluted getting past the guards ! !!!

Spain did its best to show off his best works to the world ! Well don Thyssen gallery !!! if you can get to it do, its essential to book before hand !!! the entrance is a little convoluted getting past the guards ! !!!

reviewnospace:
CÉZANNE site/non-site was an excellent exhibition, whenever you are in Madrid and you like this type of art, go and see it.
The rest of the museum is wondrfull too, really worth a visit. Ah don't forget to buy one of these explainers, to listen to an experienced viewer to hear what you are seeing. Very instructive!!!

reviewnospace: This is a great '2nd' museum in Madrid after the Museo del Prado. It's organized in 3 levels and flows easily. I would recommend this Museum if I still want after the Museo Del Prado. General admission is 10€ + 4€ for the audio guide. Only down side for me was the cost given the strength of the European currency at time of travel.
titleopinion: Organized museum. This is a great '2nd' museum in Madrid after the Museo del Prado. It's organized in 3 levels and flows easily. I would recommend this Museum if I still want after the Museo Del Prado. General admission is 10€ + 4€ for the audio guide. Only down side for me was the cost given the strength of the European currency at time of travel.

quote: Wife enjoyed this as much as The Prado.
reviewnospace: My wife is the museum person in our family. She definitely would suggest this one. Of course you cannot mis The Prado but she enjoyed this one just as muvh.
titleopinion: Wife enjoyed this as much as The Prado.. My wife is the museum person in our family. She definitely would suggest this one. Of course you cannot mis The Prado but she enjoyed this one just as muvh.

reviewnospace: Everyone rates the Prado, which undoubtedly is a great museum, but this enormous once private collection has it all. Really well displayed (start on the top floor and discover the development of European art), well displayed and a really diverse range of artists. Most importantly it isn't too big so not exhausting and draining like some of the bigger museums.The collection ranges from Renaissance through Baroque to post impressionist; El Greco, Rubens, Picasso, Monet, Hopper, Freud...the list goes on..... I went on Sunday afternoon and there were no queues and no admission charge, and once this museum closed there was time for a few drinks, some rest and onto the Prado for some of their free time opening hours. Definately worth planning schedules before to maximise visits.
titleopinion: Amazing Collection for Western Art. Everyone rates the Prado, which undoubtedly is a great museum, but this enormous once private collection has it all. Really well displayed (start on the top floor and discover the development of European art), well displayed and a really diverse range of artists. Most importantly it isn't too big so not exhausting and draining like some of the bigger museums.The collection ranges from Renaissance through Baroque to post impressionist; El Greco, Rubens, Picasso, Monet, Hopper, Freud...the list goes on..... I went on Sunday afternoon and there were no queues and no admission charge, and once this museum closed there was time for a few drinks, some rest and onto the Prado for some of their free time opening hours. Definately worth planning schedules before to maximise visits.

reviewnospace: I have been to a lot of museums, but never one like this. Paintings span from Trecento Italian to early 21st century American. It is undoubtedly the finest collection of portraits that I have ever seen, with numerous examples from Italian and Northern Renaissance through to contemporary painters such as Lucian Freud. It is not limited to portraiture--landscape, still life, religious, etc. are also well-represented. Paintings are beautifully displayed, with generous space between works and all hung at eye level so that the viewer can really appreciate the craft of each artist. If you love painting, don't miss this museum.
titleopinion: Fascinating, Unique, Excellent. I have been to a lot of museums, but never one like this. Paintings span from Trecento Italian to early 21st century American. It is undoubtedly the finest collection of portraits that I have ever seen, with numerous examples from Italian and Northern Renaissance through to contemporary painters such as Lucian Freud. It is not limited to portraiture--landscape, still life, religious, etc. are also well-represented. Paintings are beautifully displayed, with generous space between works and all hung at eye level so that the viewer can really appreciate the craft of each artist. If you love painting, don't miss this museum.

quote: Greeat Place to visit the Permanent Collection, but also the special exhibitions
reviewnospace:
Been in March and had the great opportunity of enjoy a Special Ex. dedicated to Cezanne. Have to say that the curatorship of this one is great, really enjoyed it.
They present great paintings from Rubens, El Greco, Chagall, Klee, Monet...
Say no more, right?!
titleopinion: Greeat Place to visit the Permanent Collection, but also the special exhibitions. Been in March and had the great opportunity of enjoy a Special Ex. dedicated to Cezanne. Have to say that the curatorship of this one is great, really enjoyed it.  They present great paintings from Rubens, El Greco, Chagall, Klee, Monet... Say no more, right?!

quote: Built as an art museum and it works
reviewnospace:
I love a good organized museum. As tour books will tell you, go to the top floor and tour down. Seems the art work starts with the 11th century and comes down to the 20th. All in chronological order. If you are an untrained art enjoyer,this is a perfect museum to get yourself, self educated.

Maybe it can also be described as lesser works of the great artists and greater works of the lesser artists. but it is definitely worth the admission price and time to visit.

Late March 2014 visit, no lines.

wayne iNES

quote: Lots of great portraits and landscapes...
reviewnospace: A lot of high quality art, not too much to do in an afternoon/very managable collection...rotating exhibits as well.
titleopinion: Lots of great portraits and landscapes.... A lot of high quality art, not too much to do in an afternoon/very managable collection...rotating exhibits as well.

reviewnospace: Don't be fooled by the Prado. This museum has a smaller collection but it is a GEM. Has every artist you can imagine to my surprise. Beautiful collection and don't miss a visit.
titleopinion: Favorite Museum in Madrid. Don't be fooled by the Prado. This museum has a smaller collection but it is a GEM. Has every artist you can imagine to my surprise. Beautiful collection and don't miss a visit.

reviewnospace: We returned for a second tour ( our first tour was a few years ago). There is something about the layout of this museum that simply makes it easy to see it all. some of the better art works were out for one reason or another but there is plenty remaining. One of our favorite Art museums! Go if you can!
titleopinion: Our second visit. We returned for a second tour ( our first tour was a few years ago). There is something about the layout of this museum that simply makes it easy to see it all. some of the better art works were out for one reason or another but there is plenty remaining. One of our favorite Art museums! Go if you can!

reviewnospace: A fantastic selection covering almost every period you can imagine. The rooms are arranged chronologically so you can see ideas growing and developing. Well laid out and easy to get around.
titleopinion: Excellent Gallery. A fantastic selection covering almost every period you can imagine. The rooms are arranged chronologically so you can see ideas growing and developing. Well laid out and easy to get around.

quote: Beautiful museum, not to be missed
reviewnospace: This collection is world class and comprehensive. Please leave plenty of time - at least 2-3 hours, plus the special current exhibit - Cezanne. In fact, I split my visit over 2 days.
titleopinion: Beautiful museum, not to be missed. This collection is world class and comprehensive. Please leave plenty of time - at least 2-3 hours, plus the special current exhibit - Cezanne. In fact, I split my visit over 2 days.

reviewnospace: If you only have a little time.. this is definitely one of the best museums in the world as far as quality per square metre!
titleopinion: The Best. If you only have a little time.. this is definitely one of the best museums in the world as far as quality per square metre!

reviewnospace: Absolutely a must, some truly wonderful pictures collected and curated in a thoughtful and accessible way. A wonderful building next to the Prado.
titleopinion: A must. Absolutely a must, some truly wonderful pictures collected and curated in a thoughtful and accessible way. A wonderful building next to the Prado.

reviewnospace:
A lot to see, it is best to be selective and plan what you are most interested in. It is well laid out and floor plans are available to allow for planning your viewing. Every genre of styles are displayed in an easy way to find.
We used the restaurant for lunch, this was a mistake. The burgers we had were under cooked to the point that they were inedible and a health risk.

reviewnospace:
This is accepted as being one of the finest and most varied collections there is. I enjoyed walking round it all and pausing where I especially liked a painting as in Carpaccio's young knight, Titian's Doge or Singer Sergeant's Venetian girl with onions or Picasso's hilarious The Harvesters.
The exhibition which compares Cezanne's landscapes and still life works which were rare for an Impressionist is superb and it also features his bathers.Superb.

The exhibition which compares Cezanne's landscapes and still life works which were rare for an Impressionist is superb and it also features his bathers.Superb.

quote: Great museum, very easy to navigate

reviewnospace: The Prado, for all its wonderful contents is austere, Academic and exhausting, the Reine Sofia is over didactic and presents its works in a contextually challenging and questionable framework but the Thyssen-Bornemisza is just right. Simply presented, full of exquisite paintings spanning the centuries, it is like visiting old friends. Start at the top floor and let gravity take you from pre-renaissance to pop art. Some delightful surprises, such as two small Kandinskys you want to take home with you, and an Yves Tanguy which is far better than the one in the Reine Sofia. The other two are essential viewing, but this is the best. Save it till the last.

reviewnospace:
Having visited both the Prado and the Retiro galleries on the previous two days I wasn't sure how the Thyssen-Bornemisza would compare. I'm very happy to say that I was pleasantly surprised by this large, light and welcoming gallery. It didn't have the centerpieces of the other two galleries (Goya's Black period and Guernica) but it is still a stunning varied collection, especially the ground floor impressionist collection which I actually found to be better than those in the Prado and Retiro.
If you are planning on viewing the whole museum in one go I would suggest starting on the top floor with the oldest exhibits and working your way down, finishing with the contemporary art. We did it the other way and we're a bit 'arted out' by the time we reached the 12th century religious icons. Better still split your visit over different days and focus on one floor and period at a time.
The roof terrace cafe is also worth a mention, especially on a sunny day if you can get a seat. Prices are a little more expensive than some of the other local cafes but it's definitely more welcoming than the oppressive and unwelcoming cafe in the Retiro.
titleopinion: An exceptional gallery. Having visited both the Prado and the Retiro galleries on the previous two days I wasn't sure how the Thyssen-Bornemisza would compare. I'm very happy to say that I was pleasantly surprised by this large, light and welcoming gallery. It didn't have the centerpieces of the other two galleries (Goya's Black period and Guernica) but it is still a stunning varied collection, especially the ground floor impressionist collection which I actually found to be better than those in the Prado and Retiro. If you are planning on viewing the whole museum in one go I would suggest starting on the top floor with the oldest exhibits and working your way down, finishing with the contemporary art. We did it the other way and we're a bit 'arted out' by the time we reached the 12th century religious icons. Better still split your visit over different days and focus on one floor and period at a time. The roof terrace cafe is also worth a mention, especially on a sunny day if you can get a seat. Prices are a little more expensive than some of the other local cafes but it's definitely more welcoming than the oppressive and unwelcoming cafe in the Retiro.

reviewnospace: ….assembled by just three generations of the wealthy Thyssen-Bornemisza family of Germany. The last Baron Thyssen-Bornemisza married a Spanish woman, Carmen, and she now, has added to the museum, giving it her own collection that she has been assembling since the death of the Baron some years ago. What you have is essentially two museums within one: the Baron's collection and Carmen's collection. He tended to collect Dutch, Flemish and English masters and she preferred landscapes, Impressionists and 19th and 20th C artists. Combined, the art within the museum is breathtaking in its scope and the number of spectacular masterpieces of art, that most anyone will recognize. Hard to believe that all of this art was once owned by just one couple! Do not miss seeing this museum. It's worth it… and if you go on Monday, the 10 euro entrance fee is waived!
titleopinion: Amazing Private Collection….. ….assembled by just three generations of the wealthy Thyssen-Bornemisza family of Germany. The last Baron Thyssen-Bornemisza married a Spanish woman, Carmen, and she now, has added to the museum, giving it her own collection that she has been assembling since the death of the Baron some years ago. What you have is essentially two museums within one: the Baron's collection and Carmen's collection. He tended to collect Dutch, Flemish and English masters and she preferred landscapes, Impressionists and 19th and 20th C artists. Combined, the art within the museum is breathtaking in its scope and the number of spectacular masterpieces of art, that most anyone will recognize. Hard to believe that all of this art was once owned by just one couple! Do not miss seeing this museum. It's worth it… and if you go on Monday, the 10 euro entrance fee is waived!

reviewnospace: This fantastic museum actually houses two collections, the Baron's collection and the Baroness's collection, each of which reflects his or her individual interests and taste. Together, they include outstanding works of European art from the 14th to the 20th century, including Italian Primitive, Renaissance and Baroque artists, Spanish, German, Flemish and Dutch masters, French Impressionists and Post-Impressionists, Cubists and other 20th century artists, and on and on - a veritable survey of European art spread over three levels. And, most unusual in Europe, both collections also have an excellent works of American artists and movements. Not every painting is the best example of a particular artist's work or a particular movement, but most are outstanding and all of them are well presented in modern, well-lit galleries. The visitor should expect to spend at least three hours exploring these collections and, for a break, there is cafeteria on the ground floor. The museum is free to all on Monday afternoons, when it can a bit crowded. This is one of Madrid's true gems!
titleopinion: Fabulous collection, well presented. This fantastic museum actually houses two collections, the Baron's collection and the Baroness's collection, each of which reflects his or her individual interests and taste. Together, they include outstanding works of European art from the 14th to the 20th century, including Italian Primitive, Renaissance and Baroque artists, Spanish, German, Flemish and Dutch masters, French Impressionists and Post-Impressionists, Cubists and other 20th century artists, and on and on - a veritable survey of European art spread over three levels. And, most unusual in Europe, both collections also have an excellent works of American artists and movements. Not every painting is the best example of a particular artist's work or a particular movement, but most are outstanding and all of them are well presented in modern, well-lit galleries. The visitor should expect to spend at least three hours exploring these collections and, for a break, there is cafeteria on the ground floor. The museum is free to all on Monday afternoons, when it can a bit crowded. This is one of Madrid's true gems!

reviewnospace: At just €10 entry as opposed to €23 for the Prado, this is much better value. It covers European and US art from the 15th to the 20th century. The Prado has no 20th century art, but you get to see work by Picasso, Hopper, Freud, Bacon and a whole plethora of cubist and other "modern" artists too (Kandinsky, Gris, Marc etc). There is also a substantial representation of French impressionism, although two of the better Monet paintings were unfortunately missing during my visit.

reviewnospace:
Along with Prado, for these two museums worth a trip to Madrid alone from anywhere in the world!

We gone there the day after Prado. Started in the ground floor, so gone back in time. I was amazed, how many "modern" artist I know (of course Picasso, but...)! We had seen so many great painter's work that we were touched. So much so, that when I have stood before a Van Gogh's painting, my throat was locked and I could cry!

It is very touching when you are surrounded so many greatness! Like... legendary paintings: Rubens' self-portrait for example... or Degas' dancer - I was finished. Again, like in the Prado, my brain couldn't process all the infos.

I was touched, moved by this museum!

quote: If you don't like this room, go around the next corner.
reviewnospace:
I live in Madrid, and have visited all of the big 3 museums. The Thyssen is, by far, my favorite to visit either on my own or with friends. The diversity of the collection, alone, means that it appeals to a variety of tastes. Seriously, if you don't like the style in this room, just go around the corner and you will find something different.

They have a tremendous traveling exhibit right now on Cezanne. Go see it.

If one has a couple of days in Madrid, Thyssen is a must see.

reviewnospace: I loved the Thyssen-Bornemisza museum. We spent just over two hours exploring the galleries. I found the displays easy to follow with seats every so often which aided my weary feet. There were many paintings by Titian, Goya, Van Gogh & Picasso which I thoroughly enjoyed seeing. There were other works by artists who I was unfamiliar with so now I´ve a new project to discover more about these (to me) unknowns. At €10 per person for the basic entry I thought this was excellent value – you pay extra for any additional special exhibitions. After our visit we went to their delightful café & enjoyed a welcomed cup of coffee. Whilst we didn´t eat in the café we did see meals being served & they looked delightful.

reviewnospace: I like the personal collection particularly as it's interesting to see one person's breadth of taste.

quote: Centuries of Art at this collection
reviewnospace: I really enjoyed this gallery as it took you on a history of Art tour. The top floor contains works from the early renaissance and you work your way down to the ground floor which displays the most modern . Apart fro this there does not appear to be much of a theme. You do get to see such a wide variety of artists from Canaletto to Francis Bacon , Hopper and the inevitable Picasso, Goya and El Greco. When we were there they had an exhibition of Cezanne's works which was extra but well worth it.

reviewnospace: Cezanne has been claimed by the cubists for too long. This skillful exhibition attempts a glimpse of this soulful man and his art.

reviewnospace: After the confusion of the Prado this was spacious and uncluttered. I would return but only for the second floor old masters. A great pity the exhibit labeling isn't also in English (like the Prado). 3 to 4 hours minimum needed. Entry fees but good pensioner discount. I'd rate this gallery/museum No 1.

quote: An art history lesson in one museum
reviewnospace: We really enjoyed our time here. The Thyssen is the perfect size, a great way to spend 2-3 hours looking at beautiful art. The museum is set up chronologically, so you start with medieval art and end up with Warhol and Lichtenstein. Plus they had a Cezanne exhibit too! (and if you;re over 65, the admission to both is only 9 euro!)

reviewnospace: If you are a lover of classic art as I am don't miss out the wonderful 15-18th century collection, the amount of abstractionism made me panic.
titleopinion: Abstractionism is scary. If you are a lover of classic art as I am don't miss out the wonderful 15-18th century collection, the amount of abstractionism made me panic.

reviewnospace: I am writing this based on my wife's experience of visiting the museum when we were in Madrid a couple of weeks ago. She is an ex art teacher and we have been to top museums elsewhere in Madrid, London. Florence, New York and so on. She was totally blown away by her visit to Thyssen-Bornemisza which makes me think that I should recommend this museum in the strongest terms. Fantastic range of painting styles. Extremely well laid-out. Close to the Prada and Retiro Park. The museum is free on Monday afternoon from 12pm to 4pm. If you can get along well before they close at 4pm you are in for a huge treat.

reviewnospace: Not quite as well known as Prado (which is fairly close by) but equally as impressive in many ways. Perhaps if you are only going to one museum this is not the first choice, on the other hand it is much less crowded and more manageable than Prado if you have limited time.

reviewnospace: I didn't expect much from this museum, but I was impressed by the amount of great paintings and the most important periods: Renaissance, Flemish Masters, Impressionism, Baroque and Pop Art. It is very easy to navigate and it wasn't crowded as the Prado.
titleopinion: Worth a visit. I didn't expect much from this museum, but I was impressed by the amount of great paintings and the most important periods: Renaissance, Flemish Masters, Impressionism, Baroque and Pop Art. It is very easy to navigate and it wasn't crowded as the Prado.

quote: This is another must. This collection is better than most museums.
reviewnospace:
The Thyssen is one of the greatest private collections turned museums that I can think of out of the royal context in Europe or anywhere else. It is so expansive from late Medieval to the present and it manages to display all the work in a more less chronological/stylistic fashion so that the visitor feels as if they are learning as they go. I cannot rave about this museum enough.
The store used to be a mecca but in the past few years the quality of the shopping and dining at the Thyssen has declined quite dramatically. Still, go for the art. Also, here is nothing like seeing a Hopper in Spain to make you realize that American art can sit alongside European masters with plomb.
titleopinion: This is another must. This collection is better than most museums.. The Thyssen is one of the greatest private collections turned museums that I can think of out of the royal context in Europe or anywhere else. It is so expansive from late Medieval to the present and it manages to display all the work in a more less chronological/stylistic fashion so that the visitor feels as if they are learning as they go. I cannot rave about this museum enough.  The store used to be a mecca but in the past few years the quality of the shopping and dining at the Thyssen has declined quite dramatically. Still, go for the art. Also, here is nothing like seeing a Hopper in Spain to make you realize that American art can sit alongside European masters with plomb.

quote: Not as great as the Prado but in second place
reviewnospace: A lovely private collection of art from one family spanning beautiful medieval to classic pieces. If you have seen the Prado, and want more art, this will compliment that visit.
titleopinion: Not as great as the Prado but in second place. A lovely private collection of art from one family spanning beautiful medieval to classic pieces. If you have seen the Prado, and want more art, this will compliment that visit.

reviewnospace: We were able to visit when there were not too many people so that made the visit that much more enjoyable. There is a great permanent collection here so you should try to visit. You may get lucky to also see a good special exhibition as we did. It's worth the time.

reviewnospace: The Museo is close to the Prado, much more manageable, and more recognizable art for Americans...Rembrandt self portrait, Flemish masters, a few Impressionist, etc. lunch room noisy but glad to sit for awhile! Very worthwhile...

Despite the unfortunate color of the walls and the tasteless framing, there are works of astonishing quality: the Rembrandt self-portrait, the Girlandaio (the famous woman in yellow seen from the side), several Ruisdael (a fantastic winter scene), and many more.

A particularly enjoyable aspect id the that non-flash photography is permitted so it is possible to later re-live the pleasure of the visit.
A definite must-see in Madrid.

reviewnospace: Not as good as the Prado, but they have lots of different periods and styles represented in the collection. The museum is manageable and can be easily seen in one day. Go on Mondays when it is free.

reviewnospace:
A completely amazing collection of art in a very beautyfull building. Foreseeable set-up make this a special experience. There is a concentration of painters from German, Netherlands and Italy. The place is paintet in a bright terracotta, wich is a perfect background.
This year the collection will be expanted, as more paintings from the Thyssen-Bornemisza family will be exposed.
Don't miss this while staying in Madrid

titleopinion: The best little museum. I actually prefer the Tyssen to the Prado. It's got an amazing collection, and is doable in one day.

reviewnospace: Wonderful art gallery, depending on your tastes. Lots of religious art, along with a few old masters. Takes a while to complete the whole tour but if you love art it’s worth it. There is an entry fee but if you are a senior citizen there is a discount with identification.
titleopinion: Art Galore. Wonderful art gallery, depending on your tastes. Lots of religious art, along with a few old masters. Takes a while to complete the whole tour but if you love art it’s worth it. There is an entry fee but if you are a senior citizen there is a discount with identification.

reviewnospace: Great location, great exhibitions, in many ways more interesting than the Prado or Reina Sofia. Very easy to get in or move around, great permanent exhibits as well as special showings.
titleopinion: Don't miss this!!!. Great location, great exhibitions, in many ways more interesting than the Prado or Reina Sofia. Very easy to get in or move around, great permanent exhibits as well as special showings.

quote: Another great art collection in Madrid
reviewnospace:
I went to this museum twice, one week apart. The first visit was a self-guided tour of the permanent collection; the second was to see a temporary exhibit on surrealism. It’s often been said that the permanent collection includes the works of famous artists but not necessarily their most famous paintings. My takeaway is that it is a rich collection of early modern & modern European art, much of it impressive. To me it was comparable to the Gemäldegalerie in Berlin or the National Gallery of Art in Dublin. The Dutch and Italian artists are well represented here, including works by Rembrandt, Van Gogh, Frans Hals, and Caravaggio. The collection of Spanish art is more impressive for the modern period, including works by Picasso and Dali. My favorite paintings at the Thyssen are the three Canaletto paintings depicting Venice. The visit of the temporary exhibit was equally impressive and enjoyable as it included a number of works of surrealist art from various museums around the world. It complimented well some of the art at the Reina Sofia (which I visited earlier in the week).

The Thyssen has perhaps the most impressive museum art bookstore in Madrid. They sell a wonderful guide to the permanent collection, available in five different languages. The book is more than 400 pages long and includes lots of glossy reproductions of the museum’s permanent collection— all for a cost of 20 euro.

My takeaway is that it is a rich collection of early modern & modern European art, much of it impressive. To me it was comparable to the Gemäldegalerie in Berlin or the National Gallery of Art in Dublin. The visit of the temporary exhibit was equally impressive and enjoyable as it included a number of works of surrealist art from various museums around the world. reviewnospace: Don't miss this one! If you are feeling that you can't face another gallery, then this is a good one for you! Marvelous, wide ranging collections. Something for everyone. Surprised to see a Holbein Henry VIII. Buy a combined 3 gallery ticket and you can avoid the Prado queues!
titleopinion: Wonderful collections!. Don't miss this one! If you are feeling that you can't face another gallery, then this is a good one for you! Marvelous, wide ranging collections. Something for everyone. Surprised to see a Holbein Henry VIII. Buy a combined 3 gallery ticket and you can avoid the Prado queues!

reviewnospace: This is my favourite and the best gallery in Madrid. Its much better value for money than Prado and the age for free entry for children is higher. The Gallery is well laid out and its easy to choose which era you would like to see so you dont get bogged down in say Dutch masters when you really want to see the Van Gough! Its much quieter and less crowded than the Prado and the whole experience is more relaxing and calm. Fantastic selection of paintings through the ages from 12th century to modern art and everything in between. The gift shop is fantastic. I have not been to the restaurant but that looks very nice.

reviewnospace: This museum offers a wonderful view of art across the ages, and there is such a cross section of genres - something for everyone.
titleopinion: A wonderful taste of art. This museum offers a wonderful view of art across the ages, and there is such a cross section of genres - something for everyone.

reviewnospace: This museum is just a couple of blocks from the Prado, but is well worth a visit. It has a wide variety in the collection and will only take an afternoon to get through. Clearly not as much quantity as the Prado, but the variety and quality of pieces makes this a must see!

reviewnospace: We thoroughly enjoyed our afternoon at Thyssen-Bornemisza, spending our time at a multi media exhibit on surrealism, so appropriate for a visit to Spain. We enjoy 20th century art more so than that of previous centuries and the Thyssen offered us a good share of what we were looking for. The staff are friendly; the exhibit was thorough, including film. We learned from it as well.

reviewnospace: Honestly, I really wanted to visit the Prado and Reina Sophia and then if we had time to get to the Thyssen-Bornemisza I was up for it but not super jazzed about it. We did go and I am glad we did because it was an expansive and varied collection that offered a different feel than both the Prado and Reina Sophia. It was worth the visit and I was happy to see pieces that I did not even know were there and I recognized from my art history class.

quote: WOW, for any art lover a must in Madrid
reviewnospace: This museum was not open during our earlier, long ago visit to Madrid in 1985. The collection is just astounding; for me, the Italian paintings and more modern works were a true bonus. The museum is close to the Prado as well--with master works of the world. So interesting to see the "collector's eye"--and incredible the span of these works collected by (I believe only two) generations of a family.

reviewnospace:
This museum was fantastic! In addition to the general admission, we purchased tickets for their special exhibit on Surrealism. Both the main collection and the surrealist attraction were phenomenal.

I always love eating lunch at art museums as they have contemporary, local cuisine with an artist flair. The restaurant did not disappoint here! I had a delicious duck confit.

reviewnospace: The collection is very comprehensive and easy to find the art-pieces. We followed the recommendation to start from the 2nd Floor, higher to lower level. As it was a raining day we spend about 4 hours visiting. We bought the app with the audio-guide, it worked very well for the first 50% of the art selected but it fail after that. We went to the information desk to report the problem and they provided their audio device free of charge so we were able to complete our track. They allow to take photos without using flash. We took some to remember and post to our friends. We stop over to have lunch at museum cafe and the food was very nice and affordable! So it was a perfect afternoon!

The temporary exhibitions are normally pretty good too and it's currently free on Mondays (permanent collection only).

reviewnospace: The art in this collection is awesome. The display of the art pieces was done with fore thought and spaced appropriately to give each piece its due. This is an excellent and varied collection well worth the time.
titleopinion: Fabulous. The art in this collection is awesome. The display of the art pieces was done with fore thought and spaced appropriately to give each piece its due. This is an excellent and varied collection well worth the time.

reviewnospace: I just had time for a quick visit and I only visited the surrealism exhibition which was amazing and wonderfully curated. The museum is not crowded and everything is easy to find. A must.
titleopinion: A place to go. I just had time for a quick visit and I only visited the surrealism exhibition which was amazing and wonderfully curated. The museum is not crowded and everything is easy to find. A must.

reviewnospace: They have a wide variety of great painters. There is a relaxed atmosphere. Only with a life-size work of picaso stand on either side guards. The free two-hour evening are not enough to see everything.
titleopinion: They got it all.. They have a wide variety of great painters. There is a relaxed atmosphere. Only with a life-size work of picaso stand on either side guards. The free two-hour evening are not enough to see everything.

reviewnospace: This is an amazing collection but to see it all, you probably need a few days! The current exhibition on Surrealists is very, very interesting.
titleopinion: Fantastic collection. This is an amazing collection but to see it all, you probably need a few days! The current exhibition on Surrealists is very, very interesting.

quote: Another World-Class Museum BUT with HUGE Presentational Problems
reviewnospace:
I visited the Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum as part of my 8 full-day visit to Madrid and enjoyed it a lot - I am not surprised that it is a highly-rated Trip Advisor attraction BUT viewing of the high-quality collection is, for me, HUGELY spoilt by intrusive reflections onto paintings caused by number of different 'issues'....

If you don't believe me, my example photos (which should be at the base of this review) show examples of this and how it has been avoided with some paintings.

Of course this highlights one unusual 'bonus' of this museum ie that flash-free photography is allowed !

I mentioned this issue with the Thyssen-Bornemisza in my review of the Prado museum, as the latter (superior attraction) completely avoids this problem. There is diminished value in lauding beautiful paintings shown by a museum if you cannot see them at their best !

---
I am compiling an extensive Trip Advisor 'Trip List' for my visit to see the sights of Madrid and day trips to Toledo/Segovia, it is entitled 'Madrid Attractions (+ Toledo/Segovia Day Trips) : 7 Full-Day Visit Oct 2013'. Please feel free to access it via my TA Profile (by clicking my TA 'name' below the photo on the left of this review). I hope it is of interest and use to you and that all of my individual reviews/photos/videos get posted properly; don't forget that videos aren't posted with the review like photos are, so it's best to locate them via my TA profile....
---

I couldn't take advantage of the generous 'free visit' period on a Monday so paid the normal entrance fee on a Sunday afternoon and experienced no queue problems. Unlike the Prado, separately-contained 'themed' collections on display cost extra.....

The permanent collection is impressive. I'm no art aficionado, but there was a lot there which I found of interest and to my taste, almost as much as the painting collection of the Prado...

The paintings were universally in superb condition, BUT my enjoyment was, as already mentioned, VERY diminished by intrusive reflections on a large proportion of what I looked at. The issue is caused by several factors, namely reflective glass in painting frames, lighting often shining directly onto paintings (these 2 are unforgivable !), shiny flooring and 'corridor' presentations sited opposite uncovered windows which allow light in.

Museum 'navigation' is easy (with little opportunity for getting 'lost' !) BUT you should heed the basic collection information and start on the second floor, working your way downwards, to see them in their intended 'order'.

The Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum attracts only about 1/2 the numbers of the Prado or Queen Sofia Arts Centre (Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofia) but in my opinion TA reviews properly reflect the true status of this museum, as whilst it isn't as good as the Prado, I think that it is far better than the Queen Sofia Arts Centre (Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofia) with the important caveat of the problems with presentation.

However, even if you can't (like me) completely look past' the all too-frequent reflections in the artwork on display, you can still appreciate the quality and quantity of what is on offer - that's why I've given it 4 stars instead of 3...!

reviewnospace: After touring the Prado earlier in the day, we focused on the more recent artworks from the 20th century. We did skim some of the earlier works as our younger son had slept in and missed the Prado. So this gave him a flavor of what he missed. The collection was quite varied and interesting. We used the Madrid Card to get in.

reviewnospace: One of the top museums in the world. IMHO better than the Prado Museum. Great experience and visit. A must for anyone visiting Madrid.

reviewnospace: It is very central and has a quite large collection. Nevertheless, you could lose perspective after a while as so many rooms and paintings have to be visited.

reviewnospace: one of the 3 museums that you must do in madrid. very nice collection and nicely laid out. if you only do 2 museums make it this one and the par do unless you are a HUGE modern fan.

reviewnospace: How lucky we are to have families like this that collect, collect, and collect and then show it to the public.
titleopinion: A must see collection. How lucky we are to have families like this that collect, collect, and collect and then show it to the public.

reviewnospace: This is, in my view, one of the greatest art galleries in the world. A collection made over the last 100 or so years by a German industrialist, his son and, more recently, that son's third wife. She is Spanish, and persuaded the Spanish state to hand over a most beautiful building to house the fabulous collection after the British government had refused to provide one. It was a major coup for Madrid. The relatively smaller size and the eclecticism of the collection, not to mention its superb quality, gives it for me a higher rating than any other collection in Madrid. I make it a rule to visit regularly and am never disappointed. Unmissable.
titleopinion: One of the greats. This is, in my view, one of the greatest art galleries in the world. A collection made over the last 100 or so years by a German industrialist, his son and, more recently, that son's third wife. She is Spanish, and persuaded the Spanish state to hand over a most beautiful building to house the fabulous collection after the British government had refused to provide one. It was a major coup for Madrid. The relatively smaller size and the eclecticism of the collection, not to mention its superb quality, gives it for me a higher rating than any other collection in Madrid. I make it a rule to visit regularly and am never disappointed. Unmissable.

quote: A minimum of 3 hours here, it's worth it!
reviewnospace:
Easier to take-in than the 'big' Prado. I'd give this a 3 hour visit and consider lunch as the dining area is modern, clean and food is decent. It's free Monday (in Permanent Collections between 12.00 and 16.00), and go early to bypass crowds in the afternoon. What will you see? For one, this museum is modern (opened in 1992) and the architecture of the building is interesting. The collections offer an overview of art from the 13th century to 20th century. One thousand works are here of the Renaissance, Mannerism, Baroque, Rococo, Romanticism and up to 1960s Pop Art. Also important are collections of Impressionism, Fauvism (avant-garde movement in France), great samples of German Expressionism and other avant-garde movements from Russia and Italy. Topping it off, it has a nice collection of 19th-century American Master paintings you can't even see in the USA!

Times: Mondays 12.00 to 16.00 and Tuesdays to Sundays from 10.00 to 19.00. Ticket counter closes 18.30. On Saturdays, temporary exhibits are open until 21.00.
titleopinion: A minimum of 3 hours here, it's worth it!. Easier to take-in than the 'big' Prado. I'd give this a 3 hour visit and consider lunch as the dining area is modern, clean and food is decent. It's free Monday (in Permanent Collections between 12.00 and 16.00), and go early to bypass crowds in the afternoon. What will you see? For one, this museum is modern (opened in 1992) and the architecture of the building is interesting. The collections offer an overview of art from the 13th century to 20th century. One thousand works are here of the Renaissance, Mannerism, Baroque, Rococo, Romanticism and up to 1960s Pop Art. Also important are collections of Impressionism, Fauvism (avant-garde movement in France), great samples of German Expressionism and other avant-garde movements from Russia and Italy. Topping it off, it has a nice collection of 19th-century American Master paintings you can't even see in the USA!   Times: Mondays 12.00 to 16.00 and Tuesdays to Sundays from 10.00 to 19.00. Ticket counter closes 18.30. On Saturdays, temporary exhibits are open until 21.00.

reviewnospace: I've been to the de Young, Rijksmuseum, Louvre, Vatican, del Prado. The Thyssen-Bornemisza is by far my favorite. All of the Masters are here, inches away. I was actually surprised how close I could get to Rembrandt, Renoir, Cezanne, Van Gogh. Lunch in the restaurant weren't bad neither!
titleopinion: My favorite. I've been to the de Young, Rijksmuseum, Louvre, Vatican, del Prado. The Thyssen-Bornemisza is by far my favorite. All of the Masters are here, inches away. I was actually surprised how close I could get to Rembrandt, Renoir, Cezanne, Van Gogh. Lunch in the restaurant weren't bad neither!

reviewnospace: The Thyssen was having an exhibition called Surrealism and the Dream. I did not realize that there were so many artists who specialized in surrealism until I saw this exhibition, which was very educational. For me the best painting in the exhibition was the one done by Dali, called Dream caused by the Flight of the a Bee around a Pomegranate a Second before Waking Up. The colors he used for this painting make it a masterpiece. Many of the other paintings in the exhibition were for me more like nightmares than dreams.
titleopinion: Good Exhibition About Surrealism. The Thyssen was having an exhibition called Surrealism and the Dream. I did not realize that there were so many artists who specialized in surrealism until I saw this exhibition, which was very educational. For me the best painting in the exhibition was the one done by Dali, called Dream caused by the Flight of the a Bee around a Pomegranate a Second before Waking Up. The colors he used for this painting make it a masterpiece. Many of the other paintings in the exhibition were for me more like nightmares than dreams.

reviewnospace:
See this museum first or as your only museum in Madrid. I love art and I sometimes exhaust myself trying to see too much in the time I have. I never felt rushed here nor did I have to wait longto see any particular work

Very nice collection. Easier to take in than the Prado. The pictures are hung at a comfortable height for viewing. I could get very close to some of the 14th century works and enjoy the details.
The school groups were quiet with no show-boating teachers.

The collection is extensive but not exhausting. There was some confusion on our part about our admission time. We didn't know we were supposed to see the controlled section first.

Plan to dine in there. The food is wonderful

reviewnospace: This is a really fine collection of art from all over the world. Never thought before that private collection may have such a wide range in time and style, among them a 1-st rate world art masterpieces of Rogir van der Veiden, Hans Memling, Rafael, Ghirlandaio, Holbein, Durer, Caravaggio, Murillo, El-Greco not to mention splendid collections of French, American and Russian modern art. It is a pity I had to see it all at once, If I could I would rather split visits into more than one to enjoy this works of art consecutively.

quote: An Array of Centuries of Art
reviewnospace: This Museum was a delight. I was at the Prado on Monday morning. Then split for lunch and went to this museum. It is free Monday 12p-4p Many museums are closed but this and the Prado are not and this one is free on Monday. I enjoyed the variety of art. There was some American artists( Whistler, Bierstadt,etc) Many famous painting by Jan Van Eyke, ( The Annunciation Diptych ca. 1433-1435), El Greco, Monet etc... On the web site you can look into each room and visit each painting and it is described. It is done very well. This site is not all up to date since some painting are on loan when you visit. I like the way they displayed their art from medieval in one area then modern in another. I started on the top floor and worked my way down. This went well for me since the modern art is on the lower level. I do not particularly like modern art. I did not find it as noisy as the Prado. The wall color makes it feel more modern and inviting not like an old building. Enjoyed my stay and did not need all the free 4 hours but if I liked the modern art I could have stayed the full time.

The cafe could be better. It is to expensive for the quality

reviewnospace: A spectacular art collection from 15 century to modern, from various European and a few american artists, impeccably organized in a beautiful building. reviewnospace: I visited this third on the list after seeing both Prado and Sofia in previous days. Walking into the foyer is a breath of fresh air as are the galleries. The walls are not as cluttered as the other two, so it is easier to enjoy the works without feeling overwhelmed and art saturated. Highly recommend this gallery. The collection is amazing, especially post impressionist and German expressionist. And there are seats to rest on through the spaces, unlike the other two big galleries.

quote: one of the best museums in the world
reviewnospace: thussen bornemisza hosts one of the most precious art collections in the world. From Dutch golden age painters to surrealists like Magritte, pop-art from roy lichtenstein, it has it all. The building is beautiful itself as well, and on mondays you can even visit the permanent collection for free! what more can you want? My favourite paintings: Prison, by Tatiana Glebova, Metropolis by George Grosz, paintings by Margritte. Hiring an audio guido for €4 is worth wile...

The Thyssen has a terrific collection of paintings, with a real focus on portraiture. If you only plan to 'do' one gallery or museum in Madrid then I would probably recommend the Reina Sofia to see Guernica but that's because I love modern art and no-one should miss seeing that. But it's a perfectly pleasant way to spend an afternoon.

If you're from the UK, don't miss the famous portrait of Henry VIII - it's tiny!

titleopinion: Come see the Surrealists.. Lives in the shadow of The Prado, but deserves the same status for the moderns represented their. You can walk it from The Prado if you have any legs and feet left for it.

reviewnospace: I liked the actual surrealism exhibition about dreams. It is quite surrealistic sometimes. The speakers on the headphones though could do with less music and make surrealism more approachable.
titleopinion: Surrealism exhibition. I liked the actual surrealism exhibition about dreams. It is quite surrealistic sometimes. The speakers on the headphones though could do with less music and make surrealism more approachable.

reviewnospace: This is a stunning building in a really nice area. The works are presented really well and worth the visit.
titleopinion: Great museum; beautifully presented. This is a stunning building in a really nice area. The works are presented really well and worth the visit.

quote: interesting show on sleep and dreams!
reviewnospace: The exhibit I saw was very interesting. The museography was very professional. I learned a lot! The building is impressive too. Close to the Prado museum, but it is not a good idea to do both on the same day, as El Prado is so overwhelming.
titleopinion: interesting show on sleep and dreams!. The exhibit I saw was very interesting. The museography was very professional. I learned a lot! The building is impressive too. Close to the Prado museum, but it is not a good idea to do both on the same day, as El Prado is so overwhelming.

reviewnospace: We went here first when we arrived in Madrid and I was blown away. Fantastic collection of known artist and obscure artist, I was so impressed I didn't want to leave.
titleopinion: Don't miss this museum!. We went here first when we arrived in Madrid and I was blown away. Fantastic collection of known artist and obscure artist, I was so impressed I didn't want to leave.

reviewnospace:
The museum has a huge collection, from bizantine paintings to modern Catalan school, plenty of Picasso and Miró, chronologically organized, in its 3 floors.
Besides arts, it also has an outstanding cafeteria and a well assorted shop.
Reserve at least 2-3 hours for a fast browsing tour.
titleopinion: Impressive collection. The museum has a huge collection, from bizantine paintings to modern Catalan school, plenty of Picasso and Miró, chronologically organized, in its 3 floors.  Besides arts, it also has an outstanding cafeteria and a well assorted shop. Reserve at least 2-3 hours for a fast browsing tour.

reviewnospace:
Through serendipity, we were lucky enough to visit the museum when they had a Pissarro exhibition. As a big fan of impressionist art and a fan of Pissarro, I was thrilled to have this opportunity to see so many fabulous pieces in one place.

In addition, the permanent collection contains some great works by many impressionists, as well as classical artists. We spent at least 4 hours in the museum and left happy and exhausted.
titleopinion: Great collection. Through serendipity, we were lucky enough to visit the museum when they had a Pissarro exhibition. As a big fan of impressionist art and a fan of Pissarro, I was thrilled to have this opportunity to see so many fabulous pieces in one place.  In addition, the permanent collection contains some great works by many impressionists, as well as classical artists. We spent at least 4 hours in the museum and left happy and exhausted.

quote: Complete history of art in one building
reviewnospace: Still find it difficult to understand how one individual can have built up such a fabulous collection. Start at the top & work your way down through the history of art from the early times (14th / 15th century) right up to the present day, with some real gems. Sadly ran out of time so disappointed not to be able to see the "Surrealism & The Dream" exhibition, but well worthwhile (oh, and there's a also lovely little café!).
titleopinion: Complete history of art in one building. Still find it difficult to understand how one individual can have built up such a fabulous collection. Sadly ran out of time so disappointed not to be able to see the  Surrealism & The Dream  exhibition, but well worthwhile (oh, and there's a also lovely little café!).

reviewnospace: An overview of art from the 13th century to the late 20th century. More than 1600 paintings. Was initially a private collection.
titleopinion: Incredible collection. An overview of art from the 13th century to the late 20th century. More than 1600 paintings. Was initially a private collection.

reviewnospace: For many, the Thyssen will be a more enjoyable experience than the Prado. The crowds are smaller and the art is more varied. We were there 3 hours (we had lunch i the dining room, good but pricey) and still left without making it to the third floor. We loved it and will return.
titleopinion: An Amazing Collection. For many, the Thyssen will be a more enjoyable experience than the Prado. The crowds are smaller and the art is more varied. We were there 3 hours (we had lunch i the dining room, good but pricey) and still left without making it to the third floor. We loved it and will return.

reviewnospace:
we saw the temporary surrealism show and had lunch in the museum cafe. the food was very tasty but the price was high.
the show was excellent. many different surrealistic painters were displayed. there were also a couple of very interesting surrealistic moviesthat were continuously running.
titleopinion: surrealism. we saw the temporary surrealism show and had lunch in the museum cafe. the food was very tasty but the price was high.  the show was excellent. many different surrealistic painters were displayed. there were also a couple of very interesting surrealistic moviesthat were continuously running.

reviewnospace: Lovely small museum, not crowded, very well arranged, an eclectic collection. This museum is what you would love about small museums. Each person has time to take in each painting and then compare periods to others because the paintings are arranged in chronological order. Some amazing works are housed here. Excellent book shop with very helpful clerk.

reviewnospace: This is by no means comparable to the Prado, but it's equally interesting. This is a small museum, even the works are smaller in size. And, also important, it's not as crowded as the Prado is!
titleopinion: Great Experience. This is by no means comparable to the Prado, but it's equally interesting. This is a small museum, even the works are smaller in size. And, also important, it's not as crowded as the Prado is!

reviewnospace: This tiny gem houses a permanent collection that is varied, and the peculiarity of it's "house" sized works, spanning several centuries, up to the 20th. The temporary exhibitions have been superb, this last one, "Surrealism and The Dream" definitely the best so far. An afternoon well spent, don't miss it.
