reviewnospace:
it is wonderful museum!Much less people than Parado!You can see all very good examples of big masters!
if you are in Madrid if do you like or not please visit here!
you will have great time!
titleopinion: Great Museum!. it is wonderful museum!Much less people than Parado!You can see all very good examples of big masters! if you are in Madrid if do you like or not please visit here! you will have great time!

reviewnospace: Excellent to learn the history of paintings. From the medieval works to modern art, the museum's collections cover it all.
titleopinion: Excellent. Excellent to learn the history of paintings. From the medieval works to modern art, the museum's collections cover it all.

reviewnospace: Wonderful museum where you can see 8 centuries of art under one roof. The first part is my favorite where the flamish school is present with great art pieces. I do not fancy very much the contemporary art at the end of the tour but recognize it is very rich.
titleopinion: Perfect location in Madrid. Wonderful museum where you can see 8 centuries of art under one roof. The first part is my favorite where the flamish school is present with great art pieces. I do not fancy very much the contemporary art at the end of the tour but recognize it is very rich.

reviewnospace: Very good collection, mix of old masters and later works including Picasso, Miro, Monet. My favourites were Kandinsky and van Gogh. Surprisingly, they also have some American art like Rothko and Pollock. There is a lovely shop and great two-floor cafe. Would recommend to have a lunch on the terrace once the viewing is done.
titleopinion: Great museum + shop + cafe. Very good collection, mix of old masters and later works including Picasso, Miro, Monet. My favourites were Kandinsky and van Gogh. Surprisingly, they also have some American art like Rothko and Pollock. There is a lovely shop and great two-floor cafe. Would recommend to have a lunch on the terrace once the viewing is done.

reviewnospace: Give yourself time here but don't take your break in the Thyssen's cafe. It's awful. The art is stunning, eclectic and testimony to the uncommon bond between wealth and taste. I'll let guide books and others describe what you'll see but it's rightly among the Big Three in Madrid: Prado, Reina Sofia and Thyssen.
titleopinion: Stunning. Give yourself time here but don't take your break in the Thyssen's cafe. It's awful. The art is stunning, eclectic and testimony to the uncommon bond between wealth and taste. I'll let guide books and others describe what you'll see but it's rightly among the Big Three in Madrid: Prado, Reina Sofia and Thyssen.

reviewnospace: Wonderful museum. Liked it better than the Prado. No crowds, easy to see exhibits and wonderful information posted on each work of art
titleopinion: Art-ful Dodgings. Wonderful museum. Liked it better than the Prado. No crowds, easy to see exhibits and wonderful information posted on each work of art

reviewnospace: We loved spending a late afternoon there. The audio guides were helpful. The surrealism exhibit was very worthwhile and don't miss their regular collection. It's a funky space with a most sublime atmosphere and the gift store is a treat. I highly recommend spending time at this museum as well as the Prado.
titleopinion: Beautiful physical location and exhibits. We loved spending a late afternoon there. The audio guides were helpful. The surrealism exhibit was very worthwhile and don't miss their regular collection. It's a funky space with a most sublime atmosphere and the gift store is a treat. I highly recommend spending time at this museum as well as the Prado.

reviewnospace: I first walked to Prado Museum and upon looking at the long lines of people at the ticket counter, decided to skip it and focus on the Thyssen-Bornemisza museum across the road instead. Boy, was it a good decision! Instead of hoards of people, i had the time and pleasure of browsing artworks in relative peace. It contained the works of several artists i admire - Rothko, Munch, Edward Hopper, Kandinsky. Several pieces were moved from the permanent collection to a special exhibition but it did not detract from the wonderful experience i had there. It's not too big, so you can easily cover it in 2 to 2 1/2 hours. Totally worth your time.
titleopinion: Had a great time here!. I first walked to Prado Museum and upon looking at the long lines of people at the ticket counter, decided to skip it and focus on the Thyssen-Bornemisza museum across the road instead. Boy, was it a good decision! Instead of hoards of people, i had the time and pleasure of browsing artworks in relative peace. It contained the works of several artists i admire - Rothko, Munch, Edward Hopper, Kandinsky. Several pieces were moved from the permanent collection to a special exhibition but it did not detract from the wonderful experience i had there. It's not too big, so you can easily cover it in 2 to 2 1/2 hours. Totally worth your time.

reviewnospace: This is a much smaller, less crowded museum than the Prado. Interesting collection of European Art and some American artists. Unusual German Expressionist collection.
titleopinion: Lovely collection of European Art. This is a much smaller, less crowded museum than the Prado. Interesting collection of European Art and some American artists. Unusual German Expressionist collection.

reviewnospace: We'd heard of Spain's Triangle of Art (the Prado, the Reina Sofia and the Thyssen-Bornemisza). Of course, we had to visit the Prado as it's de rigeur for any visitor to Madrid, but in my humble opinion, if you have even the most fleeting appreciation of art and have limited time, this is THE place to go in Madrid. The artists represented here leave you in awe - from Gilbert Stuart (yes, our Gilbert Stuart) to Picasso, Renoir, Goya, Cezanne, Manet and the (impressive) list goes on and on. And they're displayed in spacious rooms with high ceilings and walls painted a pastel pink which somehow works. Each work of art is afforded sufficient space around it such that you can take each one in individually. Rarely has our entire family been so impressed both with the content as well as the architecture (both the interior and the exterior) of a museum. Go! Allow for at least several hours or much longer if your schedule permits and/or you are a true fan of world class art. Bravo!
titleopinion: An amazing collection beautifully presented. We'd heard of Spain's Triangle of Art (the Prado, the Reina Sofia and the Thyssen-Bornemisza). Of course, we had to visit the Prado as it's de rigeur for any visitor to Madrid, but in my humble opinion, if you have even the most fleeting appreciation of art and have limited time, this is THE place to go in Madrid. The artists represented here leave you in awe - from Gilbert Stuart (yes, our Gilbert Stuart) to Picasso, Renoir, Goya, Cezanne, Manet and the (impressive) list goes on and on. And they're displayed in spacious rooms with high ceilings and walls painted a pastel pink which somehow works. Each work of art is afforded sufficient space around it such that you can take each one in individually. Rarely has our entire family been so impressed both with the content as well as the architecture (both the interior and the exterior) of a museum. Go! Allow for at least several hours or much longer if your schedule permits and/or you are a true fan of world class art. Bravo!

reviewnospace: Wonderful, eclectic collection. Light on the Christian mythology paintings and strong on the more secular masters. We actually enjoyed this more than the Prado.
titleopinion: Great Museum. Wonderful, eclectic collection. Light on the Christian mythology paintings and strong on the more secular masters. We actually enjoyed this more than the Prado.

quote: The most beautiful collection in Madrid
reviewnospace:
If you aren't into old masters and older paintings The Thyssen Museum really is the place to be!
You can find the most beautiful collection of expressionism like Kandinsky and Miro and impressionism like Monet and so on.

I really love this museum and would recommend it to all art-lovers!
titleopinion: The most beautiful collection in Madrid. If you aren't into old masters and older paintings The Thyssen Museum really is the place to be! You can find the most beautiful collection of expressionism like Kandinsky and Miro and impressionism like Monet and so on.  I really love this museum and would recommend it to all art-lovers!

reviewnospace: Really good selection of paintings, I personally preferred the modern art but they had a good mixture on display. Went on a Monday as entrance was free which was ideal if you are travelling on a budget however it also meant that it was crowded. Definitely worth a visit.
titleopinion: Good Selection of Art. Really good selection of paintings, I personally preferred the modern art but they had a good mixture on display. Went on a Monday as entrance was free which was ideal if you are travelling on a budget however it also meant that it was crowded. Definitely worth a visit.

location: El Puerto de Santa Maria, Spain
reviewnospace: Went to a temporary exhibition called "Surrealism and the Dream". It was amazing, with so many wonderful, thought-provoking artworks and even short films. An excellent museum, also very modern.
titleopinion: Beautiful place. Went to a temporary exhibition called  Surrealism and the Dream . It was amazing, with so many wonderful, thought-provoking artworks and even short films. An excellent museum, also very modern.

reviewnospace:
The most beautiful collection of art is to be found in the Thyssen Museum!
Old masters and modern artists are gathered in one big building - with paintings from Kandinsky to Monet. I think this is the most beautiful museum of Madrid!
titleopinion: Most beautiful collection. The most beautiful collection of art is to be found in the Thyssen Museum!  Old masters and modern artists are gathered in one big building - with paintings from Kandinsky to Monet. I think this is the most beautiful museum of Madrid!

reviewnospace: While nearby Prado might have more appeal this is a stunning site in its own right. Wide collection of European masters and, at the time of our visit, a glimpse into the world of Surrealism via a special exhibition. Good crowd control and a very well maintained building.
titleopinion: Excellent must-see visit. While nearby Prado might have more appeal this is a stunning site in its own right. Wide collection of European masters and, at the time of our visit, a glimpse into the world of Surrealism via a special exhibition. Good crowd control and a very well maintained building.

reviewnospace: This is a gem of a museum, a very well curated collection of art from 1300 to the present days. Because it is so well curated, you can thoroughly enjoy it, more than typical museums where the art is acquired by different curators with different tastes and interestes. Just make sure you plan you visit well, it's a very big collection and all of it is beautiful. My advice is to either visit on two days (there are two floors, so you can do one each day) or split the visit with a break in the excellent bar/restaurant of the museum.
titleopinion: 7 centuries of art history. This is a gem of a museum, a very well curated collection of art from 1300 to the present days. Because it is so well curated, you can thoroughly enjoy it, more than typical museums where the art is acquired by different curators with different tastes and interestes. Just make sure you plan you visit well, it's a very big collection and all of it is beautiful. My advice is to either visit on two days (there are two floors, so you can do one each day) or split the visit with a break in the excellent bar/restaurant of the museum.

reviewnospace: I think this museum is the most overlooked in Madrid, with Prado and Reina Sofia getting more traffic, but it was my favorite. I found the collection to be the most well-rounded and exciting, but it depends what type of art appeals to you. Only downside was they loan a LOT of their art out to special exhibits in other cities. So if you are going to see a particular piece, be aware it may be elsewhere. Highly recommend. But the 3 museum pass and save yourself money!
titleopinion: Loved this museum. I think this museum is the most overlooked in Madrid, with Prado and Reina Sofia getting more traffic, but it was my favorite. I found the collection to be the most well-rounded and exciting, but it depends what type of art appeals to you. Only downside was they loan a LOT of their art out to special exhibits in other cities. So if you are going to see a particular piece, be aware it may be elsewhere. Highly recommend. But the 3 museum pass and save yourself money!

reviewnospace: The layout is a little confusing because the main collection and that of Mrs. T-B are somewhat intertwined. If you like landscapes and impressionists, don't miss her collection. It was all wonderful to see. Another feast for the eyes. If you buy an art pass you can save money and see this, the Prado, and the Reina Sofia at a reduced price with no standing in line, plus the pass is good for a year.
titleopinion: Amazing private collection. The layout is a little confusing because the main collection and that of Mrs. T-B are somewhat intertwined. If you like landscapes and impressionists, don't miss her collection. It was all wonderful to see. Another feast for the eyes. If you buy an art pass you can save money and see this, the Prado, and the Reina Sofia at a reduced price with no standing in line, plus the pass is good for a year.

reviewnospace:
Great collection of art covering from 14 th Century to 21st.
A liitle confusing as the collection really starts on the Top floor. Would be better if the staff in each room were a little more approachable and less interested in chatting.
titleopinion: Fantastic Collections. Great collection of art covering from 14 th Century to 21st. A liitle confusing as the collection really starts on the Top floor. Would be better if the staff in each room were a little more approachable and less interested in chatting.

reviewnospace: Enjoyed very much. I'm not an expert on art, so the audio was great! We spent 2 hours, but I would recommend longer...cut it short to meet up with our son!
titleopinion: Recommend. Enjoyed very much. I'm not an expert on art, so the audio was great! We spent 2 hours, but I would recommend longer...cut it short to meet up with our son!

reviewnospace: While it might not offer the very best or most famous paintings of well known artists - it does offer a varied plate from Renoir to Homer to Lichtenstein. Give it a couple of hours and enjoy!
titleopinion: A Gem. While it might not offer the very best or most famous paintings of well known artists - it does offer a varied plate from Renoir to Homer to Lichtenstein. Give it a couple of hours and enjoy!

reviewnospace: A private collection turned over to the public, it was a spectacular trove of centuries of great art.
titleopinion: Wonderful treasure in Madrid. A private collection turned over to the public, it was a spectacular trove of centuries of great art.

reviewnospace: I really enjoyed the are works on display here and was very happy witty the content overall, but I found myself very frustrated with the layout and flow of the museum. We were constantly backtracking ourselves and I think we probably missed a few sections out of frustration and exhaustion. There was no natural flow or directional signage to help and you would get to the end of the section only to find the stairs down to the next level were roped off and so you had to go back the way you came. It could have been done a lot better. Many pieces had a small poster photograph with information on it to tell you the piece was on loan, or being cleaned or something. It would be interesting to know exactly how many original artworks we didn't get to see. I enjoyed the artwork that was on display and would go again, I just think as one of the top three museums in Madrid they have quite a lot that can be improved upon.
titleopinion: A Little Bit Confusing. It would be interesting to know exactly how many original artworks we didn't get to see. I enjoyed the artwork that was on display and would go again, I just think as one of the top three museums in Madrid they have quite a lot that can be improved upon.

reviewnospace: Almost didn't go to this museum as we had spent the previous day in the Prado but Im so glad that I did. I got to see some of my favourite pieces of art. Its really amazing to see them up close. I think it would be impossible to name a famous artist without finding one of their iconic pieces in this gallery!
titleopinion: My favorite museum in Madrid. Almost didn't go to this museum as we had spent the previous day in the Prado but Im so glad that I did. I got to see some of my favourite pieces of art. Its really amazing to see them up close. I think it would be impossible to name a famous artist without finding one of their iconic pieces in this gallery!

reviewnospace:
The Thyssen-Bornemisza museum isn't as big as national museums but it provides a very good overview of the development and evolution of western art. The museum is actually divided into two sections: the Thyssen-Bornemisza museum and the Carmen Thyssen-Bornemisza collection. visitors sometimes get confused with the way the rooms are organized because in a way some of the works overlap in terms of artistic development.

However it is a wonderful museum and the restaurant serves very good food.
titleopinion: Small but powerful. The Thyssen-Bornemisza museum isn't as big as national museums but it provides a very good overview of the development and evolution of western art. The museum is actually divided into two sections: the Thyssen-Bornemisza museum and the Carmen Thyssen-Bornemisza collection. visitors sometimes get confused with the way the rooms are organized because in a way some of the works overlap in terms of artistic development.   However it is a wonderful museum and the restaurant serves very good food.

quote: If its not at the Prado, it's here.
reviewnospace: Though there is a healthy selection of 19th century stuff and lots of 20th century art, what the T-B has is what the Prado does not - French, American, cubist, modern, and more. Photographs are allowed without flash, and the crowds are smaller here than the Prado. Still, one could spend 3 hours here with little effort. First rate examples of Picasso, Magritte, Mondrian, Klee, Bierstadt, Hopper, Shiele, Shahn, Chagall, and more. All in a former palace thoroughly remodeled as a gallery.
titleopinion: If its not at the Prado, it's here.. reviewnospace:
We are not the biggest art fans but enjoyed the variety in the collection.
Not so sold on the salmon pink walls though!
titleopinion: Interesting collection. We are not the biggest art fans but enjoyed the variety in the collection.  Not so sold on the salmon pink walls though!

reviewnospace: We went to this art museum while there was an exhibition of surrealist art. Wonderful. Really worth a visit and the exhibition was the icing on the cake.
titleopinion: Bonus. We went to this art museum while there was an exhibition of surrealist art. Wonderful. Really worth a visit and the exhibition was the icing on the cake.

quote: Best of the three biggest galleries
reviewnospace: Out of the big three art galleries in Madrid; the Prado, the Reina Sofia and this one, I preferred this. True it doesn't have Guernica but it does have a more select and wider range of paintings. It also is the easiest to navigate being clearly marked and with galleries more logically arranged.
titleopinion: Best of the three biggest galleries. Out of the big three art galleries in Madrid; the Prado, the Reina Sofia and this one, I preferred this. True it doesn't have Guernica but it does have a more select and wider range of paintings. It also is the easiest to navigate being clearly marked and with galleries more logically arranged.

reviewnospace:
As it was part of the combo-mueseum tickets i bought ( Prado - Reina Sofia - Thyssen) I didn't expected too much of it. But for those who likes art, it is a very interesting museum. With over 1,600 paintings the Thyssen-Bornemisza collection was once the second largest private collection in the world after the British Royal Collection.
I regret I was very tired so I did not spend too much time inside it, so in some galleries I only passed trough the arts.

I recommend not to visit it on same day of visiting any other museum.

reviewnospace: This museum was described in our guide book as "filling in the holes left by the Prado." To me it was much more than that. Although clearly smaller than the Prado, I enjoyed the variety. And there was less religious themed art. It's hard to believe this was once a private collection!
titleopinion: Spectacular Museum!. This museum was described in our guide book as  filling in the holes left by the Prado.  To me it was much more than that. Although clearly smaller than the Prado, I enjoyed the variety. And there was less religious themed art. It's hard to believe this was once a private collection!

reviewnospace: We spent several hours here looking at the paintings and felt it was good value for money. It was quite hard to do the whole museum in one visit as one's brain gets a bit overloaded but needs must! We saw the Surrealism and the Dream exhibition too. We had visited the Prado 2 days before and found the Thyssen to be complementary to the Prado. The only thing that was a bit disappointing is that several of the paintings were on loan to other exhibitions - including some of the more 'special' ones. The Renoir 'Woman with a Parasol' was my absolute favourite. The cafe was good too - the terrace area is very relaxing.
titleopinion: Culture. We spent several hours here looking at the paintings and felt it was good value for money. The Renoir 'Woman with a Parasol' was my absolute favourite. The cafe was good too - the terrace area is very relaxing.

reviewnospace: I loved being able to photograph the art that I came here to see. Very relaxed atmosphere. Beautiful, moving art. Perfection. I only wish they offered free hours at the end of the day.
titleopinion: Best Museum. I loved being able to photograph the art that I came here to see. Very relaxed atmosphere. Beautiful, moving art. Perfection. I only wish they offered free hours at the end of the day.

quote: Visit Thyssen as the first of the 'big three'
reviewnospace:
Thyssen has a wider range of art than Prado and Reina Sofia, from old masters to modern to pop-art. This is why Lonely Planet thinks this a good museum to visit first if you do not usually look at art, so you can see where your interests lie. Another good reason to visit this one first is that the lines at the ticket queues are smaller here than at the other two. So if you want to buy the combo ticket for the big three art museums, go here first. Then you don't have to line up at all at Prado and Reina Sofia.

All in all a great collection of art and I recommend a visit if you have time. If you are short of time and like old masters go to Prado first though!
titleopinion: Visit Thyssen as the first of the 'big three'. Thyssen has a wider range of art than Prado and Reina Sofia, from old masters to modern to pop-art. This is why Lonely Planet thinks this a good museum to visit first if you do not usually look at art, so you can see where your interests lie. Another good reason to visit this one first is that the lines at the ticket queues are smaller here than at the other two. So if you want to buy the combo ticket for the big three art museums, go here first. Then you don't have to line up at all at Prado and Reina Sofia.  All in all a great collection of art and I recommend a visit if you have time. If you are short of time and like old masters go to Prado first though!

reviewnospace: The museum has an excellent collection of pieces spread over three floors, ranging from early late 13th century paintings to abstract art masterpieces from the 20th century. Admission is free from 12 to 4 pm on Mondays, so go then to avoid the 9 euro per person admission charge. The cafe is a nice place to stop for a snack, although it is quite expensive even by Madrid standards.
titleopinion: Excellent, wide-ranging museum. The museum has an excellent collection of pieces spread over three floors, ranging from early late 13th century paintings to abstract art masterpieces from the 20th century. Admission is free from 12 to 4 pm on Mondays, so go then to avoid the 9 euro per person admission charge. The cafe is a nice place to stop for a snack, although it is quite expensive even by Madrid standards.

quote: Wonderful collection and I love the orange walls

quote: Of more general interest than the Prado!
reviewnospace: This was a fantastic gallery and I really enjoyed my visit. They had a wide range of artistic styles and periods and for someone who likes, but is not tremendously knowledgeable about / enthusiastic about art it provided the right amount of information and left you feeling you had had value for money, seen and learnt something, but not been bored! It was well laid out so you could ensure seeing everything and staff were friendly and helpful. The shop was a little understaffed, but had an interesting selection of souvenirs and gifts, including postcards of many of the paintings and specially-commissioned jewellery inspired by particular artworks.

reviewnospace: Do take time to see this gem of a museum with paintings that you would not normally get to see. The impressionist paintings are wonderful.
titleopinion: Gems. Do take time to see this gem of a museum with paintings that you would not normally get to see. The impressionist paintings are wonderful.

reviewnospace: We had purchased the 3 museum pass, but had not planned on visiting this one. Toward the end of our stay in Madrid we found ourselves with some spare time so we decided, on a fluke, to check it out. With a metro stop only a short walk away, it is easy to find. We went mid-afternoon and found no waiting lines and no crowds to speak of. Best yet, we only encountered one tour group! The museum presents a unique opportunity to see art as it progresses through time from the 13th and 14th century on to present. Three of my personal favorites of all the work we saw in all of the museums that we visited in Spain were in this museum. Sadly, many of the Impressionist paintings were on loan, but that happens sometimes. I would encourage anyone to visit here. It is a museum where one can spend hours or just one hour and still see plenty.

reviewnospace: This modern and well set out gallery has a comprehensive range from medieval sacred art to modern pops. We specially enjoyed the collection of Dutch masters. The cafe is excellent too.

reviewnospace: On our visit there was a surrealist exhibit ongoing - it had a few Dali masterpieces and I loved it! It had staggered entry times, which I thought was a great idea - giving you enough space to see and ponder. The permanent exhibit was great too, It's purpose built, airy, cool and never allowed to get to crowded. You can get a pleasant coffee and good service in their cafe too.

reviewnospace: Everyone always talks about the Prado, but this museum is absolutely world-class. The breadth of the art here is amazing - Rembrandt, Monet, Degas to Bierstadt, Sargent, Church, to Picasso, O'Keeffe, Kandinsky. Definitely a must-see in Mdrid!!

reviewnospace:

The museum is well organized, easy to tour with a very nice, modern restaurant of good quality and price.
The museum entry fee is very reasonable.

reviewnospace: You can actually experience this museum in one visit although it's worth a lot more time. Starting with religious art and Flemish painters on the top floor to the Hudson School and impressionists on the middle floor to modern artists on the ground, this museum has a wonderful collection that includes painters usually missing or overlooked in other collections, especially in Europe. The Guide is informative and worth purchasing. Preferred T-B to the Prado.

quote: For me the best of the 3 great galleries in Madrid
reviewnospace:
Very well laid out with an enticing range of exhibits covering the centuries of art. Neither too much nor too little. I especially enjoyed the Impressionist era and most if not all the great artists of the period were shown.
Good comfortable facilities with a coffee bar and restaurant with good food for lunch. Don't rush any of the experience.

reviewnospace:
Went there at around 3pm and there was no line at all. We are able to go straight in to the exhibition starting from the top floor. It was a wonderful experience. A lot of the more famous art museums in Europe are always fairly crowded, but this was definitely not.

We had a great time exploring and contemplating different artworks, many of which are very interesting. Some are also works from the great masters. Above all, it was great that the works can be appreciated and enjoyed without hustling around the usual tourist crowds.

quote: Not the Prado or the Reina Sofia, but still!
reviewnospace:
The Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum, while some guide books put it in a distant third place from the Prado and the Reina Sofia, was still worth it to me. A distant third from the first two is not to damn it, as the first two are clearly world-class museums. Rick Steves writes that the Thyssen-Bornemisza houses second-class works by first-class painters, and while this may be true in most cases, to see a “second-class” painting by Picasso, such as his Harlequin with Mirror” or a beautiful portrait by John Singer Sargent of, gives me great pleasure.

The other interesting aspect to this museum is that it contains solid work from Medieval Italian painters straight through to the cartoons of Roy Lichstenstein and the haunting visions of Francis Bacon. So it’s a fine trip through much history of western art.

Unless your stay in Madrid is a very short one, I'd definitely include this museum. And if you want to see all three, check out the Paseo del Arte pass, which will save you some money if you are certain you'll visit this as well as the Prado and Reina Sofia.

The other interesting aspect to this museum is that it contains solid work from Medieval Italian painters straight through to the cartoons of Roy Lichstenstein and the haunting visions of Francis Bacon. So it’s a fine trip through much history of western art.   Unless your stay in Madrid is a very short one, I'd definitely include this museum. And if you want to see all three, check out the Paseo del Arte pass, which will save you some money if you are certain you'll visit this as well as the Prado and Reina Sofia.

It's comfortably laid out and apart from a few noisy groups of school children was a relaxing and enjoyable morning.

The new restaurant has a relaxed atmosphere and is a good place to have a rest between floors. The museum has a shop with many gadgets which are expensive as all museum shops are. The museum has a wheelchair facility if you do not bring your own chair.

quote: The BEST museum in Madrid. Period.
reviewnospace:
Forget the Prado and the Reina Sofia.
This museum is SO much superior to both of them.
The museum is based on the collection of Baron Heinrich Thyssen-Bornemisza and his son, Hans Heinrich.
It is located in a beautiful 18th century building called Villahermosa Palace.
The collection includes numerous pieces from the entire history of Western art – from classical to impressionism (14th-20th centuries).
To fully enjoy the museum, allow yourself at least 3 hours of explorations in its stunning three floors.
Free for MadridCard holders.
titleopinion: The BEST museum in Madrid. Period.. Forget the Prado and the Reina Sofia. This museum is SO much superior to both of them. The museum is based on the collection of Baron Heinrich Thyssen-Bornemisza and his son, Hans Heinrich. It is located in a beautiful 18th century building called Villahermosa Palace. The collection includes numerous pieces from the entire history of Western art – from classical to impressionism (14th-20th centuries). To fully enjoy the museum, allow yourself at least 3 hours of explorations in its stunning three floors. Free for MadridCard holders.

quote: one of the best art museums
reviewnospace: I go to galleries and museums regularly but this was, in my opinion, one of the best I have been to and I could easily return. This is the private collection acquired by the Thyssen-Borenmisza family and then passed to the State in 1993. It spans a period from late 13th century (with the usual religious icons and a collections of paintings with religious overtones which start on the top floor (level 2) and build up through Italian and Flemish & Dutch painters including El Greco, Titian, Rubens, Rembrandt and Carvaggio through the Carmen T-B collection of paintings from the 17th-19th century impressionists. On the first floor are artists from Europe and America between the 17th century and the early 20th century including Monet, Renoir, Degas. Hopper and Gris. Finally on the ground floor are 20th century artists including Kandinsky, Dali, Picasso Bacon & Lichtenstein. A total of around 70 rooms and you could easily spend all day here if you had an interest in the development of Western Art, My only gripe is that quite a few of the paintings were out on loan to other exhibitions but I guess this is inevitable. There are audio guides, some facilities for disabled visitors, a café, shop, cloakroom (all backpacks to be left here) and enough toilets. Personally I preferred this to the Prado but personal choice of paintings (more modern stuff) probably played a large part in this

reviewnospace: We have visited the Prado museum in the past but wanted something different and were not disappointed. There is a wide variation of art on display on 3 floors and all organised chronologically. Thought we would spend an hour or two but were there for over 5 hours! A couple of tips: make sure you start from the top (2nd) floor as these are the earliest paintings, also it is well worth paying 4€ for an audio guide. Lots of useful information both on individual painting and the various collections.

quote: Very interesting, many positives, and few negatives
reviewnospace:
Positives: relatively cheap fee 8 euros per person
Free admission 7-9pm.... I highly recommend that
Well organized chronologically
Crash course in art in a span of a thousand year
You can take photos without flash
Negatives: it is a private collection; you are limited to what the donor collected
Very few paintings to famous artists
All of my favorite artist C. Pissarro's paintings were removed for preparation of exhibits and re-examination; it could have been nice if they just left one painting for his artist!

Pissarro's paintings were removed for preparation of exhibits and re-examination; it could have been nice if they just left one painting for his artist!

reviewnospace: Buy your Paseo del Arte covering Madrid's three leading art galleries at the Thyssen and begin your artistic journey here. The collection is arranged chronologically, with representative works complementing those in the Prado. You can view every painting close up and linger over your favourites, without being pressured by crowds. A Madrid must see - fabulous!

You can view every painting close up and linger over your favourites, without being pressured by crowds. A Madrid must see - fabulous!

reviewnospace: The Thyssen museum is the output of Spain purchasing an entire private art collection spanning 700+ years. Some amazing pieces across this building. Recommend purchase of the Paseo del Arte pass which gets you access to Prado, Thyssen and Reina Sofia.

quote: great place to start the tour of the three art museums
reviewnospace:
We picked up our art pass here, gets you into the big three art museums with no more queues.

This is well laid out and has some lovely art works. We hit the second floor and worked our way down

As with all of the three there is too much to see, so we focused on what we might like and dipped in here or there

Allow 2 hours minimum, good shop at end

reviewnospace: No queue to enter. No crowds inside. Can get up close to the art. A brilliant collection. Highly recommended!

reviewnospace: magnificent collection is well displayed and quite complete. Try the rooftop restaurant for a pleasant lunch break.

reviewnospace: Whether you are into Jackson Pollock or Degas, the Thyssen Museum is for you. Roughly divided into centuries, each floor has examples of great art, and there is something here for everyone. Getting up close to Bailarina Basculando (Leaning Ballerina) by Degas was a high point for me. So much so I bought the poster in the extremely well-stocked shop. There's a fantastic restaurant on top now, too, so you don't need to faint with hunger at all that art-viewing.

Roughly divided into centuries, each floor has examples of great art, and there is something here for everyone. Getting up close to Bailarina Basculando (Leaning Ballerina) by Degas was a high point for me. So much so I bought the poster in the extremely well-stocked shop. There's a fantastic restaurant on top now, too, so you don't need to faint with hunger at all that art-viewing.

quote: Perfect museum for a taste of many artists
reviewnospace: This is a perfect museum to see one or a few works of art by a large number and range of artists. In this museum, photography is permitted. The special exhibit was Pissaro, an artist who is not often featured and there were a huge number of artworks amassed for the exhibition.

reviewnospace: Be prepared for a long day there are many great pieces. Check for special free entry days or times. Carmen has collected a wide variety of types of art and believes it should be shared with the public.

quote: We'll worth spending a few hours here!

quote: Another excellent Art museum in Madrid
reviewnospace: All the major European artists up to the 19th and early 20th century are represented. Again there is a lot to see but one can be selective according to taste. Frankly there is not much that one can give up from seeing!
titleopinion: Another excellent Art museum in Madrid. All the major European artists up to the 19th and early 20th century are represented. Again there is a lot to see but one can be selective according to taste. Frankly there is not much that one can give up from seeing!

reviewnospace: We were pleasantly surprised by the lack of crowds, affording us a leisurely wander through the Pissarro exhibition which was a delight of light and colour, as well as the wonderful standing exhibition with brilliant works of so many luminaries. The Museo has a pleasant scale and feel to it, the staff are helpful discreet and polite. The cafe outside is also an asset to the overall ambience, nicely set back from the Paseo del Prado. Easily accessed by its central location, we walked along from the Dali at the Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofia so all and all a delightful day.

reviewnospace: You might consider this to be the Spanish version of the Musée d'Orsay as it houses some of the great works of the Impressionist and post Impressionist movement like Monet, Renoir, Degas and Van Gogh.
titleopinion: For the art lover. You might consider this to be the Spanish version of the Musée d'Orsay as it houses some of the great works of the Impressionist and post Impressionist movement like Monet, Renoir, Degas and Van Gogh.

reviewnospace:
It has a really comprehensive collection of paintings from painters all over the world.
I particularly like the fact that you can get really close to them to examine the artist's brushstrokes. I also love being able to take photographs of them.
The exhibition is organized over three floors and it is quite easy to negotiate, unlike the Prado.
There is lots of space and I never felt crowded or had to wait too long to examine any painting in detail.
It is free to visit on Mondays from 12:00 to 16:00.
titleopinion: Wonderful!!!. It has a really comprehensive collection of paintings from painters all over the world. I particularly like the fact that you can get really close to them to examine the artist's brushstrokes. I also love being able to take photographs of them. The exhibition is organized over three floors and it is quite easy to negotiate, unlike the Prado. There is lots of space and I never felt crowded or had to wait too long to examine any painting in detail. It is free to visit on Mondays from 12:00 to 16:00.

quote: If you only visit one gallery in Madrid make it this one.
reviewnospace: I enjoyed the way this collection is chronologically displayed, and the range of different artists from the Pre Impressionists, Impressionists, Post Impressionists, Fauvists and so on. There are works from the well known impressionists and also some less well known artists from Spain and North America. The range of work is truly amazing.

reviewnospace: Impressive collection just steps away from the mother lode at the Prado but not as overwhelming nor crowded. The museum is very pleasant and of a manageable size and chocked full of wonderful works. Agree with other reviewers admonishment not to do both in same day

reviewnospace: Great collections of modern art very nicely arranged. I trully enjoyed Hoper's pieces and some Dali masterpieces! The best Museum shop in Madrid. (probably the best in Spain!)
titleopinion: Amazing museum. Great collections of modern art very nicely arranged. I trully enjoyed Hoper's pieces and some Dali masterpieces! The best Museum shop in Madrid. (probably the best in Spain!)

reviewnospace:
In many ways I found this collection more accessible and fulfilling than the Prado. There are some amazing masterpieces and the collection is a credit to the Thyssen-Bornemisza family.

It is a more relaxing experience than the Prado and galleries are logically and well laid out.

reviewnospace: If you love art you HAVE to see this museum as its collection is so good, I'm surprised it's not more well known. It should be mentioned right after the Prado when talking about Madrid. The list of artists is endless: Munch, Kandinskji, Kokoschka, Klee, Monet... I spent hours in there and I would love to go back, I enjoyed it more than the Prado!

reviewnospace: Visited for a morning and found the museum quite easy to find and navigate. Stunning works of art as to be expected. Pleased that we did not attempt to visit the Prado the same day.
titleopinion: A well worth visit. Visited for a morning and found the museum quite easy to find and navigate. Stunning works of art as to be expected. Pleased that we did not attempt to visit the Prado the same day.

quote: Perhaps the best single large art gallery collection on the planet? Astounding that it was gathered by one family.
reviewnospace: This is an astonishing collection, by far the best in Madrid, unless you are obsessed by the Spanish core of the Prado, and perhaps the best single large art gallery display on the planet? The range, from early Italian and northern European painting right through to major modern artists is extraordinary, as is the quality. Reminds one of the Frick in New York, only on a far larger scale. It appears the collection was assembled with some care, and includes some unusual aspects like some American artists. The display space in the building is first class, as was the cafe near the entrance. Our visit was enhanced even more by two marvellous current exhibitions, one on Pissarro and a fascinating smaller one room show on use of mirrors in paintings. Lastly the museum website is first class.
titleopinion: Perhaps the best single large art gallery collection on the planet? Astounding that it was gathered by one family.. Lastly the museum website is first class.

reviewnospace: Most impressive collection of paintings from 14th century to contemporary works housed in beautful modern museum. Unmissable.
titleopinion: Stunning collection. Most impressive collection of paintings from 14th century to contemporary works housed in beautful modern museum. Unmissable.

reviewnospace: This gallery showcases both old and newer art, so having viewed a fair amount of impressionists, ranging from Monet to Gauguin, I then stumbled into some moderner more abstract works by Picasso, Miro and even Rothko. A great place for a novice like me, and free on Mondays too. there was also a lovely Pissaro exhibition on when we visited.

reviewnospace:
Visited the museum during a long weekend in Madrid. The museum is included in the Madrid card.

The museum was less busy than the Prado and had a very relaxed, laid back atmosphere. The collection is really amazing-a great collection of work including many current artists! A great place to visit. My personal favourite of all the great Madrid collections.

reviewnospace: The museum is smaller than the Prado but is less crowded and easier to walk around. The art was beautiful and I found a couple of artists I really like who's work I was familiar with.

reviewnospace: wonderful open style contemporary museum with lots of opportunity to view a well curated selection of masters and modern pieces
titleopinion: wonderful contemporary style museum. wonderful open style contemporary museum with lots of opportunity to view a well curated selection of masters and modern pieces

reviewnospace: The Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum is a place you can take the whole family to see art without it being painful. The art is nicely displayed in rooms that have space for everyone to walk and enjoy the art. It is big enough to be extremely impressive that most of this collection began as a family collection, yet small enough that you are not asking yourself when you will get to the end of it. They have some beautiful pieces from the 19th and 20th century not to be missed. After visiting this museum, you can reward yourselves to a drink in the outdoor café / terrace which is sheltered from the sun and allows you to enjoy the view from up above while sitting comfortably sipping your drinks.

quote: If you have time, check it out

Thyssen-Bornemisza, just accross El Prado, offers a more recent work of arts than El Prado, which allows you to check out some works of Picasso among with dutch, american, french and italian painters from century XIX and XX. Cubism, realism and others can be appreciated here, but if you are not a big fan of abstract arts, there is also very beautiful paintings.

They allow you to make photos without Flash, which is very good. Check the free entry on the website: normally on Monday (no queue when I went)

reviewnospace: I loved the small, cozy feel of this museum and I liked the way it progressed from older to more modern art as you worked your way from the top floor to the bottom. I enjoyed seeing the less well known work of some famous artists as well as great works from some less known artists.

reviewnospace: I took advantage of the free hours and wasn't sure what to expect, but I was very impressed. It covers a wide range of art genres, from the middle ages to modern day. The famous artists such as Rembrant, Manet, Renoir, Monet, Canaletto are all there, although the paintings are not generally famous, they are still well worth seeing. I really enjoyed this museum. It is very well laid out, if a little spread out.

reviewnospace:
A trip to Madrid is incomplete without a trip to el Museo Thyssen-Bornamiza. The Pissarro exhibit (79 of his works) was enthralling and the audio tours provided a lesson in pointillism that equalled any art history course.

Also on display: Monet, Gauguin, Lichnenstein, Rembrandt, Modigliani, Picasso, Renoir, ... The Baron & Baroness' collection was vast. Reserve a half day for this visit.

quote: If you have to choose, go to the Prado...but try to go here as well!
reviewnospace: Madrid is so lucky to have two such excellent Museums so close to each other. Any museum with Canalettos is wonderful but this has so much more including some interesting early American landscapes. But I confess I am not a fan of religious icons or whacky modern art so some of the exhibits left me cold. But this is largely a personal collection and its eclectic nature is part of its enjoyment. Do go. But if you don't have time for the Thyssen and the Prado - then go to the Prado!
titleopinion: If you have to choose, go to the Prado...but try to go here as well!. Madrid is so lucky to have two such excellent Museums so close to each other. Any museum with Canalettos is wonderful but this has so much more including some interesting early American landscapes. But I confess I am not a fan of religious icons or whacky modern art so some of the exhibits left me cold. But this is largely a personal collection and its eclectic nature is part of its enjoyment. Do go. But if you don't have time for the Thyssen and the Prado - then go to the Prado!

reviewnospace: Well. The Thyssen-Bronemisza has it's peculiar origin, initiated by a collection of Thyssens father. There was a long lasting dispute whether the collection would be 'entrusted' to Germany or Spain, but in the end, Ms Bornemiza used her talent to see to it that the works stay in Spain, before her husband passed away, Two flashy paintings can be 'admired' at the entrance hall, in which the couple are meant to evoke an aristocratic aura, whereby Ms Bronamiza's waistline can be said to be seen as a highlight. Overall the collection is well selected, especially from its past proprietor. The temporary exhibits are of great interest (Dali, Monet and a surely worthwhile Pissaro exhibit is to take place). Well worth a visit.
titleopinion: By all means visit. Well. The Thyssen-Bronemisza has it's peculiar origin, initiated by a collection of Thyssens father. There was a long lasting dispute whether the collection would be 'entrusted' to Germany or Spain, but in the end, Ms Bornemiza used her talent to see to it that the works stay in Spain, before her husband passed away, Two flashy paintings can be 'admired' at the entrance hall, in which the couple are meant to evoke an aristocratic aura, whereby Ms Bronamiza's waistline can be said to be seen as a highlight. Overall the collection is well selected, especially from its past proprietor. The temporary exhibits are of great interest (Dali, Monet and a surely worthwhile Pissaro exhibit is to take place). Well worth a visit.

quote: Not Reina Sofia but impressive none the less
reviewnospace: I was more than impressed at the size and quality of this private collection. The building and the collection therein is well laid out. It is not as repetitive and enormous as the Prado or as specific as Reina Sofia but it is a nice spot to spend an afternoon seeing art from every major artist of the last mellenium. Impressive and worth the visit.
titleopinion: Not Reina Sofia but impressive none the less. I was more than impressed at the size and quality of this private collection. The building and the collection therein is well laid out. It is not as repetitive and enormous as the Prado or as specific as Reina Sofia but it is a nice spot to spend an afternoon seeing art from every major artist of the last mellenium. reviewnospace: Do not miss this incredibly wide collection of the Thyssen-Bornemisza. From the Middle Age to Modern art, there are masterpieces for every taste. You will not regret to have been there. For me the best museum in Madrid
titleopinion: What an amazing collection!. Do not miss this incredibly wide collection of the Thyssen-Bornemisza. From the Middle Age to Modern art, there are masterpieces for every taste. You will not regret to have been there. For me the best museum in Madrid

quote: I wish I had gone here before Prado
reviewnospace:
I ended up liking this better than Prado. The art stretches from about the 1300s to basically present day, yet the museum as a whole is a manageable size. Lots of nice stuff to see.

I bought the Paseo del Arte card for about 24 euros. If I had been able to make it to all 3 main art museums in Madrid, it would have been worth it. Unfortunately, this one was cheaper than I expected. I think it was around 10 to get in, 15 to get in and see the special exhibit, and 10 to see just the special exhibit (not included with the Paseo card). Since the Prado was about 14 to get in, the 10 entrance fee to get in here made me break even, but I didn't want to spend 10 more on top of it to see the special exhibit. On the other hand, you don't have to wait in ticket lines once you get the Paseo card, so that's nice.

quote: Excellent permanent collection and interesting temporary exhibitions
reviewnospace: The museum is not that large so you can see the entire main collection and the temporary exhibitions on the lower ground floor are normally very well presented and interesting. There is also a nice shop and a cafeteria in the garden area where you can reste tired feet after getting to know the sights of Madrid.

reviewnospace: Loved it! Many different styles of art to cater for all tastes. When I visited there was a Cartier exhibition which was amazing! For the museum itself I would leave approximately half a day to see everything. Clean, friendly staff, nice gift shop and a beautiful building.
titleopinion: Something for all artistic tastes. Loved it! Many different styles of art to cater for all tastes. When I visited there was a Cartier exhibition which was amazing! For the museum itself I would leave approximately half a day to see everything. Clean, friendly staff, nice gift shop and a beautiful building.

reviewnospace:
After visiting the El Prado and the Reina Sofia, i have to say that the Thyssen is the best of Madrid.
What a fantastic colection of paintings, for me even better than the other two musems. Not so huge than the prado and so much easyer to navigate and enjoy the art. Visited for free on a monday from 12h to 16h and you can take as much pictures as you want (no flash) unlike the other too with so many foolish restrictions. Don´t miss this one!

quote: What a gem of a Museum
reviewnospace:
This museum is not to be missed
If you go on a mon between 12-4pm it's free.
There are paintings from every period
titleopinion: What a gem of a Museum. This museum is not to be missed If you go on a mon between 12-4pm it's free. There are paintings from every period

reviewnospace:
This is not a generic museum in the sense that it is devoted to the art of painting. In its sphere it has an extensive collection cutting across all genres. Almost all the great masters across the different schools are present. If paintings are your poison then this is the motherlode. I wasmlucky to catch the Pissaro exhibition which was the icing on the cake!

I also liked the building and the way the exhibits are set up. Kudos to the administration. Location wise it is also very convenient. Some very nice showrooms selling local ceramics close by too.

reviewnospace: Comprehensive collection covering many centuries of paintings and samples of most major artists' works from medieval to modern times
titleopinion: Great art gallery, fantastic collection. Comprehensive collection covering many centuries of paintings and samples of most major artists' works from medieval to modern times

reviewnospace: Take you time through all the galleries. This is a fantastic collection of art from around the world. Definitely will return!
titleopinion: A must see in Madrid. Take you time through all the galleries. This is a fantastic collection of art from around the world. Definitely will return!

reviewnospace:
First off, the entrance to the Thyssen is remarkable. Secondly, I love audio guides when I visit museums because it enhances the experience and I definitely recommend renting the audio guide.

We had already visited El Prado and Reyna Sofia and we were getting a little burnt on museums. We thought we'd be satisfied with just a couple hours but it was not enough time. We spent nearly two hours viewing cubism. Budget plenty of time and enjoy!

reviewnospace:
It worth the visit always. Great art collection.
Five minutes walk from El Prado art museum.
Up to September 15, there's a Pissarro exposition.
titleopinion: Great art collection. It worth the visit always. Great art collection. Five minutes walk from El Prado art museum. Up to September 15, there's a Pissarro exposition.

reviewnospace: very unique collection in a beautiful setting. The Museum is very close to the Prado Museum, so you can make a day of it by visiting both on the same day
titleopinion: Very Unique. very unique collection in a beautiful setting. The Museum is very close to the Prado Museum, so you can make a day of it by visiting both on the same day

quote: One of the best museums in Madrid
reviewnospace: The Thyssen is my idea of a perfect museum. The temporary expositions are excellent, but most important the permanent collection can be seen in 1 1/2 - 2 hours, which is perfect. You are not bombarded with too much art - after which point you can't really appreciate any of it (Stendhal syndrome). The collection is varied and complete, and quite impressive, including artists from all over. The other museums (Prado and Reina Sofia) are also wonderful, but the Thyssen is special. (I live in Madrid so this opinion is based on many visits)
titleopinion: One of the best museums in Madrid. The Thyssen is my idea of a perfect museum. The temporary expositions are excellent, but most important the permanent collection can be seen in 1 1/2 - 2 hours, which is perfect. You are not bombarded with too much art - after which point you can't really appreciate any of it (Stendhal syndrome). The collection is varied and complete, and quite impressive, including artists from all over. The other museums (Prado and Reina Sofia) are also wonderful, but the Thyssen is special. (I live in Madrid so this opinion is based on many visits)

reviewnospace: It`s alway a good idea visit it...the museum is located in one of Madrid best Areas......Resturants, bars, pubs...the area is called Barrio de las Letra ¡¡¡¡
titleopinion: Fantastic Afternoon. It`s alway a good idea visit it...the museum is located in one of Madrid best Areas......Resturants, bars, pubs...the area is called Barrio de las Letra ¡¡¡¡

reviewnospace: The building used to be a residence of some nobility and was converted into a privately-run gallery by famous Spanish architect Moneo in order to house the Baron Thyssen's collection, sold to Spain in the eighties.The building houses the collection of late Baron Thyssen and also houses the private collection of his widow Carmen, which is hung in an attached wing. You'll have access to both collections with the same ticket. There are not as many paintings as in The Prado Gallery, but the quality of the paintings is generally excellent and you will get to have a glimpse on the history of painting from the primitive italians of the 11 century all the way up to pop-art. I also like the fact that the Gallery usually has far less visitors than the Prado and the rooms are much quieter. Also, the lighting and the quality of the rooms seem to be much better. They usually have a couple of interesting temporary exhibitions. You can buy either a separate ticket or a combined ticket for the main collection and the exhibitions. It is advisable to book and pay your ticket on the internet at no extra charge, and collect it at a separate counter of the Gallery desk.
titleopinion: Excellent Gallery. The building used to be a residence of some nobility and was converted into a privately-run gallery by famous Spanish architect Moneo in order to house the Baron Thyssen's collection, sold to Spain in the eighties.The building houses the collection of late Baron Thyssen and also houses the private collection of his widow Carmen, which is hung in an attached wing. You'll have access to both collections with the same ticket. There are not as many paintings as in The Prado Gallery, but the quality of the paintings is generally excellent and you will get to have a glimpse on the history of painting from the primitive italians of the 11 century all the way up to pop-art. I also like the fact that the Gallery usually has far less visitors than the Prado and the rooms are much quieter. Also, the lighting and the quality of the rooms seem to be much better. They usually have a couple of interesting temporary exhibitions. You can buy either a separate ticket or a combined ticket for the main collection and the exhibitions. It is advisable to book and pay your ticket on the internet at no extra charge, and collect it at a separate counter of the Gallery desk.

quote: A family legacy of Art and the Love of Art
reviewnospace: A stunning venue, close to many other art venues and architectural wonders. The relationship and engagement of the Thyssen family, their devotion to all forms of art and the challenges your eyes and heart face when on a visit, is truly inspiring.
titleopinion: A family legacy of Art and the Love of Art. A stunning venue, close to many other art venues and architectural wonders. The relationship and engagement of the Thyssen family, their devotion to all forms of art and the challenges your eyes and heart face when on a visit, is truly inspiring.

reviewnospace: really nice, a lot of Picasso and other big names. I till think Prado and Reina Sofia are better, though. Mondays 12-4pm for free
titleopinion: Thyssen-Bornemizsta. really nice, a lot of Picasso and other big names. I till think Prado and Reina Sofia are better, though. Mondays 12-4pm for free

reviewnospace: We visited the museum on our short break to Madrid last week. Unfortunately this was the only big gallery that we had time to visit, but the collection is very good, apart from the strange colour chosen for the walls, a type of terracotta that doesn't really complement lots of the works. Personally I was taken by the Caravaggio and Holbein works, but unfortunately we had to leave before we could see the second half of the museum. We went on Monday afternoon when the permanent exhibitions are free to visit, but be warned that the museum closes at 4, so arrive early (unlike us!) in order to enjoy the whole gallery. All the big galleries in Madrid (including the Prado and Reina Sofia) are also free to visit between 6-8 every evening, but judging by the queue outside the Reina Sofia when we tried to benefit from this, this is a very busy time to go!
titleopinion: Excellent collection. We visited the museum on our short break to Madrid last week. reviewnospace: This a private collection of art housed over three floors. There is also normally a special collection on show - currently Camille Pissarro - which is extra to get in. The variety of paintings is impressive covering many centuries of time from Old Masters through to modern Cubism & Pop Art. The displays are quite easy to follow via the museum map although the descriptions could have been more detailed. It seems many of the paintings are out on loan so you get to look at a poster on the wall instead. Whilst we got to see many original famous paintings the visit lacked the atmosphere of our time at the Prado museum which is just across the road.
titleopinion: Impressive collection of art. This a private collection of art housed over three floors. There is also normally a special collection on show - currently Camille Pissarro - which is extra to get in. The variety of paintings is impressive covering many centuries of time from Old Masters through to modern Cubism & Pop Art. The displays are quite easy to follow via the museum map although the descriptions could have been more detailed. It seems many of the paintings are out on loan so you get to look at a poster on the wall instead. Whilst we got to see many original famous paintings the visit lacked the atmosphere of our time at the Prado museum which is just across the road.

reviewnospace: Even if you don't know much about art you'll recognise the names here - all the famous artists and more.
titleopinion: all the greats. Even if you don't know much about art you'll recognise the names here - all the famous artists and more.

reviewnospace:
The best modern art collection in Madrid, with some powerful pieces from the most significant impressionists, cubists, and a lot more.
If you love modern painting, this is the #1 place to see in Madrid.

It is not huge, so it is easily seen in a morning or afternoon (at least a 3 hour visit).
It's allowed to take pictures (but no flash, obviously) and almost every room has a central stool where you can enjoy the wonderful art and rest for a while. If you're on a budget, take advantage of the free entrance on Mondays afternoon.
titleopinion: You must visit this one!. The best modern art collection in Madrid, with some powerful pieces from the most significant impressionists, cubists, and a lot more. If you love modern painting, this is the #1 place to see in Madrid.  It is not huge, so it is easily seen in a morning or afternoon (at least a 3 hour visit). It's allowed to take pictures (but no flash, obviously) and almost every room has a central stool where you can enjoy the wonderful art and rest for a while. If you're on a budget, take advantage of the free entrance on Mondays afternoon.

reviewnospace: This museum shows you a collection from the early gothic religious art till the modern artist in the 1960's. That is unique. A great experience if you want to see how artists in all centuries have inspired each other.
titleopinion: A unique collection. This museum shows you a collection from the early gothic religious art till the modern artist in the 1960's. That is unique. A great experience if you want to see how artists in all centuries have inspired each other.

quote: really enjoyed! you can take pictures
reviewnospace:
This may sound silly, but I really like having pictures of works of art I see. I was pleasantly surprised you could take photos here - just obviously without flash.

There's plenty of modern art, but have rooms of other types of art as well. I enjoyed the Monet and Degas pieces most, I think.

I only browsed the museum for around 45 minutes because we came close to its closing time, but I felt like it was enough time because I didn't get an audio guide so I just wandered around the rooms, finding the pieces I liked the most. Very relaxing trip!

Go to the museum when it's free (I know this museum is free the least amount of time, so ask a place with tourist information - I went to the tourist stand in the plaza/ park by the post office) but get there half an hour early, because there will be a line.

quote: Works of art from world renown artists
reviewnospace: Loved the layout: 2nd floor contains Primitive through 19th century works such Hans Holbein's Portrait of Henry VIII of England ( the attention to details is breathtaking). The first level housed 17th century Dutch paintings through Neo-Dada and Pop Art. They also have a nice café!

reviewnospace: I enjoyed this museum, but it was more modern art, but - I 'm not much for modern art. I did broaden my horizons viewing this museum though.
titleopinion: Modern Museum. I enjoyed this museum, but it was more modern art, but - I 'm not much for modern art. I did broaden my horizons viewing this museum though.

reviewnospace: The collection is amazing and arranged chronologically, so you can see the different periods of art and how they changed over time.
titleopinion: Lovely museum. The collection is amazing and arranged chronologically, so you can see the different periods of art and how they changed over time.

reviewnospace: A great alternative (or supplement) to El Prado. There's no questioning the stunning array of art at El Prado, but I think it's fair to call it's collection narrow and deep. The collection at Thyssen takes a different approach, which I think would be best labeled as broad but shallow (not in a negative manner). There is an incredible array of art that covers many different styles, artists and time periods. To think that this was a private collection at one point is tough to comprehend. The current Pissarro exhibit is worth the price of admission.
titleopinion: Great array of art. A great alternative (or supplement) to El Prado. There is an incredible array of art that covers many different styles, artists and time periods. To think that this was a private collection at one point is tough to comprehend. The current Pissarro exhibit is worth the price of admission.

reviewnospace: Cosy atmosphere, friendly staff. Very good exhibition: some contemporary, a lot of expressionistic works. Not so crowded, so you don't need to buy tickets in advance.
titleopinion: Small but great. Cosy atmosphere, friendly staff. Very good exhibition: some contemporary, a lot of expressionistic works. Not so crowded, so you don't need to buy tickets in advance.

reviewnospace: Wonderful collection! Such a variety and is worth visiting. Many key paintings in the collection which is hard to see and find in museums such as Egon Schiele and Lucian Freud. Gave me inspiration to do art.
titleopinion: World class art museum. Wonderful collection! Such a variety and is worth visiting. Many key paintings in the collection which is hard to see and find in museums such as Egon Schiele and Lucian Freud. Gave me inspiration to do art.

quote: A Wonderful Art Museum- Up There with the Best
reviewnospace: We visited Madrid on the last leg of a 10 day trip to Spain. We had seen lots of museums and cathedrals, so we were a little burned out on art. Wow- I would have been so sad if I had missed the Thyssen. The galleries are wide and there are lots of benches to sit and observe the art. The crowds were very light when we visited late in the day. The variety of paintings is fabulous. Flemish masters to modern art. Beautiful American landscapes which I was so surprised to see in a Spanish museum. A Pisarro Exhibition was going on when we visited which was worthwhile to see. I would rank this up there with the Musee DÓrsay. If you have a choice, skip the Reina Sophia and go to the Thyssen.

The galleries are wide and there are lots of benches to sit and observe the art. The crowds were very light when we visited late in the day. The variety of paintings is fabulous. I would rank this up there with the Musee DÓrsay. If you have a choice, skip the Reina Sophia and go to the Thyssen.

quote: Probably amazing works of art, but could not get past the horrid color on the walls.
reviewnospace: This museum may be incredible, and if you are a serious fan of art, then please disregard this review. However, if you are like me, and enjoy perusing the paintings, this museum may not be for you. The walls are all painted a hideous color, kind of a salmon color, that actually clashes with just about every painting, and the lay out of the museum is completely monotonous. I could not wait to get out of there.

reviewnospace: I only have the chance to see the Pisarro exhibition, (10 euro), but it was worth it. the rest of the rest of the museum is close on Monday. It is free from 1 pm to 4 pm the rest of the days.

quote: Jaw - dropping - but do they have to have those terrible portraits in the lobby!
reviewnospace: Outstanding collection of the best and of every era, - something for every art lover in a building that is a pleasure to stroll around, - plan several trips, - the Pisarro exhibition was a real education and happy to see some of his best on loan from Glasgow.

reviewnospace: We were fortunate to visit on a Monday, when the museum is free....we did pay to see the Camille Pisarro exhibit. The museum is open, cool and inviting. The collection is arranged by style and era, as one would expect. We did nit visit the restaurant. I had never been to this museum on previous visits....and I will return....

The museum is open, cool and inviting. The collection is arranged by style and era, as one would expect. We did nit visit the restaurant. I had never been to this museum on previous visits....and I will return....

quote: Combines two of my favorite things - great art and equally great food
reviewnospace:
Before visiting other museums in Madrid, do this one. Wonderful art, comfortable layout, and friendly staff. The only gripe we had was the Caravaggio room. Caravaggio is right at the top of my list of favorite artists, so you can imagine my excitement to find an entire room dedicated to him. We finally found it, only to discover that there was only one Caravaggio painting in the entire room. Because of that, If the rest of the museum weren't so stunning, this review would have been quite different.
To assuage my dashed anticipation of the Caravaggio room, we headed for the museum restaurant. The lady at the next table had the largest, best looking hamburger I've ever seen, so I ordered one just like it. It came with a huge order of French fries. It truly was the best hamburger and fries I've had in a long time. So, the so called Caravaggio room was soon forgotten, and we left knowing that we had seen one of the best art museums anywhere.
