reviewnospace: This is a great museum! From the artwork to the coffee shop, it's a wonderful and serene place to spend couple of hours and unwind from the hustle and bustle of the city.
titleopinion: Wonderful museum!. This is a great museum! From the artwork to the coffee shop, it's a wonderful and serene place to spend couple of hours and unwind from the hustle and bustle of the city.

quote: Go here before Prado. More "accessible" collection for many people.
reviewnospace:
While the throngs head directly to the Prado in the morning, I strongly recommend going to the Thyssen first. The museum presents more of an overview of the many periods in European and Spanish art with a fairly good audio guide. Until early June there is an OUTSTANDING exhibit of hyperrealism works by artists like Richard Estes. It is a heavily American art movement and the best exhibit of its kind I have ever seen. Again, the audio guide is very good.

What is so terrific here, is that as you go through the museum, you will develop "favorites" among the artists and genres. You will also not be exhausted in the way the Prado can make you. When you are done, you grab a bite to eat and recharge before heading to the Prado. Once at the Prado in the afternoon, the lines will have shortened, the crowds thinned and dispersed more and the overall level of sanity will have vastly improved. Having established certain favorites at the Thyssen you can head for those areas of the Prado first. That way you will have see what you really wanted to before getting too tired.

We had the stamina to thoroughly do both museums in one day. For those who think museums aren't really their thing, then the Thyssen is a more contained and "edited" collection of outstanding works and may provide a better overall experience than the overwhelming Prado collection.

reviewnospace: The Thyssen had an exhibition of Impressionism and Open Air Painting. There were three Van Gogh paintings and the one I liked best was the Hospital of St. Remy, which was very beautiful and very colorful. Other Van Gogh paintings were Corn Fields and Poppies, and Landscape Under a Stormy Sky, also very good. There was a Monet called View of Bennecourt, which I also enjoyed.

There were three Van Gogh paintings and the one I liked best was the Hospital of St. Remy, which was very beautiful and very colorful. Other Van Gogh paintings were Corn Fields and Poppies, and Landscape Under a Stormy Sky, also very good. There was a Monet called View of Bennecourt, which I also enjoyed.

reviewnospace: It had a more interesting and eclectic collection. The wife, Carmen, who apparently convinced her husband to gift the collection to Madrid, had a better eye for art in my opinion, and the works shown in her collection are significantly better.
titleopinion: Better Than Expected. It had a more interesting and eclectic collection. The wife, Carmen, who apparently convinced her husband to gift the collection to Madrid, had a better eye for art in my opinion, and the works shown in her collection are significantly better.

reviewnospace:
The museum hosts different exhibits throughout the year so be sure to check what is on when you visit.

There were impressionism and hyperrealism exhibits on when my husband and I visited.

Tickets are bought in combinations for the main museum and visiting exhibits, which if your planning on seeing everything can be costly.

I particularly enjoyed the hyperrealism exhibit and thought it was well laid out.

Beautiful place, worth a visit.

I particularly enjoyed the hyperrealism exhibit and thought it was well laid out.  Beautiful place, worth a visit.

reviewnospace: Everyone who visits Madrid visits the Prado at one point or another. Just down the street from the Prado is another first class collection of European paintings. The Thyssen-Bornemisza family collected fabulous art including Dutch, Italian, French and of course, Spanish masters for decades and has made this collection available to the public. This collection is very large and stunning, containing some of world's most famous paintings. Don't pass this museum up. Go on a Tuesday - free admission- around 2 pm when the long line has already entered.

With an astounding collection of masters from all over Europe. My favorite pieces, with the exception of some German Expressionism, a Degas, and many other unforgettable pieces, I truly enjoy the section of the museum that is still held by Carmen, with Renoir, Winslow Homer, Degas, Van Gogh, Van Eyck, the list of masters goes on. Definitely a museum that needs to be visited while in Madrid. And it is conveniently located on the Paseo del Prado, right across the street from the famous Museo del Prado.

reviewnospace: this gallery does allow non flash photography. It is well set out and easy to follow..starting with the oldest paintings first and ending with the newest paintings. Like all personal collections it will have some very good artwork by artists who are not so well known and a lighter focus on some of the more well known artists elsewhere. That said it was a delight to walk through. The collection is very broad in its scope both in time period ( italian primitives till today) and artists from a wide variety countries. We enjoyed it more than the Prado and much more than Reina Sofia.
titleopinion: A very good gallery. this gallery does allow non flash photography. It is well set out and easy to follow..starting with the oldest paintings first and ending with the newest paintings. reviewnospace: Went to see the Hyper Realism exhibit, the Impressionists- Open Air Painting and the Interior Scenes - Women in Daily Life exhibits. All wonderful in their own way as is the permanent collection which is quite extensive. Pricey, they charge for each (2 exhibits and permanent separately). The restaurant offers a nice respite.
titleopinion: From Impressionist to Modern. Went to see the Hyper Realism exhibit, the Impressionists- Open Air Painting and the Interior Scenes - Women in Daily Life exhibits. All wonderful in their own way as is the permanent collection which is quite extensive. Pricey, they charge for each (2 exhibits and permanent separately). The restaurant offers a nice respite.

quote: A real jewel- not to be overlooked!
reviewnospace: Many tourists leave the Thyssen museum for last- after they have seen the other museums. That's great for those of us who live here, it means shorter lines to get in! Apart from having one of the most amazing permanent collections in Madrid, the temporary exhibits always have so much to offer. We never tire of going and frequent the Thyssen every month or so. The permanent collection has everything from Renaissance through Impressionism to 20th century! Plan on a few hours: take a coffee break halfway through so you don't get overwhelmed.
titleopinion: A real jewel- not to be overlooked!. Many tourists leave the Thyssen museum for last- after they have seen the other museums. That's great for those of us who live here, it means shorter lines to get in! Apart from having one of the most amazing permanent collections in Madrid, the temporary exhibits always have so much to offer. We never tire of going and frequent the Thyssen every month or so. The permanent collection has everything from Renaissance through Impressionism to 20th century! Plan on a few hours: take a coffee break halfway through so you don't get overwhelmed.

reviewnospace:
It is an absolutely top art gallery, more balanced, and in a sense more interesting than Prado. Even if you are one day in Madrid, that's still an absolute must. The portrait collection, with its marvellously representative XV--XVI centuries, might well be the best in the world. The very first room of that collection, with Robert Campin, van der Weyden, Memling, Lucas van Leyden, Domenico Ghirlandaio, Holbein, etc., etc., etc., is breathtaking.
Overall, early Italian, German and Flemish collections, Carpaccio, Duerer, and all, are simply FANTASTIC. This collection as a whole, including XX century art, shows immaculate artistic taste.
The newer part of the museum, the Carmen Thyssen-Bornemisza collection, is pathetic, in comparison. Some parts of it, like the XIX century American art, modern Spanish, etc., etc., are of purely ethnographic interest. Skip them all, if you do not have enough time.
If you spend more hours in the museum, as I did, you might wish to use the cafeteria. It is a bit overpriced, but has decent food and exquisite selection of wines.
titleopinion: An absolutely top art gallery. It is an absolutely top art gallery, more balanced, and in a sense more interesting than Prado. Even if you are one day in Madrid, that's still an absolute must. The portrait collection, with its marvellously representative XV--XVI centuries, might well be the best in the world. The very first room of that collection, with Robert Campin, van der Weyden, Memling, Lucas van Leyden, Domenico Ghirlandaio, Holbein, etc., etc., etc., is breathtaking. Overall, early Italian, German and Flemish collections, Carpaccio, Duerer, and all, are simply FANTASTIC. This collection as a whole, including XX century art, shows immaculate artistic taste. The newer part of the museum, the Carmen Thyssen-Bornemisza collection, is pathetic, in comparison. Some parts of it, like the XIX century American art, modern Spanish, etc., etc., are of purely ethnographic interest. Skip them all, if you do not have enough time. If you spend more hours in the museum, as I did, you might wish to use the cafeteria. It is a bit overpriced, but has decent food and exquisite selection of wines.

quote: Comprehensive, chronological collection of Western Art
reviewnospace:
This museum has rooms dedicated to nearly every major form of Western Painting, beginning in the 12th and 13th centuries. While it lacks any specific breathtaking masterpieces, it does a great job of showing how many great painters fit into the progression of the art form in Europe and later North America.

It's well worth a few hours for an art fan or someone who wants to learn more.
titleopinion: Comprehensive, chronological collection of Western Art. This museum has rooms dedicated to nearly every major form of Western Painting, beginning in the 12th and 13th centuries. While it lacks any specific breathtaking masterpieces, it does a great job of showing how many great painters fit into the progression of the art form in Europe and later North America.  It's well worth a few hours for an art fan or someone who wants to learn more.

reviewnospace: Great small museum with some interesting exhibitions. Perfect for a one hour getaway. Poor museum store and slow and expensive restaurant.
titleopinion: Value for money. Great small museum with some interesting exhibitions. Perfect for a one hour getaway. Poor museum store and slow and expensive restaurant.

reviewnospace:
Collection of Thyssen-Bornemisza is from 2 parts: old one, and new one, that Carmen T.-B. ollected with classical and modern artists paintings (constructivists, dadists,...) including Shagal, Goncharova, Kandinsky.
Currently, very interesting temporary exhibition of impressionists from other museums is there including some van Gogh works.

quote: A Very Comfortable Place to See Art
reviewnospace: This museum complements the Prado (It is across the street) and has a diverse, interesting collection. This was a very easy museum to visit in that it felt quite spacious and could be viewed at a leisurely pace. The artwork was part of two private collections so the selection of art also seems more focused and personal. Set aside about three hours for a good overview.

quote: Great for Impressionist and Post-Impressionist pieces
reviewnospace: Lots of pieces from those periods, lots of Degas, some Renoir, Monet, etc. Some cool modern stuff too like Picasso, Pollock that I was familiar with but a whole bunch of others that I was not that I really enjoyed (the last 2-3 rooms of the exhibit I thought were especially compelling). But to each his own, art of course is very much in the eye of the beholder and I thought the Thyssen had a nice mix of periods and styles that would appeal to all on some level

reviewnospace: The Thyssen is a Madrid must see. It is a very well run, private museum with works of art from many different periods, including contemporary. It is a managable size and less crowded than the Prado. It contains an exceptional collection of artwork and hosts traveling exhibits such as Cartier, Van Gogh, etc. (check online for what is visiting and book tickets in advance).

reviewnospace: A must in Madrid. Key artwork pieces. Varied. Well placed. Brilliant location. Interesting temporary expos.

quote: Best of the three major museums
reviewnospace:
I found this to be the most interesting of the three major Madrid galleries. It is nowhere near as extensive or prestigious as the Prado, but works as a complete collection and is not too large to be able to see everything in one visit. The works were all displayed in chronological order that demonstrated the evolution of artistic techniques in Western painting. The collection includes examples from many of the greatest names, although not necessarily their best or most famous pieces. The main collection is complemented by a smaller collection of landscapes (the Carmen collection) that are exhibited alongside.

Buy a combined ticket for all three museums to avoid having to queue three times.
titleopinion: Best of the three major museums. I found this to be the most interesting of the three major Madrid galleries. It is nowhere near as extensive or prestigious as the Prado, but works as a complete collection and is not too large to be able to see everything in one visit. The works were all displayed in chronological order that demonstrated the evolution of artistic techniques in Western painting. The collection includes examples from many of the greatest names, although not necessarily their best or most famous pieces. The main collection is complemented by a smaller collection of landscapes (the Carmen collection) that are exhibited alongside.   Buy a combined ticket for all three museums to avoid having to queue three times.

quote: Museum staff insensitive to disabled visitors
reviewnospace:
What detracted from the experience was the insensitive treatment of physically-disabled visitors. When we asked to e-mail or speak to the museum's director, we were stone-walled. Staff refused to disclose his correct name or contact details. This made the experience even more disappointing.

On its web site, this museum professes: "Our commitment is to raise the bar of quality...by implementing transparent, effective and efficient management practices..." Our experience was quite the opposite.

reviewnospace:
This museum had a large number of impressionist paintings, which I really enjoy. The rooms are a good size and well lit, you never feel like you are bumping into other people. We went a few weeks ago in the mid-afternoon on Saturday and it was not crowded at all. Two elevators available for those who cannot (or don't want to) climb the stairs.

Senior discounts are available, but you may be asked to show photo ID to prove that, depending on which person you are buying your ticket from (my mom was asked, my aunt was not).

The ground floor was great. The 2nd floor was pretty good. My eyes, brain and legs were then too exhausted to see the top floor.

reviewnospace:
This was just down the road from Prado Museum, although i did split up the 2 visits to different days. This museum had collections of impressionist, surrealist, abstract art. When i was there, they opened a section for impressionist; van gogh, renoir and of course monet. All were beautiful pieces. It was my first time seeing actual works of art from these famous painters and it was awesome.

The other sections that i quite enjoyed were works of picasso (which i didn't understand but really enjoyed) and dali & magritte.

You're not allowed to use your mobilephones in the museum. Very wierd cos i see the security allowing some visitors to take pictures (which wasn't allowed) using their mobile phones, but when i got a call, they told me i couldn't talk on my mobile in the museum.

quote: So much more than a museum...
reviewnospace: Having spent a day at The Prado and been left feeling like it was a privilege to be allowed to stroll through the corridors there, it was so refreshing to get to the Thyssen and feel a warm unaffected welcome that not only made each room's discoveries all the more enlightening but also more thought-provoking in a strange way. It was interesting that the staff had no issue whatsoever with visitors taking photos although many of the works exceeded in value and popularity similar works at Prado which were seriously off bounds for cameras there.... The cafe and shop had wonderful offerings too, way beyond the normal fare of a museum - I eagerly await a return to this city and this space.

It was interesting that the staff had no issue whatsoever with visitors taking photos although many of the works exceeded in value and popularity similar works at Prado which were seriously off bounds for cameras there.... The cafe and shop had wonderful offerings too, way beyond the normal fare of a museum - I eagerly await a return to this city and this space.

reviewnospace: I was amazed and wished I had had more time to absorb all that the Thyssen has to offer. I want to go back to Madrid just to see this museum again. The Prado is outstanding but this is a true gem. It's hard to believe this was private collection!
titleopinion: What a collection. I was amazed and wished I had had more time to absorb all that the Thyssen has to offer. I want to go back to Madrid just to see this museum again. The Prado is outstanding but this is a true gem. It's hard to believe this was private collection!

reviewnospace: Three times wow!. A superb collection of paintings, with several big names of the world classical painting - Picasso, Salvador Dali, Degas, Gauguin, Monet and many, many others. If you like classical paitings you can not loose this place. It is a must to see in Madrid.
titleopinion: Wow!. Three times wow!. A superb collection of paintings, with several big names of the world classical painting - Picasso, Salvador Dali, Degas, Gauguin, Monet and many, many others. If you like classical paitings you can not loose this place. It is a must to see in Madrid.

reviewnospace: Excellent temporary exhibition containing Van Goghs, Manets, Constables amongst others. The rest of the museum has a staggering amount of paintings. We were fascinated by some of the modern art - Mondrian etc
titleopinion: Van Gogh. Excellent temporary exhibition containing Van Goghs, Manets, Constables amongst others. The rest of the museum has a staggering amount of paintings. We were fascinated by some of the modern art - Mondrian etc

reviewnospace:
This museum is as impressive as the Prado Museum although not as crowded and easy to wander around due to the layout. You can even take photos as long as you do not use the camera flash!

Lots of beautiful paintings on display from religious ones to world class masterpieces from artists like Picasso, Leger, Kandinsky, Hopper etc. One should not miss this attraction at all.

You can even take photos as long as you do not use the camera flash!  Lots of beautiful paintings on display from religious ones to world class masterpieces from artists like Picasso, Leger, Kandinsky, Hopper etc. One should not miss this attraction at all.

reviewnospace: Located directly across from the Prado, this museum houses a once private collection. Among pretty landscapes and portraits are some real surprises by Sargent, Picasso, Gauguin, Matisse and Cezanne.
titleopinion: Excellent  Small  Museum. Located directly across from the Prado, this museum houses a once private collection. Among pretty landscapes and portraits are some real surprises by Sargent, Picasso, Gauguin, Matisse and Cezanne.

quote: One of our favorite art museums, anywhere
reviewnospace: The Prado rightly gets most of the PR, but this 800+ work museum houses works ranging from the Renaissance, to Flemish, Dutch, Impressionism, and much more. And outstanding collection in a light and modern setting
titleopinion: One of our favorite art museums, anywhere. The Prado rightly gets most of the PR, but this 800+ work museum houses works ranging from the Renaissance, to Flemish, Dutch, Impressionism, and much more. And outstanding collection in a light and modern setting

reviewnospace: Loved the ability to book on line in advance for a specific time to visit special exhibits. This meant they were not overly crowded and we didn't have to wait in line. Impressionist exhibit had dozens of famous pictues and the Cartier exhibit was duly splashy.

This meant they were not overly crowded and we didn't have to wait in line. Impressionist exhibit had dozens of famous pictues and the Cartier exhibit was duly splashy.

quote: nice museum without the hype of the Prado
reviewnospace: I liked this museum better than the Prado. Less crowded, more well-known artists (I went when there was an Impressionist exhibit) and more clearly laid out. Great morning spent!

reviewnospace: Not quitec the volume of the prado but it covers later period with some excellent impressionism, cubism and abstracts. Start at the top and work your way down. Excellent cafe with good food and reasonable prices.

reviewnospace:

I was here this month and I got to see the new Impressionism exhibit, which is highly recomendable. I personally like this one better than the Reina Sofía.

quote: Spent all day here soaking up modern art and culture.
reviewnospace: This museum had 2 terrific seasonal exhibitions when we were there. The Cartier jewelry show was beautifully staged and the items, both early and late 20th century, were delightful to see. Then we saw an Impressionist show, part of which came from the very extensive permanent collection. The museum is user friendly and has a trendy minimalist restaurant.

reviewnospace:

location: State of Rio Grande do Sul
reviewnospace: The private collection of the Baron and Baroness Thyssen-Bornemisza is breathtaking, ranging from the italian old master's of the 14th century to post-impressionism and pop art, from Tiziano to Roy Lichtenstein. It certainly covers some lacks of the other two museums of the Golden Triangle, mainly in british painting. You cannot miss Tintoretto's Paradise, Caravaggio's Saint Catherine and Dali's dream. I just didn't like the pink salmon that the Baroness chose for the walls.

The private collection of the Baron and Baroness Thyssen-Bornemisza is breathtaking, ranging from the italian old master's of the 14th century to post-impressionism and pop art, from Tiziano to Roy Lichtenstein. It certainly covers some lacks of the other two museums of the Golden Triangle, mainly in british painting. You cannot miss Tintoretto's Paradise, Caravaggio's Saint Catherine and Dali's dream. I just didn't like the pink salmon that the Baroness chose for the walls.

quote: The very best museum just opposite El Prado.
reviewnospace: Children love it, senior people adore it, everybody likes coming to this Museum again and again. The latest temporary exhibition was about Cartier and the next one goes around Impressionist painters. You shouldn't miss this lovely museum.
titleopinion: The very best museum just opposite El Prado.. Children love it, senior people adore it, everybody likes coming to this Museum again and again. The latest temporary exhibition was about Cartier and the next one goes around Impressionist painters. You shouldn't miss this lovely museum.

reviewnospace:
The Museo Thyssen is sometimes overshadowed by the nearby Museo Prado and Museo Reina Sofia, but it deserves to be appreciated more. I was surprised to find that the collection here is enormous and diverse. The collection included magnificent art from the 14th century to the 20th century and featured well-known artists like Van Gogh, Picasso, Matisse, Durant, Monet, and Gauguin, among others.

I visited on a Monday afternoon when entrance was free, and enjoyed wandering around for an hour or two. There is so much art though, I will have to return to spend more time with it all.
titleopinion: Underrated Museum - Fantastic Art Collection. The Museo Thyssen is sometimes overshadowed by the nearby Museo Prado and Museo Reina Sofia, but it deserves to be appreciated more. I was surprised to find that the collection here is enormous and diverse. The collection included magnificent art from the 14th century to the 20th century and featured well-known artists like Van Gogh, Picasso, Matisse, Durant, Monet, and Gauguin, among others.  I visited on a Monday afternoon when entrance was free, and enjoyed wandering around for an hour or two. There is so much art though, I will have to return to spend more time with it all.

reviewnospace: This museum is a must... excellent choice and variety of artists and eras, with a good review of almost everything - from contemporary to modern art... the rooms are visit and the building is simple but very beautiful...
titleopinion: Art afternoon. This museum is a must... excellent choice and variety of artists and eras, with a good review of almost everything - from contemporary to modern art... the rooms are visit and the building is simple but very beautiful...

quote: Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum is the museum of choice
reviewnospace: The Prado, Sofia & Thyssen are all adjacent to each other, but if I had to chose only one to go to, this would be it. The building is charming, the collections and exhibitions are always exciting and their presentations beautifully done. The Prado and Sofia have significant works (Goya etc), but the collections are excruciating and painful, rife with heavy history, torturous and horrifying religious imagery. You leave bruised and battered, unbalanced and craving light. The Thyssen is a breath of fresh air, revitalizing and has significant collections.
titleopinion: Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum is the museum of choice. The Prado, Sofia & Thyssen are all adjacent to each other, but if I had to chose only one to go to, this would be it. The building is charming, the collections and exhibitions are always exciting and their presentations beautifully done. The Prado and Sofia have significant works (Goya etc), but the collections are excruciating and painful, rife with heavy history, torturous and horrifying religious imagery. You leave bruised and battered, unbalanced and craving light. The Thyssen is a breath of fresh air, revitalizing and has significant collections.

quote: After the Prado, visit the Thyssen-Bornemisza
reviewnospace: The Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum, which was developed as an extraordinary private collection, has wonderful works from the 14th through the 20th centuries. One of the pleasures of the museum is following the development of Modern Art movement by movement. I found pleasant surprises in almost every gallery. The cafe provides an opportunity to rest and restore oneself. This is a Masrid museum that, like the Prado, should not be missed.
titleopinion: After the Prado, visit the Thyssen-Bornemisza. The Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum, which was developed as an extraordinary private collection, has wonderful works from the 14th through the 20th centuries. One of the pleasures of the museum is following the development of Modern Art movement by movement. I found pleasant surprises in almost every gallery. The cafe provides an opportunity to rest and restore oneself. This is a Masrid museum that, like the Prado, should not be missed.

quote: A great place to lose yourself in peace
reviewnospace: This museum and the Muse d' Orsay, in my opinion, are the two best museums in the world. If you are just starting out in life to appreciate art, or at least try to understand what all the fuss is about, this museum is a great place to start. Their permanent collection show cases a range of all the major art traditions and styles with the exception of photography and sculpture. The museum is opposite and slightly down the street from the Prado. If you only have time for one museum in Madrid...this is the only choice... and they have a killer gift shop!

reviewnospace: With a varied collection. One wonderful Monet and several delights. The gallery, like Madrid in general, is enjoyed as a local would more than as a destination for it's own sake, which is reason enough to go.
titleopinion: Intimate gallery. With a varied collection. One wonderful Monet and several delights. The gallery, like Madrid in general, is enjoyed as a local would more than as a destination for it's own sake, which is reason enough to go.

reviewnospace: For people who like museums this is an interesting museum for several reasons. It is a private collection that has been donated and so provides a wider range of paintings than some of the national collections. This museum contains a major collection of Spanish and European Art but what is unusual is that it contains British painting which are not always included in European collections and even more unusual is a large collection of American paintings both historical and modern. There are paintings by John Singeton Copely, Winslow Homer, Fredrick Church and John Singer Sargent which do not appear in any other European collections I am aware of. In addition there are modern and contemporary paintings as well and a section where there is a film of the collector in discussion with the British painter Francis Bacon. Well worth the visit and easy to get around. The museum also has a nice restaurant.
titleopinion: An Excellent Museum. For people who like museums this is an interesting museum for several reasons. It is a private collection that has been donated and so provides a wider range of paintings than some of the national collections. This museum contains a major collection of Spanish and European Art but what is unusual is that it contains British painting which are not always included in European collections and even more unusual is a large collection of American paintings both historical and modern. There are paintings by John Singeton Copely, Winslow Homer, Fredrick Church and John Singer Sargent which do not appear in any other European collections I am aware of. In addition there are modern and contemporary paintings as well and a section where there is a film of the collector in discussion with the British painter Francis Bacon. Well worth the visit and easy to get around. The museum also has a nice restaurant.

reviewnospace: Enjoyed visiting the museum, although it was very crowded and my kids got bored quickly with the overwhelming amount of paintings
titleopinion: Great collection. Enjoyed visiting the museum, although it was very crowded and my kids got bored quickly with the overwhelming amount of paintings

reviewnospace:
The Thyssen has the most understandable, and digestable, overview of western painting you will find anywhere. It is great to go from numbered and themed gallery to gallery and be able to see and understand the progression of european painting. This is a European (and American) collection not primarilly focused on Spain. For that go to the Prado.

I last visited the Thyssen in 1996, before the new wing (galleries A B C..) were added. Though it is nice to have acess to more paintings, including some excellent American examples, the simple flow of the museum has become more complex. That is unfortunate. The museum building itself also now seems a bit tired and dated.

That said, the Thyssen is a must if you are interested in an overview of an evolution of western art that can be appreciated in just a few hours.

This is a European (and American) collection not primarilly focused on Spain. For that go to the Prado.  I last visited the Thyssen in 1996, before the new wing (galleries A B C..) were added. Though it is nice to have acess to more paintings, including some excellent American examples, the simple flow of the museum has become more complex. That is unfortunate. The museum building itself also now seems a bit tired and dated.   That said, the Thyssen is a must if you are interested in an overview of an evolution of western art that can be appreciated in just a few hours.

reviewnospace: Stunning museum. Well worth a visit. You need about 3 hours. The museum also has a very elegant cafeteria serving restaurant quality food.
titleopinion: Fabulous. Stunning museum. Well worth a visit. You need about 3 hours. The museum also has a very elegant cafeteria serving restaurant quality food.

reviewnospace: This is an extensive private collection sold to Spain in the '90's who then renovated a 19th palace for it. You start on the second floor with 14th century and follow the floor plan down through the main floor of 20th century art in a chronological view of Western painting The collection holds many noted masterpieces, some of which are on loan at the time.

reviewnospace:
Though I don't live near the Thyssen I do live in Madrid and go as often as possible. It has a rich, very thorough collection -- some gorgeous German Expressionist paintings well worth anyone's time.

The Thyssen Bornemisza family gets a bad rap because of their involvement with making the gas chambers in WWII, but everytime I hear someone referring to this I remind them that the baron who gave this collection was a brother who had nothing to do with the big industrial company that were merit infamy alone.

quote: Wonderful Exhibitions of Gauguin and the Art of Cartier
reviewnospace:
The Thyssen Museum had an exhibition called Gauguin and the Voyage to the Exotic. There were many paintings by Gauguin. The most important were Two Tahitian Women, Black Pigs, There Lies the Tample, Matamoe, Mata Mua, Parau Api, and Haere Mai. There were also paintings by artists of his time. One of them that called attention was Two Nudes in an Exotic Landscape by Jean Metzinger. The paintings by other artists also had the theme of exotic places.

The other exhibition at the Thyssen was The Art of Cartier, showing the history of the firm with exhibits of their best pieces of jewelry. The exhibits were organized by themes, which included Head Ornaments, Modern Style and Art Deco, Oriental Influences, The Far East, The Power of Style with Iconic Clients, Precious Time, Precious Objects, Mystery Clocks, and Flora and Fauna. The best piece was a necklace with rubies and diamonds owned by Elizabeth Taylor, and given to her by Mike Todd. Elizabeth Taylor had the best taste in jewelry. It reminded me of an exhibition I saw in Chicago at the Field Museum in 2002 where they exhibited La Peregrina, the most famous historic pearl and owned by Elizabeth Taylor at that time.

The most important were Two Tahitian Women, Black Pigs, There Lies the Tample, Matamoe, Mata Mua, Parau Api, and Haere Mai. There were also paintings by artists of his time. One of them that called attention was Two Nudes in an Exotic Landscape by Jean Metzinger. The paintings by other artists also had the theme of exotic places.  The other exhibition at the Thyssen was The Art of Cartier, showing the history of the firm with exhibits of their best pieces of jewelry. The exhibits were organized by themes, which included Head Ornaments, Modern Style and Art Deco, Oriental Influences, The Far East, The Power of Style with Iconic Clients, Precious Time, Precious Objects, Mystery Clocks, and Flora and Fauna. The best piece was a necklace with rubies and diamonds owned by Elizabeth Taylor, and given to her by Mike Todd. Elizabeth Taylor had the best taste in jewelry. It reminded me of an exhibition I saw in Chicago at the Field Museum in 2002 where they exhibited La Peregrina, the most famous historic pearl and owned by Elizabeth Taylor at that time.

reviewnospace: Very large and varied collection, with some fine temporary exhibitions too. Particularly enjoyed the 20th Century collection
titleopinion: Excellent. Very large and varied collection, with some fine temporary exhibitions too. Particularly enjoyed the 20th Century collection

reviewnospace:
Brought my friend to come see this museum last week. They have a very very large collection of paintings including a Gaughin exhibit the Cartier exhibit. There are some beautiful pieces in the cartier exhibit. I highly recommend it. It's informative of how the Cartier brand came to be and also the influences of where Cartier found his inspiration found. The Tiaras displayed are so beautiful!

If you have a student ID card you can get a discount on the price!

quote: This collection is unparalleled for taste and selection--

A very posh place with the best of the best---De La Tour,
Ghiarlandaio, the famous paintings you've only seen on postcards and in books---breathtaking works..and lovely lighting and displays. A great modern collection as well, small but very carefullly chosen and briliant. It's real treat.

reviewnospace: was lucky to see the exhibition about cartier! good to see different items from icon women such as Grace kelly, Wallis and many others
titleopinion: cartier exhibition was incredible. was lucky to see the exhibition about cartier! good to see different items from icon women such as Grace kelly, Wallis and many others

reviewnospace: A very small Museum with mainly painting but some well worth seeing art. I am sure every art lover could find on or two pieces of their favorite artist.
titleopinion: A Great Museum. A very small Museum with mainly painting but some well worth seeing art. I am sure every art lover could find on or two pieces of their favorite artist.

quote: Shows what money, a Good Eye and Incredible taste can accumulate
reviewnospace: Based on the personal Collection of an very rich Baron and his son this Century and sold to the Spanish Nation about 2 decades ago. The collection spans all the ages of Western Art. There is an excellent American Art section due, I think to the influence of the present Baron's wife who I believe was an American with splendid taste. Though not exactly compact, the establishment does not rival the Prado for miles of passages and galleries and is the better for it and for a more focused buying history.
titleopinion: Shows what money, a Good Eye and Incredible taste can accumulate. Based on the personal Collection of an very rich Baron and his son this Century and sold to the Spanish Nation about 2 decades ago. The collection spans all the ages of Western Art. There is an excellent American Art section due, I think to the influence of the present Baron's wife who I believe was an American with splendid taste. Though not exactly compact, the establishment does not rival the Prado for miles of passages and galleries and is the better for it and for a more focused buying history.

quote: Wonderful variety of art under one roof!
reviewnospace: A very light and airy gallery, lots of wonderful art and a gem of a restaurant with a delightful outside terrace.
titleopinion: Wonderful variety of art under one roof!. A very light and airy gallery, lots of wonderful art and a gem of a restaurant with a delightful outside terrace.

reviewnospace: This museum is smaller than others.But it is beautiful as others!if you like thiskind of things you will really enjoyed with all!Unfortunatelly we had not enough time to visit all.it worth it to spend at least two hours!
titleopinion: Must Visit!. This museum is smaller than others.But it is beautiful as others!if you like thiskind of things you will really enjoyed with all!Unfortunatelly we had not enough time to visit all.it worth it to spend at least two hours!

reviewnospace: Also excellent as all the museums of madrid (more or less). This one is definitely smaller than the others but very interesting as well. A very nice way to see the chronological evolution of arts.

reviewnospace: Beautiful! Hadn't planned on this one but really enjoyed the collections. Helpful staff, easy to get around,English well spoken
titleopinion: Nice surprise. Beautiful! Hadn't planned on this one but really enjoyed the collections. Helpful staff, easy to get around,English well spoken

reviewnospace: Nice museum with a modern feel. Well worth a visit along with the Prado. Just spent a couple of hours there, but there was plenty to see along with a couple of temporary exhibitions.
titleopinion: Great museum.... Nice museum with a modern feel. Well worth a visit along with the Prado. Just spent a couple of hours there, but there was plenty to see along with a couple of temporary exhibitions.

quote: Very good variety of paintings with exceptional layout
reviewnospace:
The Prado and Reina Sofia receive a good deal of attention when discussing Madrid museums ... however the Thyssen-Bornemisza is one of my faves if not at the top of my list.

There is a wide variety of paintings from many time periods and I really love the layout of the museum.
titleopinion: Very good variety of paintings with exceptional layout. The Prado and Reina Sofia receive a good deal of attention when discussing Madrid museums ... however the Thyssen-Bornemisza is one of my faves if not at the top of my list.   There is a wide variety of paintings from many time periods and I really love the layout of the museum.

reviewnospace: Together with the Prado and the Queen Sofia, the Thyssen makes up the Walk of Art (Paseo del Arte). One of the most comprehensive private painting collections in the world.
titleopinion: Delightful museum. Together with the Prado and the Queen Sofia, the Thyssen makes up the Walk of Art (Paseo del Arte). One of the most comprehensive private painting collections in the world.

reviewnospace: Sadly we didn't have time to do the whole thing, but we did stop in for the (temporary) Cartier exhibit and WOW - Totally recommend. Also got some great prints, a mobile and some other pretty things in the affordable and interesting gift shop. Very pleasant visit!
titleopinion: Cartier! Wow!. Sadly we didn't have time to do the whole thing, but we did stop in for the (temporary) Cartier exhibit and WOW - Totally recommend. Also got some great prints, a mobile and some other pretty things in the affordable and interesting gift shop. Very pleasant visit!

reviewnospace: Beautiful private museum that welcomes tourists - no siesta time - with wonderful art pieces not seen anywhere else. Easily a 2-3 hour visit.
titleopinion: Don't miss it. Beautiful private museum that welcomes tourists - no siesta time - with wonderful art pieces not seen anywhere else. Easily a 2-3 hour visit.

reviewnospace: My 3rd time at the museum and I have not had enough. I attended two exhibitions. And the permanent collection is excellent!
titleopinion: Amazing!. My 3rd time at the museum and I have not had enough. I attended two exhibitions. And the permanent collection is excellent!

reviewnospace: The collection at the T-B is off the charts in quality and historical sweep. The museum itself can be easily digested in one long visit, unlike the Prado, which is a very big meal for one sitting. The story behind why the T-B is in Madrid and not elsewhere in Europe is also interesting. Ah, the power of romance. Discover the story for yourself. Also, when we were at the T-B it was presenting a really great Gauguin exhibit with works from collections around the world. It was exceptionally good. DO NOT MISS THE T-B if you are in Madrid.
titleopinion: Spectacular - simply spectacular. The collection at the T-B is off the charts in quality and historical sweep. The museum itself can be easily digested in one long visit, unlike the Prado, which is a very big meal for one sitting. The story behind why the T-B is in Madrid and not elsewhere in Europe is also interesting. Ah, the power of romance. Discover the story for yourself. Also, when we were at the T-B it was presenting a really great Gauguin exhibit with works from collections around the world. It was exceptionally good. DO NOT MISS THE T-B if you are in Madrid.

reviewnospace: Take plenty of time as this is one of the largest private collections in the world. You can have your ticket stamped and leave for a lunch break...refreshing rather than spending whole day in there!
titleopinion: Outstanding.. Take plenty of time as this is one of the largest private collections in the world. You can have your ticket stamped and leave for a lunch break...refreshing rather than spending whole day in there!

reviewnospace: madrid has so much art with the prado and modern art galleries, I found the thyssen-bornemisza one of the best galleries i visited in europe. a fantastic collection which was really well laid out and a lot of italian and impressionist art in particular. this is a must-see!
titleopinion: the not-to-miss museum in madrid. madrid has so much art with the prado and modern art galleries, I found the thyssen-bornemisza one of the best galleries i visited in europe. a fantastic collection which was really well laid out and a lot of italian and impressionist art in particular. this is a must-see!

reviewnospace:
Of the 3 most popular art museums (Thyssen, Prado, Reina Sofia), Thyssen was my favorite. It's not quite as big as Prado, but I found that I spent more time at Thyssen. I took my time, and it took me about 6 hours to go through the main collection and the Gauguin exhibition with audio guides (1 for main, 1 for gauguin, 4€ & 3€ respectively).

The quality of art is excellent. And there is a bit wider range than Prado. Here, you'll get all the classics, and even a bit of modern (like pop art) as well.

You can get an art pass that gets you in to all 3 museums (excluding Thyssen temporary exhibits, but including all others' temporary exhibits). You can buy this pass at any of the museums.
titleopinion: My favorite of  the big 3 . Of the 3 most popular art museums (Thyssen, Prado, Reina Sofia), Thyssen was my favorite. It's not quite as big as Prado, but I found that I spent more time at Thyssen. I took my time, and it took me about 6 hours to go through the main collection and the Gauguin exhibition with audio guides (1 for main, 1 for gauguin, 4€ & 3€ respectively).  The quality of art is excellent. And there is a bit wider range than Prado. Here, you'll get all the classics, and even a bit of modern (like pop art) as well.  You can get an art pass that gets you in to all 3 museums (excluding Thyssen temporary exhibits, but including all others' temporary exhibits). You can buy this pass at any of the museums.

reviewnospace: Its the best modern art museum in Madrid. It has a huge collection of contemporary master pieces from around the world. It has works from Lichtenstein, Warhol, Pollock, Picasso, De Kooning, Dali, Miro, Tobey, etc. If you have been to El Prado and Reina Sofia museums, don't leave Madrid without visiting Thyssen-Bomemisza.
titleopinion: Overlooked Art Museum. Its the best modern art museum in Madrid. It has a huge collection of contemporary master pieces from around the world. It has works from Lichtenstein, Warhol, Pollock, Picasso, De Kooning, Dali, Miro, Tobey, etc. If you have been to El Prado and Reina Sofia museums, don't leave Madrid without visiting Thyssen-Bomemisza.

quote: Good for a quick walk through
reviewnospace: A little disappointed in this museum. Potential is there and we did see some amazing things...but there seemed to be quite a few empty spaces where things had been loaned. Maybe it would be better viewed on its own instead of following the Prado.
titleopinion: Good for a quick walk through. A little disappointed in this museum. Potential is there and we did see some amazing things...but there seemed to be quite a few empty spaces where things had been loaned. Maybe it would be better viewed on its own instead of following the Prado.

quote: Great museum with all kind of art
reviewnospace:
If you only have time for 1 museum, I would go here instead of Prado and Reina Sofia. Good museum

quote: Visiting Cartier Exhibit Is Reason Enough to Visit
reviewnospace: This museum has exhibits from its permanent collections and visiting exhibits. We saw the special exhibit of 400 items from the Cartier Jewelery collection. Some 10 years earlier, we had seen an earlier version of the exhibit in London. This is really spectacular; I only wished there was an exhibition catalog. For the rest of the museum, select the genre or era you're interested in. The museum is far too large to see and absorb everything in one walk through.
titleopinion: Visiting Cartier Exhibit Is Reason Enough to Visit. This museum has exhibits from its permanent collections and visiting exhibits. We saw the special exhibit of 400 items from the Cartier Jewelery collection. Some 10 years earlier, we had seen an earlier version of the exhibit in London. This is really spectacular; I only wished there was an exhibition catalog. For the rest of the museum, select the genre or era you're interested in. The museum is far too large to see and absorb everything in one walk through.

quote: Not the Prado, but worth it
reviewnospace: We went here for the Paul Gaugin exhibit, but the whole museum is really delightful. I'd say if you're not much of a museum lover, the Prado and Reina Sophia are more important, but this is a wonderful place, too.
titleopinion: Not the Prado, but worth it. We went here for the Paul Gaugin exhibit, but the whole museum is really delightful. I'd say if you're not much of a museum lover, the Prado and Reina Sophia are more important, but this is a wonderful place, too.

reviewnospace: We visited this nice museum aiming the french impressionist. As always Gauguin gives you the impression that he is one of the great painters ever!!
titleopinion: Paul Gauguin at his best!!. We visited this nice museum aiming the french impressionist. As always Gauguin gives you the impression that he is one of the great painters ever!!

reviewnospace: Jaw dropping collection - beautifully displayed. Airy, elegant buidling - a great combination of old and new. Lovely garden, great shop.
titleopinion: Fabulous art collection. Jaw dropping collection - beautifully displayed. Airy, elegant buidling - a great combination of old and new. Lovely garden, great shop.

reviewnospace: This gallery is simply stunning! The permanent collection has a little bit of everything so everyone will find something for themselves. Temporary shows are also always very well prepared and worth the money. A must-see if you ever visit Madrid and are into art.
titleopinion: The best gallery in Madrid. This gallery is simply stunning! The permanent collection has a little bit of everything so everyone will find something for themselves. Temporary shows are also always very well prepared and worth the money. A must-see if you ever visit Madrid and are into art.

reviewnospace: What a fantastic collection! We went through the standard collection as well as the Cartier collection. The standard collection was full of great paintings by famous artists (Picasso, Kandinsky, Van Gogh, Matisse, Monet, Cezanne, Renoir, etc.) of various styles. My favourite was the 'Experimental Avant-Gardes' section but the whole place was great. I'd recommend allowing a good couple of hours to look around if you have a broad interest in artistic styles - if you're only looking at one collection it can be done in around an hour. I could've spent all day there! Unfortunately the shop was closed when we were there.
titleopinion: Excellent!. What a fantastic collection! We went through the standard collection as well as the Cartier collection. The standard collection was full of great paintings by famous artists (Picasso, Kandinsky, Van Gogh, Matisse, Monet, Cezanne, Renoir, etc.) of various styles. My favourite was the 'Experimental Avant-Gardes' section but the whole place was great. I'd recommend allowing a good couple of hours to look around if you have a broad interest in artistic styles - if you're only looking at one collection it can be done in around an hour. I could've spent all day there! Unfortunately the shop was closed when we were there.

reviewnospace: We were a bit cultured out at the point of our visit, but I don't think this explains why we could not cope with the lay-out of the place. Oddly it seems that same items in the various gift shops varied. The outdoor cafe space was OK, but the food inside the restaurant looked great.
titleopinion: Great art, but layout confusing. We were a bit cultured out at the point of our visit, but I don't think this explains why we could not cope with the lay-out of the place. Oddly it seems that same items in the various gift shops varied. The outdoor cafe space was OK, but the food inside the restaurant looked great.

reviewnospace: Actually preferred this to the Prado due to the greater diversity of exhibits. A fantastic collection & the audio guides are value for money providing a good commentary on selected paintings.
titleopinion: Magnificent collection. Actually preferred this to the Prado due to the greater diversity of exhibits. A fantastic collection & the audio guides are value for money providing a good commentary on selected paintings.

reviewnospace: Easier to negotiate than the Prado, this museum holds lots of hidden treasures and a small collection of Impressionist art that I very much enjoyed
titleopinion: A little gem. Easier to negotiate than the Prado, this museum holds lots of hidden treasures and a small collection of Impressionist art that I very much enjoyed

reviewnospace:
I was just blown away by this exhibition it was amazing. To see Grace Kellys engagement ring was a bonus. The art of this collection is a joy to behold.
This museum was very much worth a visit the permanent collection has so many treasures.
Very good shop too.
titleopinion: Cartier exhibition. I was just blown away by this exhibition it was amazing. To see Grace Kellys engagement ring was a bonus. The art of this collection is a joy to behold. This museum was very much worth a visit the permanent collection has so many treasures. Very good shop too.

reviewnospace: This museum must be high on your list while visiting Madrid. Wonderful location, very near the Prado. And what a collection! Really enjoyed it! And don't forget to visit the cafe.
titleopinion: Do not miss!. This museum must be high on your list while visiting Madrid. Wonderful location, very near the Prado. And what a collection! Really enjoyed it! And don't forget to visit the cafe.

reviewnospace:
We went on a rainy satuday morning, waited almost an hour to be told at about 10h30 that the temporary exhibit we had hoped to visit was sold out.Very unpleasant. So we said no thanks.
During our queing we were also more than displeased by the total lack of organisation. Evidently anyone disresecptful of queues just bypassed them and marched in despite the complaints from the onwaiting crowd.
When I mentionned this to a staff member, she replied with a smile welcome to SPAIN...
I do recall on our last visit that we had enjoyed the museum..
titleopinion: AVOID THE CROWD. We went on a rainy satuday morning, waited almost an hour to be told at about 10h30 that the temporary exhibit we had hoped to visit was sold out.Very unpleasant. So we said no thanks. During our queing we were also more than displeased by the total lack of organisation. Evidently anyone disresecptful of queues just bypassed them and marched in despite the complaints from the onwaiting crowd. When I mentionned this to a staff member, she replied with a smile welcome to SPAIN... I do recall on our last visit that we had enjoyed the museum..

reviewnospace: An exceptional museum and a must when in Madrid. Very close to the Prado and a little smaller. Superb collection.
titleopinion: Excellent. An exceptional museum and a must when in Madrid. Very close to the Prado and a little smaller. Superb collection.

reviewnospace: I went to visit the museum on Saturday but the line was ridiculous (about 2 blocks down the street!). I returned on Tuesday and there was no line. The art pieces were great although the layout of the museum was slightly confusing. It would have been good to get a map that included the 'must see' pieces. However I enjoyed strolling around for a few hours before I visited the Cartier exhibition in my alloted time slot. It was mind blowing! The pieces are all gorgeous and the layout was accessible. The cost for visiting both was 12euros and I would allow 3 hours to look around it all.
titleopinion: Cartier exhibition is amazing!. I went to visit the museum on Saturday but the line was ridiculous (about 2 blocks down the street!). I returned on Tuesday and there was no line. The art pieces were great although the layout of the museum was slightly confusing. It would have been good to get a map that included the 'must see' pieces. However I enjoyed strolling around for a few hours before I visited the Cartier exhibition in my alloted time slot. It was mind blowing! The pieces are all gorgeous and the layout was accessible. The cost for visiting both was 12euros and I would allow 3 hours to look around it all.

reviewnospace: Make sure you give yourself plenty of time to enjoy the art here, so much to see and a visual joy to experience.
titleopinion: Wow!. Make sure you give yourself plenty of time to enjoy the art here, so much to see and a visual joy to experience.

quote: Good snapshot of art through the ages: bit limited though.

Slightly disappointing for adults. Special exhibition of Cartier on at the same time completely sold out - so this was disappointing too.

Don't miss this!!!

titleopinion: Easy to navigate, interesting pieces. While not the Prado, this museum has a great layout and some nice pieces. It covers almost every era of art.

reviewnospace:
the thyssen is a gorgeous museum---easy to navigate, and laid out beautifully. the gaugin exhibition is breathtaking. you could easily spend days in this museum and still only get a cursory overview of its collection. that is the true beauty of any museum though isn't it; that it wets your appetite and makes you wish to return for "more helpings"?!
every time i return to madrid, i spend days at the thyssen and the prado---and cannot ever get enough. beauty reigns within its walls and outside in the lovely gardens and cafe.
make this a top place to visit on your visit to madrid....you will not be sorry.

quote: A visit with a Spanish friend
reviewnospace: This was a lovely museum visit. I was familiar with many of the paintings. We went early so it was not crowded so I could get close to some of the works. I was most impressed with the Museum shop. I bought a number of gifts for friends.

quote: Must see museum when in Madrid
reviewnospace: Very nice and professional museum that must be seen before or after visiting the Prado. The building is beautifully restored and the cafe is great too. Enjoy.
titleopinion: Must see museum when in Madrid. Very nice and professional museum that must be seen before or after visiting the Prado. The building is beautifully restored and the cafe is great too. Enjoy.

reviewnospace: This museum truly has everything you could ask for, specifically if you have any interest in Impressionist or Surrealist art.

reviewnospace: Amazing. All major artists appeared to be represented at this museum and the paintings were presented chronologically which helped me to understand better for example how the impressionists and renaissance artists were connected.

reviewnospace: I really enjoy this museum both for how the collection itself was created (it was a husband and wife's private collection which they continued to augment as they created the self-named museum) and for the eclectic nature of the artists on display. It's not the Prado but perhaps almost as interesting.

I really enjoy this museum both for how the collection itself was created (it was a husband and wife's private collection which they continued to augment as they created the self-named museum) and for the eclectic nature of the artists on display. It's not the Prado but perhaps almost as interesting.

reviewnospace: Much more compact, manageable and personal collection than the Prado with some great works spanning from the early Italian & Spanish painters right through to modern works from the 1970's & 80's. (The super realist paintings in the final room by Richard Estes are mind-blowing!) Good audio guides and collection in easily visited inside 3-4hrs. Only negative was that there were quite a few pieces out on loan to other galleries at the time I visited but I guess that's the sign of a great collection that is in constant demand.
titleopinion: Fabulous comprehensive art collection. Much more compact, manageable and personal collection than the Prado with some great works spanning from the early Italian & Spanish painters right through to modern works from the 1970's & 80's. (The super realist paintings in the final room by Richard Estes are mind-blowing!) Good audio guides and collection in easily visited inside 3-4hrs. Only negative was that there were quite a few pieces out on loan to other galleries at the time I visited but I guess that's the sign of a great collection that is in constant demand.

reviewnospace: The collection augments the Prado's with impressionists and modern masters, including abstractionists. Included is Thyssen's wife's collection, which is separately shown. The traveling Gauguin show, which required a separate entry fee, was outstanding and worth the visit alone. I found the bulk of the permanent collection, which is pre-1800, to be less interesting than the more recent paintings. Nice cafe.
titleopinion: Interesting . . . but. The collection augments the Prado's with impressionists and modern masters, including abstractionists. Included is Thyssen's wife's collection, which is separately shown. The traveling Gauguin show, which required a separate entry fee, was outstanding and worth the visit alone. I found the bulk of the permanent collection, which is pre-1800, to be less interesting than the more recent paintings. Nice cafe.

quote: Well designed gallery with bonus of Gauguin exhibit.
reviewnospace: We did all three galleries (Prado, Sofia Reine and the Thyssen. It is a gallery which is very easy to get around in with a good audio-guide. The gallery is organized chronologically which allows the viewer to choose specific types of art if you don't want to do the whole thing. We lucked into the temporary Gauguin exhibit which was a bonus although added an extra cost. The negative aspect of this was their 15 minute bookings to get in although you could stay inside as long as you like. BUT - it was so crowded - with tour groups taking up a lot of space in tight quarters. My husband just had to get out. But it was a lovely exhibit of Gauguin's work along with others who were influenced by his art.

reviewnospace: many modern masterpieces alongside a large collection of modern art which I suspect to the average visitor smacks of 'he emperor's new clothes'

reviewnospace:
And I got lucky as there was a non-permanent exhibition dedicated only to Gaugin
Only detail - the entrance tickets organization. In order to have not too many visitors at the same time, they would give you an "hour of visit" when you buy on site. That means that you have to come back 1, sometimes 2 hours later. My advice: book through the Internet. cheaper, faster and you don't have to waste 1 hour in a line and then one more hour before visiting...

reviewnospace: It's amasing how one person was able to collect so many fine paintings in a lifetime during the 20th century. Limit your museum visits on the same day to only this one.

quote: A very important museum for an artistic tour of Madrid,Spain
reviewnospace: This is an important museum to see in Madrid, Spain because in it you will see European Art from about the 13th. century to the Modern times. Don't miss the recently added Carmen wing. There is a nice cafe on the 5th. floor where you rest your legs while enjoying a bite to eat. The rooms are well labelled and follow a chronological pattern. If you feel that Non- Spanish European Art is under represented in the nearby Prado, a visit to this museum becomes important since that art is well represented here.
titleopinion: A very important museum for an artistic tour of Madrid,Spain. There is a nice cafe on the 5th. floor where you rest your legs while enjoying a bite to eat. The rooms are well labelled and follow a chronological pattern. If you feel that Non- Spanish European Art is under represented in the nearby Prado, a visit to this museum becomes important since that art is well represented here.

reviewnospace: Brilliant, could have stayed for ages, Lots of variety can miss many of chist on cross. Good setting and easy to get around
titleopinion: AWESOME. Brilliant, could have stayed for ages, Lots of variety can miss many of chist on cross. Good setting and easy to get around

reviewnospace: Personally I liked the Thyssen museum over Prado for its collection of Impression Art which I adore. There are some fabulous pieces of work here which make this a must see for any art lover.
titleopinion: Wonderful collection of art. Personally I liked the Thyssen museum over Prado for its collection of Impression Art which I adore. There are some fabulous pieces of work here which make this a must see for any art lover.

reviewnospace:
We wanted to visit this museum since the paintings were more modern, including impressionists. The scale of it is mind boggling. I think you need to decide what you really want to see and concentrate on that otherwise you may be tired before you get to see the paintings you want. It is a very large museum on three floors and I don't think it is practical to see all of it in one visit.

It may have been the time of year but a lot of paintings were out on loan, in some rooms upt ot half were mssing including some we specifically wanted to see. I guess this is true of all museums but I don't think I have seen as many missing elsewhere.

The star for us was the Degas pastels.

Overall good value for money.

reviewnospace: We spent all day in this museum and really enjoyed it, especially the 20th Century section. However the commentary did not provide much information and was downright irritating, with its continuous, gratuitous praise of the museum. For the most part, there was simply no content. Skip it and just focus on the paintings.
titleopinion: Forget the audio commentary. We spent all day in this museum and really enjoyed it, especially the 20th Century section. However the commentary did not provide much information and was downright irritating, with its continuous, gratuitous praise of the museum. For the most part, there was simply no content. Skip it and just focus on the paintings.

reviewnospace: I like how their collection contains works from most artists starting early and through current artists. They don't have the most famous works of anyone in particular, but do have ones from all the artists you'd like to see.

reviewnospace: This is an outstanding collection of fabulous modern art, including American, French,etc. works. Really enjoyed this musuem.
titleopinion: Not to be missed!. This is an outstanding collection of fabulous modern art, including American, French,etc. works. Really enjoyed this musuem.

reviewnospace:
With no time to visit all the museums we opted for the Thyssen as we felt it would be more manageable and more in keeping with our artistic interests, especially with the current exhibition. Entrance to the temporary exhibition is by timed ticket (9 Euros or 15 Euros for a combined ticket and requires a supplement to the museum pass).
This exhibition features works arising from exotic travel by artists such as Gauguin and was very crowded. The main gallery was quieter and, due to the layout, it is possible to focus on particular periods, styles & artists and to miss out religious works or pop art if they are not to your taste.
There were lots of gaps on the walls, but having been to a number of exhibitions in London, I know that the gallery is very generous when it comes to works on loan abroad.
titleopinion: New temporary exhibition......Gauguin & exotic places. There were lots of gaps on the walls, but having been to a number of exhibitions in London, I know that the gallery is very generous when it comes to works on loan abroad.

quote: Good museum get the Madrid Card
reviewnospace: Good museum get the museum card otherwise you will wait in long line and some days tickets maybe sold out

reviewnospace: Just what was needed for a break from sightseeing. Their apple slice was perfecto. Pleasant view of the outdoors and an outdoor setting is available.
titleopinion: Pleasant cafeteria for morning tea. Just what was needed for a break from sightseeing. Their apple slice was perfecto. Pleasant view of the outdoors and an outdoor setting is available.

reviewnospace: For us the Thyssen was the most impressive of Madrid's 'big three'. It was sheer pleasure to stand together and yet seemingly be alone with a family collection of famous paintings, the feeling was extraordinary. The layout of the gallery is second to none. Electronic maps/guides, positioned outside the lifts on every floor, allow you to find paintings by the artist's name, painting name, room number or by country or style. We downloaded a guide from the internet which suggested what to see if you were only to spend an hour in the gallery or what to see if you had 2 or 3 hours. We marked off our 'must sees' and darted from floor to floor, room to room pausing only to admire something which caught our eye that was not on our list. Our visit lasted longer than we had anticipated, so much to see, including, and it was just good luck, the Hopper Exhibition, that finished 2 or 3 days later. The current exhibition is Paul Gauguin, at least until mid January. What a wonderful gallery. Contrary to other postings on Tripadvisor there is an admission charge, currently €9.
titleopinion: Two of us, standing solo. For us the Thyssen was the most impressive of Madrid's 'big three'. It was sheer pleasure to stand together and yet seemingly be alone with a family collection of famous paintings, the feeling was extraordinary. The layout of the gallery is second to none. Electronic maps/guides, positioned outside the lifts on every floor, allow you to find paintings by the artist's name, painting name, room number or by country or style. We downloaded a guide from the internet which suggested what to see if you were only to spend an hour in the gallery or what to see if you had 2 or 3 hours. We marked off our 'must sees' and darted from floor to floor, room to room pausing only to admire something which caught our eye that was not on our list. The current exhibition is Paul Gauguin, at least until mid January. What a wonderful gallery. Contrary to other postings on Tripadvisor there is an admission charge, currently €9.

quote: It was free all day Sunday.

reviewnospace: Thyssen-Bornemisza is not as big as Prado, yet it displays an excellent selection of painting. The permanent exhibition is organized according to chronological principle starting with Renaissance masters on the first floor. Somehow we missed the suggested route, our fault, probably, but it was written in the leaflet in tiny letters. That’s why by the time we got upstairs we were tired, roaming about the halls with German and Flemish artists for too long. The audio guide is very informative, and there are rare canvases, like Gainsborough’s portrait. On the whole, the gallery houses plenty of masterpieces by XX century painters: Braque, Picasso, Kandinsky, and a beautiful collection of impressionists and postimpressionism, Pissaro, Degas, Edouard Manet (don’t miss his Woman in Riding Habit!), Claude Monet , Toulouse-Lautrec, Cezanne among them. So, if you love painting, take your time!

reviewnospace: See the close by Prado museum but add this museum to your list. We were lucky enough to spend the good part of a day here. We got to see the Hopper exhibition but it's the varied collection of art on these walls that surely makes it worth a visit. The list of famous artists with pieces in this museum is astounding. The museum itself is clean and well cared for. Get the audio guide, it's worth it. They have a decent cafe if you'd like to take a break.

reviewnospace: Using our audio guides. I felt this art gallery started very well with an explanation of 14th century art and the progress into the Renaissance. It was the fourth art gallery we visited and since we had already visited the Prado twice, we were suffering a little from cultural overload but although there were some pretty impressive paintings there were many that were more ordinary. I didn't rate the modern art at all and there was much less impressionate paintings that we had expected but there was enough good stuff to make a visit well worthwhile.
titleopinion: Interesting and varied collection. Using our audio guides. I felt this art gallery started very well with an explanation of 14th century art and the progress into the Renaissance. reviewnospace: This isn't the prettiest gallery we've ever been to, but the collection is amazing. It's a roll call of names in art, Monet, Van Gough, Kandinsky, Renoir, Freud, Miro, Picasso, I could go on. There are also plenty of less well know pieces, and the collection is so extensive that there would be something for everyone. It is manageable in one visit if you have energy and comfortable shoes!

quote: This Grande Dame needs an Urgent Facelift
reviewnospace: I must say that the Thyssen-Bornemisza Collection is rich, ecclectic and varied. Unfortunately its surroundings look quite haggard. This extremely impressive collection needs a stately surrounding instead of low walls separating paintings by periods. All of the art is set against a nauseating salmon color regardless they are showing Renaissance art, Impressionism, German Expressionism or Modern. Quite an unfortunate dizzying distribution of linear spaces. This place needs a serious makeover.

reviewnospace: A really interesting stroll through European art. It was really interesting to see so many lesser known but representative works. Unlike the Prado this museum was easy to navigate and was clean and well cared for, although the Prado had better Spanish/English description of the paintings. I would return to this museum again.
titleopinion: Recommended. A really interesting stroll through European art. It was really interesting to see so many lesser known but representative works. Unlike the Prado this museum was easy to navigate and was clean and well cared for, although the Prado had better Spanish/English description of the paintings. I would return to this museum again.

quote: A gallery that it is worth to see
reviewnospace: The second most important gallery of Madrid in front of Prado. In it you can see also some nice pictures of Picasso, Cezanne, Sisley...
titleopinion: A gallery that it is worth to see. The second most important gallery of Madrid in front of Prado. In it you can see also some nice pictures of Picasso, Cezanne, Sisley...

reviewnospace: A friend who lives in Spain said that this was his favourite gallery in Madrid. I didn't see the permanent exhibition but was lucky enough to catch the Hopper Exhibition. This was amazing. I had seen an exhibition of his work in London some years ago but this had even more of his work.On my next visit to Madrid this galllery will be a priority.

quote: Hooper Finished-Museum in Disarray! Lots on Loan!!!
reviewnospace: Spent 5 hours in the Museo Thyssen-Bornemisza and can no longer tolerate the pervasive pumpkin orange wall paint that was in every gallery! The museum was in a bit of disarray, as the Hopper Exhibition had just closed so a number of the paintings were not in their usual places. Also there seemed to be a large number of paintings on loan, especially on the 1st and 2nd floors in the A-J Galleries, so if you plan to see a specific painting, check ahead! Audio guide at 4 euros was very good. Be sure to note the audio guide number next to most room numbers, (look UP, the rooms #'s are high and you might miss the audio guide #) which gives you an overview of the paintings, history and what’s represented in that particular room-very helpful history lesson combined with art! Also don't miss the three rooms that are by the middle steps on the 1st and 2ed floor; easy to bypass if you take the elevators at the end of the exhibit rooms. Overall some excellent art but poorly displayed; they really need to overhaul/refurbish/repaint…anything to get rid of the pumpkin/salmon color orange! NO pictures! Food is average priced in cafe, lots of bathrooms along the way, good gift shop
titleopinion: Hooper Finished-Museum in Disarray! Lots on Loan!!!. quote: Interesting and varied collection- an art lovers paradise!
reviewnospace:
The gallery had an excellent collection of works form the 15th Century right up to the 20th Century.The European collection was interesting and the American collection was wonderful too. The Lichtenstein and Hopper paintings on display were really brilliant as was the work bu William Merritt Chase.

The restaurant, accessible by lift, was wonderful: up on the roof terrace with spectacular views. Sit with a sandwich and a glass of wine post wander and you have a perfect afternoon!
