reviewnospace: Liked : American artists, rarely showcased in Europe (written by a Brit.) disliked - nothing really to dislike.
titleopinion: Interesting gallery. Liked : American artists, rarely showcased in Europe (written by a Brit.) disliked - nothing really to dislike.

reviewnospace: It was a pleasure to find on arrival at the Thyssen that there was a tranquil plaza outside to sit, recover from a walk in the sun and get ready for the pleasures within. No hassle from tourist souvenir sellers. We had booked in advance to see the Hopper exhibition. This was a terrific display of Hopper's work through his career with an interesting set of slides on rotating display of some of the commercial artwork he produced before he became a full time artist. I particularly valued the range of canvases he had painted with buildings and exterior landscapes.There was plenty of space given to hanging the work so that you could enjoy each room without feeling crushed by the crowd. Peeped into one or two other rooms on the way out and enjoyed shopping for postcards and mementos at the shop. The lockers available for bag storage at the enance returned the 1 euro coin we had used to open them. Will definitely return to sample more of this restful gallery.
titleopinion: a restful gallery. It was a pleasure to find on arrival at the Thyssen that there was a tranquil plaza outside to sit, recover from a walk in the sun and get ready for the pleasures within. No hassle from tourist souvenir sellers. We had booked in advance to see the Hopper exhibition. This was a terrific display of Hopper's work through his career with an interesting set of slides on rotating display of some of the commercial artwork he produced before he became a full time artist. I particularly valued the range of canvases he had painted with buildings and exterior landscapes.There was plenty of space given to hanging the work so that you could enjoy each room without feeling crushed by the crowd. Peeped into one or two other rooms on the way out and enjoyed shopping for postcards and mementos at the shop. The lockers available for bag storage at the enance returned the 1 euro coin we had used to open them. Will definitely return to sample more of this restful gallery.

quote: Minor works by major artists, major works by minor artists
reviewnospace: Lovely building and interesting collection; a little eclectic. Lots of Dutch painters for some reason. A nice sampling of painting styles in fairly chronological order, roughly grouped by style. A large number of paintings are out on loan which was too bad, but you know times are tough in Spain right now so we understood. This museum fills in a few gaps from the Prado and Sophia Regna.

It was 39c, perhaps queuing visitors outside could be handled better, not a long wait, but could have been more intelligent use of available facilities.

quote: Love it (but the online service needs improving)
reviewnospace: Love the collection, it is really an Art History lesson. Also, it can be seen in about 2 hours, which is nice too. The museum is great then. But the service, not so much. The online service is lousy; it takes forever to get the tickets and it has already happened to me that the system allows you to buy tickets for an exhibition at a time where it is already closed (seriously, and no returns). Maybe is just my bad experience, but I guess the point is sharing a personal experience.

quote: Of art museum experiences in Madrid, the most pleasant
reviewnospace: Tired of trying to dodge the crowds in the Prado? Mystified by the circulation system and lack of interpretation in the Reina Sophia? This is the solution for you. A pleasant, well-designed museum with excellent representation of major periods of Western art from the late Medieval to the mid-20th century. One of my favorite memories of the city!

reviewnospace: We visited on the spur of the moment on a Saturday lunch time in July expecting huge crowds. We were pleased as the wait was 30 mins. The gallery shop is amazing, so spent the wait purchasing some good value prints and momentos. The exhibition itself was well put together, comparing Hopper to his contemporaries i.e. Degas. However, the crowds were surprising given the allocated time slots. The finale of the model and frame, showing how Hopper captured light and form, was sensational. Bravo!

reviewnospace:
Room 12, with Caravaggio's St. Catherine and the Ribera paintings, may be one of the most stunning rooms I've ever seen in a museum. I would still visit the Prado first, but painting for painting this collection is arguably better, especially the second floor. Top-notch curation.

If you go to their website you can do a virtual tour, which might be useful if you want to decide if this is your cup of tea.

reviewnospace: This was not my first visit to Madrid so this time I chose to visit "only" the temporary exhibition about Hopper. It really did not disappoint my expectations - a good choice of masterpieces, well displayed and with interesting experiements, like the reproduction in "3D" one of Hopper's most famous paintings. Don't miss it!

reviewnospace: A collection of around eighty Hopper works including many early works. Fascinating and well worth a visit. Get the audio tour!
titleopinion: Hopper Exhibition. A collection of around eighty Hopper works including many early works. Fascinating and well worth a visit. Get the audio tour!

reviewnospace: I wanted to see the Edward Hopper exhibition but was in Madrid for only 1 day; fortunately a friend suggested booking online, which we did. We got there early but couldn't change our entrance time, but that gave us time to see the exhibit of the restoration of Tintoretto's 'Paradise' - the video of the whole process was fascinating - and the Faces and Hands exhibit. The museum store was well stocked and there were even a few original gift items. It's amazing what people spend their money on. The staff was helpful although even with reserved tickets, I found the exhibit to be crowded.
titleopinion: Great space - well-managed. I wanted to see the Edward Hopper exhibition but was in Madrid for only 1 day; fortunately a friend suggested booking online, which we did. We got there early but couldn't change our entrance time, but that gave us time to see the exhibit of the restoration of Tintoretto's 'Paradise' - the video of the whole process was fascinating - and the Faces and Hands exhibit. The museum store was well stocked and there were even a few original gift items. It's amazing what people spend their money on. The staff was helpful although even with reserved tickets, I found the exhibit to be crowded.

reviewnospace: European art through the ages. Particularly liked the 20th century collection, and the audio guide was excellent in that it provided information regarding the context and significance of works that enhanced my understanding of them. Nice rooftop terrace restaurant.
titleopinion: beautiful collection. European art through the ages. Particularly liked the 20th century collection, and the audio guide was excellent in that it provided information regarding the context and significance of works that enhanced my understanding of them. Nice rooftop terrace restaurant.

reviewnospace:
Loved the Edward Hopper exhibition, and we were lucky that it was there during our visit.
The Audio Guide was good, but could be better. The narrations were bit too imposing, some of them that is.
Otherwise, it was well curated and took us on a journey.
Tickets were bit on the expensive side.

We didn't bother with the other exhibits from 13th -17th century - more portraits, more religious pictures and the likes.

But Edward Hoppper still resonates.
titleopinion: Edward Hopper Awesomeness. Loved the Edward Hopper exhibition, and we were lucky that it was there during our visit.  The Audio Guide was good, but could be better. The narrations were bit too imposing, some of them that is.  Otherwise, it was well curated and took us on a journey.  Tickets were bit on the expensive side.   We didn't bother with the other exhibits from 13th -17th century - more portraits, more religious pictures and the likes.   But Edward Hoppper still resonates.

reviewnospace:
Just go. We have very little of Hopper's work in Europe and when such an amount is here without crossing the Atlantic you have to make the most of the opportunity. I went to Madrid for a short break solely to see this exhibition (and have some tapas of course!) and was not disappointed. It was amazing. It was the start of the exhibition, and had been well publicised in the Spanish press, so it was very busy by mid morning. I would suggest getting there for the 10am opening time and enjoying the Hopper solitude before the crowds arrive.

I had seen the rest of the collection before, but still enjoyed revisiting it and will return. A Madrid must see.

I

reviewnospace: The Museum has a very interesting collection of contemporary art and it is a great experience. reviewnospace:

I was lucky enough to have all this - and to be there when the Hopper exhibition was on as well.

If the Prado is just too much to fit into your day then think seriously about this gem.

reviewnospace: This museum may not be familiar to many tourists and even to art lovers, but you will recognize the paintings and the artists. A fantastic collection Netherlandish (think Rembrandt, Breugel, Hals, Van Ruisdayl) and works by American artists are the hallmarks of the museum. The paintings seem to be hung lower than in US museums and this gave us a much more intimate look at the masterpieces on display.

quote: If you onloy have time to see one art gallery in Madrid, see Thyssen-Bornemisza
reviewnospace:
I saw all three big museums while I was in Madrid (El Prado, Reina Sofia and Thyssen-Born) and while I enjoyed them all, Thyssen was my clear favourite. The Prado is huge and needs at least 3 days to see properly, whereas Thyssen can be seen in a day and it has the most amazing cross section of artists all in one place. As I wrote in my notes "where else can you see Titian, Picasso, Pissaro, Whistler, van Gogh, el Greco, Goya, Mondrian, etc all in one small area". Not in NZ, that's for sure!
So my advice is, if you only have one day to look at the art galleries, don't leave out the Thyssen-Bornemisza.
If you have time to see all three, don't forget to buy the discount 3-museum pass.
titleopinion: If you onloy have time to see one art gallery in Madrid, see Thyssen-Bornemisza. I saw all three big museums while I was in Madrid (El Prado, Reina Sofia and Thyssen-Born) and while I enjoyed them all, Thyssen was my clear favourite. The Prado is huge and needs at least 3 days to see properly, whereas Thyssen can be seen in a day and it has the most amazing cross section of artists all in one place. As I wrote in my notes  where else can you see Titian, Picasso, Pissaro, Whistler, van Gogh, el Greco, Goya, Mondrian, etc all in one small area . Not in NZ, that's for sure! So my advice is, if you only have one day to look at the art galleries, don't leave out the Thyssen-Bornemisza. If you have time to see all three, don't forget to buy the discount 3-museum pass.

reviewnospace: Museum worth visiting, I enjoyed the variety of collection. Some glass framed paintings reflected lights too much.
titleopinion: excellent collection. Museum worth visiting, I enjoyed the variety of collection. Some glass framed paintings reflected lights too much.

reviewnospace:
Alrihgty, doesn't want to see Manet, Monet, Toulouse-Lautrec, Good old Pablo Picasso, Van Gogh, Matisse, Degas? So all those who put their hands up can give the Thyssen a miss!
The rest can go gorge their eyes on these and many many more. A visual feast, once again beautifully hung. You could spend an easy 3 hours starting from the 2nd floor and working down to the ground floor. Water fountains to drink from and facilities on each floor if you can't bear to tear yourself away for even 5 minutes. A convenient Bag storage on the ground floor to offload a heavy backpack or sling bags. No cameras - of course. Choose the displays you are most interested in from the touchscreen display/map on each floor in both Spanish and English.
Loved it. Highly recommend even if you have only vaguely heard of these and other Masters. Did I mention Edvard Munch? No, not The Scream but others. Do go.
titleopinion: Not to be missed!. Alrihgty, doesn't want to see Manet, Monet, Toulouse-Lautrec, Good old Pablo Picasso, Van Gogh, Matisse, Degas? So all those who put their hands up can give the Thyssen a miss! The rest can go gorge their eyes on these and many many more. A visual feast, once again beautifully hung. You could spend an easy 3 hours starting from the 2nd floor and working down to the ground floor. Water fountains to drink from and facilities on each floor if you can't bear to tear yourself away for even 5 minutes. A convenient Bag storage on the ground floor to offload a heavy backpack or sling bags. No cameras - of course. Choose the displays you are most interested in from the touchscreen display/map on each floor in both Spanish and English. Loved it. Highly recommend even if you have only vaguely heard of these and other Masters. Did I mention Edvard Munch? No, not The Scream but others. Do go.

reviewnospace: This is a relatively new museum based entirely on one family's private collection. That is the unbelievable part. As museums go, it is a terrific experience with the broad range of European and American art (at least one item from anybody you can name) arranged in chronological and thematic fashion, so that you can easily see trends and follow developments in painting. Not as comprehensive as the Prado in some areas, but seemingly more accessible.
titleopinion: Unbelievable. This is a relatively new museum based entirely on one family's private collection. That is the unbelievable part. As museums go, it is a terrific experience with the broad range of European and American art (at least one item from anybody you can name) arranged in chronological and thematic fashion, so that you can easily see trends and follow developments in painting. Not as comprehensive as the Prado in some areas, but seemingly more accessible.

reviewnospace:
By accident there was a Hopper exhibition when I went - loved being able to see so many of his paintings, gloomy, odd, sad but moving. Spent another couple of hours in the main rooms until head exploded. Everyone always says go to museums for opening - go half an hour later and most of the queue will have gone.
If you just fancy a sit down in that part of the city, they have a great rooftop cafe. Go to the front of the queue and take the door to the right. Tell the guard that you are going for a coffee. Expensive but worth it.

reviewnospace: Well worth the cost to enter! Love all the master pieces.

reviewnospace:
This has to be one of my favourite art galleries. Anywhere that brings together Northern Renaissance, Impressionism and Cubism (and much much more) under one roof is hitting all the right buttons for me!

The collection is both extensive and thoughtfully acquired. There's no sense of "canvas bought by the square metre", which I sometimes experience in parts of big galleries (and I include the Prado in that!). The gallery is just packed full of exquisite gems - many made more interesting by their relatively infrequent appearance in art books.

An absolute "must" for any art lover in Madrid.
titleopinion: Even better than the Prado. This has to be one of my favourite art galleries. Anywhere that brings together Northern Renaissance, Impressionism and Cubism (and much much more) under one roof is hitting all the right buttons for me!   The collection is both extensive and thoughtfully acquired. There's no sense of  canvas bought by the square metre , which I sometimes experience in parts of big galleries (and I include the Prado in that!). The gallery is just packed full of exquisite gems - many made more interesting by their relatively infrequent appearance in art books.  An absolute  must  for any art lover in Madrid.

reviewnospace: We enjoyed this as much as the Prado. Its smaller and less crowded but still a very extensive collection and worth several hours. We liked the way it was organized chronologically so we really had a sense of the development of art from the 14th century to the 20th.

quote: Undistinguished collection in a boring building
reviewnospace:
Perhaps I have seen too many museums but this one felt rather soulless to me. You take a big building and stick into it random pieces from big name artists from different erras and this is what you get. A major issue is that none of the works stand out, there a few Vuillards and Bonnards for example but all of the pieces seem to fade in the background. The museum curator could have done a better job of highlighting certain works as there were no comments next to any of the works, just the basic information.

It just does not stack up if you compare it to other major museums. In fact the building itself just does not feel like it is a museum at all.

quote: One of the best small museums anywhere!
reviewnospace: We absolutely loved the "Thyssen"! We actually ended up spending more time there than in the Prado, and liking it better -- certainly it was infinitely more comprehensible. The collection is very far-ranging, both in geographical breadth and representation of styles and periods, but it manages to be far from overwhelming in that it's beautifully organized and labelled. The surroundings, a pristine building and lovely garden, add to the experience. It was fun, as Americans, to see a lot of European artists' interpretations of New England and Adirondack views, and a special treat to view a selection of early impressionists, as well as German expressionists arranged in conjunction with 13th century art. (It sounds overly-eclectic and hodge-podge as I describe it -- but no. It was great fun, and we highly recommend it, even if one has a very limited time to visit.)
titleopinion: One of the best small museums anywhere!. We absolutely loved the  Thyssen ! We actually ended up spending more time there than in the Prado, and liking it better -- certainly it was infinitely more comprehensible. The collection is very far-ranging, both in geographical breadth and representation of styles and periods, but it manages to be far from overwhelming in that it's beautifully organized and labelled. The surroundings, a pristine building and lovely garden, add to the experience. It was fun, as Americans, to see a lot of European artists' interpretations of New England and Adirondack views, and a special treat to view a selection of early impressionists, as well as German expressionists arranged in conjunction with 13th century art. (It sounds overly-eclectic and hodge-podge as I describe it -- but no. It was great fun, and we highly recommend it, even if one has a very limited time to visit.)

The restaurant also offers a well-priced menu - just what you need after a few hours of art viewing!

quote: Some great paintings spoilt by the noise
reviewnospace: Although this is a unique collection, it is spoilt by the continual loud talking of private tour guides. The individual galleries are quite small and the loud voices of the guide echos off the walls and makes it very hard to concentrate. I hired the audio guide but, a lot of the time, could not hear it. I did complain at the front desk and a manager was called. He took lots of notes and apologised, but would not let me return to enjoy the pictures properly

reviewnospace: From the Dutch masters of the early 17th century to Piet Mondrain there is something in this museum for anyone who appreciates art. There are American paintings from Remmington, Homer, Whistler, Twachtman and several others. There are works by Corot and Courbet; the major impressionists Pissaro, Sisley, Monet, Manet, Morrisot, Degas; the post-impressionists Van Gogh, Gauguin, Cezanne; Early 20th century Picasso and Georges Braque; the German abstracts of Munch, Klee, Kandinsky, Gabrielle Muenter, Max Ernst; and the list continues. This museum is one of my favorites.
titleopinion: Phenomenal collection of paintings. From the Dutch masters of the early 17th century to Piet Mondrain there is something in this museum for anyone who appreciates art. There are American paintings from Remmington, Homer, Whistler, Twachtman and several others. There are works by Corot and Courbet; the major impressionists Pissaro, Sisley, Monet, Manet, Morrisot, Degas; the post-impressionists Van Gogh, Gauguin, Cezanne; Early 20th century Picasso and Georges Braque; the German abstracts of Munch, Klee, Kandinsky, Gabrielle Muenter, Max Ernst; and the list continues. This museum is one of my favorites.

Madrid and Spain are fortunate to have these wonderful works of art.

quote: It's hard to be #1 when #1 is the Prado
reviewnospace:
This museum is not up to the level of the Prado, or of some other museums worldwide that I have seen. Yet, it is a first class museum with a particular oddity in that it is actually two museums side by side, a result of the particularities of the Thyssen-Bornemisza family wills, which demand that each museum maintain its collection separately. This creates an odd flow through it because one moves from older paintings to newer on one side and then one has to now deal with the other side. Does one go back to the beginning there and again go through chronologically or does one just see whatever in whatever order one comes upon? Very odd.

As to the collection, there are some wonderful paintings here, across many eras. A favorite room of mine was of Renaissance portraits. Then, there were memorable paintings by Balthus and Hopper. Plan to spend a day here and I would say it's better to give extra time to the Prado first, and this second before going on to the Reina Sofia third. In other words, 1.5-2 days for the Prado, 1 day for this, 1/2 day for the Reina Sofia and after hours for wandering around this wonderful city. Dinners are served at most places starting at 8 and at many not until 10 pm.
titleopinion: It's hard to be #1 when #1 is the Prado. This museum is not up to the level of the Prado, or of some other museums worldwide that I have seen. Yet, it is a first class museum with a particular oddity in that it is actually two museums side by side, a result of the particularities of the Thyssen-Bornemisza family wills, which demand that each museum maintain its collection separately. This creates an odd flow through it because one moves from older paintings to newer on one side and then one has to now deal with the other side. Does one go back to the beginning there and again go through chronologically or does one just see whatever in whatever order one comes upon? Very odd.  As to the collection, there are some wonderful paintings here, across many eras. A favorite room of mine was of Renaissance portraits. Then, there were memorable paintings by Balthus and Hopper. Plan to spend a day here and I would say it's better to give extra time to the Prado first, and this second before going on to the Reina Sofia third. In other words, 1.5-2 days for the Prado, 1 day for this, 1/2 day for the Reina Sofia and after hours for wandering around this wonderful city. Dinners are served at most places starting at 8 and at many not until 10 pm.

reviewnospace: This was a surprise visit on the way to the Prado. Honestly one of the nicest art collections I have ever seen collected by a single family. It included such a wide variety of art, everything from a Rembrandt self-portrait to Picasso, to Klee. The building is beautiful and bright, the collection was well-hung, and an amazing experience for any art lover. I kept saying to myself, Wow, I didn't know THIS was here. If you love art, this is a must-see.
titleopinion: So Glad We Went Here. This was a surprise visit on the way to the Prado. Honestly one of the nicest art collections I have ever seen collected by a single family. reviewnospace: Madrid is blessed with three large and wonderful museums - the Prado, the Sofia Reina and the Thyssen. These three make up what is referred to as "the Golden Triangle of Art." I was informed that it was the second largest private collection of art in the world and covers a lot of ground from Dutch and Flemish masters to post-impressionists. Definitely worth spending an afternoon with this terrific collection.

reviewnospace: The Thyssen had a new retrospective of Chagall. This was the first time that a museum in Spain had a retrospective on this artist. What I love about the work of this artist is the color. Every painting has beautiful color. Also many of them had the quality of dreams, with small animals that seem to be flying in the air. Many of his paintings seem to have fables in them for children. I would think that children would enjoy his paintings and understand them. Chagall was probably one of the first surreal artists in Europe. My favorite painting in the collection was called The Madonna of the Village. There were many other paintings that I enjoyed, such as the Self Portrai before the House, The Cattle Trader, El Gallo, and the Red Horse. I really enjoyed the exhibition.

reviewnospace:
This was the first museum we visited in Madrid, and did it ever color our opinions of the others!

This museum architecturally is amazing, fresh and light.

They also have the coolest touch screens on each floor to explore the museum.

There aren't an overwhelming number of paintings, but what they do have is immense quality. I remember being in a room with the Picassos, Monets, Manets, Pissaros, etc ... and given the grand size of each painting, thinking that I was in a $500 million room of art.

The audio guide was well worth it to understand the art. But if you love art, and even if you don't, you'll appreciate the few incredible collection pieces bundled together. It may not have the size of the Prado, but to me, it does have superior quality of impressionistic and modern art.
titleopinion: My favourite museum in Madrid. This was the first museum we visited in Madrid, and did it ever color our opinions of the others! There aren't an overwhelming number of paintings, but what they do have is immense quality. I remember being in a room with the Picassos, Monets, Manets, Pissaros, etc ... and given the grand size of each painting, thinking that I was in a $500 million room of art.  The audio guide was well worth it to understand the art. But if you love art, and even if you don't, you'll appreciate the few incredible collection pieces bundled together. It may not have the size of the Prado, but to me, it does have superior quality of impressionistic and modern art.

reviewnospace: This art gallery was once a private collection. It has something for everyone from medieval art, modern art and Impressionism. Worth If you are just interested in art rather than an art snob

quote: If you like art - don't miss it!
reviewnospace:
I loved it! you get to see the evolution of paintings since medieval times to the modern times.
If you like Monet, Renoir, Degas, Eduard Hopper, Roy lichtenstein... don't miss it!
titleopinion: If you like art - don't miss it!. I loved it! you get to see the evolution of paintings since medieval times to the modern times. If you like Monet, Renoir, Degas, Eduard Hopper, Roy lichtenstein... don't miss it!

reviewnospace: Following the chonological sequence of the exhibition from early Middle Ages to contemporary modern art is an eye opener. Perhaps because each time segment has only relatively few paintings it is easy to follow the development in style and artistic ideas. Most important, however, is of course the outstanding quality of every single item on display. This is definitely one museum my wife and I will visit again.
titleopinion: Extraordinary world class museum. Following the chonological sequence of the exhibition from early Middle Ages to contemporary modern art is an eye opener. Perhaps because each time segment has only relatively few paintings it is easy to follow the development in style and artistic ideas. Most important, however, is of course the outstanding quality of every single item on display. This is definitely one museum my wife and I will visit again.

reviewnospace: The Chagall exhibit was incredible but, they do not tell you the second part of the exhibit is free and located in another part of town. They do tell you on the wall that the exhibit continues in another building. You have to inquire to find out about it and it is as good, if not better, then the Thyssen. You could just go to the free one and be entranced by Chagall.
titleopinion: Chagall not to be missed. The Chagall exhibit was incredible but, they do not tell you the second part of the exhibit is free and located in another part of town. You could just go to the free one and be entranced by Chagall.

reviewnospace: A nice museum and an interesting Chagall special. Quite affordable.
titleopinion: Chagall exhibit. A nice museum and an interesting Chagall special. Quite affordable.

reviewnospace: Carmen sure knew what she was doing (not that the Baron didn't). I especially enjoyed the addition to the building that houses her collection. She seemed to have a knack for selecting work from major artists right at the cusp of time when they established the style they were known for. I have studied art for decades, and I like to play the game of guessing who the artist is before I look. I was frequently--and pleasantly--surprised to see the actual attributions of work in her wing. If you want to see a stupendous collection of modern art, this is your museum. If you're after the old masters, there are certainly plenty here (especially in the Baron's lot) but you might be better served at the Prado, which could eat up all your time in Madrid!
titleopinion: Particularly excellent modern collection. Carmen sure knew what she was doing (not that the Baron didn't). I especially enjoyed the addition to the building that houses her collection. She seemed to have a knack for selecting work from major artists right at the cusp of time when they established the style they were known for. I have studied art for decades, and I like to play the game of guessing who the artist is before I look. I was frequently--and pleasantly--surprised to see the actual attributions of work in her wing. If you want to see a stupendous collection of modern art, this is your museum. If you're after the old masters, there are certainly plenty here (especially in the Baron's lot) but you might be better served at the Prado, which could eat up all your time in Madrid!

reviewnospace: great collection of art - not too big seems to be a perfect place for overseeing the art history
titleopinion: definitely yes!. great collection of art - not too big seems to be a perfect place for overseeing the art history

reviewnospace: Not so full as Prado and nice collection, liked it better than the Prado
titleopinion: Better than the Prado. Not so full as Prado and nice collection, liked it better than the Prado

reviewnospace: Visited the museum on a General Strike day not expecting to find it open, but it was. Beautiful building (with a lovely cafe outside for when your feet give up), with a cross-section of paintings any museum would be proud of. To make it even better, there was a huge temporary Chagall exhibition on when we visited (running till May 2012?) - their own 'visiting exhibition' galleries only held about a third of the paintings, with the remainder in another building about 10 minutes walk away. This was way bigger than any other Chagall exhibition I've seen in London or Paris over the years, and from the number of 'private loan' stickers on display, probably a once-in-a-lifetime exhibition. Even without the Chagall, still definitely worth a visit, and for many of the paintings you can buy high-quality made-to-order prints.
titleopinion: A real gem. Visited the museum on a General Strike day not expecting to find it open, but it was. Beautiful building (with a lovely cafe outside for when your feet give up), with a cross-section of paintings any museum would be proud of. To make it even better, there was a huge temporary Chagall exhibition on when we visited (running till May 2012?) - their own 'visiting exhibition' galleries only held about a third of the paintings, with the remainder in another building about 10 minutes walk away. This was way bigger than any other Chagall exhibition I've seen in London or Paris over the years, and from the number of 'private loan' stickers on display, probably a once-in-a-lifetime exhibition. Even without the Chagall, still definitely worth a visit, and for many of the paintings you can buy high-quality made-to-order prints.

quote: Do this museum after the Prado
reviewnospace: This museum is found across the street from the Prado. It houses most of the modern & contemporary art on the bottom floor. If you go upstairs there's more post Renaissance, Impressionist, and Classical art.

quote: Good spread of pictorial art - well worth a visit
reviewnospace: Whilst the Prado only has art up to the end of the 19th Century and the Reina Sofia from the 20th Century onwards, this museum goes from the 13th to the 20th Centuries. There are some gems here (of course depending on your taste) and it is well laid out. Take your passport along if you're over 65 as it's free. No such luck for me but at Euro 9 I thought it reasonably priced.
titleopinion: Good spread of pictorial art - well worth a visit. Whilst the Prado only has art up to the end of the 19th Century and the Reina Sofia from the 20th Century onwards, this museum goes from the 13th to the 20th Centuries. reviewnospace: Not as grand as the Prado, this museum still has a lot to offer. quote: The true gem in the triangle!
reviewnospace:
I arrived around 1100 hrs and the line was fast moving and short. Got in quickly and the staff spoke good English.
The space is amazing, and the art is arranged in a logically order - so even a none-art lover can follow what is on display.
They have at least one painting from each great artist from the last century on show, and the shop will suit even the tightest of budgets.
The resturant is a bit pricey, but the quality was good, along with very friendly and professional service.
This was my favourite museum in the triangle, which is a huge statement as the other two are amazing.

Then i saw another expo downstairs on Indian art, which was just as interesting, if not more, but I was overloaded with info so I didnt take much in. My advice would be to take one expo each day, as you pay according to the number of expos you want to see, and they all seem very information dense. Great museum shop.

reviewnospace:
Another of Madrids outstanding museums. An amazing selection spanning over several periods. Beautifully arranged and organised with the artworks in excellent lighting. A good plan of the museum is provided.

We spent 5 hours here and there is a sit-down café on the ground floor with nice food.
With the Paseo del Arte ticket you enter the museum directly and don't have to stand in the ticket lines. Those born in 1992 have free entrance during 2012!
Excellent museum shop with a lot of artbooks.
titleopinion: World class museum. Another of Madrids outstanding museums. An amazing selection spanning over several periods. quote: Sense of family and personal eclecticism, liveliness and fun in this art gallery
reviewnospace: The Thyssen-Bornemisza is generally recommended in guides and travel advisories as the third of the three major art galleries of Madrid, after the Prado and the Reina Sofía. We took that advice, visiting it third in order, and were happy with that choice. An atmosphere of family and personal eclecticism, liveliness and fun in this art gallery made it the perfect rounding off of our visits over several days to the trio of top Madrid galleries. The gallery website at http://www.museothyssen.org/ is a useful tool for planning a visit. Check for special exhibitions or events: we lucked into a marvellous free live performance of the art of dance. The Thyssen-Bornemisza's cafeteria, with indoor and outdoor areas, is among the most pleasant gallery or museum eateries in Madrid.
titleopinion: Sense of family and personal eclecticism, liveliness and fun in this art gallery. The Thyssen-Bornemisza is generally recommended in guides and travel advisories as the third of the three major art galleries of Madrid, after the Prado and the Reina Sofía. We took that advice, visiting it third in order, and were happy with that choice. An atmosphere of family and personal eclecticism, liveliness and fun in this art gallery made it the perfect rounding off of our visits over several days to the trio of top Madrid galleries. The gallery website at http://www.museothyssen.org/ is a useful tool for planning a visit. Check for special exhibitions or events: we lucked into a marvellous free live performance of the art of dance. The Thyssen-Bornemisza's cafeteria, with indoor and outdoor areas, is among the most pleasant gallery or museum eateries in Madrid.

reviewnospace:
I really enjoyed this musuem which displays essentially private collections of art works, one of which is now owned by the Spanish Government. A fantastic collection, the museum displays art works representing major periods or styles from the middle ages (and earlier) through to the 20th century.

The museum is also quiet - unlike the Prado which can be a little noisy - which allows you to wander at your own pace with no pressure from crowds and reflect upon individual pices which makes up this unique and terrific collection. Highly recommended.

And there's a cafeteria and a great shop attached to the museum.
titleopinion: A must see in Madrid. I really enjoyed this musuem which displays essentially private collections of art works, one of which is now owned by the Spanish Government. A fantastic collection, the museum displays art works representing major periods or styles from the middle ages (and earlier) through to the 20th century.   The museum is also quiet - unlike the Prado which can be a little noisy - which allows you to wander at your own pace with no pressure from crowds and reflect upon individual pices which makes up this unique and terrific collection. Highly recommended.  And there's a cafeteria and a great shop attached to the museum.

reviewnospace:
We skipped a lot of the medieval whatnot being a little immune to it from our life in Italy, but the collection was amazing overall.

Highlights include: El Greco, Rothko, Rothko, Lucien Freud and Francis Bacon.

One of the best contemporary collections we saw in Madrid. Highly recommend, but as it's private and you'll always pay, plan your trip around when the other museums are free. (i.e. Prado that is open for no cost some days/times of the week)

Highly recommend, but as it's private and you'll always pay, plan your trip around when the other museums are free. (i.e. Prado that is open for no cost some days/times of the week)

quote: Excellent - an interesting collection of art
reviewnospace:
This is an interesting art gallery, in that the paintings are apparently the personal collection of a single person, Hans Heinrich Thyssen-Bornemisza, with a separate wing containing the collection of his (fifth) wife Carmen.

Very sensibly, the paintings are arranged in chronological order, so if you start on the second floor you can follow the history of art from the 13th century onwards. Most of the major movements are covered, and it's particularly good for American art (neglected in many other galleries).

I paid extra for the temporary exhibition on Berthe Morisot, which was a bit of a waste of time. I would advise you to stick to the main gallery.

There's a good cafe/restaurant - you can have a formal sit-down lunch with menus and waitress service, or if you prefer, just a quick sandwich and crisps. And a good shop, with lots of books (including some in English).
titleopinion: Excellent - an interesting collection of art. This is an interesting art gallery, in that the paintings are apparently the personal collection of a single person, Hans Heinrich Thyssen-Bornemisza, with a separate wing containing the collection of his (fifth) wife Carmen.  Very sensibly, the paintings are arranged in chronological order, so if you start on the second floor you can follow the history of art from the 13th century onwards. Most of the major movements are covered, and it's particularly good for American art (neglected in many other galleries).  I paid extra for the temporary exhibition on Berthe Morisot, which was a bit of a waste of time. I would advise you to stick to the main gallery.  There's a good cafe/restaurant - you can have a formal sit-down lunch with menus and waitress service, or if you prefer, just a quick sandwich and crisps. And a good shop, with lots of books (including some in English).

If you have only a few hours in Madrid go to this Museum. It is a fine collection put together by people who had not only the means but the taste and knowledge of art history to make an incomparable collection. For a very small extra cost, you get into the temporary exhibition of Berthe Morisot, the French impressionist (worth a visit just for that). The coffee shop is exceptional.
PS the comment by the reviewer about Guernica is not a comment on this museum as the Guernica is elsewhere.)

quote: In Madrid this might be just the 2nd or 3rd best, but most cities would be lucky to have such a museum!
reviewnospace: My girlfriend and I spent a couple of hours exploring the Thyssen-Bornemisza museum on the last day of a two-week trip to Morocco and Spain. There was an intriguing exhibit on women in art there at the time which we enjoyed, and then we looked at their Medieval, Renaissance, and early Baroque art. They have quite an extensive collection, and I would suggest that you definitely set aside at least an afternoon to see the museum's collection in a leisurely fashion. It is worth spending the time there!

quote: Impressive private collection provides a perfect accompaniment to the Prado
reviewnospace:
Although the Thyssen's collection spans 500 years of Western art, for me its main attraction was its modestly sized but high quality selection of impressionist and cubist-surrealist-modernist pieces, boasting some big names - Dalí, Picasso, Juan Gris, Monet, Cézanne, van Gogh, Pissaro, Degas and Hopper, to name but a few favourites.

The artworks are extremely well laid out in rough order of chronology and location, and the building itself provides beautiful, light spaces that are minimal but not cold, which make for a wonderfully personal visit - just you and the art. The paintings are not roped off like so many in the Prado are, allowing you to get right up close to them; it's a great treat to be allowed to appreciate in full Monet's colour range and quickness of brush strokes. I would recommend buying the pocket guide to the museum in the gift shop for 6 euros before your visit; apart from being a nice souvenir, this little book highlights one piece from each room and gives a little description of context and background. Well worth it if, like me, you don't have extensive art knowledge and are a bit of an amateur admirer.

Because of its emphasis on more modern works, this museum is a great accompaniment to the Prado's collection of older pieces, and is conveniently just up the road from it as well. The only negatives I would highlight are a) the Thyssen's Dutch and Flemish paintings are a bit uninspiring, and b) students get free entry into the Prado but pay 6 euros for admission into the Thyssen. Still, the latter point is more of a positive for the Prado than a negative for the Thyssen.

Visit them both!
titleopinion: Impressive private collection provides a perfect accompaniment to the Prado. Although the Thyssen's collection spans 500 years of Western art, for me its main attraction was its modestly sized but high quality selection of impressionist and cubist-surrealist-modernist pieces, boasting some big names - Dalí, Picasso, Juan Gris, Monet, Cézanne, van Gogh, Pissaro, Degas and Hopper, to name but a few favourites.   The artworks are extremely well laid out in rough order of chronology and location, and the building itself provides beautiful, light spaces that are minimal but not cold, which make for a wonderfully personal visit - just you and the art. The paintings are not roped off like so many in the Prado are, allowing you to get right up close to them; it's a great treat to be allowed to appreciate in full Monet's colour range and quickness of brush strokes. I would recommend buying the pocket guide to the museum in the gift shop for 6 euros before your visit; apart from being a nice souvenir, this little book highlights one piece from each room and gives a little description of context and background. Well worth it if, like me, you don't have extensive art knowledge and are a bit of an amateur admirer.  Because of its emphasis on more modern works, this museum is a great accompaniment to the Prado's collection of older pieces, and is conveniently just up the road from it as well. The only negatives I would highlight are a) the Thyssen's Dutch and Flemish paintings are a bit uninspiring, and b) students get free entry into the Prado but pay 6 euros for admission into the Thyssen. Still, the latter point is more of a positive for the Prado than a negative for the Thyssen.  Visit them both!

reviewnospace:
Sort of the Chinese restaurant of galleries, with something from every column, but very intelligently and attractively laid out.

Truly extraordinary to think that there was an individual with the wealth it took to assemble a collection like this in the latter part of the twentieth century.

We visited on our first day in Madrid, after traveling overnight from JFK and spending a delightful couple of hours soaking up the sights of the Retiro Park, and it was a great way to ease in to a culturally demanding city.

You can buy a combined ticket - Madrid Art Pass - for the Prado, Thyssen-Bornemisza and Reina Sofía Museums, and it represents a significant saving over paying for each individually.
titleopinion: Culture-lite, but very well done. Sort of the Chinese restaurant of galleries, with something from every column, but very intelligently and attractively laid out. We visited on our first day in Madrid, after traveling overnight from JFK and spending a delightful couple of hours soaking up the sights of the Retiro Park, and it was a great way to ease in to a culturally demanding city. reviewnospace:
There were two interesting exhibitions at this museum when we went in December. One of them was Architectural Paintings, which showed paintings from the Renaissance that included perspective for the first time. There were paintings from the Renaissance to the 18th century.

The other exhibition was about paintings from Berthe Morisot. Most of the paintings were from the Musee Marmottan Monet in Paris.

The Thyssen is one of my favorite museums in Madrid because the temporary art exhibitions are some of the best. I have to visit this museum every time I go to Madrid.

The Thyssen is one of my favorite museums in Madrid because the temporary art exhibitions are some of the best. I have to visit this museum every time I go to Madrid.

quote: One of my favorite museums in the world.
reviewnospace: If you are in Madrid, and you love modern (turn of century) art, do yourself a favor and go to this museum. Its a revelation. I can't believe I'm saying this, but if I HAD to choose between the Prado and this one, I'd choose this one every single time. That woman, Carmen, had an eye for wonderful pieces.

reviewnospace:
What an impressive collection! Beautiful museum with amazing works of art from the 13th century to the late 20th century.
From the website: "In the nearly one thousand works on display, visitors can contemplate the major periods and pictorial schools of western art such as the Renaissance, Mannerism, the Baroque, Rococo, Romanticism and the art of the 19th and 20th centuries up to Pop Art. The museum also features works from some movements not represented in state-owned collections, such as Impressionism, Fauvism, German Expressionism and the experimental avant-garde movements of the early 20th century. In addition, it boasts an important collection of 19th-century American painting not found in any other European museum institutions."
This is a must while in Madrid.
titleopinion: Phenomenal. What an impressive collection! Beautiful museum with amazing works of art from the 13th century to the late 20th century.  From the website:  In the nearly one thousand works on display, visitors can contemplate the major periods and pictorial schools of western art such as the Renaissance, Mannerism, the Baroque, Rococo, Romanticism and the art of the 19th and 20th centuries up to Pop Art. The museum also features works from some movements not represented in state-owned collections, such as Impressionism, Fauvism, German Expressionism and the experimental avant-garde movements of the early 20th century. In addition, it boasts an important collection of 19th-century American painting not found in any other European museum institutions.  This is a must while in Madrid.

reviewnospace:
Thyssen-Bornemisza is a wonderful museum. I would recommend it as a first stop in Madrid. This wealthy aristocrat wanted to illustrate the art history using paintings from different periods. And he succeeded!
I strongly advise you to take an audioguide (if you are not an art historian, of course :-). This way your visit will turn into a fascinating lesson!
And if you meet a beautiful tall fair-haired Suisse guy, who doesn't speak English, asking you if it's worth paying for the audioguide, please tell him to post his opinion about the museum here, at tripadvisor! Cause I don't know if he managed to see the whole museum or not, and whether he liked..it...me...:-)
titleopinion: Marvelous!. Thyssen-Bornemisza is a wonderful museum. I would recommend it as a first stop in Madrid. This wealthy aristocrat wanted to illustrate the art history using paintings from different periods. And he succeeded!  I strongly advise you to take an audioguide (if you are not an art historian, of course :-). This way your visit will turn into a fascinating lesson! And if you meet a beautiful tall fair-haired Suisse guy, who doesn't speak English, asking you if it's worth paying for the audioguide, please tell him to post his opinion about the museum here, at tripadvisor! Cause I don't know if he managed to see the whole museum or not, and whether he liked..it...me...:-)

reviewnospace: I loved this museum for its aesthetics and layout. The artwork is arranged in chronological order, so its fun to move through this manageable museum and work your way from oldest to modern. Its also evident that these works were chosen for their ability to please the eye, rather than their perceived importance. While the museum has plenty of 'important' works, the feeling I got was being surrounded by works of art personally chosen to please. Don't miss this museum. You can see everything in a few hours and it is all truly amazing!
titleopinion: My new favorite museum. I loved this museum for its aesthetics and layout. The artwork is arranged in chronological order, so its fun to move through this manageable museum and work your way from oldest to modern. Its also evident that these works were chosen for their ability to please the eye, rather than their perceived importance. While the museum has plenty of 'important' works, the feeling I got was being surrounded by works of art personally chosen to please. Don't miss this museum. You can see everything in a few hours and it is all truly amazing!

reviewnospace: loved the selection. there are not as many masterpieces as Prado, but they are handpicked.
titleopinion: lovely selection. loved the selection. there are not as many masterpieces as Prado, but they are handpicked.

reviewnospace:
Entrance was free with Youth / student card. Great museum to visit beautifull paintings by Miró, Dali, Bacon, Picasso.
We had a great morning there.
titleopinion: Nice morning visit. Entrance was free with Youth / student card. Great museum to visit beautifull paintings by Miró, Dali, Bacon, Picasso. We had a great morning there.

reviewnospace: varied and excellent collection of art. A really nice way to spend some hours introducing teens and young children to fine art
titleopinion: What a collection. varied and excellent collection of art. A really nice way to spend some hours introducing teens and young children to fine art

reviewnospace: This is a very comprehensive painting collection, full of masterpieces. very near to Pardo and Reina Sofia, you can spend the day visiting the 3 museums within walking distance. Not to miss the Gauguins nor the portrait of Henry VIII by Holbein.
titleopinion: amazing collection. This is a very comprehensive painting collection, full of masterpieces. very near to Pardo and Reina Sofia, you can spend the day visiting the 3 museums within walking distance. Not to miss the Gauguins nor the portrait of Henry VIII by Holbein.

reviewnospace: Near the Prado, and a good alternative museum experience, but not eye-popping like it's venerable neighbor.
titleopinion: Great collection. Near the Prado, and a good alternative museum experience, but not eye-popping like it's venerable neighbor.

quote: Chronological presentation aids understanding of art
reviewnospace: This museum displays the broad collection chronologically, which helps the viewer appreciate the evolution of painting in terms of style, media, and subject matter. I was surprised because medieval art had never particularly appealed to me, but after viewing the pieces in this collection I have an entirely new appreciation of this period. Highly recommended!
titleopinion: Chronological presentation aids understanding of art. This museum displays the broad collection chronologically, which helps the viewer appreciate the evolution of painting in terms of style, media, and subject matter. I was surprised because medieval art had never particularly appealed to me, but after viewing the pieces in this collection I have an entirely new appreciation of this period. Highly recommended!

reviewnospace:
You could enter without waiting.
You can buy a combined ticket for the Prado, Thyssen and Reina Sofia at each gallery.
Good restaurant.
titleopinion: superb paintings. You could enter without waiting. You can buy a combined ticket for the Prado, Thyssen and Reina Sofia at each gallery. Good restaurant.

reviewnospace:
We bought the ticket which gives you access to all 2 museums (this , the Prado and Reina Sofia). After the first 2 we were all 'museumed out' - the museums in Madrid are HUGE - and were going to write this one off since it was not a must-see on our agenda. Our plans changed though because the Royal Palace was closed for an occasion and we had seen most of the other sites. So off we went and the surprise was that this was the best museum of the lot!. There is a nice selection or art, particularly impressionists which I love and the layout is the most user-friendly allowing you to meander through. The other 2 museums required a lot of backtracking.

I'm not going to go into too much detail about all the art to be seen because you can find easy information on their web-site. I will say, don't skip this vital part of any Madrid itinerary - it really is worth it.
titleopinion: Nice surprise. We bought the ticket which gives you access to all 2 museums (this , the Prado and Reina Sofia). After the first 2 we were all 'museumed out' - the museums in Madrid are HUGE - and were going to write this one off since it was not a must-see on our agenda. Our plans changed though because the Royal Palace was closed for an occasion and we had seen most of the other sites. So off we went and the surprise was that this was the best museum of the lot!. There is a nice selection or art, particularly impressionists which I love and the layout is the most user-friendly allowing you to meander through. The other 2 museums required a lot of backtracking.   I'm not going to go into too much detail about all the art to be seen because you can find easy information on their web-site. I will say, don't skip this vital part of any Madrid itinerary - it really is worth it.

reviewnospace: The museum cost 8 or 10 euros (can't remember). My children are students and brought their student IDs and it cost them each 5 euros. The museum is closed on Monday. The ground floor had 3 Picasso paintings and several Dali paintings. On the first floor were paintings by: Monet, Pissarro, Gauguin, O'Keefe, Degas, Bonnard, Toulouse-Lautrec, Van Gogh, Goya and John Singer Sargent and Winslow Homer. The second floor had paintings by: Monet, Degas, Pissarro, Renoir and van Dyk. There were many other artists I was not familiar with. We spent two hours there and thought it was well worth our time. This museum is located about a block from the Prado.
titleopinion: Really enjoyed the museum. The museum cost 8 or 10 euros (can't remember). My children are students and brought their student IDs and it cost them each 5 euros. The museum is closed on Monday. The ground floor had 3 Picasso paintings and several Dali paintings. On the first floor were paintings by: Monet, Pissarro, Gauguin, O'Keefe, Degas, Bonnard, Toulouse-Lautrec, Van Gogh, Goya and John Singer Sargent and Winslow Homer. The second floor had paintings by: Monet, Degas, Pissarro, Renoir and van Dyk. There were many other artists I was not familiar with. We spent two hours there and thought it was well worth our time. This museum is located about a block from the Prado.

reviewnospace: Just across the road from the Prado & although smaller still needs a full day to do it justice. The snack-bar is waiter-service & therefore you do have to wait!
titleopinion: Needs a full day.. Just across the road from the Prado & although smaller still needs a full day to do it justice. The snack-bar is waiter-service & therefore you do have to wait!

quote: One of my favorite museums anywhere!
reviewnospace: Make sure you see this museum. There are two collections. Start at the earliest and walk through chronologically and you will see the history of art unfold before your eyes. It is a wonderful experience
titleopinion: One of my favorite museums anywhere!. Make sure you see this museum. There are two collections. Start at the earliest and walk through chronologically and you will see the history of art unfold before your eyes. It is a wonderful experience

reviewnospace: The museum has very wide and good colelction, the building is lovely, the surroundings excellent. You are right in the middle of the Art quarter.
titleopinion: Good general collection of Art. The museum has very wide and good colelction, the building is lovely, the surroundings excellent. You are right in the middle of the Art quarter.

reviewnospace: It is a very good museum to visit in Madrid . I spent half of a day there and I don't regret it. There is also a very good restaurant in the property . It is an excellent place to learn more about spanish culture.
titleopinion: Excellent place to visit. It is a very good museum to visit in Madrid . I spent half of a day there and I don't regret it. There is also a very good restaurant in the property . It is an excellent place to learn more about spanish culture.

reviewnospace: Just across the street from the Prado, it has a wide ranging collection from old to new.
titleopinion: Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum. Just across the street from the Prado, it has a wide ranging collection from old to new.

quote: Rent the museum for VIP private event -- very worth it!
reviewnospace:
We hosted this past week a VIP private event for 6 employees and 14 customers for the museum one evening. It was an amazing evening to break up the groups into small guided personalised tours with the entire museum at our beck and call. It took about 90 minutes to go through and see the most interesting and unusual of the huge collection. Of the 20 in our group, a few felt 90 mins was a bit long, but most were amazed to have the access and understanding we gained from our guides.

Afterwards we had a private drinks and dinner at their rooftop restaurant which was nothing short of amazing overlooking Madrid. Loved the exclusivity of the event was a common feedback from our guests!
titleopinion: Rent the museum for VIP private event -- very worth it!. We hosted this past week a VIP private event for 6 employees and 14 customers for the museum one evening. It was an amazing evening to break up the groups into small guided personalised tours with the entire museum at our beck and call. It took about 90 minutes to go through and see the most interesting and unusual of the huge collection. Of the 20 in our group, a few felt 90 mins was a bit long, but most were amazed to have the access and understanding we gained from our guides.  Afterwards we had a private drinks and dinner at their rooftop restaurant which was nothing short of amazing overlooking Madrid. Loved the exclusivity of the event was a common feedback from our guests!

reviewnospace: An incredible tour de force of a private collector's ability to amass a phenomenal private collection now on view to the public. Don't miss it.
titleopinion: private money buys art. An incredible tour de force of a private collector's ability to amass a phenomenal private collection now on view to the public. Don't miss it.

reviewnospace: We were fortunate to be there during the retrospective of Antonio Lopez, which was superb, and then I had to cajole my family to go through the permanent collection - they were a bit museum-ed out at that point, but OH! What a collection! Nice to be wealthy enough to collect, nicer still to fill a museum and share with the world. Full of beautiful pieces you may never have seen before - Madonna of the Dry Tree virtually leapt off the wall, only the size of a postcard but WOW, packed an incredible punch.
titleopinion: A gem. We were fortunate to be there during the retrospective of Antonio Lopez, which was superb, and then I had to cajole my family to go through the permanent collection - they were a bit museum-ed out at that point, but OH! What a collection! Nice to be wealthy enough to collect, nicer still to fill a museum and share with the world. Full of beautiful pieces you may never have seen before - Madonna of the Dry Tree virtually leapt off the wall, only the size of a postcard but WOW, packed an incredible punch.

quote: world class small museum - have to see
reviewnospace: go to the top floor and check out the portrait of henry 8th by hans holbein the younger, as well as the few portraits just next to him (catarina de aragon, anonymous blond boy) and rembrandts self portrait, these are among the top gems in world art, the whole museum takes some 3-4 hours to visit but just seeing the top two floors would suffice and could be done in just 2 hours
titleopinion: world class small museum - have to see. go to the top floor and check out the portrait of henry 8th by hans holbein the younger, as well as the few portraits just next to him (catarina de aragon, anonymous blond boy) and rembrandts self portrait, these are among the top gems in world art, the whole museum takes some 3-4 hours to visit but just seeing the top two floors would suffice and could be done in just 2 hours

reviewnospace: Absolutely loved our afternoon jaunt to the Thyssen-Bornemisza. They cover any and all genres across a wide range of time periods. Make sure you opt for the audio tour...it's incredibly informative and enthralling. The layout is unique and gives you a roughly chronological view of various art movements across the world. I especially loved their collection of early modern Russian works.
titleopinion: DO NOT MISS THIS. Absolutely loved our afternoon jaunt to the Thyssen-Bornemisza. They cover any and all genres across a wide range of time periods. Make sure you opt for the audio tour...it's incredibly informative and enthralling. The layout is unique and gives you a roughly chronological view of various art movements across the world. I especially loved their collection of early modern Russian works.

reviewnospace: I hate the way staff treat you. You must remember to have your ticket at the ready if for example you go out to drink of cloakroom to avoid the stuffy heat in October/Novemeber.The art was fine but a bit too good and playing to the mass common denominator...though they did have R.B.Kitaj...and the collection was of course Swiss. I wonder why it came here?
titleopinion: Very Prissy. I hate the way staff treat you. You must remember to have your ticket at the ready if for example you go out to drink of cloakroom to avoid the stuffy heat in October/Novemeber.The art was fine but a bit too good and playing to the mass common denominator...though they did have R.B.Kitaj...and the collection was of course Swiss. I wonder why it came here?

reviewnospace: The museum is a short walk from Prado and deserves to be visited mainly for its wonderful collection of impressionists painintings. From Van Gogh to Toulouse Laurec you'll remain astonished by the quality of pieces in this location. Visit takes 1 to 2 hours and you can purchase discounted tickets for PRADO-THYSSEN and REINA SOFIA MUSEUMS (the top 3 museums of Madrid). Don't miss them but if you need a relevance order... #1 PRADO #2 THYSSEN #3 REINA SOFIA
titleopinion: wondersul Impressionists Collection. The museum is a short walk from Prado and deserves to be visited mainly for its wonderful collection of impressionists painintings. reviewnospace: This museum is the perfect complement of the Prado and Reina Sofia. It has very good collection of XIXth & XXth Century Western art.
titleopinion: Amazing. This museum is the perfect complement of the Prado and Reina Sofia. It has very good collection of XIXth & XXth Century Western art.

reviewnospace: recomendet also for visitors with small knowledges about painters. You can stop for a while or longer time by pictures thay bring you to own peace.
